Â He likes being out in just about any weather.The only one bothered by the storms is Max. When I was sitting, he curled up under my feet or got into the tub when I wasn't. Our newest addition Diezel is slowly setting in. Â But it is having its challenges. Â He is so comfortable and content outside and I think he'd stay out all day if we'd let him.But inside it is the total opposite. Â We've decided that Deizel has probably not lived inside for awhile and when he did, he was probably restricted to just the kitchen. Getting him to leave the kitchen is being met with a lot of resistance. Of course it goes without saying that we'll keep working at it and we'll figure it out together.But if anyone has any advice on how to make the transition easier for Deizel, we're listening! Â All of us except Max -- When he's not hiding in the tub, he's busy watching television.

title: Deizel Arrives at Golden Pines
text: With the recent arrival of Max, I'd asked to not take another foster dog. Â I guess that the request was forgotten about because I was asked if we would consider taking a "special" new addition. That special new addition is named Deizel, and he arrived first thing this morning. Â He's ten years old, and almost totally blind. Â Given up, and I quote, "because of his family not wanting to take care of him anymore because he is blind." Sadly and unfortunately, you can't make this up, and I wouldn't call them "family" because of their excuse for not wanting to keep him. Â The only good thing that I can say, is that they did one thing right, in turning him over to the rescue. Deizel's introductions to his new pack members have gone well. Â He's a nice dog, and how much he can see of what's around him, I'm not sure about. Â He is of course a little confused about where he is, and what's happening to him. So we're taking it extra slow and letting him get to know us and become familiar with his new surroundings. I don't know what Deizel's story will be. Â But I do know he's going to be okay.

title: Ciao Bella!
text: It was a day that I knew would come too soon. Â As we said good-bye to Bella, someone else, was saying hello to her, and welcoming her into their home. Â Bella has been adopted! Â ~Bella ready for the ride to meet her forever family~The retired couple that met her in late April were finally ready to move forward with adopting her. Â There were several last minute hurdles that we had to get through with Bella. Â She had a few issues with her health that required a few more tests. Â But I hope (and pray) that Bella continues to have good health as she begins this new chapter in her life. ~Smiles all around~Bella had been with us for just over a year. Â But I'd felt for a long time that she should have a family all her own that she didn't have to share.~Bella being spoiled~Â While she may have growled at our dogs and the cats, Bella has a gentle spirit and is truly a dog with a big heart and a lot of love to give and share. Â I think that living in a retirement community, with a lot of people around will give her the chance to share that love. Â And at the end of the day, she has a family all her own. It could not be more perfect. Â The below e-mail that I received this evening confirms those thoughts.Hi Kim,Â  Â  We have had a wonderful day with Bella! The ride home was uneventful and, after a brief mid-day walk, we all had a short nap. Then, Bella spent the afternoon either with Dick watching TV or with me in the office. She was very content to nap with an occasional raising of her head to confirm that we were just a few feet away. After dinner, she had a walk with Dick where she met several neighbors, who all fell in love with her.Then it was back to the house where she now is lying at our feet while we are watching a PBS mystery program. Â  All in all, Bella's first day with us exceeded our expectations.Â  Â  Â She said to tell you and her four-legged friends that all is well and to be happy for her because she thinks she has found her forever home.Â  Â  Â  Best wishes from the three of us,Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  JudyI hope for many good days like this for Bella. Â I will and do miss her. Â  Bella on the first day we met her. Â She was tired and not feeling well.

title: Fields of Gold
text: Another busy week is over, and we have a busy weekend ahead. Our newest addition, Max went to the vet for an evaluation and treatment plan. Â We've decided on acupuncture, cold laser therapy and medications for the first two weeks to see how it goes.Max has settled into his new life and routine. He's a nice boy, that is affectionate, and is always willing to give you his paw, lick your hand or face, or whatever he can reach. Â He is still a little growly when our dogs get to close to him. Â But I'm okay with that, because the dogs seem to be okay with it.I took Friday off of work to get a few things done. Â But I ended up with a little spare time in the morning, so I packed up Sheba, picked up a good friend and we went over to Maryland to see the sunflower fields.Most of the bigger sunflowers are past their peak blooms. And I know they are nowhere close to the magnificent sunflower fields in France. But I do love the golden sunflowers. They are really beautiful and I'm glad my friend and I were able to go and see them this year. We'll be mostly inside this weekend because of the high heat.And tomorrow is a bittersweet day when a new chapter begins for one of our pups. Â I'll tell you about it on Sunday. Â Enjoy your weekend!

title: Max Arrives at Golden Pines!
text: Summertime fun and life continues to keep me busy and away from blogging. Vet visits for both Bella and Jake this week filled the precious spare time, ~Bella~Both are doing well, and today we celebrate 164 days since Jake left the shelter where he'd been taken to be euthanized. He continues to do really well, as he and Bella are in competition for the worst ear infections.~Jake celebrates 164 Days of Grace!~The busy pace continued on Saturday when we welcomed a new addition....Say hello to Max, a six year old Goldendoodle! For those of you who don't know, a Goldendoodle is a â€œdesigner dog,â€ or a hybrid-mix of a Poodle and a Golden Retriever.Max was given up because his owners, a retired couple are leaving for a church mission in Ethiopia. Having a Goldendoodle, and giving up a dog to fill a mission to Ethiopia are firsts for us. And as you well know, we don't typically foster dogs that are his age. But Max is having problems with his back, and is unable to do a lot of steps, so we were asked to take him. Â I have to admit, I couldn't resist that face! Â  After Webster, our last dog for Lab Rescue, I'm very relieved that the intros to our crew have gone pretty well. Â Max has growled at all the dogs except Todd and Charlie. He lived with "smaller dogs" so that may be why. Â But I'm glad that it's getting better the more he interacts with them."Max keeping an eye on the fiercest dog in our house, George."Â With the intros behind us, the smile on Todd's face this evening, is mirroring the one on mine. Â I think Max is going to be just fine with us. Paws crossed, just in case!

title: Here and Gone and Worn Out!
text: We had family from out-of-town visit us this past week. Â  It's always great fun having family and friends come! Â We enjoy using their visits as a chance to go and see a few of the sites of Washington D.C. that I never get tired of seeing. ~Tomb of the Unknowns, Arlington NationalÂ Cemetery~~Arlington National Cemetary~I love the late nights, and the chance to cook, bake and eat out!~Crabcake Sandwich at Clyde's~This visit was perfect, in that when my family left, it had me wishing they could stay a day or two longer. ~Todd and Bella~But maybe it's just as well that they're gone.... Â Because I think all of us, including Todd are feeling just a little worn out. Â Is that possible for him?

title: The Week in Review
text: This week at "Golden Pines" ....Our regular dog-walker went on vacation and the girl who filled in on the first day, got locked out of the house just as she was getting everyone back inside. She's not sure how it happened, but she thought she heard snickering on the other side of the door. ~I'll bet Todd knows how the door suddenly closed on the dog-walker~Our foster kitten went missing. Â After a search of the entire house, top to bottom several times, including closets. he was nowhere to be found. Â Just as panic had set in I was about to give up, Mo was found laying on a chair. Â  For the past few weeks I've been working with Sunny to allow him to be off lead during our walks. The very first morning he was totally off of a leash and not dragging one behind him, he ran off after a rabbit. Â He was so beautiful as he ran across the yard and into the woods. Because I had slow-pokes George and Jake on leads, I couldn't go after him. Â All I could do was stand there and watch him disappear. Â Fortunately, I also worked on Sunny's recall and he came back to me, his eyes all sparkling and happy.Charlie is all dressed up. Â He has a skin infection and is on antibiotics. Â He's not loving the new look. Â So I took off the shirt, and he's a little happier. Axel, our foster boy for Lab Rescue, went to his new home on Thursday. Â I'll admit, he was another dog that I was on the fence about keeping. We were all crazy about him! But a retired couple that lives on the Maryland shore offered him a chance at a good life of fun and lots of family. Â The report today was that Axel had met all the grandchildren, their dogs, and he was loving being able to play in the water. Â Retired Dog-Mom doesn't think that his tail has stopped wagging.~Axel will be missed Â and not forgotten!~Â Axel's dog bed didn't have time to get cold. Â On Friday we welcomed a new addition named Webster from Lab Rescue. Â Just as a coincidence he came from the same shelter in West Virginia that Axel did. Â But it's thought that all the changes and boarding proved to be too stressful for him, because he ended up with bloat, and had emergency surgery on Monday. UnfortunatelyÂ he wasn't getting along well with our crew. Â He was very reactive around the dogs every time they came near him and it was getting worse. All the dogs just ignored him. But Lab Rescue and I agreed that it would be best if a new foster home was found for Webster. Â I'm grateful that on a holiday weekend a new one was found that he could be taken to this afternoon. I felt badly that it didn't work out. Â But Webster really needed a quiet place to recover from his bloat-surgery, and as an only dog in his new foster home, he'll get that chance.~Webster, we hardly got to know him~Through the stress of the last couple of days, I was really proud of Todd. Â He's always ready to rumble but did as I asked when I told him to "go on" when Webster was barking at him -- Even though I could tell he was hesitating and having to think about it. Unlike the video below, doing exactly as he was asked, was a little un-Scottie of him!

title: Owner & Beloved Pet, Together
text: I know that it's Thursday (already?) but I have to tell you about a family memorial service that we attended this past Sunday.Long time readers may remember the 16 year old spirited girl we met in May of 2014 named Crickett. Crickett had been the treasured companion of "Flossie" who had passed away. Â When Flossie was in hospice care, her niece had taken Crickett to visit her, and she promised Flossie that she would make sure Crickett had a good home after she was gone.The Niece and I met when she turned Crickett over to the rescue. Â We became fast friends, and The Niece would often contact me asking how Crickett was doing. Â When Crickett passed away in January of 2015 we met afterwards and shared her loss; finding comfort that Flossie and Crickett were together again. Â Knowing how loved and adored Crickett was by the entire family, I felt strongly that they should have her cremated remains, and so I gave them to The Niece. Â  Fast forward to Sunday, and a lovely headstone (below) has just been put into place for Flossie and her husband. We were invited to a memorial service where family members gathered to remember them both and celebrate what would have been Flossie's 90th birthday. And it took a little bit of doing, but in the same resting place as Flossie, there is also a new smaller marker for Crickett -- Her ashes are now buried with Flossie. Â Beloved pet and owner truly together again. Â Just exactly how it should be, and how Flossie would have wanted it. I think that the cemetery may want to think about changing their sign.

title: Internet Fully Restored!
text: When the week begins, you just never know what it will bring. Â Monday was uneventful, but Tuesday clobbered us with a severe storm that knocked out our power. There is nothing like a power outage to let you know how unprepared you are for one.Of course, the dogs didn't care about any of that. But it was easy to tell they were a bit confused about the change in routine that evening. and they weren't crazy about flashlights (and my camera) flashing in their faces.The power came back on in the early hours of Wednesday morning. Â However we have been without a stable, reliable or fast internet connection until today. Â I've missed not getting a "full dose of internet" but we're just grateful that was all we lost. Â Some have sadly not been as fortunate. With my eyes off the computer screen, on Thursday my eyes caught this little one wandering around our yard. Â Smaller than a can of soda, I worried that he was too young to be adventuring on his own. Â I called a wildlife rehab center and they told me that indeed he was. They told me to catch him (I have a net) and bring him into them if I see him again. Â Fortunately I haven't, and I'm hopeful that he had just wandered a little too far away from his family and they've moved on.This weekends highlight has been meeting good friends at a nearby winery for a picnic and wine tasting. Â It was an enjoyable and relaxing afternoon,It was just what we needed, and I so hope we are back on track for the coming week!~Bella~With our internet problems, I'm sorry I've not been able to drop by your blogs -- I look forward to catching up on your news! ~Our foster cat, Mo is *still* with us~

title: Tea or Berries Anyone?
text: The weather and the weekend could not have been any better. ~A field near our house~It began with me and four other friends being treated by another for our June birthdays to a three course "Manor House Tea." Â  The tea was at historic Rosemont Manor, which was a respite for U.S. Presidents and celebrities as well as a previous estate of a Virginia Governor.Â The company, the tea and the setting could not have been more lovely or enjoyable. Â Back at home, just as she has in previous years, Sheba let me know that the wild-black-raspberries are ripening -- And just as it has been in previous years, I can't wait to make that first cobbler. Â Â The weekend also gave me the chance to focus on George. Â I've ordered chinese herbs for him. Â There are a couple of herbs which can be used to treat cancer as a primary therapy in cases like his because I've opted to not do surgery. I've had mixed results in using them. But they have very few side effects, and so I'm always willing to give them a try. Â I hope you had a fun and enjoyable weekend too!Finally, thank-you all for your caring words on the loss of our boy Dusty. Â Once again, you have made a loss easier by your sharing in our loss, and by your kindness and friendship. He is missed!

title: Good-bye (for now) to Dusty
text: ~The day we met Dusty, August 25, 2015~Today we said good-bye to Dusty. Â It was a day I had been dreading, but expecting. Â Despite that, I just wasn't ready, not even remotely, which is crazy, because these past few months have been so tough for him. Â The tumor on his back leg had grown to be quite large and he was no longer able to lay on that side. Â And this week I noticed that he was getting a pressure sore on the other hip. Â Added to that, his ability to walk and get around was getting harder and harder. Â Dusty was clearly on a journey for which there was only one possible end. ~Dusty last fall, the tumor visible on his left hip~I guess I was just holding onto hope that adding medications, or changing something else would make a difference, but it didn't. Â And when the holistic vet came on Tuesday night to see Jake and I asked her to give me her thoughts on Dusty, I already knew what she would say. Then Wednesday morning came and we sat on the porch together, I asked Dusty (and the cosmos) to let me know if it was time for him to go. Â In the early morning there was nothing but silence as he quietly slept next to me. Â I took the other dogs for a walk a few minutes later and it began to rain. Â In the west, I saw a rainbow. Â Some will say that it was just a coincidence that I'd see one. Â But for me, seeing it before 6 o'clock in the morning, once again confirmed what my heart already knew.~January 2016~Dusty came to us in August of 2015. Â He'd been given up by an elderly couple earlier that year after a car accident left them unable to care for him. Â At the shelter, Dusty caught the eye of a mother grieving the loss of her son who had committed suicide. Â By late summer her heart had healed enough that she felt she was ready to move on with her life, and so she gave Dusty to the rescue.At Golden Pines, Dusty found his place in our home. Â Inside he was a very quiet and unassuming Golden, that would gently nudge my arm for attention and twirl in circles at mealtime. Â Outside from Todd, he learned to bark at the fence at whatever happened past. His most content times were when he was laying in the grass. Â The last few weeks he seemed to gain strength from the warm sun, and never wanted to come inside. Â This morning we had Dusty outside for the last time, and as he stood there in the bright warm summer sun, he raised his nose and sniffed the air before he collapsed onto the ground -- His strength to continue was gone. Â I couldn't help think of the words another blogger had written about their own dog, "He stood tall but this morning the grass grew taller." ~September 2015~The Mobile Vet would come shortly afterwards, and we said our good-byes on the front porch that he loved. ~Dusty sleeping on the porch in 2015~A wren landed at the other end of the porch and started singing just as Dusty was leaving this life for the next -- Reminding me that there are other worlds to sing in. He is now free and no longer in pain. Â I am grateful to have had the chance to get to know Dusty and to have had him as part of our lives for 10 months. Â I will look forward to seeing him again one day; he will be missed and not forgotten. Our candle has been lit all day to help him find his way to the Rainbow Bridge, where I know he was greeted by all those who have gone before him. Â  Â God-speed my "DUSTy-Bunny."

title: Axel Settles In
text: Thank-you all for the good vibes and thoughts for George. Â I really appreciate the well wishes, thoughts and support for what's ahead. Â I was reminded by an article I was sent on Friday that George doesn't know he has cancer. Â So, life to him, at the moment is unchanged. Â The goal will be to keep it that way for as long as we can.Our new arrival, Axel had a good bath today and now smells of rosemary and lavender instead of Â yeast. Â  At about 6 years old, he is painfully thin, and understandably very focused on food. Axel has come to us from a shelter in Charleston, West Virginia. Â He'd been taken there by his owners who no longer wanted him. Â The shelter reached out to the Lab Rescue of Cincinnati Ohio and asked if they could take him. Â Unfortunately they are "full" and were unable to accept him into their program. Â It's not uncommon for neighboring rescues to help one another and so Lab Rescue of Cincinnati contacted Lab Rescue here in Virginia, and the trip of more than 300 miles (400+ kilometers) was arranged and Axel arrived last week. Although it appears that he doesn't know any commands (sit, etc) he makes up for it with his charm and affectionate personality and that he gets along great with the other dogs and ignores the cats. Â If we've had any problems at all, it's that he's showing some separation anxiety. He is getting better making me think that it mostly has to do with the unsurety of what's happening to him, along with being isolated in the shelter and in boarding. All in all, I think he's going to be just fine until his forever home finds him.What has found us this weekend is high heat and humidity. Â Summer is really here. Â And from here on our front porch to yours....I hope you're having a good weekend!

title: George and A New Addition
text: A typical work filled week that included a call to the vet. Â I'd taken a few pictures of George last weekend, and when I opened them on my computer, I noticed a lump in George's mouth. Â I called "Mobile Vet" who came today and looked at it. Even though George's teeth are in good shape, I was hoping it was an abscessed tooth. Â But knowing what I do about lumps and bumps, I knew there was a better chance that it wasn't. Â Mobile Vet does think that it's cancer. Â We discussed all the options to treat or surgically remove the tumor. The majority of tumors like this one appears to be, invade the bony structures of the jaw and even with very aggressive surgical measures, complete resection (removal) can be difficult. Â George is about 14 years old, and so it is a lot to think about.~Bella standing, Jake, Josh and George this afternoon~And finally, just because Lab Rescue asked nicely, last evening we welcomed a 6-9 year old Lab named Axel. He has traveled more than 300 miles (400+ kilometers) to get here. Â He's a really nice boy, and I'll tell you more about him in my next post. ~Axel~

title: Art and Canine Independance
text: A quick trip for a gift on Saturday had me browsing through an art fair instead.I always enjoy and admire the creativity and talent of artists,But I have to admit that sometimes I really don't "get it." Back at home I got to work in my flower gardens. Â My neglect of them along with the rain we've had really helped the weeds to overgrow. Â I still have a lot more work to do, but I stopped after a couple of hours because of the heat. Â I'll also admit that I'm putting off and dreading the work to be done in the bed that has poison ivy growing in it. ~Sheba exhausted after watching me pull weeds~Today as afternoon storms approached and before Berkley went back home we did get all the dogs out for a walk. ~Berkley~Cissy has been having days where she doesn't seem to feel all that well. Â Today was not that kind of day for her. Â Cissy is definitely her "own dog." She is the only dog in the house that doesn't have a place to eat. Â I bring her bowl to wherever she happens to be. Â Her medication is always tucked inside a piece of cheese, and she always eats it first, even if I've put kibble on top of it. In the morning she'll bark once at about 5:00 to let us know she's awake. Â If we try to "encourage her" to get up and go outside, she'll growl. Â A moment later, she's there and wants to be let out. Â Once outside, you can't really tell her what to do, she is off lead, and so Cissy goes where Cissy wants, and comes back inside when she's ready. Â She doesn't usually wander off, so this isn't a problem. Â And today was no different. Â I called her to come. and she just looked over her shoulder at me.Then she sat for a few more minutes as if she was enjoying the view. Â Maybe she was. Â I can't help but chuckle at Cissy's canine independence that knows that a lot of the rules don't apply to her. And can you guess another dog in our household who thinks the rules don't all apply to him? Â  Â  ~Jake and Todd an examples of (Scottie) canine independence~

title: Can't Help But Notice
text: It's hay cutting time here in northern Virginia. Â Over the last few weeks despite the rain I've watched the hay mature and ripen in the fields and thought how beautiful it was as I drive past. The farmers here usually get two cuttings of hay during the summer. Â But if Mother Nature cooperates, they might get three cuttings. Â  Tonight the air is humid and as a light rain falls the smell of the fresh cut hay and honeysuckle fills the air. Along the treeline there is the flash of lightening bugs. It's truly a night where you can't help but notice that it feels like summer. Â I also noticed this afternoon that Berkley seems pretty happy and relaxed. Â He fits in really well at our house. Â His foster home mentioned that he has some separation anxiety, but I've not noticed any of that. Â He seems to really like the other dogs, (and vice-versa) and he's totally "bullet-proof" with the cats. Â I think its been a good week with him. Â I hope you've had a good week too!

title: Carefree Blissfulness?
text: ~Sunset out my window~It's Memorial Day weekend and it's officially the unofficial start to summer! With the rain and the cooler temps we had for most of the month, I couldn't be happier. ~Cissy's happy about the good weather too!~This weekend marks the beginning of long days, the lightning bugs which I saw for the first time a few nights ago, ice cream and as a friend put it, "sun-kissed and carefree blissfulness."~Charlie in a carefree blissful moment~I'm not so sure about carefree blissfulness, but it has been a pretty good weekend. Â Our week long guest, Berkley arrived yesterday. His reintroductions to our pups was uneventful. Â Maybe they remembered him, or maybe they don't care that he's here. Â Maybe it's both. Â Either way, everyone seems okay that Berkley is here.~Sunny on the left, Jake in the middle, and Berkley on the right~Â Despite having a lot of yard work to do, and a few pots of flowers that I have got to get planted, I've not gotten any gardening done. Â But I have turned on the garden-hose and let Todd run through the water a few times.Does that count?

title: Hotter or Happier?
text: With the exception of some yard work this week, and Todd barking at the mower,its been a relatively quiet and uneventful week for us. As Memorial Day weekend approaches we've had a really nice summer preview in our corner of the world.It's supposed to hang on through the weekend, and Todd could not beÂ hotter ...Â happier about it. We have no real plans for the weekend, but we do have a 4 legged guest coming for a few days. You may remember this 12 year old boy named Berkley that spent the Thanksgiving holidays with us. He's a real nice and handsome boy and I've once again had to promise the foster home that I'll give him back. Â So, again, I just have to ask, with a face like Berkley's why should they be worried?

title: A Rocky Creek Scottie Reunion
text: On Saturday, the day of the Rocky Creek Scottie reunion began with rain in our direction.Todd wanted to be his best, so he rested up during the nearly 5 hour drive.Â The closer we got to Rocky Creek Farm, blue skies and lots of sunshine started to appear.~Todd's birthplace, Rocky Creek Farm~It really was a good day with great food and old and new friends~Todd catching up with family~And of course there was Todd's 4 legged family.Below is a photo of his brother Arlo. Â Arlo is actually the puppy I chose before Todd. Â But Lynn (breeder) had other ideas and she picked Todd for us instead. Â There is no doubt that it worked out like it should have!Todd did take a break to try and make new friends with the Rocky Creek cattle. Â They didn't want to be friends.Â Along with us for this trip was Charlie. He handled the day pretty well. Â But he did need a break a few times because he didn't do so well with a couple of the more rambunctious Scotties who knew Charlie wasn't exactly related. Â Â All too soon the reunion was over, and it was time to leave. I think the fun wore Todd out -- Is that possible?At the hotel there was no doubt Charlie was really worn out from the days events.On Sunday we were all recharged, and left early to get home. Todd was ready to help navigate!Â This morning it's back to work for me, but the echoes of the reunion are still fresh in my mind. Â If you'd like to know what a Scottie Reunion sounds like, play the video below.Â Â Enjoy your Monday everyone!!

title: Will It Ever End?
text: The weekend is in sight, and I can't wait. Â Todd and I will be off to his birthplace for the annual "Rocky Creek Scottie Reunion" to see old friends and make new ones. Â It's always great fun, and a nice chance to just get away, even if it just overnight. Â  Here at home, we are minus Lady, who did go to her new home on Saturday afternoon. Â After meeting Retired Couple in person, I really did like them. Â I know Lady will have a good life! Â A few text messages and photos this week have given me no reason to not think that. Â I am however, hoping that the two missed phone calls from "Retired Teacher" is just the promised call to catch up on how it's going. ~Lady settling into her new home~Today while Charlie is at the goomer, we're getting a little bit of sun. Â It's a welcomed break from the rain and clouds that are supposed to return for the weekend. Â  ~Charlie before his spring-makeover~I'm wondering if the rain will ever end? Â ~Todd watching it rain~

title: A Lucky Friday the 13th
text: Some may see Friday the 13th as an unlucky day, but it's not for our boy Jake. Today marks a milestone of 100 days since he left the shelter where as you know he'd been taken to be euthanized by his owner because he had trouble walking. Each day I marvel and am so grateful for how well he's getting around and that he's not letting his diagnosis of spondylosis slow him down.It was also a lucky day for Lady, our foster girl for Lab Rescue. Â I was caught off guard by phone call this afternoon from an adoption coordinator from the rescue telling me about applicants who are very interested in meeting Lady. Â I received a call from "retired couple" and I chatted with "former teacher" on the phone for about an hour. Â My first impression of her is that she could not be more kind and gracious. Â She has had Labs for 50 years, and got choked up telling me that they have been dog-less since they lost their yellow lab last year. Â Former Teacher sounded so excited about the prospect that if it goes well when they come tomorrow afternoon, Lady would be going home with them. ~Josh, Jake and Lady~Of course it goes without saying that I'm very fond of Lady. She is a dog of great character, attitude and spark. Â But she is another dog that I feel that we're the "gateway" to get her to where she's supposed to go. Onto Dusty. Â I'm guarded about how he's doing. Â He's preferring to spend all of his time outside in the grass sleeping the day away. Â With the sun finally returning after 16 days, I'm letting him stay out as long as he'd like. Carl and I both check on him, and offer him and treats and water which he always gratefully takes. Â The picture below of Dusty was taken a couple of months ago. Â The last week it has been easy to see that he's not feeling well, which is why I'm letting him rest and set his own pace for this part of his life's journey.

title: On the Flipside
text: 'With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,' wrote Shakespeare in a what I think was a cherry mood. But I have to admit that I have not been all that cheerful because of rain for more than a week.Â The rain and the lack of sun really zapped my energy and affected my mood.Â ~Bella~On the flipside, Todd didn't mind the rain at all.Adding to the dark cloud overhead, we had water leak in around the outside door to our basement. Â We hardly ever go into our basement, and I was so thankful that I'd thought to check downstairs before any real damage occurred. Â On the flipside, I've no doubt the dogs would have come down to help us with the clean-up if we'd let them. Saturday morning I was off to the vet with Dusty. Â The tumor on his leg has some redness to it, and feels warm to the touch. I felt that he should be put onto an antibiotic to help hold off any infection. Â Mobile vet doesn't see the dogs from the rescue, and with our second choice vet not working, we saw new-vet contestant #3. Â I'll spare you all the details, and just say that my preference will be to not see new-vet contestant #3 again. ~Dusty~On the flipside on the drive home the sun came out. ~Cissy enjoying a sunny afternoon~My inner-solar batteries are recharging and I'm feeling better!~Sheba~On the flipside, for 94 days, Jake has never stopped feeling better!

title: Bella Waiting and Dreaming
text: Off early this morning on a little road trip with Bella to Culpeper, which is not far from Charlottesville. Â I've been e-mailing with a retired couple about Bella over the last several months. "Retired Couple" spend their winters in Florida, and spring, summer and fall in Virginia. Â Unlike some rescues, the Golden Retriever Rescue I volunteer with allows the foster homes to decide who will adopt their dogs from the approved applicants that contact us. Â Because of Bella's diva-moments, I'm pretty specific about the kind of home and family that I think will fit her best. And Retired Couple certainly check all those boxes and then some - They loved her, and as you can see in the photo below, the feeling was mutual! Â  ~Is love in the air with Bella and Retired Couple?~The only glitch is that the husband is having a hip replacement surgery between now and the middle of June, so they wouldn't be able to adopt Bella until early July. Â I asked the adoption coordinator from the rescue her thoughts, and she is suggesting to say to them that "IF she's still available when they're ready, I would love to place Bella with them. However, I need to remember to keep Bella's options open until its time for her adoption."Â  The Adoption Coordinator is right. I can't imagine anyone else better than Retired Couple who would be more perfect for Bella. But for now I guess we wait and see what happens. Â Until we know, Bella is fine here with us, as she waits and dreams about her very own forever home. I wonder what Todd dreams about?

title: Stinky and the Twins
text: My train traveling husband returned via plane on Tuesday. Â He said that he enjoyed traveling by train and would like to do it again. ~View from the train on the second night~While in Washington he visited Mount St. HelensAnd he said he'd forgotten how beautiful the state of Washington is.Back at home, our foster kitten, Mohawk, or Stinky as I've been calling him saw a specialist. Â For the two months that he's been here, he's had "bowel upset" the entire time. Â The diagnosis after seeing the internist is "Irritable Bowel Disease." Â We're changing up his food (for the 3rd time) and putting him back on medications in hopes that it'll do the trick. In the photo below you'll notice that Jake and Josh (on the right) ) are looking a bit like twins.At 14 years old, Josh's arthritis is starting to take a toll on him and he often needs help getting up on his feet. Â Acupuncture and cold laser don't seem to be helping, but the daily pain medications are easing his discomfort. Â To help him to stand up and keep him mobile he needed and I wanted a harness. Â The one I have and like the best is being used by Jake, so I needed to order another one. Â Unknown to me, back in January, another blogger (who I will let remain anonymous) sent us an online gift that I didn't find out about it until I decided to get a harness for Josh - And Her generous gift was the exact amount I needed to buy it -- It was meant to be! Â I cannot thank "Her" enough for thinking of us and making a difference for Josh, as well as the others that will use the harness after him.I've no doubt Todd would agree -- But for now he just thinks it's funny that they're wearing matching outfits!

title: Scottie Comic Relief
text: Carl has been out of town all week visiting his brother in the state of Washington. Â He decided that instead of flying, he would take the Amtrak train across the country. Â A nearly 4 day trip. Â There are people that think this would be great fun, however, I am not one of them. Â He made it to Washington, and said the trip while a long one, was one he enjoyed. Â I guess that's what matters. ~The train station at Harper's Ferry~On the homefront, I have to admit, that its not been the best week for us. Sunny developed a large lump on his chin. Getting in touch with and arranging a time with our new "mobile vet" proved to be a bit of a challenge. We were finally able to meet him in a parking lot. Â Mobile Vet doesn't think it's tooth related, but rather from an injury on his cheek that's gotten infected. Â Sunny thanked Mobile Vet for seeing him by snapping at him. Â Mobile Vet returned the gesture by giving Sunny 2 antibiotics that are upsetting his stomach. But the medications are working, and the lump is much smaller.~A rare photo of camera-phobic-Sunny through the window~Not to be outdone Jake also has an upset stomach. Â I'm not sure what's caused it. Â But after a couple of nights of letting him outside several times, along with a bland diet I can tell he's feeling better. Â Usually single-parenting and dogs with upset stomachs aren't a problem. Â However, I was also pretty under the weather this last week and stayed home from work. Â Something I never do.However, today I am finally feeling better -- But how could I not with this kind of Scottie-comic-relief? What would we do without Todd?

title: George's Bucket List
text: The most unassuming member of our household has got to be George. Â Yes, he lets me know at mealtimes that I'm not getting his dinner to him fast enough, but for the most part, he's happy to just go with the flow. Â George may not be the star of our household, but there is no doubt, that he has his place among our cast of characters. Â He is liked and respected by the other dogs, including Todd.This week, the Labrador Retriever Club of the Potomac was holding their annual "Specialty". Â A "Specialty" show is an event limited to a single breed - In this case, it was Labrador Retrievers. One day during a lunch break, they have a "Rescue Parade." If you've never seen a rescue parade, and you get the chance, you need to go. Â If not, you're missing out on what I think is something special. Â As you can guess, the parade features dogs that have been rescued. Â As their names are called, their age and rescue story is told as they walk around the show-ring. I have seen many rescue parades, and have even helped to organized them, but I've never actually been in one. Â Until this week because I entered George.This parade began with the several Labs, some who were trained by inmates, and are now working in drug-enforcement. Â How wonderful that these dogs that came into the rescue, who may not have been suitable for the typical home because of their energy and overactive instincts have been given the chance to truly make a difference!After the "working dogs" it was George's turn. Â It's usually done by age, so at 14ish years old, he was the oldest in the parade. Â I've decided that if George has a bucket-list, he can now check off walking around the show ring, receiving applause from a crowd and getting a rosette. In my book, George really is the best in show! Â I hope you have a good weekend!!

title: Jake and Selma Mansion: Part 2
text: Back in February, IÂ wrote about "Selma," a 100+ year old historic property and former plantation not far from where I live. Â It was so sad to see this magnificent home abandoned and falling victim to time and neglect, standing in the background of new homes. Â  ~Selma in February 2016~I was really taken by Selma Mansion. Â And, in my February post, because Jake had just come to us, I'd compared the two, because I really felt that like Jake, Selma should be "rescued" too. Â I really hoped that somehow it would be.~Jake and Selma Mansion, February 2016~Well, I read this week, that in March, Selma was Â purchased by a local couple, and restoration work has already begun. Â Over the next two years, they plan on restoring Selma to use as their private residence. Â So of course, when Jake had a vet appointment on Friday, I had to go and see for myself. Â  How wonderful it was to see the windows open as this grand home is being brought back to life!~Selma coming back to life, April 2016~You'll recall that the staff at the shelter where Jake was taken felt that he had "spark and life" and should be given a chance. Â I'm glad that someone who could make a difference, saw that in Selma Mansion!~Jake and Selma~**If you're as taken by Selma Mansion as I've become, you can see more photos and follow the progress of the restoration on Facebook by clicking here for the link

title: Five Years Ago -- Already!
text: This time five years ago...Â a little Scottie was born...at "Rocky Creek Farm" in south-west Virginia. Â He may have been the forth-born in a litter of eight....But Todd is truly number-one at our house!Â And trust Â me,He knows it! Â Â Happy 5th Birthday Todd!!Past Birthday photos -- Do you see a trend here??And yes, it is a real cookie that Todd gets to enjoy! Â I hope you enjoy your Saturday!!

title: The New Vet and Charlie
text: My day off today has been a very quiet one spent at home. Â When Charlie was seen by the vet late last fall, it was recommended that he have his teeth cleaned. Â I was also told during that appointment that he would probably have to have some teeth extracted as well. At the time, the holidays were on the horizon, so I decided to wait. Â Well, of course Charlie's teeth weren't getting any better, and so today was the day I'd planned to have them taken care of. Â My vet that I've been going to for about 10 years is leaving the area, and I've been slowly getting to know a new one, closer to home. Â Actually, this vet comes right to our house, so it works out pretty well. Â "New Vet" is a man, which is a change -- For whatever reason, all my vets have been women, so this may take a little getting used to. Â  But I think there's no better way to break in a new vet than to have them do surgery on one of your treasured family members. Â I'm always nervous anytime one of the dogs has to be put under anesthesia. Â It was a little more nerve wracking because I was inside looking out and waiting. Â From start to finish the procedure took a little more than 3 hours. Unfortunately, more of Charlie's teeth needed to be removed than we'd first thought. Â But at the end of the day, he's still a bit groggy, but doing pretty well. Â He ate a little dinner, and I think he'll be fine. Â For that, I'm grateful.~A Very Sleepy and Groggy Charlie~

title: Day 59 for Jake!
text: We end the weekend in a good place with our newest addition, Lady. ~Lady, checking out the view from the front porch~Her meeting her new pack-mates one-on-one went really well. Â Lady is a nice, easy going gal, that loves attention and aside from her over-interest in the cats, which we'll work on to curb, I think she's fitting in well! Â  Â Lady, "was that a cat that just went by?"Of course, Todd is always the proverbial wild-card when meeting any new arrivals. Â He was okay with Lady until a treat was (accidentally) dropped on the floor, and Lady and Todd both went for it at the same time. Â She quickly learned that you don't get between a Scottie and a treat -- something I should have remembered because I'm sporting a pretty good bruise on my hand from putting my hand where it shouldn't have been. Â Lesson learned for both of us!Today also ends with a milestone. Â Our foster boy Jake, as of today, is celebrating day 59 of grace. Â Fifty nine days ago he left a local shelter where he'd been taken to be euthanized. From not being able to walk to now being able to go up and down the 2 outside steps unassisted is a reason to celebrate! Â We are really enjoying having Jake as part of our household. And just when I thought I knew him, I found out a couple of days ago that he can balance and catch treats that are put onto his nose. Â He misses more than he catches, but it's fun to watch him try!~Jake~

title: A Lady Arrives at Golden Pines!
text: Its been a busy week for me and the dogs! Â I don't even know where to start. Â I think for this post, I'll start at the end of the week, and just hit the highlights.Today at Golden Pines, from Lab Rescue, we welcomed Lady! Â A stray that has come to us from southern Virginia, about 200 miles from us (321. kilometers). Â She's estimated to be about 10 years old. Â She's thin, with several bald patches, and a story to tell. ~A Lady in my Rearview Mirror~We're still getting to know Lady, and we haven't given her much of a chance to make friends with our group. Â There's time for that this weekend, and to try and convince her that the cats are not toys. ~Lady at the shelter~**And since we're welcoming another Yellow Lab, below is an update that Lab Rescue sent me about the other Yellow Lab we had that got away.... "Sherlock is now Reggie, that's what Kim was calling him and I decided toÂ keep it. Everything is going so well. Scruffy and Reggie got along rightÂ from the start and I think they will be buddies. Reggie has been checked byÂ my Vet with a good report and he has already had a laser treatment and aÂ spin on the water treadmill. I think he's going to fit in just fine. So,Â the check's in the mail as they say.Â Thanks for everything!!"LindaÂ Â ~Reggie and his new pack-member Scruffy~Â Todd who got his spring-haircut at the "fur-stealers" yesterday and I hope you have a good weekend! I look forward to catching up on your news! Â Thanks for stopping by!!

title: Home and Home
text: This week took me to Kentucky for a few days. Â Sometimes the 11 hour drive isn't all that "environmentally friendly." Â  -A gas refinery on the border of Kentucky and West Virginia-It was my youngest brother's birthday on Tuesday, so we celebrated by going out to lunch. Â  It was an enjoyable day that ended with my baking his favorite, chocolate brownies, to celebrate his growing older. My visit was to also (finally) order the marker for my brother's grave who died last year. Â Even though it will match the headstone of our parents, it could have been done via phone and e-mail. Â However I felt that this was something that needed to be done in person. Once again, I stayed at the Airbnb I had stayed at in the fall. Â It's a lovely home and the room that is spacious and quiet is perfect for me! The homeowners, a retired dentist and his wife, are both warm and welcoming. I feel lucky to have found such a nice place to stay when I visit Kentucky.All too soon my visit was over, and I was on my way back home to Virginia. Carl did a great job single-parenting the dogs and the cats too. Today, I spent time with the dogs, and caught up on things around the house.-Jake-I caught Todd and tried to take his picture with a spring-flowered headband for Easter. Of course, he made it clear he would have none of that!Sheba was a little more cooperative, but trust me, she didn't like it either. What we do like is this great weather we've having this weekend. Â I hope you're having a good weekend too! Â Happy Easter!-Josh-

title: A Decision for Reggie
text: The Lady, her dog Scruffy and her friend arrived early. During our visit, I did my best to not like the Lady and try to talk her out of liking Reggie/Sherlock. Â But I realized about an hour after she was here, that in many ways she was like me in how she felt and cared about her dogs. Â And as hard as I tried, and believe me I tried, I felt I had to give her a chance at giving Reggie a forever home. ~The Lady and her friend walking Reggie~It may not have been what was best for me, because I'd gotten quite attached to the dog that hardly wagged his tail, who followed me everywhere and often rested his head on my knee. But Reggie trusted me from the first day I met him in November to keep him safe and make the best decisions for him. Â And I felt that The LadyÂ should have the chance to make the same best decisions for him too. ~Reggie, the first day we met~I promised The LadyÂ that I would take Reggie back if it didn't work out and I let Lab Rescue know that too. All I can do now is hope that it goes well, and keep the door open just in case. Letting Reggie go today has been harder than I thought it would be. Â I will and do really miss him. But the e-mail that's below, that I received from Lab Rescue just a few minutes ago, and a voice mail has helped.So far, so good with Sherlock. Â  He made it home and was getting settled at Lindaâ€™s house. Â It appears Scruffy is underfoot a bit, but, is surviving too. Â  The big test will come when they are left alone. Â Who knows....they may do pretty well! Â  Linda use to raise dogs and is still very busy with dogs in many functions. Â  Â I know she will provide a great place for Sherlock. Â I will keep you informed with Sherlockâ€™s status. Â  I did ask for photos once they were settled so I could share them with you!Take care and I will for sure keep you informed!Carol

title: Hopefully the Last Snow Fall!
text: It snowed today, and so we aren't quite welcoming spring the way I had in mind. The Lady is due to be here between 1 and 2 o'clock. title: Resurfacing!
text: A busy last weekend volunteering at a free dental clinic. Â Despite the day beginning at 4:30, a nearly 2 hour drive to the clinic, it was a good experience that reminded me how fortunate I am. But I dragged myself there, and I was glad we attended. Â Despite a late night, it was a nice evening.I switched my day off to today and napped off and on through most of it. title: The View
text: A good day off, helped by the really warm and sunny weather we've had this week. Â It also marked the return of my favorite bird of spring, the Eastern Phoebe. title: Ending Quietly
text: While Todd worked on his spring gardening and landscaping...I was off to the vet with the lovely Ms. Yellow who hasn't been feeling well. Â My "usual" vet wasn't working, so I saw the young vet. Â I think that she's kind and caring and there is no doubt she has the potential to be a really good vet. (see previous post) Â I guess you really can't keep whales in captivity. Â Or maybe it was just too cold. However, there are plans to re-inflate him very soon. title: Whale Watching!!
text: We've all had instances where we're left a little speechless by something that happens -- So much so, that when you tell people about it, it's so ridiculous that they don't believe you. Â Well, this is exactly what has happened in my town this week. There has been a problem with a large group of turkey buzzards roosting on the town's water tower. Â We all know that while they aren't the most attractive bird, they do serve an important role in the environment by helping to "recycle and clean." However when they form big groups in towns, it becomes a problem. The water tower that the buzzards took up residence on is very near a subdivision. Â And so the town council consulted with an expert to help resolve the problem. Â I'm not sure who this "expert" is or where they found him, but they were told that turkey-buzzards are afraid of Orca whales. Â Yes, Orca whales. Â How they know that is anyone's guess.So, on Tuesday afternoon, despite high winds, what the town has dubbed Â Operation â€œFly Willyâ€ began with the town mayor himself climbing to the top of the water tower to attach three orca whales (Humphrey, Moby Dick and of course Willy) onto the railing of the water tank to try and scare the turkey-vultures away.Â All that the town could do was wait and see if it would work.Well, big surprise, it didn't! Â The buzzards returned that very evening, just as they always did. Â And believe me, social media was lit up with jokes about the whole thing! Â  But it's only because I think, it's the craziest and most far-fetched thing I've ever heard of and seen. Â Thank-goodness things are normal at my house.... At least they are at the moment! Â Maybe they should try putting a Scottie up there instead!

title: Out and About

title: Is it Todd, Jake, Cissy or Sunny?
text: Friday again! Â Its been a quiet week, so to wrap it up, I thought I'd post a five-question trivia quiz about a few things that happened this past week. See if you can guess who did what. Â The answers are at the end of the post.1. Â Do you think it was Todd, Jake, Cissy or Sunny that when kissed on the nose this week, quickly ran to a blanket and wiped their face? Â  Â 2. Â Who would you pick as the pup that thinks chasing the new foster kitten is a great sport? Â Todd, Jake, Cissy or Sunny?3. Â Who has decided that they don't want to come inside, even after dark -- Todd, Jake or Cissy or Sunny?4. Â Who was the alarm clock this week when we overslept? Â Actually, this dog IS our household alarm clock, always barking at 5:30 every morning. Â Do you think this task is taken on by Todd, Jake, Cissy or Sunny? 5. Â I always give the dogs fresh fruit and vegetables. Â Who do you think passed on the apples and oranges I had for treats this week? Â Todd, Jake, Cissy or Sunny? Do you think you've answered correctly?Â Well, lets see.Question 1. Â If you answered Todd, you would be right, he's done this before, but the answer for this week was actually Cissy. Â I gave her a kiss on the nose, and she turned around, plopped down onto a dog bed and started rubbing her face. ~Cissy, a kissable nose!~Â Question 2. Â If you think it's Todd, you would be almost right again. Â Even though he knows better, sometimes he just can't resist. Â But for this week, the culprit is newcomer Jake. Â He's still unsteady on his feet, but he tries to chase the kitten, so we're working on teaching him that the cats are to be watched and not chased.~Jake had no idea chasing cats could be such great fun!~Question 3.Â  If you answered Todd, you would be right, yet again. Â He likes being outside any time day or night! Â But this week, it's Sunny. Â For whatever reason, he's decided that he likes to just sit outside. Â I don't know if I should worry about his doing this or not. Â Thoughts?~A blurry Sunny after dark~Â Question 4. Â If you answered Todd, you would be wrong about this! Â When the clock-radio comes on, Todd is a slow-riser. Â He stretches, yawns and rolls on the bed and likes to be scratched and talked to first -- But when his feet hit the floor, he's all business, fully charged and more than ready to go!~Todd, a little slow first thing in the morning, but once he gets going....~HOWEVER, Cissy is our dog-alarm-clock. Â She knows when it's 5:30, and I think that we could set our clock by her internal one. Â She's like Todd, always ready to go and get the day going!Question 5. Â If you answered Todd, add that to your "got it right" column! Â Todd will eat just about anything, but he doesn't like "that raw stuff" but he will eat raw carrots. Â I did introduce Jake to fruits this week. Â It's easy to see that he's a little confused about what he's supposed to do with an apple or orange slice. He'll figure it out, I've no doubt!And there's no doubt its been a quiet week for us. Â Thanks for playing along, and especially for stopping by! Â I hope you have a good weekend!

title: Jake and Selma Plantation
text: I may have been off work today, but I was out the door at my usual commute time to do what I seem to do a lot on my day's off, and that's going to the vet. It was once again Jake's turn for a follow up appointment. Â The Holistic vet came yesterday to do acupuncture and cold laser therapy for Jake and Josh. Â I was anxious for Dr. E to see Jake. Â Last time she saw him, it had taken both of us just to get him outside because he could barely walk or stand up on his own. Â Two weeks later, thanks to the medications, rest, and (especially) your good vibes and the POTP, Jake is now up on his feet and getting around pretty well! Â He still sometimes needs help getting onto his feet and keeping his balance, but there is no doubt that he feels much better! Â Both my vets are really pleased at how well he's doing, and how much happier he seems! The vet visit wore Jake out, and he slept through the errands afterwards. On my way home, I decided to make a slight detour. Â A couple of weeks ago, I was really intrigued by a story I came across about a deserted plantation not far from where I live. From a distance, the 110-year-old mansion known as Selma retains much of its grandeur and charm. Â Preservationists say the far-off view of the mansion, which is on the list of endangered historic sites in Virginia, belies what sits inside: the ravages of time.Â With its three stucco-covered stories nestled against Catoctin Mountain and a portico entrance with Roman Doric columns, it is a pristine picture of the Old South.Taking away from its beauty are newer homes which surround it. Â However, it is on a 50-acre conservancy lot, which means the property can't be subdivided. Â But unfortunately, there is no protection for the home itself. Some of the out buildings are still standing as well.The former plantation was best known as the home of Armistead Thomson Mason (1787â€“ 1819), a U.S. Senator from Virginia. Â He built the original house and lived there until he was killed in a duel in 1819. His widow and young son stayed on until a change in fortunes forced them to sell. The original house was destroyed by fire in the 1890s and the current mansion was built in the early 1900s. Despite passing through several owners and developers, nothing seems to come of efforts to bring life back to Selma. Â I think this is really sad, because there's no denying its historic beauty.And because there is no doubt, that just like Jake, it's worth rescuing.

title: Nice While it Lasts
text: An unexpected snow day closed my office today. But in the end, I didn't really do anything. ~New boy, Mohawk, watching the birds~Todd never has days like I've had. Â A Scottie stays busy and is sharp in any weather! And a Scottie never forgets. title: Hello Kitty and Restful Times
text: Flowers and chocolates this Valentine's Day weekend are always nice, but so are warm gloves and a maybe a dog (or two or three) to warm your feet! Â The arctic-like air has blasted us with what is being called â€œthe coldest air in more than a decade.â€ No, (thankfully) we don't have the below zero temperatures that some people are getting this weekend. Â But with icy winds, it certainly felt like it first thing this morning when I walked the dogs in single-digit temperatures.Todd thinks the cold feels pretty good. Or maybe ..... Â ...He just doesn't want to wear a coat. Â Maybe both! But despite the cold, there were still errands to run. Â One errand we had today was to "swap out" one foster cat with another. Almost two weeks ago, a lovely kitty named Scarlet arrived. ~Scarlet, we hardly got to know her~Today, as she went off to her new home, a little boy named "Mohawk" took her place. Â Is that a trending name for cats? ~New boy, Mohawk~Even with a new arrival, it was a quiet day at home. Â These days, I think of winter as a restful time. ~Josh~A time to take stock, and build up some reserves. IÂ make less plans, I read more books, I look ahead and look forward to the active months ahead. What do you look forward to?

title: Reggie, Sherlock or Sam?
text: I love when Thursday comes, and the week starts to slow down. My time belongs to me and the dogs too! Â The below freezing temperatures today kept us inside.~A bored Bella~Except Todd, he doesn't care what the temperature is, he wants to be outside defending his turf!Todd somehow hurt his shoulder last week, and was heavily favoring it. Â The vet thought it may be a soft tissue injury and was recommending restricting his activity. Â This meant not letting him run or jump. Â That lasted about a day.... While I was at work.... If it's still bothering him, he's not showing it.~Hurt shoulder? What hurt shoulder?~This week I had a call from Lab Rescue about Sherlock/Reggie. Â Apparently someone was perusing the rescue's website, and saw his photos. Â Their dog was stolen 3 years ago, and they think that Sherlock/Reggie looks exactly like their dog. Â With no microchip, the only way they can identify their dog is by a lump on the muzzle. Â I was asked to look for a lump and call him by the name of Sam. Â I looked Reggie over really well. Â I even checked for scar tissue in case a lump may have been removed. Â I found nothing. Â He didn't respond to the name Sam. Â Of course he doesn't respond to Sherlock or Reggie either. Â But I don't think the dog I call Reggie is their dog. Â I feel badly that their dog was stolen, and that after 3 years, they're still looking and no doubt wondering what happened to their dog. Â Lab rescue will let me know if anything more becomes of their inquiry. **As a caveat, I'll add that Lab Rescue owns Reggie/Sherlock legally. Â He did his hold and "stray time" in a shelter, and was turned over to them after that time was up. Â Â ~Reggie, Sherlock, or Sam?~Finally, thank-you all for your good vibes and POTP for our new boy, Jake, they are truly making a difference! Â He's settled into his new life and routine nicely this week. Â He's still unable to get to his feet without help. But once he's standing, he has better balance than he did a week ago and once he shakes off the cobwebs from having to be confined, he's ready to go. Â  ~A relaxed Jake~Kind of like Todd is!

title: A Diagnosis for Jake -- Good Vibes Needed!
text: Thank-you all for your words of support in my last post, and welcoming Jake to Golden Pines! Jake and I were up and on the road early to see our primary vet. Â Jake was nervous and shaking during the whole drive. Â I felt badly for him. Â With his world having been totally turned upside down, I had to wonder what he may have been thinking. Â Once at the vet, the fuss the staff made over him, quickly reassured him that he was going to be okay. X-Rays were taken and very soon we had a diagnosis for Jake. Jake has "degenerative spinal stenosis." Â It's a painful condition caused byÂ excessive bone formation in the spine, which causes a narrowing of the spinal column and puts pressure on the spinal cord. Â It's a progressive and debilitating disease, and there is no "cure." Â My vet, said it was the worse case she'd ever seen. Â So we are going to try to relieve the inflammation along the spinal cord with a steroid, heavily restrict his activity for a month, (because we don't want to chance having a ruptured disc), put him on pain medications, and ask for you to send some good vibes for him. Â Our hope is that by reducing the inflammation, it will improve his ability to get around, and give him a good quality of life for whatever time he has left. Â If this doesn't work, the reality is, is that a decision about letting Jake go may have to be made. Â But I do not want to think about that right now. Â Jake seems happy and is settling in nicely. Â So, the rescue and I feel strongly that we have to give him the chance that his previous owner wasn't willing to give him. Thanks for sending your good vibes for Jake!

title: Jake Arrives at Golden Pines!
text: Even though we are bursting at the seams with dogs at our house, I've always said that I would make room for a dog that needed a place to go, and that's what I did this week. Â On Wednesday we welcomed Jake to Golden Pines.~Jake's mug shot from the shelter~ Â Jake is 12 years old, and was brought to a local shelter by his owner who wanted him euthanized because he's having problems walking. Â Yes, you read that correctly. Â However the Shelter felt Â "Jake was a very happy, friendly, engaging dog and that he definitely had some quality time left." Â So they convinced the owner to let Jake be turned over to a rescue.Jake's is very weak in the rear end, and I had problems getting him outside first thing this morning. Â Actually, I couldn't get him out at all this morning because he wouldn't stand up. Thankfully the vet that did acupuncture and cold laser therapy for our boy Gus last year, was coming to see Josh today -- The timing of Dr. E coming could not have been more perfect. Â She helped me get Jake outside, and did a thorough assessment of his condition. Â She's recommending he see a primary vet for spinal x-rays and blood work to decide the next steps to take. Â Jake is now fitted for a "Help-em-up" harness, which is a big help in getting him onto his feet and outside. Â He already seems like he's feeling more confident outside now, and was trying to play and acting silly when we had him out. Â Good signs! Â  The rescue of course approved the vet care, and Jake has an appointment with my vet on Saturday morning. Â Paws crossed for our newest arrival!

title: We'll Take It!
text: ~On our road - A view of the Short Hill Mountains~Â Blue skies and warming sun as I was off to the vet early this morning with George and Bella. Nothing serious for either of them. Bella, just a follow up appointment for her thyroid. ~Bella~George was due for a six month check up, and to meet our primary vet. Â He's really slow getting up, and I know it's a combination of arthritis, and his weight. Â When he was weighed this past summer, I was a little disappointed that he'd lost hardly any weight. Â But we liked this scale today, he's lost 10 pounds since he was last weighed -- He's now 95 pounds! Â  About 10 more to go!~George~ Â We'll take it, and celebrated with a cookie! I've looked at so much snow this week, that now I'm actually starting to see see things in it. title: Plowed Out -- Finally!
text: The snow may have been fun to watch fall, but on Sunday, the reality set in. Â We had to dig ourselves out. I had parked my van near the bottom of the driveway that is around 250 feet long. (about 76 meters), so we knew we weren't totally snowbound. Â But Carl's car was in the garage, and was snowed in, kind of like this school bus below. Â  In the past, we've shoveled what little snow we've had, or called someone to do it for us. Â However, because of the amount of snow, the people who provide this service were coming at a premium. Â One person promised to come on Monday. Then said he'd come on Tuesday. Â After waiting all day, he finally said he couldn't come at all. Â Frustration because of two wasted days. ~A skeptical Sunny watching the camera~More calls on Wednesday and Carl found two people who would come, but each were charging a "trip fee" of $250 (!!) and the other, $150. Â This fee did not include the $100-150 an hour just to plow the driveway. Â Needless to say, we were feeling a lot of things -- overcharged and gouged to name two. Â Added to that, they both wanted cash, and wouldn't take a check or credit card. Â I'd returned to work on Wednesday and Carl who was home, didn't have enough cash on hand. Â So, with that, warmer temps and the snow melting, he decided to do it on his own. Â He had pretty much just started shoveling when someone with a tractor and plow stopped and offered to help. Â He refused any money and only wanted something to drink -- In 20 about minutes our driveway was cleared! Â Needless to say, we were both most grateful for the help of a good samaritan -- Who wasn't in it for money.Today, I'm feeling relieved that our driveway is clear. The snow has melted enough that Todd is back to guarding his yard -- Even somehow finding a mole to "make dead." Â --How did he find one in all this snow?And life seems to be getting back to normal. Â ~Reggie and Bella~Whatever normal may be.Or not be.

title: Clobbered!
text: I saw this sunrise on Friday morning as I was on my way to work. Â Knowing the snow-storm that was coming, I thought to myself that there was truth to the old rhyme, "Red sky in the morning sailors take warning." Â I left work around noon just as the snow was starting to fall. Â By the time I was half-way home the roads were getting snow covered and slick.We hunkered down and just watched the snow pile up as Todd (below) would disappear in it.Â Â We did go out several times and shoveled a path for the dogs.But it wouldn't take long for the dogs and the path to get covered in snow. Â ~Georgie the snowman!~At times they reminded me of fish swimming in a bowl. Â ~Reggie/Sherlock~The dogs seemed to take it all in stride, hardly noticing that the size of yard and being able to get around outside had really diminished.Â ~Charlie and Dusty~By Saturday night, after more than 24 hours, it finally stopped snowing. We ended the day with around 30 inches of snow. Â Some people are saying there is more, but with blizzard conditions that made the snow drift, it was hard for us to measure; Â I just know we have a lot of snow! Thankfully our power has stayed on the entire time.Â Today it was bright sun and blue skies and the big job has begun to shovel ourselves out. I think that it's going to take awhile. Â But with a little Scottie to lead the way, it may not!

title: Ready or Not, Here it Comes!

title: Introductions
text: ~A Coopers Hawk, looking for a meal~I was off work by 1 o'clock on Friday afternoon and decided to take advantage of that by going to a "tag sale" in a nearby town. Â Despite that there were a few things I would have liked to take home with me, I opted to leave empty handed. Â As I was walking to my car, a man approached me smiling, He said he "was pleased to run into me again." Â My mind started reeling because there was something kind of familiar about him, but I didn't really know who he was or how I knew him. Â We talked for a few minutes and we had a really nice conversation that ended with laugher. And despite my covering the topics of dogs, dentistry, and even the church I attend, I still have no idea who he was. Â Has that ever happened to you? Today the perspective adopter for Flurry arrived and needed no introduction. "Scott" was a very nice man, who has recently moved to Virginia from Oregon along with his dog. Â Flurry seemed to approve of him, and within an hour, the new friends were gone. Â The adoption-coordinator from the SPCA and I both agreed that it was a good match, and we both wish Flurry well as he begins a new chapter in his life. Outside, the only introduction Todd is interested in are the deer who've not jumped the fence Â again.Â But he's watching and waiting, just in case.

title: A Weekly Rundown
text: Our week has been going full speed as the wind howled, and we saw our very first snow flakes. Â Here's a rundown of our week so far...Sheba, must be having some kind of mid-life crisis, is that possible for a 11 year old dog? Â She has never, ever, chewed up anything, until this week. Â She developed a taste for a plastic flyswatter, and ate practically the whole thing while I was at work one day. Â At first, I didn't think it was her -- Josh, yes. Â Charlie, he's done it before. Â Todd, no, he was in his crate. Â But when she vomited some small pieces of it, that gave it away. Â She also decided to chew up a cat toy, and a book that I caught her with. Â I'm not sure what to make of it. Â (So far, Sheba is okay, and it appears that everything was chewed into small pieces and is "moving through" just fine ). Â ~Sheba, a 2nd puppyhood?~Onto Sherlock/Reggie. Â He was back to see the drill sergeant vet for a follow up appointment. Â The vet quickly examined him, said she thought his range of motion had improved, called to the assistants to draw some blood, asked me about medication refills, told me to she wanted to see him in six months, and to wait in the reception area -- All in one breath...~Reggie/Sherlock, waiting for the Drill Sergeant Vet~`Moving on to Dusty... Â He also had a visit with the vet. Â I've been discussing with the medical coordinator of the rescue his overall health, in particular the tumor that he has on his back leg that continues to grow in size. Â Right now he's in a good place in how he feels, and how connected he is with the daily routine of the household -- A big switch from what its been previously. Â The board of the rescue voted to allow him to stay with us as a "long term foster." Â This means he'll remain with us the rest of his life, and they will continue to pay his medical expenses.~Dusty will be staying at Golden Pines!~Â Flurry the kitten is still with us for a few more days. Â His perspective adopter couldn't make it to come and meet him last weekend.This takes us to Todd. Â A couple of times this week deer have taken to jumping our 5 foot high fence, and grazing in our yard. Â It goes without saying that Todd won't have any of that. So, he's been religiously patrolling it to fend off those would be trespassers. He takes that job very seriously. Â But of course there's always time for play too.

title: Available for Adoption?
text: Bright sun, blue skies, and single-digit cold at the start of our week has given way to clouds and warmer temperatures today.Rain is on the way for a busy weekend ahead.-Sheba~Since Sherlock/Reggie (below) came to us in November, we've not been asked about keeping him, and I've not mentioned it either, because I've not yet decided. Â Lab Rescue does have him available for adoption on their website and several other places, and so I knew it was only a matter of time before I got a call about him. Â A call came on Monday. Â The couple are "retired pastors" and liked Sherlock/Reggie because he reminded them so much of their previous Lab. Â I'm not sure how you feel, but I never like it when a would-be-adopter is interested in a dog solely because they remind them of a former pet . So putting that aside, I decided to keep an open mind about them. Â I did like them well enough, but their house has two stories, and because of Sherlock/Reggie's weakness in his rear-end, Â he's unable to do a flight of steps. Â So with that, I told them I felt they weren't a good match for Sherlock/Reggie, and I'm glad that Lab Rescue agreed.~Sherlock, or Reggie as we call him~On the feline side of our household, I decided to Â make "Flurry" available for adoption. I think that if he stayed here, he and the lovely Ms. Yellow would eventually work out their differences. Â  Â  But with that aside, if I've learned anything in the past 6 months in fostering cats, is that there's no shortage of them. Â I'd like to be able to help the rescue again if needed, and keeping Flurry may not make that possible. Â He was put onto their website, and now the SPCA says they have three "good" applicants for him. Â One is coming this weekend to meet him, so we may be saying good boy to this little boy. Back to the canine side, Todd doesn't care whatsoever about who may be leaving. Â Today he was pretty concerned about what was arriving -- An unexpected package from our friend Sugar and her Mom that was full of treats -- What a nice surprise! Â While the others stood nearby, because Todd "insisted," he got to inspect the package first.Dog treats are (of course) highly valued at our house, and are always enjoyed and devoured too! Â (If you don't know Sugar, the Golden Retriever, stop by her blog, (click here) she and her Mom are truly the best!)Â We hope you're having "the best" week too! Â ~Charlie~

title: Normal -- What Do You Think?
text: Bright sun and colder temperatures arrived over the weekend. Â The holidays are in our rear view mirror, so it's back to our normal and hopefully quiet schedule, Of course with Todd, every day is a chance at an adventure and mischief -- No day is really a quiet or a normal one for him.While I was running a few errands, it was such a nice day, and with a little extra time, I decided to take a more scenic route on the way home. Â I'm not sure about you, but I don't think there's anything "normal" about the photo below. Is it a grave site of a favorite and loved cow or bull? Â With only the camera on my phone, it's hard to see that the cow isn't something from a toy store, and looks "custom-made." Â  I'll admit that I was surprised to see it, because it's a little (?) unusual, and not something I've ever seen before. What do you think?

title: Onward to 2016!
text: The last day of 2015. Â Looking back, just as so many of you have also had, we've had our share of Â loss, heartache and happiness.~A rare view of our resident Barred Owl~Of course I can't help but reflect on our losses. Â Each had its own personal sadness and sorrow. Â We said good-bye to four dogs in 2015.... The lovely little Cricket.The gentle and easy-going Beau.The charming, silly and handsome Gus.And the endearing and carefree BuddyThe subtractions brought additions. Â We fostered our first senior boy for Lab Rescue, welcoming George in the spring. I just couldn't let him go, reasoning that he shouldn't have to go through another change in homes, so he became a permanent addition. We got to meet Lexi from the Golden Retrieve Rescue and helped her find her way to a forever home where she's truly a star!Then of course there was the arrival of Bella, who despite her diva-moments, has a gentle and joyful soul.~Bella~And lets not forget the five kittens that were living behind the gas station in my town. Â I volunteered to foster them when no one else would. Â It introduced me to someone from the SPCA who found homes for all of them. Â We've since welcomed two more kittens from the rescue, and still have "Flurry" (Jack-Frost) in Â residence.At the end of the summer we welcomed the ever patient, quiet and affectionate boy, Dusty. Â Â Lastly we have welcomed Sherlock, who I call Reggie, from Lab Rescue. Â His story is still being written, Will he stay, or will he go? But he's looking so much healthier these days, don't you think?~Sherlock, or Reggie as I call him~Of course there was the loss of my brother, John, in February. Â The sale of my family home in the spring. Â The celebration of my nephews wedding in July. Each event brought me closer to my brothers and reminded me of the importance of family.Through those good and not so good times, there have been the antics and mischief of the star of our household, Todd. Â His energy and high-spirit have made us laugh, cheering me up through the not so good times of 2015. Yes, every star has its supporting cast, and needs an audience and there's no question, our house has a great collection of co-stars. Â Together they ALL teach me so much.~A few of the co-stars at Golden Pines~One thing is that joy can and should be found in the simple things in life. ~Charlie's new toy, or is it Todd's?~The dogs remind me not to worry about the past or what's behind you -- But to instead focus on what's in front, and enjoy the moments, and live in the present.Â And to bound through life with a smile. Â Happy, Happy New Year from all of us at Golden Pines!!

title: A Job Well Done
text: ~Christmas Day~It was quiet at our house on Saturday for a couple of reasons. Â One was because I'd taken my brother to the airport to catch an afternoon flight home.~Dulles International Airport~I'd also gotten a call from the SPCA about "Flurry" (Jack Frost?) telling me there was a spot for him at the local store, and I was asked to bring him. (A reminder that I need to decide if he'll be staying with us, or going to another home.)Â  Â  Â So, we were minus one person and a rambunctious kitten. The dogs were worn out from not getting their daily 20 hour naps last week. ~Sheba, worn out from Christmas~Â It was eerily quiet. Â Too quiet actually. Â It was then that I realized it had been awhile since I had seen or heard Todd. Â He wasn't inside. Â I called him outside, and he didn't come. Â If you're a dog owner you'll know that nervous feeling I was having. Another quick search inside, and I was outside calling him again.
