Then I saw *it* Â It looked like Todd, but *it* was totally covered and caked in mud from head to toe. Â Todd. Â I don't think I'd ever seen him so covered in mud. Â His tongue that was practically hanging down to the ground was even mud colored. Â He was smiling and out of breath from digging, and I wish now I'd gotten a picture. Â But you'll have to take my word for it because all I could think about was giving him a bath.He didn't seem to mind too much. Â Afterwards Todd was basking in the glow of what he knew was an excavating job well done. ~Todd, post yard work and bath~

title: Merry Christmas!
text: Our weather for this Christmas Eve in no way reflects the season. Â The news is reporting that it's the second warmest December in history.~In front of me on the way to lunch today~Â Even though it doesn't feel like Christmas, it certainly hasn't been stopped from coming. Â Time has not been on my side, because I ran out of it, and never did get my baking started. Â But I have high hopes to get the final package out to a good friend for their New Years. Its been a busy week with my youngest brother who arrived on Sunday. Â The dogs adore him, and its been great fun to have him here. Â We think its been more than 20 years since we were together for Christmas. Today we celebrated by having lunch at my favorite restaurant. Â Afterwards my brother and Carl were off to see Star Wars.~Clydes at Willow Creek Farm -- My favorite!~This evening, as I wait for them to come home, I want to take a moment to say Merry Christmas to all of you, my friends and readers! Â I canâ€™t thank you enough for coming by to visit us and keeping me and this blog going with your kind comments and support. Â I will be honest and say that I have struggled with continuing to blog this year. But what has kept me going is knowing how much I would miss the glimpses into your lives and your friendship, which I never take for granted. Â Despite my being erratic in posting this year, you have stuck with us, always taking a moment to stop by and leave your thoughts; it really does mean so much, and I cannot thank you enough for that.From all us at Golden Pines, we hope you all have an amazingly wonderful Christmas! I hope you spend it surrounded with love, laughter, warmth, good food, and great memories.

title: Racing With Christmas
text: Has it really been a week since I posted? Â It's not because I've not thought about it. Â It's finding that spare time that as we all know tends to be a bit elusive this time of year. Â However, despite the pressure of the race with Christmas, I'm closing in on it. Or maybe Christmas is closing in on me, I'm not quite which it is. What I've not done is any baking whatsoever. Â I'm hoping I can at least get it started this weekend before company arrives on Sunday afternoon. Â Hopefully I'll be sending out the last of the packages on Monday.The dogs have no idea what the fuss is all about. Although they are curious about the tree that took up residence in our garage on Friday. We've never had a "live" tree with several of them before, so we'll see how they do. We'll also see how our foster kitten "Flurry" does with the appearance of what will no doubt seem to him as a fun playground. -Foster Kitten, Flurry -- Who has made himself at home~Away from all the Christmas rush, there's been work, and a discussion with the rescue about Bella. Â My contact on the Board of Directors called me, and we discussed their decision about Bella. Â We all agree that she has "special needs" and will require a certain type of home. Â Given this, they (still) feel that an attempt at finding her a forever home should be made. Â It's a decision that I understand, respect, and I support. Â So, after the holidays, I'll do a write up for Bella for the rescue's website, and a search will begin. Â  Until then, it's full speed ahead with the holidays! Â Earlier in the week we had warm weather and soaking rain. Today began with cold blustery wind and temperatures below freezing, that's supposed to hang on through the weekend. Â So, keeping moving is the best way to keep warm!

title: Cissy's Rules
text: Our weather today has been more like a warm spring day, rather than December. Â The dogs were feeling frisky on our afternoon walk. Â Cissy doesn't wait for warmer weather to feel good, she feels frisky on most days. We were on the far-side of our property where the tall grass marks the boundary. The driveway for the home in back of us is on the other side, and the dogs who are off lead, know not to cross. Â Cissy went into the grass, and stood there for a moment. Â I had a feeling about what she was about to do. Â I told her "no" and to come to me.The warm weather must have been getting to her because she was suddenly deaf. Â I watched her turn left and look.I told her no again, as she looked right...And as if she knew no cars were coming, she was off and running, and so was I! Â Thankfully I caught her before she got too far. But I've a feeling that Cissy is under the impression that the rules don't apply to her. Â Okay, she's right about that, but I'm not going to tell her. Â But then again, she may already know. We hope you're enjoying your weekend and your holidays!

title: Sherlock, Bella and a Ball
text: A typical week at our house, with all the usual busyness of work and commuting and trying to get ready for Christmas. Behind the scenes I've been talking to Lab Rescue about Sherlock (who's having an identity crisis because I keep calling him Reggie). I've also been discussing Bella with the Golden Retriever Rescue.~Bella~With Sherlock (Reggie?) because he's just the second dog I've had for Lab Rescue, and I've never personally met anyone from the rescue, I don't know really what to expect and how they manage dogs with issues like Sherlock has. Are they willing to provide whatever is needed, or do they have a limit as to what they will do? Â Of course they don't really know me either. So, maybe we're each treading a little lightly. Â The approach seemed to work in my phone conversations with them this week. Â Its been decided that we'll put Sherlock on the anti-inflammatory medications and supplements to see if that makes a difference for him. Â After the holidays we're going to add in either swim therapy or acupuncture. I agree with that, but what I don't agree with, is to letting him remain available for adoption while this is all worked through. Â But it's a decision I can live with. Â  For Bella, it's a bit more complicated. It's time to make a decision about her remaining with us permanently and the rescue continuing to cover her medical expenses, or finding another home for her. Of course I would love for her to stay here. But as much as we care about Bella, we need to consider the dogs that we own and their expenses. Â I personally know several on the board of the rescue and know them to be fair and always having the best interest of the dogs in mind as decisions are made. Â All this will be needed when considering Bella, Â Her "diva moments" where she lets us know that she doesn't want any dogs or even cats around her, is a concern. Â Its lessened over time with us, but I worry about Â her behavior unintentionally being allowed to escalate in another home. Â Added to that is Bella's inability to do steps, and tripping over her back legs when she tries to run. Those things together, make her a challenge to find a home for. And if one was found, is it what's best for her? Â The board of the rescue will have to decide, and I'll support that decision. Â Todd on the flip side has no interest whatsoever in "rescue politics." Â His only concern yesterday was the early Christmas present that he refuses to share or give up. Â Todd wouldn't give it to me, and kept it close by, insisting on taking it to bed with him last night. When I moved it to the nightstand, he would have none of that, and wanted it back. Â Just like a kid with a new toy, he wanted it by his side as he slept. Â Of course I let him have his way.

title: A Glimpse Into Sherlock's Past
text: An early start on a cold frosty morning with temperatures just below freezing to take Sherlock to the vet.You may recall I've been concerned that he doesn't shift weight onto a back leg. I've not ever taken any dogs to this particular practice in Maryland, so I wasn't sure what to expect.The vet reminded me more of a drill sergeant than a vet because she was all business and no nonsense. Â Getting right to the point after examining Sherlock, she told me to "go back to the waiting area while x-rays were done, and to leave the door open to the examining room." Â About an hour later I was asked by the Drill Sergeant Vet to come to the back and get Sherlock and review the films. The Drill Sergeant had already called Lab Rescue and discussed everything with them. She quickly reviewed everything with me, told me to return in 4-5 weeks for a revaluation, told the techs what medications to dispense for Sherlock, and said "she needed to get caught up," and with that, we were done.It's said that a picture is worth a thousand words, and that's so true about the x-rays that were taken of Sherlock today, that gave us a glimpse into his past. Â At some point in his life, he had a broken pelvis that was (probably) caused by getting hit by a car. Injuries to a dogs pelvis are typically allowed to heal by being confined. But as dogs age, the healed injury can lead to arthritis, and compressed vertebrae in the spine. Â That's what's happened with Sherlock and caused his muscles to atrophy in his back legs. The Drill Sergeant Vet thinks there isn't anything that can be done for him other than palliative care to help maintain his quality of life. Â I'm not sure what Lab Rescue does in these instances, so I'll need to discuss everything with them. But there's no rush, and Sherlock who is still sleepy from the anesthetic, isn't in a hurry either.So, while Todd is checking to see if there's more digging that can be done in a place that he's dug up more times than we can count....Â I hope you're enjoying your weekend!~Sheba modeling our wreath~

title: Dusty and the Weather
text: Our weather at the start of the week was cold, rainy, wet and dreary. Â Perfect weather if you're a Scottie!Â The weather has matched how Dusty has been feeling since about Sunday. On both Monday and Tuesday night I was up in the early morning hours letting him out and cleaning up.I was trying every remedy I have in my bag of tricks for Dusty, hoping that by Wednesday he would feel better. Unfortunately, nothing seemed to be working, and by the time I was ready to leave for work yesterday, he seemed to be a little worse. Dusty needed a bath, so I quickly gave him one, and did something I never do, and that was to call my vet and let them know I was on my way with him -- But not before I pulled over in rush hour traffic, in the pouring rain to get Dusty cleaned up the best I could and put down clean towels for him. At the vets office, because I'd already started him on a medication I had on hand (metronidazole) the vet wasn't recommending doing much more than giving him fluids. After we left the vets office, I was feeling really worn out, and so I did a second thing I hardly ever do, and that was to call my office and tell them I wouldn't be coming in. Â I really just wanted to go home, but Dusty also needed another bath. Â I stopped at a nearby shop and told them about Dusty, and they generously donated everything he needed for a good bath. They had done that before for Cissy, and I so appreciated their doing that for Dusty as well.Once home we settled in for a quiet day at home. Â After a good nights sleep for both of us, today our weather is again mimicking how Dusty is feeling; the clouds are clearing and the sun is trying to shine. Â He is feeling better!

title: Onward to Christmas!
text: It's the end of the Thanksgiving weekend. Â It doesn't feel like I've been off work for 4 days, because it passed by so quickly. -Cissy, everyday is a weekend for her!-This afternoon the handsome Berkley did go back to his foster home. Â We enjoyed our weekend guest, and I'm glad I could do a favor for another foster home.-The only photo of I have Berkley-This week on the agenda is a visit to the vet for our newest arrival, Sherlock. Â I've noticed that he's not putting any weight on a back leg, so he'll be seeing the vet to have that looked at. -Sherlock-Around the house we are at the very beginning of preparations for Christmas.-The lovely Ms. Yellow-We all know it will be here before we all know it! Â It never came this fast when we were kids, did it?

title: The Handsome Houseguest
text: I can't believe that it's Thanksgiving Day, and we're just less than a month away from Christmas. Â With the warm temperatures we're having today, it is not feeling quite like the holidays. Later this afternoon we'll be enjoying Thanksgiving dinner at the home of our good friends and their family. Â My rolls for the meal are all baked and ready. Until it's time to leave, we've just been enjoying a nice, quiet day at home.~Bella~~Sherlock~Since Monday we've had a houseguest. Â His name is Berkley and we're keeping him for another foster home until Sunday when they return from the holiday. Knowing how much I love the senior boys, the foster home said to me, and a couple of other people from the rescue that they were afraid I'd not want to give him back. Â Now I ask you, with a face like Berkley's, (below) should they be worried? ~Our Handsome Houseguest, Berkley~Despite what I think of this most handsome boy, and how easy going he is, Berkley is not staying. There really is no more room at the Inn -- Is there?~Charlie~

title: I Resisted Everything -- Almost!
text: I returned yesterday afternoon from my overnight trip to see our good friend, "Sid" in Pennsylvania. Having lost her Golden about a year ago, she recently added a new addition to her home, and Sid was anxious for me to meet her new girl, Gracie.Anytime I have the chance to get together with my friend, I know it's going to be a great time. Â This trip was no exception. Â We had a fun day catching up, and we took advantage of the beautiful day to drive around Lancaster and see a few places I'd not gone to before. I had no idea that there was not one covered bridge in Lancaster.But there are twoAnd you can still drive across both. Â  My friend wanted to use the day to get ready for Thanksgiving, and pick up a few things for the dinner she's planning at her home. Â That meant several stops at a few of her favorite places.First on the list, were pretzels at the Hammond Pretzel Company. Then we were off to the bakeries. Â Despite how good everything looked, I resisted buying anything here.And here... And here too.One of our last stops was the "Wilbur Chocolate Company. Â Where, I am not kidding, the air outside smelled like chocolate, Â Again, I resisted buying anything. Â Despite there being a great selection. Â  But the one thing I just had to buy was this monkey hat. Dusty didn't seem to mind wearing it. But when I put it on Todd, he made it pretty clear that he wished it was one purchase I had resisted!It didn't last long, and as soon as I removed the hat,Todd's dignity was quickly restored!I hope you've had a good weekend!

title: He's a Good Boy
text: ~Cissy on Thursday afternoon~We're at the end of our week with what I hope is our phone and internet problems all sorted out. Â We've also gotten our hot water heater fixed, and Sherlock is pretty much all settled in.This week he remembered his house-manners and he's had no accidents (knock on wood) in about the last 3 days. Â He still has to learn that the lovely Ms. Yellow is to be looked at and not touched or chased -- And I do think that if Sherlock wanted to make a meal out of her, he would have done that by now. Â However, I still don't totally trust him around her, so we're still watching him very closely and treating/or rewarding him when he turns and walks away from her. I'm still trying to decide about his hearing. Â I'm pretty convinced that he can't hear much if anything. Â I also think that he's afraid of getting left outside because he'll go out, "do his business" and come back to the door to be let back in pretty quickly. This shows that Sherlock has at some point, lived inside. Â He knows all about sleeping by a bed, and that the refrigerator is where the food is. Sherlock also knows about begging and how to endear himself; he'll rest his head on my leg and just look up at me with his big, hopeful eyes. Â I'll pet him and tell him "he's a good boy" Â Then he'll go and lay down. Â  Enjoy your weekend... Â ~Another "good boy" at our house" Â I'm off this morning for an overnight road trip!See you tomorrow!

title: Getting to Know Sherlock
text: ~A freshly groomed Todd on Thursday~Despite our internet being spotty at best since Friday, (knock on wood that it's easily and quickly resolved), its been a quiet weekend. Â Our crew meeting Sherlock the newcomer, as hoped was thankfully, uneventful. Â He's been easily accepted into the group, which is great news, and always a relief. Â  Some of you mentioned in my last post, that maybe Sherlock's reasons for not responding to us, may be because of his hearing, or possibly because he doesn't understand English. Â Both are possibilities. Â Golden Retrievers rescued from the streets and shelters of Istanbul, Turkey earlier this summer were flown to a rescue in Atlanta. Â The dogs had to be taught English, and their caretakers a few Turkish words. I think you'll agree that we will just have to get to know him better to hopefully figure it out. Â  What I do know is Sherlock really is a nice boy. Â He follows us all around the house and the yard, and is interested in whatever we're doing. Â He is rough around the edges, and needs (re) training on his house-manners -- It's all no doubt from being a stray and outside for an extended period of time. Â He's also a bit too interested in the cats, so we'll work on curbing his over interest in them. Â But all in all, I think he's going to be okay. I hope you have a good week!

title: Sherlock Arrives at Golden Pines
text: To start, like so many all over the world, I join in offering my prayers for all those wounded, and my deepest condolences to all those families who lost loved ones in the terrorist attacks in Paris. Â Itâ€™s truly heartbreaking.While we will remember what the day brought for France, it also brought us a new arrival. Â FromÂ Maryland's northern most shore, comes Sherlock. Found as a stray standing in the Â middle of a Â country road one night, he was taken to the county shelter where he was given a new name, that he totally doesn't know, and when his "hard time" was up, he was given to Lab Rescue. When we got home last evening, it was easy to see that Sherlock was really happy to be out of the kennel (all dogs coming into Lab Rescue via a shelter are kenneled and boarded first for evaluation). Â I do not think he stopped wagging his tail or barking the entire evening. Â Because he was so excited and happy, I decided against doing one on one meetings, to just let him relax and get used to his new surroundings. Sherlock is estimated to be about 10 years old. Â As you can see in the photo below from the shelter, he is very thin, probably from being a stray.Sherlock, or whatever his name is, is not responding whatsoever to anything I'm saying to him. Â Meetings will be done slowly and one at a time this afternoon. Â Judging by the smile on his face that hasn't disappeared since I met him, I've a feeling it will go just fine. Â Wish us luck, as we welcome this new and enthusiastic boy to Golden Pines.

title: The New Neighbors
text: ~A contented Cissy~ Â I've not mentioned that last year the 10 acres that adjoins our property was sold. Â The same person also purchased 10 acres that adjoins it to the south. Â In August, construction started on a house. I'll reserve my thoughts about how I think it's strange that what I think (??) is the front door of the house facing us to the north, and not west as all the homes on our side of the road do to take in the view of the mountains and face the road. Â We can see the house, and withÂ the electricity now turned on, I can see its lights at night from our back porch. Â I know it's really trivial and petty, but given that they have 20 acres to build a house on, I was bothered that I can see the house, and now its lights at all. Â But it's just that in the 8 years we've lived here, I've gotten used to the darkness and the privacy as well. But then it occurred to me, sound really does travel here in the country. Â And now I wonder if they're going to be bothered that there's not going to be a shortage of dogs barking that they probably will be able to hear. Â *Of all of our dogs, who do you think barks the most?Â The lights being visible and dogs barking aren't going to change, so I'm thinking that if the new neighbors are bothered by it, maybe it makes us even.

title: From Black to White
text: Thanks for your thoughts about the ring in my last post. Â I have checked with everyone that has been a guest at our home and it doesn't belong to any of them and they are as clueless about it as I am. One friend suggested that cosmic forces were to blame, while another taking a more earthy approach thinks that the dogs could have somehow tracked it inside. For now, the story of how the ring came to be on the floor in my hallway remains a mystery. It's been a busy day for us. Â It began with an early morning vet appointment for Dusty to just recheck the tumor on his leg, and refill his medications.The trip was combined with giving our foster cat "Apple" to her new family, who are so excited to add her to their two-cat household.I was home for nearly an hour when a text came from the cat-rescue... Despite my telling them that I wouldn't be able to take another cat, SHE asked if I would please consider it. Â SHE Â did say please... Â So about an hour later, we were welcoming "Flurry" to Golden Pines. Â Flurry and his brother "Blizzard" (very un-original names for two white cats don't you think?) are both about 4 months old, and with several other cats were rescued from a hoarding situation. Both little boys were pretty sick, and now that they're feeling better they need to learn that people are a "good thing." Â The brothers have been separated in hopes of their finding their own self confidence and that they can trust people.So, we've gone from a black kitten to a white one. Â But no matter what color the kitten might be, Charlie is of course pretty happy about it and Todd at the moment doesn't know quite what to think. But I know that's only temporary.

title: A Real Mystery
text: Tuesday evening before I went to bed, my eye caught sight of what I thought was an earring on the floor in our hallway. Â When I picked it up, I realized it was a ring that I'd never seen before. Â I asked Carl if he knew where it came from, and he didn't. Â I figured it probably belonged to my dog-walker and thinking that she may be worried about having lost it, I texted her to let her know I'd found it. Â "Connie" replied that it wasn't her ring. Â With no school here on Tuesday, sometimes her daughter comes with her and so I asked if it was hers or if it could belong to one of her friends? Â It does not. Â I have asked everyone that has been in our house if they have lost a ring, and sent a picture, and everyone is saying the same thing that I've said, "it's not my ring." Â I am totally baffled and have no idea how this ring came to be on the floor in my hallway, or who it could belong to.It's times like this, that I wish the dogs could talk. Â Maybe they know. Â But if they could talk, would they tell me? Â I've a feeling that George wouldn't. He's a dog of few words, especially if it's not dinnertime. Neither would Dusty....Charlie can barely see, so I'm sure he couldn't shed any light on where the ring came from. Â And yes, if you look closely, you'll see that's a leaf on his beard. Apple the kitten is too busy watching television these days to notice.And I'm sure Todd wouldn't know. Â He's too busy with MY shoes out in the yard.I guess where this ring came from is just going to have to remain a mystery. ~The lovely Ms. Yellow in a favorite spot~

title: Back to Our Usual
text: Our company left yesterday and our house is feeling a little emptier today. In place of cooking and going out to eat, we are back to our usual (boring) dinners at home. Â Todd is back to just having having his toys outside to play with.As I said in my last post, it was an enjoyable visit and one that is never complete without going "downtown" to see all the sites in Washington, D.C.Â ~Washington Monument, the reflecting pool is being renovated~I arrived home first this evening, and I noticed Josh and Sheba kept looking down the driveway, like they were looking for someone. I guess they are probably missing our company too. Â During lunch today I took our foster kitten, (remember her?) Appalachia to meet a couple that is interested in adopting her. They are a couple that I have known for quite sometime, and they became taken with "Apple" when I posted her photos on Facebook. The meeting went well, and I cannot think of a better home for her. Â We're just waiting for the rescue to process their application to adopt her. The wife is a vet tech, and the husband manages the shop where I buy dog food every week -- As I said, they're perfect!

title: The Blues Chased Away
text: We rounded the end of the month with a mix of fall weatherand out of town company.The dogs of course love having someone new around and love showing off.Â Because they just know that anyone that visits is here just for them. Okay, they're partly right. Todd never even questions that thought. Â He just knows that the shoe of our guest is a new toy.As was the sock.And the off-limits guest bedroom is for him to enjoy as well. Â Or maybe it just provided a moment to escape and get a moment to himself. Â I'm not sure which. Â Both maybe?At the end of the week, I'm really tired from working and the late nights. Â But, it has been a really good visit. Â We've eaten out, I've cooked and baked, and we've had a great time. Â It's really given me a much needed lift and chased away the blues I've been feeling. Â I hope you've had a good week too!

title: We Are Okay!
text: ~Taken on the scenic route home today~To start, I want to thank you all for your kind words you left on the loss of our boy Buddy. Â It means a lot that you took a moment and left your thoughts here (and on facebook) and have shared his loss with us.Our week ended on a good note. Â The beautiful weather really helped that. ~Dusty, is feeling pretty good these days!~We all enjoyed being outside yesterday,Â ~Todd and Sheba, who do you think is on the wrong side of the fence?~Charlie loved rolling in the grass.Â And George? Â Well, he was just happy.Today the shop where I buy the food for our dogs was celebrating 10 years in business. Â The manager of the store knows a few of us that volunteer for the rescue and he asked if we would come and support their anniversary event. Â Of course we agreed. Â I took Bella with me. Â I was hesitant to bring her because of Â her "diva moments" that she has at home -- I was ready to put her back in my van if she didn't behave. Â  Â Well, Bella totally surprised me by acting very much like a lady and was a perfect advocate for the rescue! She happily greeted people of all ages, their dogs and in return she managed to get a few dollars slipped into her vest for donations. Â  I was really proud of her! These dogs really do have a way of surprising us, don't they?

title: Good-Bye to Our Boy Buddy
text: ~The day we met Buddy, November 9, 2014~Today, I woke up with a heaviness in my heart because it was a day that came much too quickly. Â It was the day to say good-bye (for now) to Buddy. Â Even knowing the reality of the situation, I wasn't fully prepared to accept it. Â This was because I'd hoped that Buddy would get better. Â But it was not meant to be.Â It has been a heart-wrenching week watching Buddy not get any better, as we continued to hold onto that thread of hope that the medications and the fluids we were giving him, would somehow work and that his appetite would maybe return. Â But it never did. Buddy didn't seem to be in any pain, just uncomfortable. Â There were moments when I'd see a glimpse of the dog we knew, and he would bark, wag his tail, and walk in happy-circles. Â Sadly those moments passed too quickly, and the last couple of days, all I saw was a dog that was not feeling well and slipping away. Â I knew that letting him go would be the kind thing to do. As I drove to the vet this morning, I listened to music on my iPod and from Les Miserables, "I Dreamed a Dream," played. Â The line from it that says Â "there are dreams that cannot be, and storms we cannot weather"Â are truly the perfect words for Buddy. Â I had a dream for him that he would find the perfect forever home and have a family all to himself. But it was a dream that was not to be. Â And the cancer, or the storm, was something that sadly he could not weather. Tonight, even though the other dogs are here, it seems quieter. Â I will miss seeing him roll in the yard and always following me into the kitchen, watching me with those hopeful eyes that just knew there was going to be a nibble of something for him and playfully woo-wooing at me and wagging his tail if I was considering not giving him something. In the children's story book, "Dog Heaven" by Cynthia Rylant, Â she writes; "that in Dog Heaven, there are Biscuits and biscuits, as far as the eye can see. Â ...There are kitty-cat biscuits and squirrel biscuits, Ice-cream biscuits and ham-sandwich biscuits." Â Â Buddy was a dog that loved and lived to eat. Not being able to eat anything this past week I know had to be hard for him, I could see that at times he really wanted too. Â More than anything, I hope that as he arrives at the Rainbow Bridge, free from what kept him from enjoying his meals, he's enjoying those biscuits. Â I hope he will not forget us. Â I hope that one day we'll see him again. God speed "my handsome Air-Bud"... as you are met at the Rainbow Bridge by all those who have gone before you, know that Â like them, you will be missed and the story of your year with us will not be forgotten. Â We will always be grateful that we got toÂ knowÂ you Buddy, and had you as part of our lives.

title: A Diagnosis and Advice
text: The results of Buddy's biopsy were returned today. Â He hasÂ gastric carcinoma. The Internist said that this type of cancer is typically very aggressive and metastasizes quickly unless it is caught in the early stages and the mass is completely removed. When asked if there was anything we might be able to do for Buddy at this stage, he said that we certainly could go for a consult with oncology, but he felt that there wouldnâ€™t be much they could do for him at this point. He felt we were at the stage for providing palliative care. Â Tomorrow I'll talk to my vet and see what she recommends.Â A patient in the office where I work was telling me not that long ago about a diagnosis she'd been given nearly two years ago that she wasÂ probably not Â going to live through the year. But her doctor told her to "take his words and throw them out the window because he wasnâ€™t in charge!Â  Â Her doctor said to "live life with joy, laughter and hope instead of under a cloud of fear and doom." Â He also said to her that "We all live in the â€˜Circle of Lifeâ€™. Â Donâ€™t waste the â€˜Lifeâ€™ part!" Â I remembered that advice this afternoon when I was out in the yard with Buddy and the other dogs.Watching Buddy roll in the warm grass and soak up the afternoon sun, it occurred to me that dogs are perfect examples of that advice, aren't they?

title: Buddy's Unconfirmed Diagnosis
text: It has been a long day not just for me, but especially for Buddy. Â First up on our agenda this morning was his ultrasound. Â I will fast-forward and spare you the side-story about the mix-up with the appointment time (their fault), and my insistence that Buddy be seen today or tomorrow and not next week some time. Â What matters, is that the ultrasound was done. Â The Internist felt that what he saw on the ultrasound indicates that it is probably Gastrointestinal lymphoma. Â To confirm that diagnosis, a biopsy was done, and we should have the results in 2-3 days. Yes, I know I've gotten bad news before about our dogs. Â But trust me, it never, ever for a single moment gets easier to hear. Buddy has been through so much in dealing with his allergies, and we finally had them sorted out. Â And today, to add a proverbial insult to injury, I was reminded by someone that exactly one year ago today, Buddy came into the rescue. Â That just added a whole other range of emotions and sadness over the hopes that I had for him. Tonight Buddy is still refusing food, and hasn't eaten hardly anything since Sunday. Â I am hoping that along with a good nights sleep and the two new medications on board to help with nausea, he'll feel better and feel like eating. Paws and fingers crossed that he will, and that the days until we get the results of the biopsy will pass uneventfully and quickly.

title: Happy With Himself!
text: The weather and the weekend could not have been better. Â I think Cissy (below) agreed!Â I went to a "tag sale" at a nearby town with two friends. My friends found a few more things to buy than I did. Â I only bought a bag of clothes pins....But with lunch afterwards at a favorite restaurant and great company, I felt like I did pretty well.Â Back at home, Todd continued his landscaping and excavating in the yard, making-dead, not one, but two moles. Â It was easy to see that he was pretty happy with himself. Â And I've a feeling that Todd thinks he had a better weekend than I did.

title: Destinations
text: Clouds, heavy rain and fog followed me almost the whole way to Kentucky last Friday. I made good time despite the weather and arrived on time at the place I was staying. Â As you know, my family home has been sold. Â And since my brother's apartment is too small, instead of staying at a hotel, I opted to try something different, and used AirbnbÂ at the recommendation of some friends. (Airbnb is a website for people to list, find, and rent lodging in something like 190 countries.) Â In my reading about it, I found there are a lot of pros and cons to the whole thing, but it worked perfectly for me. I really felt like I was staying at the home of friends -- The homeowners, a retired dentist and school teacher, were people I had a lot in common with and I could not have felt more welcome! Â I felt so lucky to have found such a lovely place to stay and hope to stay there again on my next trip to Kentucky. -My room, with a sitting area and kitchenette was more like a small apartment-My visit with my brother was a good and productive one. It included a stop by our family home. Â It's now for sale by the investor who bought it in April. Â He has totally refurbished it, inside and out. It's good to see it looking all brand-new, but it seems a bit lonely, if a house can be that way. Before going home, there is always a visit to the cemetery.Â On my return trip to Virginia the sun followed me the whole way. I've driven the same way for more than 20 years, and I am not sure what possessed me, boredom maybe, to try another route home. Â The other route is about the exact same distance, with less traffic, so what did I have to lose? Â The answer is "plenty!" Â The other way had its moments of great scenery, but was boring, and seemed to go on forever. Â Suffice it to say, lesson learned that sometimes it's better to not take the road less traveled. I was so glad to get home! Â All the dogs had done well while I was gone, thanks to Carl's great care! Â I know he was helped in part, by Todd who kept an eye on everything outside. Buddy is no better or worse, and is scheduled for an ultrasound on Tuesday morning. Dusty is doing well and I'm happy that he's up and around as much as he is, and seems to feel well. It is great to be home!

title: Scottish Weather
text: It's foggy, chilly and raining here today and Todd thinks that it's perfect Scottish weather and he wants to be outside. I've called him several times to come inside, but he's content to stay right where he is. The rain is expected to last for the next several days as we await for the effects of Hurricane Joaquin to work its way up the coast. Â The latest forecast predicts that it will stay out at sea -- Only time will tell if that prediction is right. Buddy is still the same. Â He feels "okay" for the most part, and is eating some, but is still really picky about what he wants. He was at the vet again yesterday. Â Now that we've done x-rays and tried several medications, it's time to go to the next level, and take him for an ultrasound. Â I'm hopeful I'll get the approval from the rescue, and be able to take him next week. Â Until then, he's on an appetite stimulant, and we're feeding him whatever he wants. On a positive note, Dusty is much better. Â His appetite is fully returned, and he's up and around. Â The tumor on his leg isn't feeling warm like it was previously, and the ulceration seems to be healing nicely too. I'm grateful for your good vibes for both Buddy and Dusty. Â I am still worried about them, and I'm hopeful they'll both be okay. On Friday I'm off on a quick dog-less trip to Kentucky. Â I'll be back in a few days and just hope all goes well while I'm away. Â Paws and fingers crossed that it will be. Â See you soon!

title: Another Weekend Ends
text: ~Cissy~Another weekend has come to an end. Â Our friend from Pennsylvania came for a couple of days, and we could not have enjoyed her visit any more. Â At the moment, "Sid" is dog-less, and she said that she needed a "dog-fix" --so where is a better place to come than our house? Â The dogs absolutely adore "Sid," Â Even Charlie put his babysitting duties with the kitten aside for her visit. Â He is crazy about Sid, and even goes as far as sleeping with Sid at night. Todd made me proud by (again) remembering his manners and more than once came to Sid for attention. Â Our friend may have come for a dog-fix, but I had something else in mind for her visit. Â On Saturday we were off to West Virginia to an Apple Festival. Â It was day of apples...Apples of just about every kind -- Some varieties I'd not heard of. Â and many, many more waiting to be picked. Â We chatted with someone from the orchard, and he told us that for every tree that he picks an apple from, he takes a bite from one apple. That's a lot of bites!And if you wanted something besides apples, there were lots of varieties of pumpkins to choose. These "warty pumpkins" were interesting. You could even "smooch da pooch" to help a local rescue. It was a good day spent with a good friend. Â The good energy from the weekend must have rubbed off on Dusty, who is definitely feeling better. His appetite seems stable, and he's up and around more. ~Dusty with Bella in the background~Buddy lost his appetite a few days ago. Â Nothing I could give him, could get him to take as much as a nibble. Â So I cooked ground beef, and added a couple of scrambled eggs and pasta, topped with cheese for good measure. Â It worked, and he's eaten the last two meals. Â But he's turning his nose up at kibble or anything dog-food. Â I'm trying to stay positive that Buddy is at least eating, and I just hope we can figure this out sooner rather than later. ~Buddy, feeling a little better~

title: Charlie the Helper!
text: This has to be the week that technology is against me. Â Something happened to my cell phone. It was able to be resurrected, but I have lost all my new contact information, texts and photos since I'd gotten the phone because they'd not been saved. Â My phone is now set up to not let that happen again.~Cissy~Then my dishwasher stopped working. Â I'd seen it coming because the lights on the control panel seemed to be going off and on at random times even if it wasn't running. Then it just stopped running. Of course the dishwasher was totally full when this happened. Â To some, not having a dishwasher is not a big deal. Â But I can never remember a time when I liked washing dishes. Â Fortunately I had help because... Charlie was more than happy to help with the "pre-wash." Â  Â Once Charlie and I were done in the kitchen, he helped again by keeping an eye on Apple. What would I do without Charlie? Â What would Apple do without Charlie? I'm glad we don't have to find out! Â ~Bella~

title: On the Mend--I think!
text: On Friday morning I said good-bye to our three little kittens who have found new homes. Â It was a good and learning experience, and I've no regrets in volunteering to take them in. Â I was a bit surprised when I was asked if I could take another little one. Â She was found on the Appalachian Trail (a marked hiking trail in the eastern United States extending between Georgia and Maine) by a hiker who was followed by her for more than a mile. Â The hiker turned this little girl who has wounds from head to tail, into the rescue. Â "Appalachia" (Apple for short) is a friendly little kitten, who was previously spayed -- So at some time in her short life, she belonged to someone. Â How "Apple" ended up on a remote part of a hiking trail is anyone's guess. Of course Charlie is overseeing her recovery,and the other dogs are snickering at her having to wear a "cone of shame." ~Apple, feeling better today~While Charlie is taking care of the kitten, I'm taking care of Buddy and Dusty. Â At the vet, Buddy had x-rays that thankfully showed nothing. So, we're trying a few things with his diet (you may be right Tammy!) to see if it'll help. On the flip-side is Dusty. Â He has a large tumor on his back leg, and the plan at the vet originally was to do a biopsy. Â But our vet thinks that its gotten infected. Â So, we've put him on several medications to help with the pain we think he's having and the infection. Â The medication may be making him sleepy, but he seems to feel better today. I hope we are headed in the right directionÂ Â ...and on the mend!

title: Contagious!
text: ~View from our front porch this morning~Back after a week away, and I wish I could say we were away on a fun trip. Â But actually, I've not been feeling well for almost a week. Â I'll admit that I don't make the best sick person. Â I've come home from work, worn out and just fallen into bed but not before I complain, moan and groan. Â The dogs are sympathetic, but even they just got to the point where they ignored me, except when it was dinner time. ~Cissy~Not feeling well must be contagious. Â Buddy (below) has also not been feeling well the past couple of weeks. He's getting sick after eating. Â You name it, I've tried everything from changing his food, to the bowl height, and medication. Â None of it seems to make a difference -- He still gets sick, and there's no rhyme or reason for it and no way to predict that he will or won't. When his regular vet wasn't working, we saw a new vet that is just starting her veterinary career. I have to admit, that I felt that she was no help. Â So, I've made an appointment for our regular vet to see Buddy on Saturday. What was I saying about being contagious? Â Our new comer Dusty isn't feeling well today either. Â I've no idea what it could be. Â He was just fine yesterday, but today he's refusing food, and won't get up. Â Thinking that it could be pain from overdoing it yesterday, I've given him pain pills today in hopes that he'll feel better by tomorrow. He also has a vet appointment on Saturday. ~Dusty~Todd is totally oblivious to everything that's going on inside. Â This morning he didn't come when called for breakfast -- He was much too busy running around the yard barking at the gangs of delinquent deer and rabbits that are trespassing on his turf!

title: Wet Dogs!
text: This morning we woke to much needed rain. Â Outside with the dogs on our first walk, no birds were singing and even the cicadas were quiet. There was only the sound of the rain falling as everything seemed to quietly be soaking it all up. Everything feels a bit fresher, and the trees and grass are looking a little greener this afternoon. Of course the dogs have been wet all day. Â Â As a result, its been a day that I've been reminded more than once that there is nothing more affectionate than a wet dog. There is also nothing found in a bottle or spray that smells like one either.But all dog-owners know that there are things that do come in a bottle that will help get rid of it. Thank-goodness!~Sheba, left and Bella~***As a remembrance of September 11th, here's a tribute to Bretagne who at 16 years old is the last known living search and rescue dog who worked at Ground Zero. To thank her for her service, Bretagne was treated to "a dog's best day" in Â New York City Â Â --Click here for her tribute--

title: Weekend and Friends
text: Labor Day may mark the unofficial end of summer, but we've had a sun-soaked humid weekend that has felt more like the middle of it. If Todd wasn't inside laying on the cool vents, he stayed in the shade outside. I decided to pick the pears off our tree, even though I think it may be a little early for them. But because my nemesis, the dreaded brown-marmorated stink-bug who ruined them all last year is starting to arrive, I decided to pick them with Sheba's help.I've got them in brown bags to ripen in hopes we'll get to enjoy them as much as Sheba and Josh have been the last few weeks. While we were at home, two of the kittens were spending their long weekend at a local store in hopes of finding a new home for them. Left behind was the tiger kitten that is the adopted sister. If a cat can be lonely, this little left-behinder really let it be known with her crying that she was.As you know, Charlie loves the kittens, and tried to be friends with her. Â But as you can see in the video below, she really didn't want to make any new friends. Â  She wanted her old one. This afternoon she got her wish when the two little vacationers were returned, and two friends were reunited.A pretty good weekend for all of us. Â I hope yours was too!Â -Josh-

title: What Really Matters
text: I will start this post by saying that I am totally devoted to my current vet that has seen our dogs for more years than I can remember. Â But for Sunny who is stressed by a car ride and all that a vet visit entails, I decided to try a vet that would come to the house. After several recommendations, we met our new vet. It went really well, and I couldn't be happier with how they handled Sunny, and he immediately liked the mobile vet, which spoke volumes.~Sunny likes the new-vet more than the camera~Since the vet was here, I decided to have George seen as well. Â When George arrived here in April, because of his being overweight, he struggled on the few stairs and to get up. With daily walks, changing his diet, I've had high hopes that George was slimming down -- Because he looked to me like he was. Â He seems happier, and he's up and around much more than he was. ~Josh and George~So, of course I was anxious to put George onto the scale and feel that proud moment as his owner that he's lost weight. Â According to their scales, he's lost two pounds. Â Proud moment gone. Â But George was happy and relaxed during the entire exam, and let "mobile vet" do a pedicure. I guess that's what really matters. Â  Â ~George, still happy afterwards~Â Todd thinks that what really matters is that he didn't have to be seen.

title: The Three H's
text: With the doctor that I work for in the hospital recovering from surgery, I'm only working one day this week. Â It's a good chance to catch up on a few things and do my annual pilgrimage out of my county to "the city" for an appointment. ~Reston, Virginia~With that behind me, at the start of September and the three H's, hazy, hot and humid returning for a summer encore, we're going to be a little lazy and just pace ourselves.~Lexi~I think Todd agrees.... Â As does Dusty, who continues to get along wonderfully with his new pack-mates!

title: Why Was I Worried?
text: -Moon-set on Sunday morning~Back to the airport on Friday afternoon to the "arrivals" and as quick as you can put a suitcase into the trunk of a car, I was no longer a single parent. Back at home, all the dogs were happy to see their missing pack member and tell him all that had gone wrong while he was away. Â George is the worst at keeping a secret.~The face of a dog that can't keep a secret~Of course it was no secret that there is our newest addition, Dusty. He's had a hard time settling in, mostly because I was keeping him away from the other dogs, and it wasn't where he wanted to be. Â But given Dusty's stress level, I just thought that I needed someone else to help with those introductions. Â I was wrong. Â I think they'd all looked at one another so long through the fence that meeting him up close and personal was no longer exciting. Â I simply opened the gate, and with barely a second look, it was business as usual.Why was I worried?

title: Minus Two & Plus One -- Welcome Dusty!
text: This morning my day off started with taking the five kittens to the vet for exams and vaccines. Â I also said good-bye to two of them that will be going to a new foster home. Â It's time. Â They are now about 4 months old, weighing around 4 pounds each, and are active and mischievous as all kittens are.While the kittens leaving has been planned for a couple of weeks, a new arrival wasn't. Â With Carl out of town, I have welcomed to Golden Pines, a new 12 year old boy named Dusty. He comes to us from someone who adopted him from a shelter this past March. Â Dusty was originally given up in February by a elderly couple who were no longer able to care for him after a car accident. *She* was dealing with family losses, and saw Dusty at the shelter and adopted him. When I met her *She* told me that Dusty helped her through those losses, but now *She* was no longer able to care for him, and *She* felt that *She* needed to focus on herself now, saying to me in an e-mail today, "I know I made the right decisionÂ for both of us as yesterday I felt a bit lighter in spirit andÂ was able to get a good workout at the gym. Not worrying about Dusty is such a blessing."Â  This is the part where I don't openly pass judgment on someone....Dusty is what's important, and I think that by nature he is a nervous dog. Â With all the changes he's had in the past several months, it hasn't helped for him to be that way, and it's totally understandable. Â I asked our dog walker to come over to help me with the intros to our gang, that didn't go so well. Â Dusty was really feeling the stress of the day, and so I decided to forgo the meetings which included Todd. Until then, he's got his own space in the house where he can relax and get used to his new life.I'll do the rest of the one-on-one meetings in a day or so when Carl returns. Â I've not told him about Dusty and until then I'll be practicing the look in the photo below for when Carl sees him.I hope your week is off to a good start!

title: All Present and Accounted For
text: The weekend began with a trip to the airport and as much time as it takes to drop someone off, I became a "single parent."~Dulles Airport~So far, it's going pretty well and I'm keeping up with everything. But does it matter that I accidentally left Todd outside during a storm? ~Todd just before a storm~Or that I forgot to feed the lovely Ms. Yellow on Saturday morning?~Ms. Yellow half starved~That we're out of dog treats?And that I didn't remember to prop the bathroom door open, and Sunny got stuck in there while I was gone...What's important is that all the catsAnd the dogs are "all present and accounted for." Â Or are they?~Sheba~Because that may change later this afternoon after lunch with family visiting from out of town.Stay tuned...

title: Convincing Todd
text: The first of two days off this week. Â Inside and away from the heat and humidity we're taking it easy. ~Josh, feeling very, very sleepy~With Todd however, there's no taking it easy. Â He was on full alert and patrol. Â You probably know that the Scottie was bred by farmers to help them manage vermin problems. They are known to follow prey, such as badgers, foxes, and other vermin, right into their burrows and then try to dig them out. That is exactly what Todd has been doing. Â In the last three days, Todd has dug out and "made dead" two moles. This morning with no one around, (i.e., Carl), it fell to me to bribe Todd into giving up his newest prize. Â It was before breakfast and a weak moment and it only took a few treats to convince him. But it was easy to see that he had to think about it first. However, I think that he's also still convinced there has to be more where those two came from. I hope he's wrong!

title: Closer to Home
text: An uneventful weekend for us. Â While Carl did things like mow the lawn, I tried to get photos of the five kittens. Â This is proving nearly impossible to do given that they are almost always in constant motion.So I turned my attention to something that stands still for a little longer, George. You'd never know it, but I've a feeling that he loves his picture being taken. Â  Â  Cissy is feeling photogenic these days. ~Cissy~With her allergies being managed with a limited ingredient kibble, Cissy is definitely happier and feeling much better. Â She doesn't seem to be bothered too much by the torn meniscus in her left knee. She is getting around pretty well, but she does walk with a pretty good limp. Â ~Rolling in the grass always makes a pup feel happier!~I took her to an orthopedic surgeon to see about doing surgery to repair it. Â He said that because of the damaged tissue around her knee from years of untreated thyroid disease it has made a repair impossible to do. Â He did suggest cold laser therapy for Cissy which is what our vet recommended doing twice a week to start. But because of the distance to my vet's office, (an hours drive each way) it's impossible to do with traffic and work. Â So, I've been asking around for someone that can do it that is closer to where we live. Because I'm for anything that will keep me off the road and closer to home.~Sheba and Todd~

title: Nothing and Something
text: The first of two days off this week and I was up early and on the road to the dermatologist with Buddy. ~Buddy, my co-pilot~He had a recheck of a pretty ugly ear infection that's only marginally better. A culture was done and maybe new medications for him when the results are returned next week. The good news continues to be that the Apoquel that Buddy is taking for his allergies is still working really well for him. We both couldn't be happier!Afterwards there was time to stop at one of the local farmers markets. I prefer the no frills markets.I think they let the fruit and vegetables speak for themselves.Back at home for a mid-day walk and lunch.~Sunny, unaware I've taken his photo~Â I did pretty much nothing the rest of the day,Â ~Sheba~Â Todd on the other hand, of course, always finds something!

title: Is Niceness Contagious?
text: ~A quick shot of Sunny escaping the camera~Its been just about six weeks since Bella arrived at Golden Pines. Â From the beginning she let us know with her growling and snarling just how unhappy she was to be living in a group home. Â My "support team" from the rescue and I felt that it wasn't helping that Bella wasn't feeling well. Â When she seemed to be feeling better, and her behavior continued, I had a discussion with the rescue about finding another foster home for her. Â A plea was sent out to other foster homes, and two people came forward. Â When we thought that we had found a perfect match for Bella, the person changed her mind at the very last minute. Â Another plea was sent out that added a few more people to the e-mail. Â Still no takers. But I guess Bella has just decided that maybe we weren't so bad after all, or all the medications and supplements she's taking are working, because I realized that she seemed happier. Â She still has her diva-moments, but they are coming farther apart. Â I'm now seeing a lot more tail wagging and the scowl and hard tense look I've seen on her face so much is being replaced with a softer look and smile. Â ~A much more relaxed Bella~I had to stop and wonder if the "niceness" was contagious and infecting Todd. Â As a Scottie, he's devoted and affectionate to those he likes. However, he can take a while to warm up to strangers and visitors to our house. Â Last week we had company, and I fully prepared our guest with lots of treats, and I was ready for Todd to show his displeasure of the intruders. Â He didn't surprise me by at first keeping his distance from our friend. Â But he did surprise me when she was allowed to pet him shortly after she arrived. Â He was a true gentlemen Scottie during the entire couple of days. Then Â yesterday Buddy was rolling on the grass with Todd's favorite red ball that he never shares. I had to stop and wonder if the gentleness of the Goldens or the "cuteness" of the kittens was getting to him? Â Was Todd at 4+ years old growing up and mellowing? Â Judging by the torn up dog toys,Â along with the barking and chasing and the holes he keeps trying to dig...I'd say no, and I'm glad about that!

title: Forever Homes
text: The reports coming from Lexi's new home have been good ones. Â She is settling in and doing well. Â I got a text message from "Val" on Sunday that said,Â "All is terrrific! Â We had a small family fathering andÂ Lexi was the star! --Â I'd not mentioned to them that I thought that Lexi should be in a place where she was the "star," so when he said that she was, I took that as sign.Val's message continued by his saying,Â "LexiÂ gets long famously with her new brothers, and sleeps in our bedroom on a new orthopedic bed that she claimed right away. Â She is a real love bug and is doing great! Â She is confident and keeps up with the boys on walks and romps in the yard and enjoys a nap afterwards.Â ~Lexi and her new pack-mates~Val concluded his message with: Â It's like she has been here forever!"Â ~Another photo of Lexi in her new home~Speaking of "forever" it seems like forever that the kittens have been with us and its been just a month. Â I didn't mention that a 5th little girl was captured over a week ago. Thought at first by one of my counterparts to be just a random kitten, when I saw her, I knew, she wasn't. Â "Star" as I call her, is a nearly perfect "bookend" to one of the original group. Â The plan is for ALL these mischievous kittens that all weigh around 2 pounds now, and who have taken over the office to be on their way to their forever homes in about a week. Â  Who's going to break the news to Father Charlie?

title: A New Forever Home for Lexi
text: ~Lexi, the start of her first day at Golden Pines~You'll all recall how in May we welcomed a lovely dog named Lexi to Golden Pines. She had her ups and downs as we dealt with bouts of her getting sick because what we decided is from a very sensitive stomach. Â ~At the Vet and ready to leave!~Â Once we got that all worked out with a good balanced diet, I had a discussion with the rescue over what the next step would be for Lexi. It was decided to put her up for adoption. Â Of course I thought a lot about keeping Lexi and struggled with the decision to let her go to another home.-June-But several times I felt that for Lexi, I was her gateway between the shelter and her finding another forever home. Added to my decision was knowing that she is a "star." Â Whenever I had her anywhere by herself, people were drawn to her because of her smile, lovely white face and gentle temperament.Lexi was getting lost at our house because of "stars" like Todd, Charlie and the others.~Charlie and Lexi in May~I had several phone calls from perspective adopters from the rescue. Â As I checked them off my list for various reasons like one couple who were worried about Lexi getting sick on their carpet, I got a call from a couple that I thought might be a fit. Â I took Lexi last Saturday to meet them, and their other two dogs, a 12 year old Golden named Carver and a 14 year old black lab named Marcus. Â It was easy to see that this retired couple in their 70's were crazy about Lexi. Â Lexi and I shared those feelings. So, yesterday I left work early and met them at a park, so we could make it official.-On Our Way Yesterday!-After we signed the adoption contract, Lexi was happy to be put into their truck and all too soon it was time to let go, and say good-bye to her. Â When they closed the door to get ready to leave, I felt that old familiar sadness come over me. Â But Lexi looked at me, and seemed so relaxed and it was easy to see that confident smile on her face. This "star" that I had the chance to have as part of my life for nearly 3 months, was truly shining. Â It's how it should be. ~Lexi, ready to start the next chapter of her new life!~

title: The Church and Father Charlie
text: The county where my Nephew's wedding was held was Isle of Wight County.Â  Someday I would love to visit the original Isle of Wight, but this just might be the closest I'll ever come to it.The church where the wedding was held wasÂ St. Lukeâ€™s, circa 1632. Â It is the oldest existing church of English foundation in America and the country's only surviving original brick Gothic church,Â  For nearly 200 years, St. Luke's was known simply as "Old Brick Church."The brickwork around the church exterior is detailed and elaborate. Â And has walls two feet thick.You enter the church through a wicket door that leads into the nave. Folklore says that small doors set into a larger wood door and requiring those entering to take one high step inside, shut out evil spirits, Â On the practical side, it probably kept the interior drier and warmer.Inside you can't help but notice that the church looks like an upside down boat. Â Someone mentioned to me that this was because most of the colonial leaders had experience with building boats.There are many beautiful stained glass windows, There is one window that is in memory of Pocahontas, who is said to have been christened in the church.There is a triple-level pulpit (right in photo) that was built with a sounding board attached to the ceiling which amplified speakers for court and church. It is simple and beautiful.I wish I would have had more time to walk through the cemetery. Â And to explore more of the grounds. Â But it was so hot, and time was not on our side.Â St. Luke drawing a portrait of the Virgin MaryBut we did have time for a late lunch in the town of Smithfield that is the "Ham Capital of the World." Â How could you not love a town famous for its ham and bacon? Â It's really a lovely town with Victorian homes and specialty shops that really made me wish I could have just forgotten about the reception. But of course I couldn't. Â Maybe next time! All too soon my trip to Virginia Beach was over and it was time to come home. All was well at Golden Pines, and Charlie had done a great job taking care of the kittens while I was gone--You can watch the video below and see for yourself. Â "Father Charlie" really does love "his" kittens!

title: The Tumbleweeds and the Beach
text: More than a week has passed since I've blogged, and the tumbling-tumbleweeds blowing around my blog show the neglect, and dust-bunnies blowing through the house show neglect there as well.The past week was a full one that began with my trip to my nephew's wedding. With a few hours before the wedding, I did manage to squeeze in a sunrise walk on Virginia Beach.Mornings on the beach are much different than during the day when the crowds are there.It's peaceful and serene with only the sound of the birds as they fly past and the sound of the waves crashing on the shore. Â I'll admit that I'm not one to go barefoot, but who doesn't love that feeling of the grainy sand against your feet as you walk across the beach? Sunrise on the beach is a special time and I've a feeling that the lady below agrees with that. I think that when given the chance everyone should experience it at least once.Â All too soon, and before I realized it, the crowds of people began to arrive, and it was time to leave and get ready for the wedding. Â In my next post I'll tell you about the wedding that took place in "Isle of Wight County" at the historic St Luke's Church, which is the oldest church of English origin in America.THANKS for stopping by, I've missed visiting with you! Â ...And you didn't think I'd not post at least one photo of a dog (Josh) ....Or of Todd, did you?

title: Needed:  More Hours in a Day!
text: A very full week has come to an end. Â "Pink nose kitten" also known as Libby (below on the right) was hospitalized overnight this past week for an abscess, dehydration, and an intestinal infection.Under the watchful eyes of Charlie, she's doing much, much better, and we're working through a few health issues with the "All Girls Club" who should all be okay.The tiger kitten, (below) who is the new comer in the crowd is adjusting to her new life and being around people. She's no longer swatting at me, and only hissing at me once or twice a day so that's progress. She's estimated to maybe be a month older than the others, and it's amazing how the others adapted and "tamed" so much more quickly than she has. We've not made any progress with "Feral Mom" even though I tried. One of my counter-parts in this rescue of the "West End Kittens" has found a good barn home for her, and she'll be leaving us this morning. ....And speaking of leaving, I am leaving too. Â After I take Mom-Cat to her new home, I'm off on a small road trip for my nephews wedding. I'm really looking forward to this trip for several reasons. One is that my Nephew doesn't live far from the beach, and I'm trying to make time during my visit to at least see the ocean. Â The other is that I just need a small break to recharge my inner batteries that are really in need of recharging. Â ~Todd's batteries never need recharging~I'm sorry that I've not been able to visit your blogs lately. Â But while I have no regrets in taking in the kittens, and they are fun to have around, they are taking a lot of time added to the care the dogs need too. Â At the end of the day, I have hoped to at least read a few blogs, but I have just collapsed into bed, and hope that the next day will bring a few extra hours, but so far, it hasn't. Â I am missing having the time to take a peek into your lives that I always enjoy. But I have hopes of being able to catch up with you very soon!

title: One Cat Away!
text: A week ago today, a trio of kittens joined us here at Golden Pines. Â A week later, these three little Musketeers have come a long way. Â We're able to hold them, and they're beginning to play. Â However one, that I've thought since the first time I saw it, is not as healthy as the other two and has a puncture wound on the side of its neck that I only noticed on Thursday when I held "her" for the first time. Â  It's easy to notice that she's the smallest and the skinniest of the 3 and the most quiet. Now that I can hold her I've been able to clean the wound really well today. No question, that these little ones need to be taken to the vet, but unfortunately their care was put on the back burner with the arrival of two more cats at Golden Pines. ~Momma Cat~Yes, that's two. Â Late Wednesday evening, I got a call that two more cats had been trapped, one kitten, and an adult . When they arrived it was easy to see that this new kitten didn't belong with the others because of its size. Â However, it does "match" the adult.~Trapped Kitten #4~The two new comers were taken to the vet and both girls were spayed, and returned to Golden Pines on Thursday evening. The "Momma Cat" is quiet and we've left her alone to recover. Â The kitten on the other hand, is all feral, and each meeting (so far) is met with a lot of growling, hissing and swatting at me. Â Tomorrow morning I'm meeting with someone to try and sort out the details for vet care and fostering for the cats.Aside from being as my brother said, "one cat away from being the crazy cat lady"Â Charlie is still crazy about the kittens and is taking his job as their nanny very seriously. He's allowing supervised visits.But I have a feeling that these kittens at some point just may be able to hold their own, even against Todd. I hope you're having a good weekend!

title: It Takes a Village
text: My week may be off to a slow start at work because the Doctor I work for has had to be out of the office. Â But we are busy at home.Because on Saturday we welcomed two new additions... Then a third one...How did we end up with these three little ones? Â Well, I first read about them on a Facebook group page for the town that I live. Â Someone posted about seeing four kittens in the back of the gas station in town, and playing near the road. Â Several people chimed in that they'd seen them as well and agreed that it would be "unfortunate if one got hurt, or worse." Â But no one volunteered to help these little ones. Â Finally someone named "Beth" who regularly helps to trap feral cats for a rescue, said that she would trap the kittens, but someone else would have to take them. Â ...the sound of crickets goes here.... I'll pat myself on the back and say that I waited nearly 8 hours for someone else to speak up and say they'd take the kittens. Â But no one did. Â So, I volunteered, telling myself that I'd figure it out somehow. Â  Â Â Then (thankfully) someone named "Laura"Â said that she would also be willing to help trap the kittens and would arrange with a rescue group to have them vetted. So, on Saturday morning, we set the traps, and by 10:30 that night, Laura and Beth had managed to trap all but one. Unfortunately, the 4th kitten has not been seen since Saturday night. We're not giving up, and the traps are still being set in hopes that this little elusive one will return and can be caught. Â Â Laura is also going to speak to the owner of the gas-station and ask him to make a donation to the rescue to help with their expenses. (I personally think he should, and think we did him a favor in taking them.) Â Â Because the kittens, that are estimated to be about 8 weeks old, are "semi-feral" Beth has put me in contact with someone who will be coming over this weekend to help me with handling and socializing the kittens, which I did for the first time this evening. Â  ~Being held for the first time!~My new friends and I have decided that with each of us taking a part in rescuing these kittens, asking for the donation from the gas station owner, the rescue who will be taking them, and getting someone to help me socialize them, that it truly Â "takes a village to rescue kittens." Â However, Charlie who absolutely loves them...and is a bit obsessed with the kittens, Â Â doesn't think I need any help because he's here!

title: Four Days
text: I have been off work since Thursday and we pretty much had no plans for the long weekend, other than our usual catch up on things around the house. Â It was also time that had been set aside to catch up on the dogs summer haircuts.Todd was first up on the list, and sat still long enough with the bow on for me to get his photo not once...but twice...Josh and Sunny were taken to the groomers as well.Â ~Sunny pre-grooming~Sunny's experience at the groomer could be a post all its own. Â I took both Josh and Sunny to a new groomer, because I wanted to stay on "good terms" with the one who regularly sees Charlie and Todd. Â So I'll Â just say that I don't think Sunny will be going back to the "new place" again. Â Long time readers of this blog know that Sunny can be "difficult" in two kinds of situations. Â One is when he doesn't want to do something, and the other is when he's nervous. His being groomed fit that perfectly. It's too bad that Sunny doesn't like to have his picture taken, because he looks great.Â (I will add that yes, I can and do groom the goldens, but even I have problems doing anything more than brushing and trimming Sunny).~Best photo of Sunny afterwards~However, Sunny bypassing me and going straight to the door afterwards, the looks on the faces of the two groomers and especially their short and restrained comments about how "Sunny didn't like his nails trimmed, feet touched, tail messed with, that he hated the dryer and that he could live life happily for the rest of his life without another bath," said perfectly how it had gone. Â There were no comments at all on how Josh did. Â That had to be good news, right?Back at home, the success of the week has come with our newest addition, Bella. We felt that part of the problems with Bella and our dogs was coming from her just not feeling well. Throughout the week, it was easy to see that she was feeling better and becoming more relaxed. Â So with that, we very slowly began closing the space between her and our dogs. Â It took a lot of praise, a lot of treats that yesterday resulted in this...Bella is the one in the middle of the photo below. Yes, Bella is still a little growly around our dogs, in particular when she's sleeping and eating. Â But I think and really hope she's going to be okay here at Golden Pines. Â  ~Bella on Friday~I hope you have an enjoyable, memorable and safe July 4th celebration! Â ~Main Street in "My Town"

title: A Full Plate
text: ~My hydrangeas are in bloom~~Its been Â a very busy and very full weekend that began with Cissy and Josh both running after a deer on our morning walk. Usually this isn't a problem, but it became one when Cissy came back limping, and holding up her left leg. Â Oh no...Â  Fortunately Cissy just happened to have a vet appointment where unfortunately the vet confirmed that her knee has a torn cruciate. Â I'm not sure what the next step will be. Â I'm hoping that with rest, restricted activity and medications, we can *maybe* avoid doing surgery to repair it. At the moment, Cissy is not able to walk real well, so we've put Gus's harness on her to help her get up and around. ~A carefree moment for Cissy last weekend~Â Then of course there's our new addition, Bella. Â She has come to the rescue via an owner who had recently moved to this part of the country. They said "they had no room for Bella in their new home, and couldn't give her the care she needs, or afford to take her to the vet."Then Bella became sick. It is times like this when I try very hard to not judge people, but am just grateful they contacted the rescue and they were/are there for her when she needed someone.Â  As you can see (below) Bella is on quite a cocktail of medications.However, on her third day, it's easy to see that Bella is feeling a lot better physically...And emotionally too. Â She still isn't thrilled with her new pack mates, but it is getting better.Bella & Charlie, with a new summer hairÂ So, I'm hopeful and trying to remain optimistic--for both Bella and Cissy. Â  Â Â ~Todd on Saturday, watching Bella~

title: Four Years and TWO Plus Ones
text: ~Todd, June 25, 2011~I've been going through all the files of photos that have been transferred onto my new computer, and deleting the ones I don't want to keep. Its been a fun trip down memory lane that has reminded me that it was four years ago, plus one day, that Todd arrived at Golden Pines. It goes without saying that he was the perfect addition to our home and we cannot imagine our lives without him! ~Todd getting acquainted with Sam~In keeping with the plus one theme, today we welcomed a new addition named Bella. Â She's about 8 years old, and comes to us with multiple health issues. She has spent the past several days hospitalized and so it's easy to see that she's tired and not feeling all that well.~Bella during the ride to Golden Pines~With people, Bella is a perfect lady and is eager for attention. Â But with the dogs, even though the dogs ignore her, she's reactive when they are around. Â So, for today we decided to forgo the one on one meetings to give her time to rest and settle in. Â It has been a long, tiring day for all of us and I'm trying to be hopeful that tomorrow will be a better day for Bella.

title: Berries and Buddy
text: Under the hot sun and humidity I continued with the berry picking, while the Berry Patrol continued their berry eating. Â Yesterday we added Todd to the group. Â He isn't as crazy about the berries or as good at pulling them off the canes as the other dogs, but he keeps up.This morning it was Sheba (below). Â We are pretty much at the end of the season for them now. There are a few here and there, but we'll let the birds, bugs and spiders have what's left. Â ~Sheba--Berry picking is hard work!~This is probably a good thing since homemade cobblers like the one I made this morning are a favorite this time of year. Â My favorite recipe is one that I like because it's simple, quick, and pretty good. (Recipe here) And speaking of eating, Buddy is a dog that lives to eat! Â This makes getting him to take his allergy pills, a snap. Â This also means that Buddy will eat anything that even remotely looks edible. Â I'd noticed a few days ago some white around his mouth that looked like he'd gotten into something. Â I wiped his face and it didn't come off. Â A couple more times I'd try to scrub it off with no luck. Finally I took him outside to get a good look at whatever it was that couldn't be washed off. It was then that I saw what it was... Â Because of his allergies, Buddy hasn't had any hair around his mouth because he was constantly rubbing his nose and face, and now, it's finally growing back! Â (Sorry about all that hard scrubbing Buddy!) But it does show that the itchiness, especially on his face, has gone away and the allergy pills really are working!~Fuzzy hair growing back on Buddy's face!~I hope its been good weekend for you too!

title: The Berry Patrol
text: Growing around our property, we have wild-black-raspberries, and "The Berry Patrol" let me know that they were finally ripe. Â We have one good-sized patch near the woods with more canes scattered here and there around the barn and along the edge of our driveway.~The Berry Patrol, Sheba, Charlie and Josh~None of these areas produce large amounts of berries, as they are not managed by us at all; they are overgrown and compete with weeds, opportunistic vines and other brambly-type bushes. Â But there are plenty for us and even enough to share. Â If there's a down side to the berries it's that they're not the easiest to pick because there are sharp thorns and some of the bushes are buried so deeply in a thicket of brambles that it makes getting to them pretty tricky. Unfortunately. ~Sheba finding her way into the berry patch~But stillâ€¦ wild black raspberries. I need to hurry up and pick them before they're gone so I can make my traditional cobbler, muffins or just enjoy them by themselves. All of us are enjoying the warmth of the sun, and these summer days, especially Charlie (below) who is scheduled for his summer haircut in a few days.

title: Watch Out for the Quiet Ones!
text: Georgie fooled me. Â He fooled all of us. Â Underneath his quiet, relaxed, unruffled exterior lies the heart of a renegade. Â On our morning walk, I accidentally dropped his leash. Â Georgie immediately saw his opportunity to make a getaway, and he took it. Â Off he went, just like an escapee, straight into the woods, leash skipping along behind him.
