We are once again fighting the fall invasion of my nemesis, the dreaded and much despised 'Brown Marmorated Stink Bug. Just as in previous years, they are everywhere.I'm not exaggerating when I say that they are crawling all over our house. When you do venture outside you are dive-bombed by this fearless insect that just dares you to tangle with it.Despite all of this, there is one dog that doesn't seem to mind being outside with these most unpleasant of invaders. Â Can you guess which one? Â If you said Todd, you're right. He's always on guard, watching for birds to fly over so he can chase them, or bark at whatever else may come into view. Â He is a Scottie after all...As for the Goldens and Charlie, on any day they like to be inside because that's where the treats are and the comfy dog-beds. Â ~Charlie~They are (almost) Goldens after all...~Sheba~I hope you've had a good weekend!~Annie~

title: Second Impressions
text: Fall like temperatures have arrived at our house. Â But staying is the lack of a reliable internet signal. Â We were sent new equipment and have found out that wasn't the issue. Â Carl and Verizon are at a total loss. Â I have a feeling it's something really simple that hasn't been thought of. Â But at least it's kind of working so I can get an internet-fix and read blogs when the signal allows. Our excitement today was the return of our new neighbors and an impromptu meeting with the power company. Â While the dogs barked non-stop, I stood there agreeing to whatever was needed. At least today I looked a bit more put together. Â But I wondered afterwards if they had noticed that my shoes didn't match. I did have an explanation for it, and was going to point it out to them, but I just thought it best to not say anything. Â I wonder what kind of second impression I made?Although I really want to leave them with a good impression, I've decided that it doesn't really matter too much what they think--Because after all, I'm not Â running for public office, just for the position of 'good neighbor!' Â (Toby and 'friend' --can you spot the friend?)I hope you've had a good week!

title: The Doubters
text: As I mentioned yesterday, we've been having problems with our internet connection. Â Carl called yesterday and Verizon said they would come on Sunday to repair it. Â Many of you were like me and had doubts that someone would actually come today. Â So this morning we got comfy on the porch and we waited ...And we waited a little more...Then Verizon Man showed up, and before noon! Â Unbelievable, I know! Â But even though Verizon man came, he wasn't able to find the problem. Â Our internet connection is stillÂ intermittent, but we are staying connected a little bit longer than we were before--I guess that's something....Isn't it? Â  ~Josh~

title: First Impressions
text: It was a beautiful Saturday, although the breeze was a little chilly, the bright sun was very warming. Mid-morning was the perfect time to get the dogs out to run off some energy and explore. Â I had my camera with me and we were enjoying our time outdoors.~CarrieAnne~As you know, things can change and with no warning, that's what happened. Â A deer ran out of the woods behind us and I heard voices at the same time. Â Of course all the dogs ran in that direction as a couple walking down the newly graveled driveway came into view. Â I quickly found out that it was the owners of the property in back of us. Â Work began a few weeks ago, and with the completion of a new driveway, the foundation work of the house has begun.~The new neighbors driveway~They were nicely dressed and introduced themselves. Â Of course IÂ immediately became nervous--Not only to meet them, but I wondered what kind of first impression I was making--My hair was a mess and windblown, I was wearing an old over-sized denim shirt and pants, with garden shoes. Todd and Charlie were barking hysterically in the yard and the dogs were running around them having totally forgotten their names and acting like they had never heard my voice before or ever been told what to do. ~Josh~In the midst of my trying to get control of the dogs and appear calm and collected, they began talking about easements and power lines--Asking me if it would it be possible to have permission to dig on our property so their power-lines could be underground? Â While they were going on about the utilities, my mind was spinning and I was even secretly saying a prayer of thanks that they hadn't been jumped on by one of the dogs--And with that, I found myself agreeing to their request.~Toby~First impressions were that our new neighbors seemed nice enough. Â I have to admit that it's a relief to finally put a face on the worry that I've had since the property was first put up for sale nearly 2 years ago. Â The wife is retired and they mentioned that this home has been in the planning stage for almost 10 years and should be completed sometime in the spring. Â They have NO plans to cut down any trees (whew!!!) and they told me they are 'avid gardeners and animal lovers who enjoy the outdoors, nature, peace and quiet and privacy.' Â No question they'll be able to have everything on their list, but the quiet? Â I don't know, we Todd after all! I hope you're enjoying your weekend! Â  We have been havingÂ internet issues and we're only getting anÂ intermittentÂ signal the past couple of days--We have a connection for a few minutes, and it goes out for a few minutes. Â It makes blog-hopping a little difficult. Â Verizon said they would come tomorrow to repair it--On a Sunday??!!--Should I believe them?

title: Nerves of Steel
text: With Carl home it marks the end of being out of town, and having company for awhile. Â You know how I thrive on routine, and I'm hoping by the end of the weekend, we'll be back to one. Today started out early, even for a day off. Â Our cat, CC, got sap from one of our pine trees all over her yesterday. Â I tried to get out as much of it as I could, and thought maybe she could do the rest, but when I watched her try to clean herself, I realized that she wasn't going to be able to reach all of it. Â It didn't help that Todd and Lucas found her new aroma even more alluring! I decided we probably should give her a bath. Â I have to admit to having never bathed a cat before--But I have heard the harrowing tales of those who survived giving their cats one, and so I made sure that Carl and I were well prepared and ready. Â With latex gloves, and long sleeve shirts to minimize the scratches or bites we were sure to receive from CC, we were ready. Â The plan was to wet CC with my hands and apply Dawn dish soap. Â The hard part would be putting her under the bathtub facet to rinse her off. Â We started and CC was so calm and seemed to like my running my fingers through her coat. Â When it looked like the sap was all broken down, it was time for the rinse. Â I turned on the water, gave Carl his final instructions and we were ready. Â Since this whole thing was my idea, and knowing that the wrath of a wet and unhappy cat was going to be upon us, I decided that Carl should have the job of holding CC--He naivelyÂ willingly agreed. Â So, I poured the water on her, and CC had no objection. Â We finished rinsing her off under the faucet and she continued to not struggle at all. Â We dried her off, set her down and she immediately went to the kitchen and demanded her breakfast.I have to admit to being more than a littleÂ surprised by what had just happened. But in thinking about it, I realized that I should have known that CC having lived in a multi-dog household for 11 years has given her nerves of steel, and she canÂ coollyÂ and calmly handle anything, even a bath! Â  Nevertheless, it all just seems so un-cat-like, don't you think?

title: Words for Wednesday
text: 'Todd is really just a little person covered in fur, thoughtful, intuitive and kind.Â Â ...He looks into the distance and ponders life.Â Â To him, the world is a place of endless joy.' Â My version of a quote I read that I thought fit Todd and the photo. Â  Â  Â I hope you've enjoyed your day!

title: Secrets
text: Carl is FINALLY going to be home tonight! Â The evidence of my guilty pleasures that I indulged in like frozen pizza and Moose-Track ice cream with chocolate sauce have all been thrown away. Â The chocolate cake is history too with the exception of one big piece in the freezer for him. Â The laundry is done and put away, and the dishwasher emptied. Â Dog toys left outside have all been brought inside and the yard is all cleaned up, including the hair from a little impromptu grooming session that Sandy had last evening.Carl will never know about those little things that happened that would not have if he were here. Â They will remain secrets kept between me and the Goldens and Charlie--However I have a feeling Todd cannot keep a secret and is going to tell him everything! Â  ~Todd with a 'hairy' secret~Enjoy Â your Tuesday! Â ~Toby, whatta ham!~

title: Found!!
text: Ahead of the afternoon storms I got an early start to help a friend and run errands. Â Sitting on the side of the road I saw this discarded piece of someone's history. Â Before I really thought about it, I was putting the old rocking chair into my van. Â Despite not having a seat or rockers, it's solidly made and still really sturdy. Â There's a part of me that thinks I shouldn't have picked it up, but another part of me is thinking of things that I could do with it--What are your thoughts? Once back home, the dogs played while I took a few pictures. Josh found his old frisbee that has been missing for some time. Â It's times like that, I wish he could talk so I could ask him where he found it.I found this yellow garden spider. Â Did you know, the zig-zag reflects UV light and is meant to warn birds and deer (and us) that the web is there, so it's not crashed into? Â I appreciate those warnings! Sheba and Todd found great fun in a good game of ball.Afterwards, when the rain rolled in everyone found a good place for a nap!~Sheba~I hope you've found yourself enjoying your Saturday!!~Annie~

title: They Don't Seem to Mind
text: What a crazy week! Â When Carl gets back next week he's getting a raise! Â Who knew that it took two people to take care of this crazy crew? Â Okay, I knew that already, but its been confirmed more than once over the past few days!Â I don't know which dog to feel most sorry for in Carl's absence. Â Maybe Sandy? Â He is given 3 different types of eye drops, 3 times daily. Â He's so unlike our previous boy Tanner who also had glaucoma, and he's not that easy to give them to because he won't open his eyes. Â Carl has somehow figured out the trick to easily do it, but me, I think Sandy is ending up with more on his face than in his eyes...But he doesn't seem to mind... Â Maybe I should feel sorry for Sheba? Â She had burs all tangled between her front leg and chest. Â I noticed them on Wednesday evening. Â But I forgot about them and remembered this morning to cut them out. Â She didn't seem to mind ...Lucas also makes the list of dogs to feel sorry for. Â This morning he was having a little problem breathing--He was coughing and sneezing and kept swallowing and inhaling through his mouth. Â I stayed with him for a while, hoping it would pass. Â It didn't, but he seemed comfortable enough so I left him alone for just a few minutes, while I took care of something else. Â When I came back, Lucas had a long blade of grass sticking out his nose.Â Â Of course I removed it, cleaned up his slightly bloodied nose. Â He didn't seem to mind...Another one who may deserve some sympathy is CC. Â She somehow got left outside last night. But just like the dogs, she didn't seem to mind ... Â Trying to get everything done does take a lot of time. Â We try to stick to a schedule and together Carl and I get the dogs fed around 8 o'clock in the evening. Even though they always get a snack when either Carl or I get home, it's still more 12 hours since their previous meal. Â Last night they didn't get their snack or dinner until about 9 o'clock--They didn't seem to mind ...Â Today I'm grateful for the easy going nature of our crew. Â And even though things may be out of sync this week, they don't seem to mind...

title: Just Me the Dogs and Cake
text: Carl left this morning on his trip to Kentucky and Wisconsin to see family, and our company that was here for 4 days has also gone. Â I've always enjoyed people coming to visit and staying at our home--But the only requirement is an obvious one, is that they MUST be dog-lovers! Â  Aside from that one rule that is truly etched in stone, I try to look at the positive that my house is just a little bit cleaner than usual. Â And before company arrives it's a good feeling because I've even gotten to a few things I've been meaning to do. Â With a house guest it also gets me out of my routine and I get to do a few things I wouldn't normally make time for.I also have to admit that I don't even mind the extra cooking that goes along with it. Â For this visit with our friend, I made 'my special' chocolate cake. Â HoweverÂ Carl was supposed to take the leftover cake to Kentucky Â for he and my brothers to enjoy and he forgot it. Â So, as the dogs who are worn out from all the activity are enjoying the peace and quiet, all I'm hearing is the cake calling to me from the kitchen. Â What is a girl to do?

title: CarrieAnne -- It had to be Okay!
text: Many, many thanks to everyone who thought of CarrieAnne yesterday when she had surgery and sent good thoughts for her. Â I can honestly say that I felt assurance all day that everything would 'be okay.' But I have to admit that when 4 o'clock rolled around and I'd not heard from my vet, I started to get really nervous. Thankfully about an hour later I got the call I had been waiting on letting me know that Carrie was doing Â just fine; and although it was a very long surgery (more than 3 hours) she had no problems whatsoever with theÂ anesthetic--This was because of the detailed notes made by my previous vet, theÂ anesthesiaÂ was given differently which made all the difference. Â Two hours later, I was picking up a very woozy CarrieAnne. She had a good nights sleep and after a slow start this morning by this afternoon CarrieAnne was enjoying time outside with all of us. Â This evening she ate her entire meal. IÂ do have to think that she's doing well in part due to the gift given to her by the Tooth-Fairy which was pain medications--What a nice gift! One thing I've never mentioned before is that CarrieAnne had a sister named Lucy that she was very, very bonded to and who was very protective of Carrie. Â Lucy waits for CarrieAnne at the Rainbow bridge, and it's days like yesterday, that I have to think that Lucy is still there watching over her sister, making sure she's okay--With that and all of your good thoughts and prayers, there really was no way that CarrieAnne's surgery could not have turned out 'okay.'

title: Home Alone
text: I'm home from work today. Â I have to be honest, work and life's stressors have become a little overwhelming--And there is still plenty of week ahead with company coming this evening, again on Thursday and Carrie's surgery on Wednesday. Â So rather than toughing it out at work and because I was feeling a bit snippy with everyone and not very much apathy, or empathy, I'm not sure which for patients, I decided what I needed was a day off....at home....alone...with the dogs of course. To start our day, since I was already feeling guilty for not being at work, I decided that I would just add to those feelings and have a guilt-filled breakfast. Â So Josh, Charlie, Sheba and I got into my van...And crossed the Potomac River into Maryland...Â And went to the only place that you can buy guilt on a dollar menu...Guilt or not, it's good to be home today!I'm feeling a bit more like myself already. Â I hope you're enjoying your Tuesday!~Annie~

title: Not the Best
text: A busy and hectic weekend for us to get ready for company coming at the end of the week, and Carl getting ready to go out of town. Â Yesterday we cleaned every area rug in the house and put them onto the porch railing to air out and finish drying. Â While we were gone to church this morning heavy storms drenched every one of them. Â We've used a wet-dry vac and hope they'll dry and not be ruined.On Wednesday CarrieAnne is having surgery to remove a cracked and broken canine. It goes without saying that I'm worried about her having this done--Worried because five years ago she had surgery to remove a growth and my vet at the time told me CarrieAnne had a very difficult time waking up from the anesthesia. Â Of course remembering that makes me uneasy, but I don't know that there's a choice given the condition of the tooth. Sandy's weekend hasn't been the best. Â Friday and Saturday he was restless and panted and paced throughout the night. Â When he would lay down, he'd start a high-pitched barking that was almost non-stop. Â Today he seems comfortable and has slept almost the entire day and we had to wake him for his evening meal. Â Sandy is storm-phobic and I'm wondering if Sandy's restlessness could have been brought on by the change in weather the last couple of days? My own weekend hasn't been the best. Â Yesterday I took a break to take pictures of butterflies that were on a thistle on the edge of our yard. Â I guess my presence wasn't welcomed because something stung me making my hand swell up like a balloon. Â But I did get some good pictures ...Speaking of butterflies, today after the storm there was a beautiful swallow tail that had gotten drenched and was in the grass of our yard. Â I gently picked it up and showed Todd thinking that he would be curious about the insect that was crawling on my hand...Instead of being curious, he ate it--I guess sometimes you have to eat something to get an appreciation for its beauty...I hope you had a good weekend!!

title: A Gain for Lucas and a Loss for Sandy
text: I've been plagued with time consuming and very frustrating (!!!) problems with my blog all week. But I'm hopeful that the blogger-guru-gods have solved them for me--All paws and fingers are crossed, that they have. Along with trying to solve the issues with my blog's reading list, the week started off inÂ high gear with Sandy and Lucas at the vet for rechecks from appointments a month ago. Lucas loved going to the vet! Â This was only because the free entertainment in the waiting room was a cat that wasn't CC, and he got to bark at it. Â Can someone tell me why you would ignore the signs posted throughout the office to have your cat crated while waiting, not sit in the 'cat waiting area' and then get upset when a strange dog starts barking and scaring your cat? Â I'm afraid I just don't understand...But Lucas got a good report in that he's gained about 5 pounds and I'm hopeful that when the test results come back in a few days, that infection will be cleared up.On the flip-side there was Sandy. Â At his last appointment he was diagnosed with glaucoma so we rechecked his eye pressure. Â Good news for him in that the medications seem to be working, making us hopeful that no other treatment will be needed for his eyes. Â Sandy also started thyroid medication when he was diagnosed with being hypothyroid--At his last appointment he weighed in at a portly 120 pounds. Â This appointment Sandy weighed in at a trimmer 99.9 pounds! Â Of course we're concerned we may have over corrected the problem with his thyroid, but we'll see. Â To me, no matter what his size, I think he's always going to remind me of a bear. Â Not only does Sandy make noises like one, but when he rubs along our fence, (photos below) I think he looks a bit like one too, don't you think? Sandy is totally confident finding his way around our house and yard and I find myself forgetting that he can't see. Â Today marks his being with us for exactly two months. Â When we first met Sandy, he wouldn't take any treats from my hand, no matter how good it may have smelled to him. Â Now he takes everything and anything, and I find myself humbled by his trust. I'm so, so glad that my blog issues are resolved, and I'm looking forward to enjoying my day off catching up with your news and things around the house. Â Enjoy your Thursday!!

title: No Fleas Please!!
text: Yesterday was a very, very long day that started at 8 o'clock in the morning with the arrival of the workmen to replace our entire heating and air system. Even knowing that Todd would have wanted to be here barking and barking (and barking) at the workmen, I made appointments for he and Charlie to be groomed. Â Charlie and Todd went from this ...To this ...However, a little bit of 'panic' set in at the groomers when looking at Todd's coat, a flea was spotted! Â I got a warning from the groomer about how hard they can be to get rid of, which in turn put me into high gear and cleaning mode! Â I took all the dog beds, all the blankets and rugs and anything else that could be washed to the laundry mat. Â While I was gone, Carl vacuumed everything and anything in the house, and emptied everything into the outside trash. Â We treated the area rugs with '20 Mule Team Borax' (it kills fleas and their eggs on contact) vacuumed again, and then because I'm obsessive compulsive and because I just knew Carl may have missed a spot or two, I vacuumed every nook and cranny again. Â Then we gave all the dogs a bath (with Dawn dish-washing liquid that also kills fleas on contact) and we have all crossed our fingers and paws that what was on Todd was just an anomaly; which is what the groomer said afterwards because she never saw another one on him or Charlie--And I never saw any on the other dogs, and believe me, I really looked!LucasSo you can see why I was just a little worn out. Â I think everyone else was too. Â But for the first time in a long while, our house is comfortably cool and even though last night we could have slept with the windows open, they are going to remain closed tightly and locked--I don't want a flea to get in! Sheba & Toby

title: Josh and the Pear
text: ~Josh~With it just barely light this morning I got the dogs out for the first walk of the day. Â The last few weeks Josh and Sheba have been making their first stop of the day the pear tree where they pick and eat the unripe pears. I've just decided to just let them eat them because the stink-bugs will get them if they don't.~Josh and Sheba raiding the pear tree~This morning Josh took off in the direction of the pear tree and I immediately heard his signature howling and barking and I knew he'd seen something. Â I started after him and walked right through a spider web. As I furiously swatted at the sticky threads that were all over my face, I knocked my glasses off in the process. In the darkness and tall grass I couldn't see them and decided to leave them to retrieve Josh. Â His barking had stopped and with Charlie on lead, and theÂ entourage of the others following me,Â I knew going after him may mean I'd lose track of them in the chase. Â So I tried calling to him. Â I waited, and heard and saw nothing. Â I called Josh again and waited...nothing. Â I called again and waited....Still nothing.I got the other dogs back inside and grabbed a flashlight. Â Fortunately I found my glasses, (in one piece) but there was no sign of Josh. Â It was getting light and I looked for Josh in the direction I thought he'd gone and didn't see him. I decided to go back to the house and wake Carl up so he could help me look for him--And there was Josh waiting for me in the garage. Â When he saw me he stood up and started wagging his tail. Â His eyes were all sparkly and there was something so innocent about him as he was smiling and munching on his morning pear.Josh, Josh, Josh.....

title: On The Mend
text: I was on the road early this morning to get Todd to the vet for his yearly exam, blood work and rabies vaccine. Â Todd weighs in at 26.4 pounds (12 kilograms) and got a clean bill of health and lots of treats! Â He was really good at the vet and celebrated when he got home by harassing the cat. Thank-you for the healing thoughts for Annie and I. Â I am just fine and Annie's toe is looking better and is not nearly as sore or as swollen as it was.There's no doubt that she's feeling much, much better and it shows. Â It's a quiet weekend for us. Â The weather is just gorgeous and we've not done much other than spend some time on the front porch relaxing and watching Carl do yard work. I should probably help him, because we are really behind on mowing and trimming, but he's doing a great job! ~Sheba~

title: A Terrible Week Explained
text: It hasn't been the best week for me or the dogs. Â It all took a turn on Tuesday evening when I got home and Annie, who up to this point could do no wrong and even if she did, it would be 'okay,'Â uncharacteristicallyÂ started a fight. Â I'm not sure exactly how it started. Â I only know I'd just gotten home and the dogs were all around greeting me, I saw Annie turn on Sheba and it became a free-for-all. Â I was able to break up the fight, but not before one of my hands was bitten several times, causing it to become sore and swollen. (Making it difficult to type) I checked Annie very carefully to make sure she'd not been hurt in the fight because she instantly become a real grouch. Â I found myself scolding her that evening when she snapped at Todd and the other dogs more than once. Â Her soft and gentle eyes even looked different. Â Needless to say, I was very concerned about this sudden change.On Wednesday morning Annie wasn't putting weight on her back leg. Â By the evening it was even more than apparent Annie wasn't feeling well when she refused her second meal of the day. Â I gave Annie a really good once over paying particular attention to her back leg and I looked closely at her foot. Â It was then that I realized that one of her toes was really red, swollen and sore--It all made sense now! Â I think that this is why Todd has been so obsessed with her feet, this foot in particular, and why there was such a sudden change in her disposition--On Tuesday her foot was probably feeling tender and it must have gotten stepped on, starting the fight. Â Annie's continuing to snap at the other dogs, I think explains why her behavior continued. At the vet this morning we took an x-ray and her toe isn't broken and there is no visible tumor. Â We're hoping that the infection has not spread into the bone and a medicated foot soak along with antibiotics and pain medication will do the trick and bring back the lovely Annie that we are all quite fond of!!

title: I Had To Do It
text: 'Blog etiquette' says that you shouldn't post political views on your blog, and I will just say now, that this isn't what this post is about. Â It's only about having the opportunity to see the President of the United States this week, and I just felt that I couldn't pass it up. President Obama's new campaign office opened up right across from where I work, and they were giving away tickets to an event he was speaking at in the county where I live on Thursday, which is my day off. Â  Even though I live relatively close to Washington DC, my chances of Â ever seeing the President are not that great, so I attended. Â I have to admit it took a lot time--I waited in line after work on Tuesday to get my ticket. Â Then I waited in the searing heat to get into the event that had crushing crowds. Then I got home late on a night where I have to get up early the next morning--I don't know that I would do it again, but this time, I'm glad I did.

title: Murphy's Canine Law
text: Murphy's Canine Law dictates that the dog with the most sensitive digestion will also be the dog with the least discriminating palate. I am finding that Todd is a living example of this law. Â He'll eat anything that is not dog food and I have learned to just expect to see an unpleasant revisit of it somewhere later at the worst possible time and place.~The Lovely & Fair Annie~Along with chasing the birds that fly overhead Todd's favorite hobby is wandering around the house or yard with his nose to the ground looking for something to eat. Â Note that I didn't say he's looking for something 'edible.' Â Many of the things that Todd eats are not things that should be eaten. Case in point is that lately Todd has gotten a bit of a toenail-chewing-eating-obsession and it's NOT with his toenails, but Annie's.As you may or may not know, all of the dog's love Annie. Â Lucas admires her from a safe distance because Sheba defends and protects her. Â Sandy can't see her, but that doesn't matter, if she's nearby he knows it and will follow her anywhere. Â Even Charlie seems happier when Annie is around. Â I guess given all that attraction to Annie it may just make sense that Todd would find something else to 'admire' about her. ~The Blonde Sisterhood, Sheba (left) and Annie~Â I've no idea what to do because I can't seem to stop Todd from chewing and eating them, and so I guess all I can do is be thankful that she only has 18.Enjoy your Thursday! Â Its another busy day for me and at at the end of it, if I can take the heat and the wait, I'll be hearing President Obama speak at an event in Leesburg.

title: And We're Back!!
text: I'm not even sure where to start....It has been a hectic and busy week with my brother visiting. Â He left this morning to go back to Kentucky. Â While he was here he saw the space shuttle Discovery at the Smithsonian....Carl took time off work and they saw the sites of Washington D.C.Then another day while I was at work they went to see a couple of movies. Â We met for lunch at my brother's favorite place to eat while visiting us--Red Robin Gourmet Burgers. Â Carl returned to work, and I took time off and my brother and I spent a day in Baltimore...We enjoyed the inner harbor....and we visited the National Aquarium. Toby is smiling too--Not because 'Jeff' is gone, but because we had a good visit with him.I have to admit that we're all a little worn out...I'm looking forward to relaxing, watching the Olympics and catching up on your blogs! Â I hope you're enjoying your weekend!!

title: On the Porch With Annie and Lucas
text: What was I saying about 'rhythm' in my last post? Â I really thought I was going to find that on Saturday, because I had so much to do to get ready for my youngest brother who was due to arrive later in the day. Â But some things are out of your control because our power went out, yet AGAIN! Â ItÂ occurredÂ to me as I was sitting there doing nothing, that you really don't need power to dust and clean, so that's what I did--Amazing how much you can get done without any distractions like a computer or television--I even went as far as to clean the rocking chairs on our front porch. Thankfully the power came on later in the afternoon before I got out the paint! I finally was able to discuss the blood work results for Lucas and Annie who went to the vet last week. Â The news for Annie is not the best. Â If there was any good news, it was that her kidney values are unchanged from last month. Â The bad news, is that her liver values continue to change. Â We've put her on a liver supplement Â called denamarin which raises antioxidant levels and has silybin to help improve liver function. Â Paws crossed that it works for her. Â All this is a reminder that when our pups are taking non-steroidal-anti- inflammatory medication like Annie was for an extended period, that regular blood work should be done to to make sure they are not damaging their kidneys and liver. Â Unfortunately her previous owner didn't do this, and sadly this is the result. The news for Lucas was mixed.Â  He has a high white blood cell count but where the infection is, is unclear.Â  He's on antibiotics for 2 weeks in hopes that will take care of it.Â  Lucas has been made available for adoption through the rescue I volunteer with, but so far, not a single call about him.Â  Even with the articles that have been written about him, no one has expressed an interest.Â  I know it's probably due to the limitations of his adoption.Â  Lucas as you may recall was a stray so he cannot be placed with young children because we don't know his history around themThen there is Lucas's never ending fascination and obsession with the cat. Â He and CC still have their moments when she's had enough, but they don't occur as often as they did at first and she allows Lucas to closely admire her, which he does every chance he gets. Â Our poor cat, CC, never gets a break, no matter where she is...~Todd and CC this morning~Enjoy your Sunday!!

title: We've Got Rhythm
text: ~Toby~I don't know about you, but Iâ€™m a schedule person. Â I like schedules, rhythms to my day and to my week. Â When those are changed I end up feeling out ofÂ syncÂ until I can get back into that rhythm. Â Some people refer to this as 'balance.' Â I try not to call it that because if you could see me on a daily basis, you'd know that's not what I have--Instead I go for rhythm. Â Each day, each week and each month has its own rhythm. Â Itâ€™s up to me to make adjustments and find the rhythm and flow. Our dogs are good examples of lives that have rhythm and they often help me to find it. Â We do the same things each day, almost always in the same sequence. Â This rhythm even finds its way into meal time. Â When we feed the dogs, their bowls are all put down in the same order every single time. Â Each dog knows where they eat, and will wait in that spot. Added Â to their daily rhythm, our dog walker comes about the same time each day--On days when we're home, at around 12:30, the time 'Christy' usually comes, they become restless and want to go outside for a walk. The dogs know when it's time to play and when it's time to relax and take a nap.~Annie~I think our daily rhythm and has really helped the new comers to our household adjust--Sandy is the latest example of that. Â Being totally blind he has had to make a lot of adjustments and learn a lot of new things. Â THANKS to your suggestions, he's learned the rhythm of our routine. Â Sandy knows by sound (and probably smell) when we're getting the meals ready. Â And because we've taken him to the same place each time, he waits patiently in that spot for his bowl to be brought to him. Sandy has also learned his way around the outside yard and can now easily find his way back inside.Inside the house, Sandy easily navigates the floor plan. Â Yes, he will still sometimes knock over a floor fan and get caught in the curtains or behind a door, but not as often as he did at first.When Sandy first came, I have to admit that I only focused on his being blind. Â But he and I have gotten into that rhythm and I have gotten to know an endearing and affectionate senior boy, who just happens to not be able to see, and who has found a place in my heart and our home.

title: Lancaster Was Delicious!!
text: I think that you can always tell a good trip by how you feel when itâ€™s over. Sometimes extended weekends away are fun, but then you return home feeling tired from everything and behind on that to-do list. Â My trip to Lancaster? Â I've returned home feeling relaxed and even though there's the never-ending laundry and housecleaning, at this moment, I'm finding these things are really not that important.I don't know about you, but when I take a trip I always seem to take on the idea of being on vacation to heart and I promptly forget about maintaining any sort of diet. So let me just show you how much fun I had and why I won't be stepping on that scale for a few days...It all started withÂ dinner on Thursday that was deep dish pepperoni pizza.We were up early on Friday morning where we met another friend for breakfast. Â As the rooster was crowing, we made our way to 'The Green Dragon' in Ephrata (in Lancaster County) where local growers, merchants and craftsman meet for one of the largest farmers markets in the area. Â Most often I gravitate towards the fresh produce. Â Not this time...I was drawn to the delicious and fresh baked goods offered by the Amish. Afterwards, because I'm a chocolate lover, a visit to the Wilbur Chocolate Candy Factory was a last minute addition to our agenda.All this and it was only lunch time! Â This took us to the Tomato Pie CafÃ©. Â With a name like Tomato Pie CafÃ©, there's a hint that there must be something really special on the menu that shares that name; and 'special' it was! Â Tomato pie has layers of fresh tomatoes with cheese, that is flavored with basil and layered on a buttermilk crust that was a cross between a biscuit and fluffy bread--Delicious! I returned home on Saturday afternoon and we enjoyed a late dinner with friends. For some reason, I just wasn't that hungry......Today I'm making chocolate cupcakes for a co-worker who is celebrating 25 years with the practice where I work. Â However I am finding that I just don't have the enthusiasm that I usually do for baking...I think we all know why that is...But I really hope you've had a good weekend! Â Once again, I am looking forward to catching up on your news! Â Enjoy your Sunday!

title: On The Road Again
text: Off to the vet this morning with our three foster pups, Annie, Lucas and Sandy. I thought taking the three of them would be easy enough but I hadn't taken into consideration that Sandy can't see where he's going and Lucas is a little bit leary about being taken anywhere--Annie on the other hand is happy wherever she is.Sandy was the main focus of the visit. Â Despite putting drops in his eyes they continue to be red and today was the day to check his eye pressure. Â As expected, it was high in both eyes indicating that he has glaucoma--Having previously had a dog that had glaucoma (Tanner) I felt pretty sure of what the diagnosis would be and would have been moreÂ surprised if it hadn't been. Â We're going to try medications in hopes of lowering the pressure, but if it doesn't help, he'll need to see anÂ ophthalmologist for more treatment. Â Paws crossed. Tomorrow I hit the road again for Lancaster Pennsylvania to spend a couple of days with my good friend Sidney. Â We have some things planned to do, and I'm excited to see her and have some fun. Then the following week my brother comes from Kentucky to spend a week with us. Â Will the month of July slow down--Probably not until Todd does!

title: The Cat in the Hat at Golden Pines
text: The sun really shined...It was too hot to play...So we have sat in the house, where it's cool for these past three days....I sat here with the dogs, when the temperature reached more than one-hundred-and-two...And only Todd and Annie have found something to do...But even Todd will agree it's to hot to be out and much too hot to play ball...And so we have sat in the house--We have done nothing at all. ~Sandy~So all we did all weekend was to Sit! Sit! Sit! Â And we have not liked it...Not one little bit....

title: An Award and Our Jewel, Wendy
text: While we're all staying inside trying to stay cool I thought I'd take today to give a heart-felt thank you to two bloggers who recently passed on the 'Sunshine Award' for my blog. Â The first blog was Ruled By Paws which is written by Brooke who works with a guide dog. Â Her blog is about her adventures with all her pups, Cessna, Canyon, Aspen and Rogue. The second time the award was given to us, it came from brown dog cbr Â which is a blog chronicling the antics of Hawk, a Chesapeake Bay Retriever who is an easy going boy who loves to run and find adventure. I really enjoy both blogs and hope you'll stop over for a visit and get to know them!When you receive the Sunshine Award, you're supposed to answer seven questions about yourself. Â Since I usually only follow rules when I absolutely have to, I've decided to change that up a little. On July 3rd we celebrated 13 years with our girl Wendy, who is now almost 15 years old. Â She was the second dog Carl and I got, and of all of our dogs, she has been with us the longest. Â When I think of the years we've had together, and how embedded within our life she is I am humbled and grateful for that time with her. Â So, today as a tribute to Wendy, I'm breaking the rules of the 'Sunshine Award' and am going to tell you seven things about her that you may not know.1. Â Wendy is our only dog that will 'speak' when you ask her to2. Â  She never had an interest in chewing on bones, swimming, tennis balls or stuffed animals--In her younger days she was an energetic frisbee gal through and through. 3. Â She is not a full-bred Golden and is mixed with Border Collie. (probably why she loves the frisbee)4. Â Wendy doesn't like the other dogs (or us) touching her while she sleeps. Â She'll give a single bark and a harmless snap to remind us to leave her alone. 5. Â Wendy is the very first dog we got from a rescue which means she has known every single dog we have ever fostered, adopted and owned. Â She also has known the 3 cats we've had too. Â  Â 6. Â She came to us with the name of 'Amber' which I changed to Wendy, my favorite character in Peter Pan.7. Â I knew the first time I met Wendy, that I really wanted her. Â We didn't get to bring her home with us that night, and I was worried that the foster home wouldn't pick us to adopt her--They did, and the rest is history! ~Wendy and our First Golden, Tod~So today,Â Here's to Wendy,Â the Jewel of Golden Pines, Cheers!!

title: It's Good to be Home??!!
text: It was a good visit to Kentucky where I spent time with my four brothers and sister in law. Â I really enjoyed catching up with them, doing a little shopping and just getting away, I needed the break. Â My trip was pretty uneventful, compared to the weather which seems to be grabbing all the headlines.Â Â In Kentucky the temperatures soared to over 100 degrees. Â On Friday, from the Midwest to the Mid-Atlantic, a small, upper-level disturbance near Chicago interacted with all the heat to produce a rare, straight-line wind-maker known as a "derecho." Â Winds at times approached 100 miles-per-hour, twisting and toppling too many trees to count, including the one below on our road. Â But the trees took down thousands of power lines, leaving more than 3 million people in six states in the dark.We were among those that lost power on Friday night. Â I arrived home last evening after an 11 hour drive to a sweltering, dark house, which put me in a less than cheerful mood. Â Even though it cooled off after we'd gone to bed, not even hearing the Barred Owls in the quiet of the night could console me--I was miserable.~Josh and Todd~I don't think that the dogs were enjoying it either. Â The heat was even taking its toll on Lucas who has breathing problems. Thankfully by late afternoon today the power company arrived to repair the downed electric lines. Â It took them all of about 15 minutes to make the repair, and we had power once again. Â YAY!!! At the end of the day, the house is finally cooling down and I'm feeling better, and I know the dogs are too! ~Annie~Even with the loss of all the food in both freezers and refrigerator, and still being worn out from the heat and the trip, I can honestly say 'it's good to be home!'It'll also be good to catch up with you and your blogs on Wednesday!~Sheba~

title: New Tricks and a Road Trip
text: Sandy is settling in really nicely and learning his way around our house and yard. It's a slow process. Â For his sake, it'll be a big help when he knows the routine and where things are. Â After not eating anything last weekend, and trying everything to get him to, I added parmesan cheese to the top of his meal and he FINALLY ate on Monday morning! Â It makes sense that a dog that is blind and unfamiliar with hisÂ surroundingsÂ would be tempted by a strong cheese. Â As I mentioned in my previous post, we've never had a blind dog before. Â So I really appreciated your advice on helping this very sweet boy learn his way around on my last post. Â If there are any other tips that you would like to pass on, please feel free to leave them. The rest of the week is going to be a busy one. Â Today I am off to Kentucky. All of my brothers are going to be home and I've not seen two of them in about 4 years and so I am looking forward to spending time with them. I'll look forward to catching up on your news when I return early next week! Enjoy the rest of your week!

title: A Hole at Golden Pines is Filled
text: As you know, with the loss of Sam, I've had a 75 pound golden-sized hole in my heart this week. While no dog could ever take Sam's place, the hole that was left in my heart and our house was filled with a 120 pound (!!) Golden named Sandy who arrived on Friday. It all happened so quickly. Â Someone from the rescue called me around lunchtime yesterday and asked if I'd consider taking in a 14 year old boy named Sandy. Â When she was reading me the information on him I have to admit that I didn't really hear much of what she said--Other than the original owner had gone into a nursing home and the daughter had been keeping Sandy in the basement and they were unable to afford to pay for food for him--And Sandy is also blind. Â With all of that, of course I said yes. Â Another volunteer for the rescue agreed to pick him up and meet me and by 4 o'clock I was on my way home with Sandy. It could not worked out better if it had been planned days ago. Our crew are seasoned pros at meeting new dogs, and meeting Sandy was uneventful--Even Lucas behaved himself. Â I think he's in awe of his size; actually we all are, Sandy is a big boy! I've never had a totally blind dog before. Â We've been showing Sandy around the house and this morning he found the water bowls on his own and his way to the back door to go outside. Â He's yet to eat a meal, but I am sure that will change. Â He and I are off to the vet this morning for a checkup.Afterwards I am hoping, hoping and hoping that I will have the time to sit, relax and read your news. Â It has been a hectic and tiring week and I could use a little escape to your blogs to see what's happening in your world~Thank-you for stopping by to see what's happening in mine! Enjoy your Saturday!

title: Six Words
text: ~Sam, left and Toby last Sunday~I would like to thank everyone for the kind and thoughtful comments that you left on the loss of our boy Sam on Monday. Â It has again confirmed to me that the blogging-community of animal lovers truly understands how difficult it is to go through the toughest task many of us faceâ€”saying good-bye. Â I will tell you from experience that it never, everÂ for a single moment gets easier to make those decisions or to lose one of our four-legged-family members. Â I can also tell you without a doubt that there is so much comfort in knowing that there are people who understand how difficult the loss is, and hearing from friends and family (and even strangers) who offer their support really helps and is priceless. In trying to think of a tribute to Sam, I am reminded about a famous story where literary great Ernest Hemingway was challenged to write the worldâ€™s shortest story using only six words. Â He is said to have declared his resulting creation his best work. The entirety of the story was:For sale: Â baby shoes, never wornÂ I decided to take up this same challenge and do a tribute to Sam, using only six words. Â I found it to be a bit more difficult than I originally thought it would be, especially because I'm still suffering from a bit of a writers-block when it comes to him. Â But below are the six that I've come up with for tribute to my boy Sam:Content, Confident, Charging Ahead, Remembered, MissedCare to share what your six words would be for that special someone in YOUR LIFE, past or present, two legs or four? Â I'd really love to hear them and I think others would be interested too.So as the 'Chapter of Sam' closes, I would again like to thank-you for your kindness and your friendship! Â Today as a real taste of brutal summer heat has arrived, I'm staying inside today and am looking forward to catching up on life and your news! Â Enjoy your Thursday!

title: The Battle Ends for Sam
text: Today dawned cool, gray and damp. Â As a gentle rain fell this morning, I knelt next to Sam as he lay in the grass. Â He'd been there for several minutes and was starting to become soaking wet. Â My attempts to get him to come inside were met with resistance from him, but eventually he did what he was asked. Â I wasn't sure what exactly was happening or what had changed because outwardly at least to me, nothing had. Â But known only to Sam, something was different, because it was obvious the pain and his battle with cancer had become too much for him.Holding Sam's face in my hands I looked at him and pleaded and promised I would do whatever it took to help him, if we could just have more time together. Â But another world was calling to Sam and I knew it was time to let him go--Sam had done what he always did--He chose what he wanted to do. There is so much I want the world to know about Sam. Â Things that I don't want to be forgotten. Â But tonight, I am flooded with emotions and as hard as I have tried, the words just won't come. Â I can only give thanks for nearly 3 years full of memories with one of the most well adjusted, confident, self assured and independent Goldens I've ever known.Tonight our candle is lit to help Sam find his way to the Rainbow Bridge. Â Along with being met by our pups, I am finding comfort in Sam also being reunited with his very first owner whose life sadly ended much too soon. Â And as he and Sam cross the Rainbow Bridge together, I hope that Sam won't forget what he meant to us, and how much we are going to miss him.God speed 'my handsome Sam.' Â You fought a good fight.

title: The Front Porch
text: A beautiful SaturdayÂ morning to just sitÂ on our front porch with our old and very slow laptop and write this post. Â The door and windows areÂ open, and it's cool enough that even the air conditioning doesn't have to be on.Â  The sky is clear and there's hardly a cloud in the sky.Â Â In the yard the Mother rabbit watches over her family. Â We didn't see her at all yesterday and we were a little concerned that something had happened to her--Am I the only one that worries about wildlife in the yard? Â In an effort to keep the rabbits safe, we're not allowing the dogs into that part of the yard--But all of our worrying about her yesterday was for nothing because we finally saw herÂ late in the evening.Â Â Across the road I can hear the voices of the farmer and his sons and the mooing of cows as they moveÂ cattle into the pasture nearest to us.Â Â Apparently the cows are not happy about the change. Â The dogs really enjoy being on the front porch with me, watching and listening.Â Â I'm glad that Sam has chosen to come out here with us.Â  A friend of mine who also has senior Goldens has insisted that SamÂ be put on more herbs--She swears that's what is keeping her 16+ Â year old going.Â  She is so convinced of it that she purchased themÂ and had themÂ delivered to us.Â Â Thinking that Sam and I have nothing to lose, I started giving them to him.Â  I'm not sure what they all are, but I suppose that time will tell if they are effective or not.Â Today on my agenda is to look upÂ blackberryÂ recipes.Â  We've picked the last of them, and I haveÂ more than a gallonÂ in theÂ freezer andÂ 4Â quarts sitting on the counter and two more in the fridge.Â  There are so many and I'm worried they may go to waste.Â Â This morning I've already baked 'blackberry bread' butÂ would like to find something a bit more interesting to do with them. (Any thoughts?) Â However at this momentÂ theÂ front porch is interesting enoughÂ andÂ right now I'm not worrying about anything.Enjoy your Saturday!

title: Anchored in Peace
text: There are some people who thrive in a room full of people or in crowded places and having a constantly moving life. Â I am not one of them. Â I like simplicity. Â I like living quietly and being home. Â Especially on days like today where there has been a soft rainfall all day. On Saturday Carl discovered a nest of baby rabbits in the middle of our yard. Â (I don't understand why the Mother chose the unprotected open space of our yard to raise her family) Â ButÂ seeing the Mother rabbit sit in the rain watching over her family has a feeling of peace to it as well. The clouds and the rain even effect the dogs. After a very brief walk in the rain, they've all found a place and settled down for a nap, anchoring the house in peace and quiet.~Charlie~Â Finally, thank-you continuing to remember Sam. Â There have been a few changes the last couple of days, but he's still happy and going strong! Â  Below is a picture I took of him on Sunday, which was also my birthday. It made the day that much better to have him with us and being able to spend it with good friends. I hope you're having a good day too!I'm off work today and thought that on this rainy day it would be a perfect time to catch up on my blog-reading. Â However an issue that I had about a month ago with the blogs I follow has once again started to reoccur. Â I'm having a problem where some of the blogs that I follow are not appearing on my dashboard (or in goggle reader). I've posted 4 times in the help forum and getÂ absolutelyÂ no response. Â I've tried everything, signing in and out, clearing the cache, etc., and I even reloaded google chrome, re-followed the blogs that I know aren't there and they still don't appear--Nothing resolves the issue--I have to admit that I'm feeling really frustrated. Â Does anyone have any thoughts about what I could do or who I could contact? Â Can I just tell you how frustrating it is? Â THANK YOU for your thoughts, I appreciate it!!Sheba would rather go outside and play than be inside, in any weather!

title: Berries and a Bat
text: The week ended as one of those weeks when, despite the uncertainty with Sam, things seemed right and how they should be. Â With good weather this past week it allowed us to pick the bumper-crop of blackberries that are ripening faster than we can get to them. Â Unfortunately many are going to waste.Â But I had no idea that there were so many blackberries growing on our property. Â Sheba still cannot get enough of them!Yesterday Sheba and I went for a walk around our property and picked the ones along the edge of the woods. Â One of the things I get most nervous about is seeing a snake, so I'm always watching where I step. Â I should probably spend more time looking up because when I did, I saw a little brown bat clinging to a branch. Â I backed way off and stayed just long enough to take a couple of very quickÂ pictures. When we first moved here it was not unusual to see bats. Â On a warm spring or summer night, shortly after dusk from our front porch I would watch their fluttery, erratic flight as they caught insects with the greatest of ease. Â But the last few years we've not seen as many because of Â 'white-nose-syndrome' that is killing them in record numbers. I personally think that bats are a little misunderstood because of the myths associated with them--And I understand and respect why many don't like to have them around. But for me it was good to see this nocturnal resident, and I hope it has friends.

title: Going Off
text: ~Charlie~It's Wednesday and with the rush and chaos of the week behind me, my time is now becoming my own. Â It's time to get caught up. A friend of mine in an e-mail asked me how Sam was doing. Â I sent her a picture and said that I thought that Sam was 'riding a wave' and was doing okay. Being an avid surfer, our friend responded back that she was so glad that Sam was 'going off'Â  and explained that this is a surfing term used to describe a very good, consistent surfer who is surfing particularly well. I liked it, and thought it fit Sam perfectly; he's riding the wave pretty well right now! Â Even though the left side of his face is swollen, and he's lost the use of his left eye, Sam seems to be comfortable and not having any pain. We're continuing to let him set the pace of this part of the journey. Â He's up to going for walks with us, and is enjoying the bumper crop of blackberries that we've had every day this week. ~Sam enjoying his evening~I feel like at the moment we're in a good place with Sam. Â Words cannot explain how humble and grateful I am for these days of grace with him. Â I think this calls for another blackberry cobbler like the one I made for my co-workers yesterday. I'm looking forward to catching up on your news, Â  Â THANK YOU for stopping for a moment to read ours!

title: An Upbeat Note
text: Our week ended with severe rainstorms. It was raining so hard at one point, the gutters were overflowing. Â JustÂ acrossÂ the Potomac River from us, there were tornado warnings.Â I have to admit that I was a bit unnerved by it all.Todd thought he wanted to be outside while it was pouring rain, but once out, he just stood there, seemingly unable to make up his mind what he wanted to do. Â He came back inside. The past week seemed to be filled with nothing but bad news. Â Even the news for our newest addition Annie was not that good. Â Her test results from her recent vet visit show she has kidney and liver damage that was probably caused by extended use of anti-inflammatory medication for her arthritis. A special diet will be needed for her. Needless to say, my spirits were at an all time low, my heart felt broken and my head was just spinning. Â But I'm ready to begin the weekend on a more upbeat note.Sheba let me know this morning that the wild blackberries are already starting to ripen. Â I hadn't even noticed them, because they're a little early this year. Â Each year it has been a contest between Sheba and I and Rudi (who passed away last August) and the birds to see who will get the most. Â Right now, Sheba is winning.It helps to begin the weekend with Sam acting like he's feeling a little better. He was barking and wagging his tail as we got ready for our morning walk. Â He even enjoyed blackberries with Sheba and I and gobbled down his breakfast and Lucas's too. Â I don't know how long we'll ride this wave with Sam, or even if it really is one. But the good notes at the start of the day has created harmony and peace at Golden Pines this morning. Â Enjoy your Saturday!

title: It's About Sam
text: It has been a difficult week with Sam. Â The high hopes that I had for the prednisone to make a difference for him has been dashed because it made him very, very sick. We took Sam off of all the medications to give his stomach a break, and have restarted everything again this morning. Â The tumor continues to grow and is affecting his eye even more this morning than yesterday. Â The picture below was taken on Monday and seeing it today, reminds me of that. Â I know that Sam's time with us is nearing its end. Â But we all know that sometimes when we think that, it may not be. With the exception of what I thought was a bit heartless and a callus comment left this morning on my previous post, I have really appreciated all of your very kind, caring thoughts and support you have left for Sam and I. It helps more than you know and makes this burden a little easier to bear knowing that this journey is not being taken alone. Â For those of you who think I am a 'strong person' to get through all of this and other losses, thank-you for thinking that, but you don't see me behind the scenes--The truth is, right now I am a 'blubbering mess!' Â I don't know how I get through it all, I just know that I will because it's not about me, this time it's about Sam. Â  Â Enjoy your Thursday!

title: The Sun and Sam
text: Memorial Day weekend is the official kick-off for summer, and that's exactly what it is here in Virginia. Â Hot temperatures and lots of sun have been plentiful all weekend. Â The dogs have opted to stay inside where it's cool, only going out when coaxed and when they have too. Â The only one with any real interest in being outside is Todd, especially if the water-hose is turned on. Â On hot days like we've been having, I remember as a kid, playing in the sprinklers. Â Where there was water, there were kids playing. At our house, it's Todd and it's just what Todd loves to do.Sam's vet visit on Saturday was not the best. Â I've done a lot of reading about the oral cancer that Sam has. As I have found out, it's very fast growing. Â I think that I have mentioned that the treatment for it would be a radical and very invasive surgery to remove a large portion of the side of his face, and chemotherapy and radiation. Â In the end, it would (probably) only prolong his life for a few months past what he would have without it. Â I cannot and will not put him through it. Â So, with not many options my vet and I decided to putÂ Sam on prednisone to try and get rid of the inflamation and hopefully shrink the size of the tumor to give him some comfort.Â  The side effects of the medication are outweighed by the relief that he'll hopefully get from it, but it will only be temporary. Â My vet said that on the steroid he probably has about 2 months that should hopefully provide him with a good quality of life.Â  Without being on the medication,Â he probably would have those same 2 months, but would be miserable. Â I'm hoping for a miracle and more time.Â  It's all I can do. Today Sam seems to be feeling a little better, which made me feel better too. Â Its been a good day for both of us. Â I hope you're enjoying your weekend!

title: Good Karma
text: Hot, sunny and searing temperatures end the week. Â I was in a hurry to get home this afternoon after work, but had to run a few errands. While I was waiting at a red-light, an elderly gentleman was crossing the road and as he hurried across, he tripped and fell right in front of me--I watched him try twice to get back to his feet, but both times he fell again. I got out of my van to help him, and a man in the car next to me did too. Â As we were helping him to his feet, the red light changed. Â I couldn't believe it when the person in the car behind me impatiently started honking his horn--He also rolled down his window and started yelling and swearing at us to hurry up. The man that had fallen said he was okay (although terriblyÂ embarrassed) and he thanked us. Â I took my time getting back in my car, but not before I smiled and blew a kiss to the man who was still upset that we were delaying him. Â My gesture of course made him a little madder but I thought to myself how sad that he put himself above someone who needed help.I rushed in and out of the grocery store and as I was putting my groceries into my van, I looked down and there was a little Yorkshire Terrier looking at me. Â I was a bit surprised and looked around to see if I could see where he'd come from. Â I realized he was a little renegade so I tried to catch him but he ran off, through the parking lot. Â About that time I heard a woman's frantic voice calling a name. Â I went to her and found out that the dog belonged to her. Â Pointing in the direction where the dog had gone, I got into my van and tried to keep track of the dog. Â I caught only glimpses of him through the cars and traffic. Â Because he was so small, I lost sight of him and his owner as well. Â Another quick circle around the parking lot, and I saw the owner holding her dog! Â I was so thankful she'd managed to catch him! Â The dog was so hot (as was she) and I gave them each a couple of bottles of water and a portable dog bowl I had. She thanked me and offered to pay me for the water and bowl. Â Of course I refused and started home, glad that owner and dog were reunited! Â  With the holiday weekend, traffic was unbearable--But I think because I'd helped 2 strangers, 'good-karma' was there and I found a way around it and got home pretty easily. Â I'm hoping that tomorrow morning when I take Sam to the vet, there will be 'good karma' for him too. Â The left side of his face has become really swollen this week and is affecting his eye. Â I know he's in pain. Â I've increased the dose of pain medication and it seems to help. Â I'm hopeful there will be something that can be done. Â Paws crossed...I'm overwhelmingly worried about Sam.

title: Welcome Home Old Friend!
text: I love living in Virginia because of the distinct change of seasons.Â Â We all know that when leaves begin to fall autumn is here. And when flowers awaken from their winters sleep we know that spring has indeed sprung. But on nights like tonight, when IÂ see the first lightning bug of the year itâ€™sÂ like welcoming home an old friend--One whoâ€™s been gone for months and now suddenly comes back bringing with it the feeling of summer! Â As a kid there was always a feeling of wonder as I caught one of these little critters and then watched it slowly climb to the highest part of my finger, spread itâ€™s wings and fly away.Like so many kids would do, I'dÂ capture them and put them in an oldÂ jar (mason jars worked the best) with holes poked in the lid from the sharpest and usually my Mom's best kitchen knife. Â Then Iâ€™d fill the jar withÂ long blades of grass to contain my treasures.Â Of course at some pointÂ the lights in the jar would start to go out as the lightning bugs would begin to succumb to the lack of air--And with that, Iâ€™d have to release them on my Mom's demands.But it's nights like tonight when I have no interest in watching television or doing anything inside because there's a pretty good show right outside my window.

title: Enjoying the Day
text: The weather this weekend could not be better! Â Bright sun, warmth and not doing much have all helped me to FINALLY feel like myself again! Â The trip to the farmers market on Saturday helped too. Â I enjoy walking around seeing all the produce and plants--However I have to admit to not buying much. Â I know my feeling better makes Carl and the dogs happy because I have to be honest and admit, that I've not been the most pleasant person to be around. Â Even Sam seems to be feeling better. Â This morning when the timed-light in the office came on he started barking, giving the wake up call to the entire house. Â Its such a good feeling to know that he's enjoying the day.I think the other dogs enjoyed being on the porch watching me while I worked in my flower garden. Â They were quick to point out any weeds I didn't pull and where the poison ivy is. Â The butterflies were finding something they loved around the driveway....Any idea what it could be? Â Â Whatever you've done this weekend, I hope you've enjoyed it too!

title: Post-Partum Blues
text: I've decided that I'm suffering from a kind of 'post-partum-blues.' Â I think this is partly due to the let down and end of the county wide food drive that I've been working on since February. Â Along with working every day this week, Todd and the toxic-toad, and Sam I am, once again at the end of the week, totally exhausted. Â  Sam's tumor has unfortunately gotten bigger. Â The Chinese herbs that I've been giving him don't seem to be working to shrink its size. Â I ordered new ones that arrived on Wednesday, but my fear is that we missed the window of time where they would have been effective. Â Sam does seem to feel pretty well, but I've started him on pain medication to ease any discomfort he may be having. Â I've not yet been able to take him to see 'the Mom' of his previous family. Â She's been undergoing medical treatment this past week, so I am hoping next week she'll feel well enough for us to meet. When I finally arrived home this afternoon, I felt consumed by sadness for Sam and a few other things that haveÂ occurred. Â But in a moment when I was almost totally lost in those feelings, I turned on the hose to water my flowers and Todd became excited about the chance to play. A couple of minutes of watching him have fun and my blues were gone. Â Just in time for the weekend.

title: Todd and the Toad
text: There's a saying 'life is merrier with a Scottish Terrier.' Â I have to say that I'm actually finding that 'life is hairier with a Scottish Terrier.' Â I don't even know how to start in telling you what happened this morning...The day started out okay. But Todd, right away, was really interested in something by the corner of the back porch. Â I just shooed him away from it, thinking he'd just leave whatever had captured his attention, alone. Â I went back inside and forgot about it. Â Todd however, didn't forget. Â When I went out to check on him 5 or 10 minutes later, all I saw was 'foam' all over the backyard and all over Todd. I grabbed Todd and ran my fingers through his mouth to get rid of whatever was causing the reaction, but there was nothing. Â I thought that hisÂ tongueÂ looked gray and he was also coughing just a little bit. Â I took him into the kitchen and shoved his face under the faucet and washed his face off and opened up his mouth to rinse that out as well. Â I grabbed a towel and continued to wipe is mouth out and clean off his tongue and gums. Â  Â  When I put Â Todd down on the floor to get a better assessment of how he was, he ran away from me and messed all over the rug. Â I had NO idea what he'd gotten into and I was really starting to panic. Â I was also feeling the urgency to get him to an animal emergency clinic. Â I wasÂ relievedÂ that Todd was no longer foaming from his mouth so I gave him some ice and water and put him in his crate while I got dressed. No more than 20 minutes had passed since all this started, but Todd was looking better. Â He seemed comfortable and he even ate a piece of ice. Â With that, I decided to sit and wait and see what happened. Â With the calm it occurred to me that he must've bitten one of the toads that we have around our porch. Â I'd seen them last evening and had told Carl that we needed to watch for them because they are poisonous and Todd was taking an interest in them when they hopped. As I sat there with Todd, I looked it up 'dogs and toads' on the internet. Â Sure enough, what happened to Todd was the exact thing that had happened to other dogs who had come in contact with these particular toads. Â While eating them can be fatal, I really thought that Todd had only ingested their poison when he either licked one, or tried to pick one up in his mouth. Because dogs get sick immediately after direct contact, the articles said that rinsing their mouths out was the prescribed treatment. Â It also mentioned that the 'episodes' pass in about Â half an hour. Â I was feeling much better and confident that he'd be okay, but to be sure, I called the animal emergency and spoke to a vet (that I happen to know). Â Of course she told me to bring him in for a check and observation. Â But because he'd eaten his entire breakfast and seemed okay I opted to take him to work with me instead. Todd was really good at work with me today. Â This evening he played with his ball and harassed the cat. Â HeÂ seems to have totally forgotten the events of the morning. Â I wish I could...

title: The Scottish Terrier...
text: The Scottish Terrier..."As a guard it is impossible to better him.He gives his warning, and if it passes unheeded, he shows very definitely that he is there and in charge.He is self-centered, deep-natured with a soul both for laughter and tragedyâ€¦There is nothing frothy or shallow in the nature of a Scottie.He never forgetsâ€“his heart may break with grief, but he will not yowl about it.He is absolutelyÂ honorable, incapable of a mean or petty action, large hearted and loving...With the soul and mind of an honest gentleman."Dorothy Gabriel,Â The Scottish Terrier, 1934I really loved this and had to share...Enjoy your Saturday!!

title: Behind...
text: I am so far behind on 'normal life' this week. Â I'm so sorry I've not been able to read your blogs. But the food drive is consuming much, if any, of my spare time as we head into the last 2 days.~Our little hungry hatchlings~But I've been behind in getting to work on timeAlthough it helps when there is something like this to look at...Instead of reading license plates...I've been behind in getting home...And behind in spending time with the dogs. Â This week I heard from Sam's former family. Â They have been thinking about him, and have asked to see him again. Â You'll recall that Sam came to us from a family at the church I attend. Â They had him for about 5 years, and when 'the Mom' was diagnosed with cancer, because of her health and a move, they were unable to keep him, and they gave Sam to us. Â Its been about 4 years since they saw him, and 'the Mom' in particular would like to see him one more time. Â I've no doubt that they dearly loved Sam, and I know had it not been for 'the Mom's' health, they would have kept him. Â Of course I have agreed to the meeting which will probably be next week. Â I noticed this week that the swelling has returned to Sam's cheek. Â We've started him on antibiotics again, and I continue to hope and pray that along with the medication and the Chinese herbs they will work to reduce swelling and the size of the tumor.Â In the rush of the week, I am so glad that I was able to carve out some time to meet a fellow blogger, 'Louise,' writer of the blog,Â Wildlife, Wildflowers and a Window,Â who was in my neck of the woods from New York to see her Aunt. Â We had such a delightful visit, and she brought me some of her Tartarian Asters. Â They were originally transplanted from her Aunts garden, to hers in New York, and now they have once again found a home here in Virginia. Â I hope I can remember what they are, because for some reason, 'Aunt Dottie's Asters' are what I have been calling them.Whatever you call your week, I hope all is well and I look forward to a slower pace and Â catching up with your news! Â Thanks for stopping by and catching up with us at Golden Pines! (Mom or Dad Phoebe with a meal for their hungry hatchlings)

title: A Place for Annie
text: Its been two weeks since Annie came to live with us. Â Unfortunately, as you know, we got off to a bumpy start with her because of Lucas. Â Thankfully his school-boy crush has all but vanished for the fair and lovely Annie.I've heard from Annie's previous owner several times asking how she was doing. Â Â I also mentioned to Steve how much I liked Annie's spark, and that when she wants something, she always lets us know...And that along with finding a place on our bed at night,Â Â I told Steve that Annie hasÂ found a place in our hearts too.

title: The Pace of the Day
text: Today marked the start of the pursuit of fresh and delicious produce from our local farmer's markets.Â  This morning I loved seeing the fresh vine ripened strawberries and rhubarb all together with baked goods and plants from local gardeners.Â It was a much welcome break from the pace of the last few days as the food-drive is consuming a lot of my time and energy as it ramps up and heads into its last week.
