(Below is Sam, who is doing well after his bout of a terrible upset stomach)Â Â I hope you're enjoying your day!~Toby~

title: A Peaceful Week-END?
text: The very early morning routine was the same. Â Carl got up about 4 o'clock to get ready for work. Â He let Todd out of his crate and got him outside. Â The backdoor was left open to allow the other dogs to go in and out as they please. Â I, of course, stayed in bed. Â This morning's peace and quiet was abruptlyÂ interruptedÂ by theÂ unmistakable high pitched wild and frenziedÂ bark of Todd--The other dogs quickly join in and pandemonium and bedlam filled the darkness. Â I don't think my feet touched the floor when I leapt out of bed and ran outside, (not stopping to put shoes on). Â The dogs were all barking and jumping at the fence. Â In the darkness I didn't see anything but I somehow managed to herd them all out of that part of the yard and close the gate. Â I got all the dogs back inside and once I caught Todd, I gave him a really good once over. Â Other than being on the edge of hysteria, he was fine. Â Of course there is no question it was all caused by 'something' that didn't belong in the yard. With peace restored, Carl left for work. Â  However somehow in the chaos and trying to get Todd settled down, I hadn't noticed that Sam was missing. Whenever I call him he always comes. Â I searched the entire house, the garage, and he was nowhere. Â I turned on the barn lights and walked out to the closed gate and called him, no movement, nothing. Â But when I shined the flashlight into the darkness, I saw him laying in a dark corner of the yard. Â My heart literally sank and my knees turned to jello. Â I went to him to try and get him to stand up and he wouldn't. Â Of course I thought that he'd been injured by whatever was in the yard. Â But I manged to give him a really good once over and saw nothing that indicated he may have been hurt. Â What I did HEAR was his stomach really gurgling--Obviously he's eaten something that hasn't agreed with him. Â He's since gotten up a drank some water. Â He declined his breakfast but I'm hoping that it's just a badÂ restaurant review and nothing serious. He wants to be outside laying in the grass, so if it makes him feel better, I'm just going to let him. The week has been an extremely busy and hectic one with work and the county-wide food drive that I'm helping to organize. I'm really hoping that it ends peacefully with all in good health and spirits. ~CarrieAnne~

title: The Blonde Sisterhood
text: A hectic and tiring week has come to an end. Â Sam is doing really well. Â Yesterday he was rolling in the cool grass and later he was counter-surfing--All good signs! Â After a long conversation with a friend, who I consider an expert on natural and holistic treatment for dogs, my optimism and focus has returned. Â In the past I've had pretty good success in using Chinese herbs and I have no reason to not hope for this same success in using them for Sam too. Â He'll begin taking them today.On the flip-side, the unwanted affection and attention of Casanova Lucas for the fair and lovely Annie has finally waned.Â PersuadingÂ Lucas that Annie was not the girl for him, happened in the most unusual way. Â Annie, unable to convince him herself that his advances were unwanted not just by her, but by all of us, we had an Â intervention. Â The intervention was not something that Carl or I did, but something Sheba did. Â Sheba as you recall is our youngest Golden, and she is not afraid to stand up for herself or even start a fight. On Wednesday, for some reason anytime that Lucas got near Annie, Sheba began getting into the middle of the two, would growl at Lucas, and with that, Lucas would walk away from both of them. Â This is something I've never seen Sheba do, and I can only conclude that 'the blonde-sisterhood' is just standing up for one another and sticking together!~Sheba and Annie, the Blonde Sisterhood~Leontien, Â your friends, two and four legged at Golden Pines dedicate our first blooms of the season to you. Â We send you comforting hugs and healing energy! Â To send Flowers for Leontien click here

title: What's Ahead for Sam
text: TheÂ overall news for Sam today was unfortunately not all good. Â He had 8 teeth that needed to be removed. And whatÂ the vet and I thought was swelling from a root abscess because of a bad tooth and a blocked salivary gland is actually a mass, and given that he's a Golden it is probably cancer. Â My vet and I discussed treatment options, but I was so stunned by what she was telling me, I just couldn't make a decision. Â However I did decide to not do one of the options and that was to do surgery to remove the mass. Â Because of its size, surgery would probably entail removing a good portion of Sam's jaw and at his age (about 13) I just won't put him through that. Â Â To be told that cancer is going to take yet another one of our dogs that has been so healthy has me feeling really defeated. Â When Sam needed to have his teeth cleaned and the 'bad ones' removed, something about it had me a bit uneasy. Â But I held onto the thought that it would all be routine and that everything would heal, and Sam would be fine. Â So instead of being able to put all this behind us, I'm feeling the return of a familiar ache in my heart when I think of what's ahead for Sam.

title: A New Addition--A Girl Named Annie
text: When it rains, it really does pour...Along with Sam's surgery coming up on Wednesday, on Sunday we welcomed a new addition, a 13 year old girl named Annie. Â Her owner, who is named Steve, lost his wife about 5 years ago, lives alone and has stage 4 pancreatic cancer. Â As his health has deteriorated, he has found it harder and harder to care for Annie and so he made the difficult choice to give her up. Â And, as heartbreaking as it is to think about, Steve wanted to make sure Annie had a home prior to his passing away. Â It was a sad meeting and I hope in our conversation I was able to assure him that Annie would have a good home. Â I also told Steve that he could contact me anytime to find out how Annie was doing. Â  Â  ~Annie and Our Gang waiting for dinner~Annie is a lovely, confident and well cared for treasured Golden. Â Steve and his wife got her, and her partner who was named Sid (who passed away last year) when they were about 8 weeks old. Â Annie is pretty well mannered, and hopes for a bite of whatever it is Â you're having, and she loves to sleep on the bed. Â She met our gang, who are pros at meeting new dogs, with no problems, and fits right in. Â The only problem is Lucas. Â He has dusted off every single one of his hormones and will not, and I mean will not leave her alone! Â Annie seems to take it all in stride. Â But I have to be honest and say that his amorous behavior is causing a lot of stress for everyone because of his barking, panting and pacing and he will not listen to any of our corrections--And we have tried every one that we can think of. Sadly, I don't think it's fair to Annie or Lucas if he can't get his hormones in check. Â If he cannot in a couple of days, I will have to ask the rescue to find another home for her. Â I hope this doesn't happen because I am totally smitten with a beautiful blonde Golden named Annie who when I look at, reminds me of my beloved girl Kasey--And whose eyes I look into and want to get to know better.

title: The Hole Digging Scottie Knows
text: Sam's visit to the vet went as expected; it is just as I thought, a rootÂ abscess. Â Surgery to remove 1-2 teeth is scheduled for Wednesday. Â He'll also have his teeth cleaned and any others removed that could become problems down the road for him. Â Sam is about 13 years old, and for the 3 years that we've had him, he's always been healthy. Â Knowing this, I'm optimistic that the surgery can be done safely, but I have to be honest in that I'm worried. Â Worried because there is another lump in the very back of his mouth. Â After an aspirate was done I'm hopeful that it's what my vet says it might be, which is just a blockedÂ salivaryÂ gland and not something really serious. With the confirmation that Sam needs surgery, I was feeling a bit down. Â When we got home it helped to sit on the porch and soak up the warmth of afternoon sun with the dogs and recharge my batteries. There's nothing like the peace of the outdoors and the sound of ripping paper to clear your mind. Â That and...Later being given a half eaten 1-dollar bill. Â The 10 dollars that was with it is nowhere to be found. Â I'm sure Charlie hasn't seen it. Â But why do I have a feeling that my muddy-faced, hole digging Scottie may know where it is?

title: Friday's Hope
text: Aside from the space-shuttle Discovery coming to our area, the week has been an uneventful one. Â Fog has started our day, butÂ it's forecast to be a beautiful day ahead. The weekend is supposed to bring much needed showers and cooler temperatures. Â This means that our grass which really needs to be mowed, won't. For about a week now, the Eastern Phoebe that has built its nest above our garage door is sitting tightly on 5 eggs that as of yesterday, have yet to hatch. Â She has gotten so used to our coming and going that she never leaves the nest when we exit the garage, or stand under the nest. I have taken today off work because our boy Sam needs to be taken to the vet. Seemingly overnight, a hard lump appeared on the left side of his muzzle. Â I think it may be a rootÂ abscess, because the tooth beneath it appears to be in good condition--However having just gone through all the dental work with Lucas, I think my opinion of Â 'good condition' has changed. Â But I'm hoping it's nothing (too) serious.I'm hoping you've had a good week and enjoy your day! Â ~Wendy~

title: A Special Event
text: Today we had a special event as the space shuttle Discovery made its final flightÂ piggybacked atop a modified Boeing 747 jet. Â It flew from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida to my neck of the woods, Washington, D.C. Â (picture below was posted on Facebook)Â Practically everyone scannedÂ the sky to catch aÂ glimpse of the rare sight, as the jet looped around the entire Capital area before landing at nearby Dulles Airport.Â Â The retired shuttle will get a new home at the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum.My co-workers and I watchedÂ the 'live feed' of Discovery's landing andÂ couldn't help but beÂ filled with emotion as we saw it touch down for the last time. Needless to say, I was once again in awe as I saw the 'special passenger' that same model plane carried today.

title: The Giddiness of Spring
text: This is about as nice of a holiday weekend as one could ask for with a lot of sun and mild temperatures. If I needed something to complain about, (which I don't) I'll just say that we could use some rain. Â The last couple of nights and in the morning hours we've enjoyed a really bright, full and beautiful moon. Â In reading I found that the first full moon in April is called 'The Pink Moon.' Â This name comes from the wild ground phlox, which are as you know, one of the earliest flowers of spring.When the moon finished its show this morning, it was time for the next act, the birds. Â The air has been filled with the cacophony of their singing. Â I recorded the video on the front porch to give you an idea. Â If you listen closely, you can even hear a rooster crowing. Â Â (You may Â have to turn it up to hear it and get the full effect). Â  Â With the crisp temperatures, the full moon, and the birds singing, it's no wonder that a couple of the dogs, especially Toby are feeling downright giddy. On our morning walk there was a different air about him as he lagged behind and wouldn't listen when I called to him. I lost sight of him when I entered the woods to go around the barn. Â Toby took that moment to go on an adventure. Â Maybe he caught the scent of the turkey that has been around, or the other animals that are everywhere. Whatever the reason, needless to say, the birds weren't the only sound being heard this morning as my voice calling him seemed to echo everywhere. Â Fortunately he was found, and I can thank him for getting me myÂ exercise! Â  Â Good boy!! Â ~Toby~

title: Lessons From Wendy
text: I've previously mentioned how Wendy (who is more than 14 years old) had problems with arthritis this past winter. Â She has still enjoyed going on walks, but she's staying closer to the house. When she does wander, getting her back to the house can take a little extra time. Wendy has always been anÂ independent, confident and high-spirited gal. Â  In the 13 years we've had her, she has never really seemed to want or need our help. Â However, this seems to have changed in the past several weeks. Â Wendy will now wait at the bottom of the steps and won't stop barking until we come to help her up the steps and into the house. However nearly every single time when we start to help Wendy, she'll go up the steps herself. Â She'll then look back at us as if she's saying 'never mind, I'll do it myself!' Â  Todd seems to have adopted this same 'I'll do it myself' attitude. Â When he wants something off the counter, like the green ball, he's decided that he'll just (try to) get it himself. Â I guess he's been taking lessons from Wendy!

title: Monday:  A Piece of Cake!

title: It's Going to be a Better Day

title: Hope and Luck
text: Today was again on the chilly side with the highs barely edging above 60Â (16Â Â°C). Â Tack on the gusty winds, and it continues to feel like....well...March.Â  The tree pollen count has soaredÂ to a record high set in 1998.Â I have to admit to not minding the cool so much, but with the combination ofÂ pollen and the dogs shedding my allergies have really given me a goodÂ punch, leaving me with a migraine headache.Adding to my headache is the thought of replacing our heating and cooling system in the house. Â We knew last year it was on borrowed time and I have held onto some hope that it could once again be fixed. Â Today a repairman came and gave us a fatal diagnosis. Â When he told us he would like someone else to come and look at it to give us a final estimate on its replacement, it made my headache worse and left me seeing only dollar signs. Â All I can do is hope to win the 'Mega Millions' lottery that is now up to over 540 million dollars. Â I only have to pick all the numbers correctly and buy a ticket. Â I think I should just save my dollar and put it towards the new heat pump--I'm just not that lucky....Â But you know what? Â I feel lucky enough!! Â ~Toby~

title: No Stopping for Weather
text: It's now feeling like March because we had aÂ cold frosty start to our day.Â  IÂ turned the heat back on last night just to get the chill out of the air.Â For Wednesday,Â the warmth is forecasted to return.Â  This unpredictability of the weather makes me feel likeÂ Mother Nature may need some kind of an intervention to get our seasons back on track.Â Â But whateverÂ is happening withÂ the weather,Â it's not stoppingÂ one of my favorite birds, the Eastern Phoebe, from building its nest above our garage door. It's also not slowing downÂ the new growth onÂ the Forsythia bushes. TheÂ blossoms are falling off as this years leaves start to appear.Â Â  The weather also doesn't stop Lucas from doing what he does best, watch CC.Â  Except in this picture, I think she's watching him!In any weather,Â theÂ antics of an energetic puppy named Todd don't stop either.Â Â Except in this case, CarrieAnne's look did!Â  Enjoy your Tuesday!

title: Out of Sync and Unusual
text: Off to work on Friday in clouds of fog. Â I've decided that driving in heavy fog is like driving with a blindfold on. Especially on our road because of the narrow and steep curves. Â The fog gave way to bright sun and the warmest day of the season. Â Leaves are starting to appear on the Forsythia bushes. When I arrived home from work, outside it all seemed as it should be. Â But inside, it wasn't. When I went inside, the dogs seemed agitated about something, and I know it may sound silly, but I remember thinking that they seemed relieved that I was home. Â Todd who is crated during the day was practically hysterical and he wouldn't stop barking. Â I got everyone outside, and CarrieAnne went over to the neighboring field and just stood there and wouldn't come back. The dogs really seemed out of sync and kept coming to me for reassurance. Â We played a round of frisbee and I took a few pictures. Â Eventually the dogs seemed relaxed and content. Â  It wasn't until we came back inside that I realized that in 3 different rooms, the screens were off the open windows. With such nice weather I have been leaving them open during the day; someone had obviously tried to get into the house through one of them while we were gone. While we joke that the only way the dogs would hurt anyone is if they fell over them, they still would have all barked at anyone that came near the house. Â I think this does explain why the dogs seemed out of sorts when I got home. Â I called our dog-walker who said 'everything and the dogs seemed fine' when she came. Â Even though there was no break-in, nothing missing etc., at her urging that it should be reported, I phoned our Sheriff's office. They said they would patrol our road and for us to take note of anything or anyone unusual. Â I feel really safe where we live, but I do take this seriously and will of course make sure windows etc., are closed and locked when we're away. Â But I hope that with all of our dogs, we'll be the only 'unusual' thing on our road.

title: It's Good to be Home!
text: I mentioned in my previous post about it being an exhausting week. After a good night sleep, and having nothing scheduled to do today, it has felt really good to be at home. Â I actually felt energized so I decided to tackle a couple of cleaning and organizing projects. Â It's amazing how much stuff one can accumulate. Â How does that happen??I contacted the rescue today about Lucas. His recovery from this last surgery has been pretty uneventful. Â He is feeling really well and his energy level is up! Â When he came to us, he only ate to live, now he shows his true Golden personality, and lives to eat! Â But I have decided that a new 'forever home' should be found for him. Â While we adore Lucas, he is way to obsessed with CC, our cat. Â I have no worries about his hurting her, however I don't think that Lucas's constant chasing and bothering CC is fair to her. Â He's a really nice boy and will make a wonderful addition to someone's home -- That doesn't have cats! Â  Â  ~CC on the front porch being watched by Lucas~Our sunny afternoon has ended with our taking a walk and playing ball with Todd. Â Days like this are really fun for me ....~Perfect Air Time!~Â I think they're fun forÂ Todd too!Â Enjoy your evening!!~Our Boy Sammy~

title: Thank-You Todd!
text: Despite the beautiful weather, it is a stressful start to my week. Â I'll spare you the drama and just say that I came home this evening, exhausted. Â Carl is working late so that left me to care for the dogs alone. Todd is of course the one with the most energy. Â You'll remember in my last post his very favorite toy, 'red ball' was missing. Â We've moved furniture, searched in places that there's no way it could be, but we've been unable to find it. But tonight, throwing a tennis ball for him did the trick to wear him out. Once all the dogs had been loved and fed I decided that I was going to lay down for a few minutes. Â Things were quiet in the house, and it was just starting to get dark. I must have dozed off because Todd woke me up when he jumped on the bed and dropped something next to me. Â When I looked at him, it was easy to see that he was really excited about something, and he was wagging his tail. Â I put my hand on what he had dropped and I was stunned--It was the red-ball!!! Â Of course I had to chuckle because I'd love to know just where in the world he found it! Â Even though I'll never know that answer, I do know that its reappearance gave me a little needed grin at the end of my long stress filled day! Â Thank-you Todd!!

title: In A Fog
text: Saturday morning we wake to a heavy fog. Â We take the dogs for a walk before the sun burns off the mist. Walking in the fog is one of my favorite experiences.Â I think the closeness of the fog creates surprises because even on familiar paths you can see something new....This morning I noticed freshly spun spider webs all around that seemed to just glisten. Â The bright yellow of the forsythia seems to glow against the grayness. Â Â Â I also notice on mornings like today there is the lack of an echo.Â Even the sound of the gravel crunching under our feet as we walk down the drive way didn't seem to go far.The only thing that seems to have 'gone far' is Todd's favorite toy, red ball. Â Its been a really tough toy that he has played and played and played with, and not chewed up. We have looked everywhere and it appears to be nowhere. Â Maybe it's lost in the fog...

title: The Day-Care Dilemma
text: Incredible - There were 400 record highs set or tied across the US yesterday. Â Some of the warmest weather so early in the season EVER in parts of the Midwest. Â And the warmth is predicted to last for several more days. Â TheÂ continued streak of warm weather means the famed cherry blossoms in  the nation's capital will now peak a week earlier than originally predicted. Â All around us, trees are blooming, birds are singing, the dogs are shedding and my allergies couldn't be worse--I am really enjoying every minute of it! Â -Tulip-Magnolia tree blooming near my office-This morning I took Todd for another evaluation at a second-day care. Â The place I took Todd last Thursday is located in the town where I live. Â Along with boarding dogs, they do have a day care. Â It's an older facility, clean and well kept. They keep the dogs on a regular schedule with play in the morning and are kenneled for an hour at noon. Â Weather permitting, in the afternoon they play in the outside areas. In the heat of summer, they will sometimes set up pools for the dogs to cool off in. Â The day ends between 3 and 4 o'clock in the afternoon and the dogs are crated until the owners come to pick them up. Â Knowing that Todd would be crated or kenneled for 3-4 hours a day was something I didn't really like. Â There were a couple of other things that I didn't like, so I didn't make a commitment about his coming there. Â Where we went this morning is the total flip-side of the first. Â It's a 'Pet Resort' and that's exactly what it is, a resort. Â The automatic doors welcome you into the large designer lobby with a hotel-styled front desk. Â There is a gift shop, a pool and an agility course. Â While your cat or dog enjoy their stay, you can check up on them anytime because there are live pet-cams in each 'suite' where they are staying, and in the day-care as well. There is a restaurant style kitchen with a cook to prepare any special meals that your pet may require while there. Â And when they're all worn out from playing, they can have a spa-treatment to ease those tired paws.Todd felt right at home in the posh surroundings and turned on his charm as he was 'evaluated' in the day-care. Â I watched from a viewing area. Â They introduced all the dogs to him and towards the end, when a Golden was brought in they took an immediate liking to one another and started playing right away. Â Of course since he lives with so many Goldens, I just thought it was just because of that. Â But I found out afterwards it was one of his pals from the other day care where he used to go--Who said dogs don't remember other dogs? Â There's not much to not like about this place. However my reluctance is only because they have very large play-groups of 35-50 dogs each day. Â While their dog-to-people-ratio is appropriate, I felt it was too many dogs, because they do not have divide groups of dogs by age or size. I have a concern about the Great Danes, Mastiff's and very large dogs being around Todd.Â So, onto the next day care which Todd goes to on Wednesday. Â It was recommended to me by a friend, so I have no idea what to expect, other than it's a smaller facility. Â But as I write this, I have to wonder, am I putting too much thought into all of this?

title: Those March Days
text: Charles Dickens perfectly described our weather when he wrote,Â "It was one of those March days when the sun shines hot and the wind blows cold:Â   when it is summer in the light, and winter in the shade.â€ Â There have been times when I've forgotten that it's early spring and on chilly mornings like today, I'm reminded of it. Â But I'm not the only one enjoying the warming temperatures. Â I've seen the turtles sunning themselves on a log, and a snake (!!!) on its way somewhere that I hope is far away. Lucas is doing really well and it goes without saying that I'm glad that the surgeries are behind him. As you may (or may not) know, a dog has 42 teeth. Â People have 32 which includes the wisdom teeth. Â Lucas has had 38 removed. Â It's overwhelming, at least for me, to think about that number. But it had to be done, and I'm thankful that he has been able to have the treatment that he needed. Â You may recall that Lucas's surgeries were not inexpensive and the total cost has been around $5000. Â I was told this week that all of his dental work has been paid for from a special fund-raiser that the rescue held for him and other dogs have expensive medical needs. This weekend you'll find me basking in the warmth of the spring sun, and in the reminder of the kindness and generosity of people who have helped to make a difference for Lucas. ~Enjoy your Saturday!!~~Charlie~

title: Lucas:  Flying or Driving?
text: This morning Lucas is resting comfortably. Â His surgery on Wednesday didn't take nearly as long as the first, but unfortunately it was not  without its little glitches along the way. Â When I dropped Lucas off in the morning, he was anxious and seemed nervous, and that continued while waiting for the surgery to begin. Â For some dogs, this may not be too much of a problem. Â However I've thought that Lucas has a bit of laryngeal paralysis because his breathing when he's excited becomes really loud and raspy. Â When he had problems breathing before his surgery, the dentist took an x-ray to look at his  heart and lungs, which were thankfully okay. Â And since Lucas was under anesthetic, the doctor took a peek at hisÂ throat via a scope, whichÂ confirmed thatÂ the folds of his larynx are not opening and closing as they should. Â Lucas's breathing  problems continued afterÂ he woke up and an injection of Acepromazine which is a tranquilizer, was given to help keep him calm. Â Needless to say, he was pretty loopy, wobbly and glassy-eyed when I picked him up. Â He was of course that way the entire evening. Â ~Loopy-Lucas~On the way homeÂ I made a really quick stop with Lucas and when IÂ came out of the store, he was sitting in the  drivers seat of myÂ van.Â  He's never gotten into one of the seats beforeÂ andÂ wish  I'd had my camera becauseÂ he was quite a sight sitting up in the seat but with  hisÂ head on the window and his eyes all glassy and half opened. Â I guess he was so 'drugged up' he thought he could drive? Â I  guess if he'd been a person he would have thought he could fly--Maybe Lucas  thought that too, who knows? Â ~Lucas?~Its been a hurried and very tiring week with very little spare time. Â This morning I'm taking Todd to check out a new day-care. Â I don't know much about the place other than it's an indoor and outdoor facility and has a pool. Â Afterwards, I get to do my favorite thing which is to be home. Â I'm really sorry I've not been able to read your blogs this week and so I'm Â really looking forward catching up on your news! Â Enjoy your Thursday!!

title: Conversational Snow
text: The week as always is off to a running start. On the schedule tomorrow is Lucas's second surgery to have the remaining un-salvageableÂ teeth removed. I've been assured that the length of time that he's to be under the anesthetic will be shorter than last. Â I'm hopeful that will be the case, and everything will go well. Winter has also returned. Â Today it's bright and clear but we are having a blast of cold wind and temperatures below freezing, reminding me again how stubborn Old Man Winter can be about leaving. Â Yesterday we had what the weathermen call 'conversationalÂ snow.,' Â I've never heard that term before but it apparently means that it amounts to nothing more than a conversation. Â Where do they get these terms? I was told yesterday that Todd's day-camp where he's been going for several months is closing. Â I was so disappointed to be told that. Â They were a top-notch place that truly made a difference for my shy, but energetic and playful boy. Â It hit all the notes as far as care of the dogs, playtime, nap-time (can you believe they had down-time for all the dogs?) and the staff was the best. While its only been open for less than a year, apparently their closing has something to do with the landlord of the building.Â  I've decided that he wasÂ obviously not a dog-lover, because he made it impossible and very expensive for them to continue to be in business. Â I really want Todd to continue to play with other dogs and be around different people. Â So once again my search for the perfect place will begin.

title: Through the Briars and the Brambles
text: I've been feeling really restless the last several days. Â I've decided that it's either spring-fever, or too much sugar. Â But I've had real problems staying focused on any one thing in particular. Â So Carl and I took the dogs for a walk yesterday afternoon. Â As you can see in the new header picture, it was a beautiful day of blue skies and sunshine.Since we've not seen anyone new or any changes to the property in back of us, we headed in that direction. Â Carl was about half way up the hill when all of the sudden Josh who was not on a leash started his excited barking and howling as he ran into the woods after some deer he'd seen. In the picture below on the left, Toby is looking at Josh the moment he started running.It didn't take but a moment to lose sight of him. Carl had the dogs on a leash so that left me to get Josh. Â I decided that I'd cut him off on the other side. Â Of course I am not as fast as either the deer or Josh, but I caught sight of him going into the woods on the other side of the clearing. Â He had been totally outrun by the deer, and he had also gone totally deaf never looking back as he started the next leg of his adventure. Â I went into the woods to get him and became tangled in the briars. Â As I freed myself, I kept calling to Josh and a miracle happened, he regained his hearing and came to me, all sparkly eyed and smiles!!~Josh after his adventure~Of course I didn't scold Josh for running off, but praised him for coming back. Â On the way home the words to the old country Â tune "The Battle of New Orleans" which is a traditional hillbilly tune by Johnny Horton tumbled through my head,Yeah they ran through the briars and they ran through the bramblesAnd they  ran through the bushes where a rabbit couldn't goThey ran so fast that the  hounds couldn't catch 'emÂ On down the Mississippi to the Gulf of Mexico...Now, even a day later, I can't get rid of it...Finally my mind is focusing on something.

title: The Rainbow and the Rabbit
text: My day started with a rainbow, and has ended with several places flooded on our road because of pouring rain, all day. Â Coming home in the dark was a little tricky because there is water across the road in several places and I couldn't really see how deep it was. Â Our driveway looks like a stream, and our backyard is a mud-lovers paradise.Todd's day started out with an encounter with a rabbit whose ear became a fun play-toy for him. Getting it away from him proved to be a little challenge. I chased him through the house, and outside. Corrections and trying to bribe him with a treat fell on deaf ears. Â There's no way to catch him; Todd is just way too fast and way too quick! Â Then I remembered 'blue squeaky ball.' Â I grabbed it out of the drawer and Todd immediately dropped the ear, and came running to me, anxious for his treasured toy. I picked up the rabbit's ear and put it with the other one that has also come off...Oh, did I forget to mention that Todd didn't have a 'real' rabbit ear but one from a garden statue?

title: Today It's About Toby
text: Today was all about Toby. Â He was past due for his six-month senior wellness exam, so off we went to the vet and to spend the morning together. Â The assistant that took us back is new to the practice and I'd not met her before. Â Looking at Toby and his portly figure, she felt the need to lecture me on his diet and nails that were a little longer than they should be. Â I told her that Toby was 'full figured' when he came to us, and I thought that he looked so much better. Â I even pointed out that he was almost 4 pounds lighter than he was when he was last seen. Â I also remarked on how much stamina he has, and that he even manages to run a little now. I don't think she really heard what I said because the scolding continued. Â Toby and I politely sat there, pretending to listen, but daydreaming of what we would do afterwards.Â Because of scheduling conflicts, this was the first time that my usual vet was meeting Toby. Â She has taken such wonderful care of all of our dogs, and also Toby's companion, Bubba, so she was anxious to meet him. Â We talked very briefly about his weight and moved on, discussing how he was adjusting to life without Bubba. Â She knew I had been worried about him when Bubba first passed away. Â I think how Bubba felt was mirrored in how Toby felt and acted too. Â But he has started toÂ blossomÂ in the last month doing things I've not seen him do before. He really seems happy and relaxed. Â We left the office feeling the same way.

title: A No Regrets Friday
text: Feeling like I still needed some distance from my job, I decided yesterday to take another day off from work. Â At the start of the day, I watched the dogs and realized that they were feeling the same way about things that I do. Â Charlie looks, just how I was feeling.... I only had one thing that I really had to do today. Â Otherwise the day was one with noÂ â€œto doâ€ or  â€œmust doâ€ lists. The only thing that Lucas had on his 'to do and must do' list was to stalk the cat. Â I've pretty much done what I wanted ...Todd did what he wanted to as well; and that was to dig a hole. Â Â And I've not felt guilty about my choice of not doing anything. Â Todd, being a Scottie, didn't feel guilty about digging the hole... Â The day is coming to an end, and looking back at it, I have no regrets. Â Lucas, Â I know, has no regrets stalking the cat...All of us feel relaxed and refreshed! Â ~CarrieAnne~Whatever your weekend brings, I hope it's an enjoyable one!!

title: A Busy Day for Lucas and Todd
text: My day off switched this week to today. Â So I've had to remind myself all day that it's Wednesday, I need to work on Thursday, and Friday isn't as close as I'd like it to be!Â Actually, it was nice to be off today because I had a bad day at work Tuesday. Â I've needed the day to forget all about everything and enjoy a beautiful day of blue skies, sunshine and lots of warmth!~Toby~Lucas did have to go to the dentist for a post-op check. Â The dentist was really Â happy with how everything has healed and he has given Lucas the 'all clear' for the next surgery in two weeks. Â He is now free to rub his face on the floor and have crunchy treats if he'd like!Todd went to the groomers today. Â I think the groomer clipped him a little short, but that's okay. Â I'm remembering when I have had my own hair cut too short, it grows--I know Todd's will too! He didn't seem to mind or notice. Â He was more bothered by the chiffon bow! Â  Todd was really worn out from the day! Â I hope you're not too worn out from your week and all is well with you!

title: Gypped Again!
text: ~Toby~Say it with me....PFFT!Â  I have once again fallen victim to the  weathermen's promise of snow.Â  So strong is my desire for the white stuff that I was  willing to believe their original forecast. Â Even when the hype for this latest  storm started on Friday, the system that was going to bring 'significant accumulation' hadn't formed and was still over the state of Texas, I just knew this time they were right. Â Their  reports were thatÂ convincing. Â Just to make sure,Â even though the sun was shining and there wasn't a cloud  in the sky, the dogs did a little snow dance.Â ~Toby doing a snow-dance~And Todd dug a couple of holes. Â Okay, maybe that's not part of the snow-dance ritual, but I guess he figured, 'why not?' Â In the end, we were gypped again.Â Maybe next time the dogs, and especially Mother Nature and the weathermen, will get it  right.Â  But when 3 things intersect, isn't that like the Bermuda  Triangle? Â ~Toby~Speaking of the Bermuda Triangle, the blue squeaky ball from yesterday's post that  brought Todd hours and hours of fun and enjoyment, disappeared under mysterious  circumstances.Â  If you see it, don't worry about returning it. Â Please keep it, I know you'll give it a good home.

title: Who Will Outlast the Other?
text: It's Saturday morning. Â All is calm. Â The sun is out and it's supposed to be a gorgeous day. Â The dogs have all had a good walk and been given their breakfast. Â They areÂ settlingÂ in for a quiet relaxing morning. Â However one sound has been playing over and over and over (!!!!) again since before it was daylight. (play video)I'm thinking this is going to be like a 3 way contest. Â With me as contestant number 1--Will I be able to listen to the endlessÂ squeakingÂ all day? Â Contestant number 2, The Ball--Will it survive the rigorous workout? Â Contestant number 3, Todd--How long will the ball keep his interest? Â For some reason, my money is on the Scottie. Â What do you think?

title: Making Room for Change
text: Today is a day that I've been dreading for well over a year. It's the day that the 10 acresÂ directly in back of us is sold, and a house willÂ be built. Â I have to admit, that I have never been very good at dealing with changes. Â And in thinking about this change, for me, it'sÂ all a bit unsettling.Â  Even though the property doesn't belong to us, with its sale,Â I feel as if we are losing a part of what I have loved about living in the country.Â Â I really feelÂ a strong connection to my surroundings and treasure the memories we have made with the dogs in the 4 years that we've lived on Mountain Road.Â Â Knowing that we'll no longer to beÂ able to walk them any time we'd likeÂ up the hill to runÂ in the open fields to explore as we enjoy the beautiful views has me feeling a bit of sadness.This feeling of attachment to where we live hasÂ been magnified as I have combed throughÂ my counties website where there are aerial pictures showingÂ our property datingÂ back to 1957. At that time, our landÂ was part of a large farm which still exists today and is owned by the same family.Â Â Our house now stands is in the middle lower portion of the picture below. ~1957 View~This next pictureÂ was taken inÂ 2002, and it shows our house andÂ barn.Â In looking at all the photos, there was one thing that stuck in my mind.Â  ThisÂ was thatÂ despite theÂ county that I live in being one of theÂ fastest growing in the country, our road has changed very little over the years.Â  ~2002 View~As I mulled over theÂ upcoming changes, a thought occurred to meÂ which was thatÂ just as 'room' was made for our house, I knowÂ there is room for another.Â  But it still makes me sad to think about...~2010 View~

title: Winter Dampness
text: Another typical hurried week of work and traffic and things like... Â Getting Todd to day-camp, and ...~Todd at day-camp~Of course taking care of the other dogs...Lucas continues to do really well. Â He's now able to eat his entire meal of 'porridge' without our helping him. Â There is still some swelling around his nose, but it doesn't appear to be sensitive to the touch, so I don't think it's anything to be concerned about. I've been able to look inside his mouth a little and from what I can see, the tissue is healing nicely. Â  Â  Â ~Lucas~As is always the case at this point in the week, I feel pretty drained.Â It's not helping that today we have clouds and rain. Â I'mÂ trying to avoid the dampness and cold that seems to set into your  bones this time of year. Â This morning I crossed the Potomac into Maryland and I thought that the river really had a winter stillness about it. Â It's days like this, it's good to be home!

title: The Word of the Day
text: Our word of the day is 'blustery.'Â  Our wanna-be-blizzard that brought hardly  any snow did bring with it a nearly intolerable blast of winter! Â High gusty winds have kept our temperatures  below freezing all day. Â ~Todd~But the forecast is for the warm spring like weather to return as we head into the first part of the week. Â ~Charlie~Looking at the calendar, it's easy enough to see that February is quickly slipping away along withÂ any hope I have for a good snowfall. Â But there is still two more weeks, so I won't give up yet. Â ~CarrieAnne~Today has been a quiet day that is being spent inside where it's warm. Â I think I'll throw an extra dog on the bed and take a nap! Â I hope you're enjoying your Sunday!!

title: He's Listening
text: A small amount of snow at the start of our day, melted by lunchtime. Â But I'll take whatever we get and try to be happy with it. Â Forecasted to come by the end of the weekend is a blast of cold air from Canada that will send ourÂ temperatures plunging. Â Listening to the weathermen, because they seem to know the temperatures to come instead of a snowfall, I've gotten out my warmest scarf and gloves. Â We'll see if I end up needing them. Â  I continue to be very grateful for all the healing thoughts you've sent for Lucas! Â He continues to do pretty well, but his face is still pretty swollen. Â If there is any problem we're having with him, it's his habit of rubbing his face along the rugs. Â I wasÂ specificallyÂ told by the dentist to not allow him to do anything like that because it could pull out the sutures. Â To try and 'protect' his face, I've put a small e-collar on him. Â He became really subdued and kept his head down when he realized it wasn't going to come off. Â I told Lucas there was no shame in his having to wear the 'cone of shame.' Â I think he believed me, because he didn't object to it nearly as much after I said that. Its been my experience that Golden Retrievers will believe just about anything you say to them...I am finding that Scottish Terriers do too. Todd really loves being outside. Â But I told him that his digging in the yard means he's not going to get to play outside by himself for the time being.Todd responded by running off with my house-slipper, the dishtowel he pulled off the counter, and whatever he could grab out of the clothes basket. Â At least he's listening...

title: Better Than Expected
text: Everything went well for Lucas yesterday and I am contributing it to your good thoughts and prayers that you sent for him! Â The work began on the right side of his mouth. Â It was originally thought that all of his teeth would have to be removed. Â However with Lucas underÂ anesthetic, the dentist was able to do a more thorough exam and it was decided that about 5 of his teeth on the right wereÂ salvageable; but in the end 15 (!!) were removed. Â He will have another surgery in about a month to do the left side to remove and save about the same number. From the time Lucas came to us, he's not been able to eat a kibble based diet. Â Instead he eats a freeze-dried food mix (called Grandma Lucy's) that when warm water is added, becomes like a porridgeÂ with meat and vegetables. He likes it really well, and is eating with no problems. Â As you can see in the pictures, his mouth is swollen from the work and the sutures--However he's up and around this morning and is even doing a little bit of stalking of the cat. Â There are a few hurdles to get over as far as healing, but I think he's going to be okay!

title: Today is the Day
text: As is always, always how it goes, the week is off to a running start. After today it (hopefully) turns a corner and slows down. I called the animal shelter yesterday and the black lab that I picked up on Saturday was reunited with his family--Good news!! We are also having a birthday at our office today. Â My co-worker and her family really enjoy the outdoors and camping so of course s'mores over the campfire are a favorite. Â With that in mind, I have made her s'more bars instead of a cake. Because I've never tried making them before, (at least not in the kitchen!) I did a preliminary taste test. title: Gone to the Dogs!
text: My weekend was all about dogs! Â It started out by my finding a black lab on the highway. Â A couple of people were stopped trying to catch him. Â I opened my van door to get a leash and he jumped in. When I looked around, everyone had suddenly disappeared, and I was left with this rambunctious happy boy who was wondering what the next chapter of his adventure would be. Â Not knowing exactly what do to next, besides take him home with me, I took him to our county animal control--Probably not what he had in mind. Â But he was in great shape and had 2 collars on, but no tags so my hope is that someone will be looking for him. Â Just in case they aren't, to make sure nothing happens to him, I put my name down as a possible adopter for him. Â And just to cover another base, so his owners know where to look, I later put up posters in the area saying that a young black lab had been found and taken to animal control. Â Paws crossed that he finds his way back home!I have to admit that usually I take a found dog home with me and hope I can find the owners. Â But I was on my way to our friends house to take pictures of their new addition, Parker. I have to admit that I caught puppy fever all over again! Â But when I'm reminded of all of the things that a really young puppy needs, I'm thankful that our puppy, Todd, who is now almost 10 months old, is past all of that! We had little bit of wet, sloppy snow as the day was ending. Â It didn't last long, but the dogs, especially Todd, enjoyed each and every flake that he could catch or chase. Finally, thank-you for sending good thoughts for Lucas! Â I heard from the rescue that they have approved his treatment! Â He'll have his first surgery this Wednesday. Â Until then, his stalking and love affair with our cat, CC, continues.

title: What Goes Around!
text: I received a text message in the early morning hours. Â It was from a co-worker and she said that she has apparently gotten the same thing that I had on Tuesday, and she won't be into work today. Â She asked if I would please cover for her at the front desk. Â If you read my last post, you'll hope as I do, that if her 'illness' is anything like mine was (NOT), that she enjoys her Friday. Â I hope you enjoy your Friday too!!~Lucas~Â **No word from the board of directors of the rescue on Lucas's dental treatment. Â I expect and hope to hear this weekend.

title: Just Not Feeling It
text: Despite the sunny spring weather and unusually warm temperatures, Iâ€™m really having a blah week. I'd taken Tuesday morning off work because I had to take Lucas to see the dentist. Â Because I didn't feel like going into work and because there was only one patient scheduled in the afternoon, I decided to just take the rest of the day off, thinking of it as a needed 'mental Â health day.' Â My co-workers and the doctor must have known why I took the afternoon off because no one asked how I was feeling Â yesterday. Lucas's appointment went as expected. Â The dentist, who I really liked, agrees that all of his teeth should be removed. Â There is so much recession, decay, bone loss and infection around his teeth that nothing can be done to save them. The treatment plan is for Lucas to have 2 surgeries to limit the amount of time he will have to be under anesthetic. Â The first surgery will be to remove the worst teeth, clean everything really well and treat what will most certainly be sinus exposures from the extractions. Â The second surgery will hopefully be much easier, shorter and would be done in about 4-6 weeks. Â I've scheduled the first surgery for next Wednesday. Â However the board of the rescue has to approve the treatment and its cost which will be around $5000. (aboutÂ Â£3,200 orÂ â‚¬ 3,804) Â I spoke to the medical coordinator of the rescue last evening, and there were a few questions from board members about alternative and less expensive ways to treat his periodontal disease. Unfortunately there aren't any and it needs to be and should be done. Â I feel confident that the board, in the end will agree to pay for Lucas to have this treatment. ~Lucas~Punxsutawney Phil On another note, today Punxsutawney Phil, theÂ world's smallest and furriest weather forecaster who holds perhaps the greatest responsibility of any groundhog, emerged from hisÂ burrow on Gobbler's  Knob in Punxsutawney Pennsylvania saw his shadow andÂ predicted six more weeks of winter. Â I guess a winter with no snow, unusually warm temperatures and the early arrival of daffodils won't be too bad! ~Toby~

title: Good Weather--Good Weekend!!
text: Our weekend so far could not be more enjoyable! Â On Saturday, warmth and bright sun allowed us to enjoy some extended time outdoors. Â Despite the high winds, the dogs enjoyed a good round of frisbee. Â I enjoyed a round of taking pictures with my new camera. Â I'm still getting the hang of it because there is so much to learn! ~Josh~Toby had a round of rolling in the grass...In the evening we met up with good friends for dinner. Â They are welcoming a new family member next week and are borrowing a few of our 'puppy things.' Their little boy will quickly outgrow them, but are needed none the less. Â Below is a picture from when they went to meet the puppies. Â  For dinner we ate a beautiful restaurant called 'Clydes of Willow Creek.' Â The food is amazing and the setting is stunning. Â The restaurant itself has a story to tell. Â A restaurant group purchased a series of antique heavy timber structures, dating back to as far as 1780, that had been destined for the wrecking ball. These structures were photographed, labeled, disassembled, preserved, and stored for later restoration.Â Â These four original antique buildings, have now been connected, and restored and represents the classic American Inn. Â It boostsÂ paintings of the hunt country, classic carriages and buggies and early American artwork along with other reproduced ells from the early days of our country.Included within theÂ restaurant is aÂ structure known as 'TheÂ Chandler Barn, which was built c.1885. This amazing Victorian beauty hasÂ two elliptical cupolas, and was originally built for hay, feed, and stock. (The below picture is taken from their website)It really is a lovely place to enjoy with our friends and spend a Saturday evening! Â I hope you've had a good weekend too!~Sheba~

title: The Loss and the Rediscovery
text: Growing up, my mostly stay-at-home mom cooked almost every meal from scratch. Of course there were occasional meals out, but for the most part, everything was homemade. And in thinking about it, I don't rememberÂ eating many pre-made meals  at all and when we did,Â it was a real treat!Â  But that was my Mom. AndÂ even though I enjoy cooking I'm just not an everyday-from-scratch-cook. With a busy hectic schedule, especially during the week, I rely  on frozen or prepared food and a microwave oven.Â  Unfortunately on Sunday,Â our  microwaveÂ stopped working.Â Â I thought we'd be just fine.Â  But I found thatÂ when  I would open the cupboards to look for something to make for dinner, there would only be unopened cans and boxes staring blankly back at me. Â I was a bit bewildered because I couldn't cook or thaw anything that required the use of the microwave. Â In my mind everything in my freezer was now going to waste and collectingÂ freezer burn.Â   Then there was the moment when IÂ realizedÂ that we were not even able toÂ have a  favorite treat--microwaveÂ popcorn. Oh the perplexity of it all.....!!...~Lucas~Â But then, something unexpected happened...I rekindled my love affair  with.....the stove-top!Â Â Yes, you read that right, in the midst of my despair over  not having a microwave, I discovered thatÂ the multi-functional stove-top can revitalize leftovers with the twist of a knob and heat up soup in minutes. Â Then there was an unexpected bonus when I discovered itÂ can even make a grilled  cheese sandwich! Â Okay, I already knew it could do that--But what I did realize that using the stove-top is like so many other good things in life that just take a little time. ~Todd at day-camp this week~As you can tell, all is well here this week at 'Golden Pines' and I hope it is for you too! Â I look forward to catching up with your blogs today, after I buy some 'Jiffy Pop Popcorn!' Â  ...do they still sell Jiffy Pop??~Wendy~

title: What's In a Name
text: Borrowing the words from an 'Eagles' tune, 'the sky won't snow and the sun won't shine,' pretty much sums up our weekend as the cold weather and clouds seemed content to stay around. Â It's times like this, when we're home and its cold that I start looking on the internet for something to bake. Â One website that I looked at had cookie recipes that sounded promising. I don't know about you, but for me, there's something about having a name in a recipe that tells you immediately that whatever it is, it's going to be good! Â At least this is what I think when I see a recipe with 'My Grandmother's' or 'Mrs ---' in its name. Â I just feel like I should automatically trust the recipe, and make it right then. Â I also feel this way about church cookbooks. Â But this is exactly what I thought about a cookie recipe I came across called 'Mrs. Siggs Snickerdoodles.' Â I don't know who Mrs. Sigg is, but she she had a pretty good (and easy) recipe for snickerdoodles! Â Because I am a bit of a chocolate person, especially on days like today, it takes a lot for me to make something without chocolateÂ in it somewhere. Â But I made them yesterday and for whatever reason, we just didn't seem to have enough, so I baked them again today. Â It just seemed like the thing to do. Â There were no complaints from Carl. ~CarrieAnne~When I wasn't baking, I tried to spend as much time as I could outside with the dogs. They really do enjoy even the smallest amount of snow. Â However, I'm really hoping for more. ~Sheba~But like the cookies, what we have will just have to do for now. Â Its been good enough for the weekend. Â I hope you've had a 'good enough' weekend too!

title: Another Non Weather Event
text: Ahead of what was to be a snow and ice storm, all of the errands and shopping were done on Friday so the day could be spent at home. Â As I should have predicted, the event which the weathermen had touted beforehand as 'possiblyÂ significant' did not occur. With temperatures hovering around freezing and slick roads we didn't want to venture out and have just spent a very quiet day at home. However, the lens it came with doesn't have the 'zoom' that my old one has. The ones below are straight out of the new camera with no editing. Â So farÂ I like the crisper close up pictures when the lighting isn't that good. But I have plenty of time, and plenty of things to take pictures of. Â  ~Todd~I hope you're having a good weekend!! Â ~Charlie~

title: It's Thursday and It's Okay
text: For many reasons it's always such a relief to me when Thursday unceremoniously arrives. Â The hectic and exhaustive pace of getting up early, getting home late and 3 full days at work are behind me. Â Ahead is my day off and the weekend after a short work day on Friday. Â My life and my time become mine again.Lucas saw the vet this week and all the tests results show that he's in good health--Except for his teeth. Â My vet commented that she has never seen a dogs mouth in such terrible condition and with so much active infection. Â A thorough exam of his teeth was difficult to do because he was whining and crying when she pulled back his lips. Â Lucas has been referred to a veterinary dentist because he is unfortunately going to have to have all or almost all of his teeth taken out. Â I've called for an appointment and he won't be able to be seen until the 31st. Â Until then he is on antibiotics and pain medication. Lucas isÂ getting along well with the other dogs and is right in with the crowd for treats (which he swallows whole) and mealtime. Â It has been a bit of trial and error but I have finally found the right combination of a dehydrated food, mixed with canned that he likes and is able to eat with just a little help from me. Â All in all, he really has settled in very nicely this week! Â He will come and sit next to me and put both front paws on my leg, look at me and wag his tail. Â Needless to say, it melts my heart. Â ButÂ I think he knows he's going to be okay. ~Todd & Lucas~Enjoy your Thursday!

title: Family Treasures
text: My last Uncle passed away this week at the age of 90. Â Even though I'm very sad about his loss, there is comfort in knowing that he had a good long life. And even despite a few health problems, he was lucky to be able to continue living at home with his wife (my Aunt of course) of more than 60 years. Â My Uncle's passing reminded me that he and my two remaining Aunts are truly a connection to other family members, my past, my childhood and my Mother. Â They are what I consider our 'family treasures.' Â With the arrival of Lucas this week, I have thought a lot about 'family treasures.' Â He is as you know a senior dog, about 12 or 13 years old. Â To many, Lucas would be considered a family treasure. Â One that would be looked after, worried about and cared for. Â But he wasn't...Or was he?Â I was contacted by someone from the rescue that Lucas's owner had come forward late on Friday to claim him. Â The shelter contacted the rescue and asked about perhaps returning him. Â I discussed at length with the volunteer from the rescue about Lucas's physical condition--He's almost totally deaf, thin, and as mentioned, his teeth are in terrible condition (!!), and he's also not neutered. Â While he may have been loved, I don't believe that he has been cared for or worried about. Â This was confirmed when the shelter manager said that the explanation given about why he wasn't looked for earlier was because he was an outdoor dog and 'would be gone for several days, but always came home.' Â The owner also said that Lucas 'knew about cars and knew to stay out of the street.' Â My problem with that is that Lucas came from the inner-city of Baltimore, not the safest place for anyone on the street, two or four legged.However the question remained, should Lucas be returned? Â He was held at the shelter for the required 5 days. Â The rescue legally owns him. Â However, when there are extenuating circumstances and owners come forward afterwards, there have been times when dogs have been returned. Â But all things such as the owners explanation, the condition of the Golden and the life they would be returning to are all considered and discussed.In Lucas's case, because of the extensive cost, he probably won't receive the needed vet care. Â He also would probably be returning to a life on the street, or maybe even tied up outside.Â Taking all this into consideration, it was decided and I agree that he should not be returned to his previous owner. Â I know that some of you will disagree with this decision, and may find it 'heartless.' I respect those feelings. Â But I feel strongly that Lucas should have the care he deserves at his age. Â He should have a warm place to sleep and good meals every day. Â He should have someone who worries about him, every day. Â Lucas should have a home where every day, he's treasured.

title: A New Story and Life for Lucas
text: Today, a dog known as 'Elmer' to his shelter friends was sprung from his unfortunate incarceration, and put into an awaiting Subaru. Â Leaving the hussle and bussle of the big city of Baltimore, his next stop was an inconspicuous and out of the way meeting place, a parking lot of a McDonalds. Â A bit unsure about what was happening to him, I took his face into my hands, looked into his brown eyes and told him to trust me, that I'd done this lots of times before, and he would be just fine. Â He was thenÂ put into my van and unceremoniously and without notice we quietly crossed the border into Virginia--His next stop, Golden Pines. Arriving in the quiet country side of western Loudoun County,Â 'Elmer' was introduced to his new housemates. Â His initiation was a 'smack down' by the cat, and a nip in the face by a tough-boy Scottie named Todd. Â In the end, all decided that he was okay in their book, and could stay! As the leader of the pack, I have given 'Elmer' a new identity. Â At Golden Pines, he'll be known as 'Lucas.' Â We think it suits him. Â He'll be taken to the vet on Monday where his tired body will be given a good once over. Â He is thin, has someÂ laryngealÂ paralysis, and severe periodontal disease. Â The smell of infection from his broken, missing, loose and infected teeth and gums can empty a room. Â Lucas is unable to eat anything other than canned food. There are other things that I could tell you about Lucas, but they can wait. Â Right now he's sleeping by the backdoor because he's reluctant to venture much past the kitchen. Â When I've gone into the kitchen, he wags his tail. Â He's a sweet boy. Â I wonder what his story is? Â I wonder what his story will be?

title: Waiting to Come Home
text: It has been a very busy week so far! Â It started before daylight on Monday morning when I realized that Carl had locked my keys inside my van the day before. Â Yes, I'm blaming Carl. Â It had to be him, I would neverÂ do such a thing, especially when I knew my keys were inside, right?! Â Right... I know that to some, it may not be such a big deal. Â But when you don't have an extra key, the office where you work is short-staffed and everyone is counting on you to be there, and the only other person who has a key, in this case Carl, works 2 hours away from home, it turns into one. Â Fortunately it turned out 'okay.' Â Carl made the drive back home, and I got to work only about an hour late. Â He decided to take the rest of day off because of something about not wanting to drive a total of 8 hours, to only work for about 6. Â I guess in doing the math, it really didn't make much sense to go back. Â  Todd returned to day-care on Tuesday for the first time since late November. Â He was so excited when he saw where he was, and he reallyÂ had a great time playing with the other dogs!Â Â He especially had a good time with a young Rottweiler named 'Lola.'Todd was totally worn out when I picked him up at the end of the day. Â I was exhausted as well and we all went to bed early. Â Today will be another busy day at work. Â But I have no real plans for tomorrow whenÂ I'm off work. Â Hopefully I'll have the chance to catch up on your blogs and things around the house. We've also been asked to take another senior dog. Â He was stray found around Baltimore Maryland.Â Â Right now he's doing his time in a local shelter, and is estimated to be about 12-13 years old. Â His owners have until Thursday to claim him. Â While I hope that his owners will come, it's good to know that if they don't, he'll have a new home to go to, which will be ours. Â Stay tuned.

title: Basic Truths and Observations
text: It's the end of the first week of making a conscious effort to try and be a bit more mindful of what Carl and I are eating. Â I have to admit that I've done pretty well despite that lurking within the cupboards of the office where I work are the remnants of the Christmas baskets we received. Â As a result, I have been reminded of the basic truths about eating that I just can't deny which are:Â 1. Â Cake is delicious anytime.Â 2. Â Broccoli tastes better with cheese sauce.3. Â There is no real substitute for butter.4. Â Fruit does make a great dessert---Â But it's even better bakedÂ with a crisp topping and served with ice cream.Â 5. Â At the end of a long day, when you're tired, worn out and stressed out,Â something 'light and healthy' can make for a disappointing meal.Â These are just my observations after the first week. Todd on the other hand, continues to be stuck on his own observations.Which are the turkey buzzards that have been flying over our house this weekend. Â Each time Todd sees them, he barks and chases them. He's done this so much that now Josh and Charlie are noticing them too. Â When they kept coming back, and flying so low, I began to get a little concerned that they might be thinking of Todd as a meal. Â Crazy thought? Â Probably. Â But I looked it up, and read that they won't. Â So I'll just let him continue his game as they fly and soar quietly overhead looking for their next meal. Â  I wonder how they feel about eating healthy?

title: The Healing Continues
text: The calendar may say it's early January, but for the past couple of days,Â it's  feeling more like November or March.Â  Today and yesterday the dogs and I  weren'tÂ planning on beingÂ outdoors long, but we got caught up in the  warmth.~Sunrise on Friday morning~Todd however, got caught up in watching the cat, CC, walk the fence. title: So Much for Enthusiasm!!
text: When I got up this morning, I was ready to start the day! Â We've had 2 days with temperatures well below freezing, and the day was predicted to be a sunny and warmer one, giving me some added enthusiasm!When daylight came, I took the dogs for their morning walk. Sheba had a vet appointment to recheck how her leg is healing. (it looks great by the way) I had an appointment to get my haircut. Â My van needs an oil change and a headlight needs to be replaced.
