title: We Begin Again
text: While I'm (of course) still saddened by the loss of Bubba, I'm ready to get up, dust myself off and begin again. Â Yesterday Toby rolled in the grass, and playfully ran off in another direction when I called him. Even though Toby still at times seems a bit withdrawn, Â I think he's ready too, that spark is back. Â Thank-you again for your friendship and support. Â Enjoy your Tuesday.

title: Inside Warmth
text: Finally, a cold front with some bite delivers a legitimate winter chill to  start off this first week of 2012. Today outside temperatures will struggle to  gain any forward momentum and the squirrels will also struggle to get the suet at the bird-feeders. Inside, the antics of a puppy bring warmth, as have your  kind, thoughtful comments on the loss of Bubba. Â I have felt comforted as I have read each and every one, and have been so grateful to receive them. I cannot thank you  enough.Â  Â  Toby seems a bit 'misplaced,' which is totally understandable.Â Â I can tell  that he's missing Bubba.Â  For some reason, heÂ won't eat in the place that he and  Bubba shared.Â  So,Â I've moved where his bowl is, and we are giving him lots of  reassuranceÂ as I know he is also mourning the loss.Â  Todd hasÂ been snuggling up  to him, something he's not really done before.Â Â It reminds me of what Charles Schultz  who wrote the Peanuts comic strip once said about 'happiness being a warm  puppy.'Â Â Comfort can be found in one too. Â Â Â Today I have to return to the vet.Â  On Friday in the midst of what was  happening with Bubba, there was another fight between CarrieAnne and  Sheba.Â Â Sheba's leg that had just healed was re-injured more severely this  time.Â  The vet was able to suture everything together.Â  But she's not very  encouraging because she'sÂ concerned that more surgery may be needed if there is  not sufficient healing--That decision will be made today when the bandages are  removed.Â Â Over the weekend I've spoken withÂ several Â people about the  situation.Â  There is a single 'trigger' that causes the fights. And because we know what  that is and when it occurs, we will enlist the help of a dog-trainer to try and change and redirect  both of them.Â Â We are also using herbal remedies to reduce any stress--Theirs,  not mine...Hmmmmm...Maybe I should try them too... Â Â I found out yesterday that the property that is behind us now has a contract on it. Â I didn't follow the time-honored southern traditionÂ of having black-eyed peas for New Years,Â and I wonder what the year will bring.

title: Farewell to Bubba and 2011
text: We who choose to surround ourselves with livesmore temporary than our ownÂ liveÂ within a fragile circle,easily and often breached.Unable to accept its awful gaps,Â we still would live no other way.We cherish memory as the only certain immortality,never fully understanding the necessary plan."~Irving Townsend~This quote tumbled around in my mind several times yesterday as Bubba quietly left this life for the next. Â We are thankful for the 18 months that he spent with us. Â They were not always easy ones because of his health and limitations. Â But knowing that Bubba is free from all those things brings peace. Â His kind, quiet, gentle nature, licks on the hand, and high pitched 'woo-woo-wooo's' when he was happy will be missed. Â His lifetime companion, Toby, like us, is missing him already. I wish I could explain it all to him, but as I mentioned yesterday, I think he already knows. Â The day was a very difficult one. Â Those of you who are 'Facebook friends' may have seen my update saying that it 'was the worst day I'd ever had as a dog owner.' Â It truly was. With those events and the loss of Bubba and the six others this year, my spirit and the 'fragile circle' that I live in truly feels breached and broken. Â I cannot remember ever being at a lower point. Â This circle that Carl and I have chosen to live in, and my broken heart will hopefully be made whole by your friendship, family, and the good memories and times of the past year. Â At least as the last day of 2011 dawns, and a new year is on the horizon, that's my hope.

title: The Vigil
text: I mentioned a few days ago that Bubba was not doing well, and we were having problems keeping him on his feet. Â He's been managing quite well with our help this week and I wasn't worried too much about him. Yesterday he was having a bit more difficulty but together we managed and he seemed fine. Â However, last evening he came into the office, lay down and fell into what seemed like a deep sleep. Â Our attempts to rouse him were unsuccessful and afterwards I noticed that Bubba was shivering. Â Thinking it was a 'focal seizure' I put a coat on him, and covered him up hoping it would pass. Â It did somewhat, but Carl stayed with him through the early hours of the morning. Â I got up about 3 AM to check on him, and let Carl get some rest. Â There has been no change. Â He is warm and his breathing, continues to be slow and deep. Â He seems comfortable, and really appears to just be in a deep sleep. Â However, he is a little responsive to my talking to him, and shortly I'll wake Carl to see if we can get Bubba to wake up and get him on his feet. Nearby is Bubba's life companion, Toby, who has not left his side, even at my insisting that he go out, he won't leave him. Â Just inside this circle and watching over the two is Sam. Â I wish they could tell me what they know. Â When my eyes met Toby's, there was an instant that I think he may have. Â I am feeling an old wound in my heart opening once again.

title: A Lame Duck Session
text: A very busy week as co-workers were on vacation, and we are cramming 5 days of work into 4. Â Outside, the cold has returned, but a beautiful crescent moon has been along with me on the drive home, and Venus has also been visible. Â I can't believe that it's two days and counting before the New Year. Â I'm already planning a resolution or two for the year ahead, one of them is one that many of us make which is to eat a bit healthier. Â However I know that I don't dare begin that one as I am experiencing what I am going to call a 'Lame Duck Session' -- You may Â know what I'm talking about--The week after Christmas and before New Year's day where you would gladly begin a healthier diet if it weren't for all the leftover sweets and tempting food that seems to be everywhere you are! Â Today I had a nice lunch with a very dear friend who was so thoughtful and bought both us each a delicious, freshly baked cookie that I enjoyed every single bite of as we chatted in front of a warm fireplace. Â I felt absolutely no remorse for my continued indulgence! Â Happening at our house are the teenage antics Todd. Â Tired of barking into the darkness, a pulled out chair became an invitation to see what was on the table it was sitting next to. Â A black laundry marker was used to recolor my rug and his paws. Onto the next thing which was to chase the cat. Â Checking that off the list, it was then time to see if the laundry basket held a sock in need of chewing up. Not disappointed, and that task completed it was then time to jump into my lap to play the newest computer game which is to jump at anything that moves on the monitor. I ended that game and Todd found his next one. All of this was before 6:30 this morning. Â I don't think he feels any remorse for his indulgences either!

title: All is Calm, All is Bright
text: A very quiet Christmas and day after. Â Exactly one year ago today was what became known as the Boxing Day blizzard, or known  locally as Nomageddon, as snow clobbered our area. Â This year, itâ€™s not  even a close call for any snow, with high pressure and bright sunny skies. It makes for perfect weather for taking the dogs for long walks. Bubba is becoming increasingly immobile. Â More and more he is having problems walking and we are helping him to his feet most of the time. Â Unaware of his limitations, he wanted to come on a walk with us today, so despite my best judgement, we took him along. Â Once Bubba gets some momentum going, he does pretty well. Â But on this walk Carl ended up with the job getting him home after he had difficulty walking through the tall grass. I know it wears him out, so I covered him up with a blanket as he napped afterwards. The dogs and I really do enjoy the walk up the hill in back of us. Â The two 10 acre parcels that adjoin our property was put back on the market to sell in late October. Â With 2 significant price reductions, I wonder how much longer we will be able to have it all to ourselves without feeling like we're trespassing. I just can't get enough of the view with the pond.I always look for little treasures on these walks. Â Hanging on a branch today was this little birds nest that I noticed had dog hair loosely woven into its construction. Â I love thinking that the dogs hair was keeping baby birds warm this summer. Â The only one not worn out from the walk and all the fresh air is Todd. Â In typical terrier fashion, he just needs a recharge of his batteries and ...he's already looking for his next adventure. Â I wish I had his energy.

title: Merry Christmas!!
text: A Christmas candle is a lovely thing;Â It makes no noise at all,Â But softly gives  itself away;Â While quite unselfish, it grows small.Thank-you for your cards you've sent, via e-mail and post!Â And thank-you for the best gift of all that can't be found under the tree,Â the gift of your friendship!Â Merry Christmas everyone!!

title: What Did He Notice the Most?
text: I was wearing Carl's garden shoes, my gray-flannel pajamas with pink hearts and mice on them, and an old over sized green sweater. Â In one hand I had a bucket of bird-food, the other held a few feathers and my camera. Â In the background there was the chaotic barking from the dogs inside the fence. Â Not having any neighbors, for me, the scene was all perfectly normal. Â To some, like the mail-man who had come to deliver a package, it may not have been. Â When he left I glanced around and feeling a bit (okay, a lot)Â embarrassed, I wondered what he'd noticed the most and what was he thinking as he stood there with his broad smile at 9 o'clock this morning?

title: Christmas is in Sight!
text: I can't believe that it's less than a week before Christmas. Â I feel like I should be running around like a chicken with its head cut off trying to get everything done, but I'm really not. Â I only have 1 more day of work for the week. Â Its been pretty hectic with kids home from college and people wanting to use up their dental benefits for the year. Â To keep us going and to ease the stress, the office has been totally bombarded with gift baskets.Â  Weâ€™ve had everything from Walkers shortbread and Lindor Truffles to homemade cookies and fudge.Â  I happen to be a chocoholic (and love other sweets too) but I usually do pretty well avoiding them.Â  But whenÂ my co-workers and I sit in our break-room and theyâ€™re right in front of us, theyâ€™re hard to resist!Â  Â Â We are also having the most random weather. Â We had a light dusting of snow on Sunday, but the past couple of days it has been in the 50â€™s, tomorrow the weatherman said it may get to 60 degrees. Â My forsythia bushes are budding and even have a few blooms on them.Â  This is December, right?Â  The dogs are doing pretty well.Â  Todd is not attending day-camp this week. Heâ€™s now more than 8 months old, so Iâ€™m trying to get him used to staying home during the day.Â  He does stay in a crate while weâ€™re gone, and the dog-walker does come midday and he gets a break. Â The past couple of days, he seems to have a Â realÂ fascinationÂ with Carl's computer. Â It makes me wonder what heâ€™s doing when we're not around? Â I hope your week is going well!!Â ~Toby on Sunday~

title: A Walk With Wendy
text: A cold, cloudy day where gloves are needed when out for any length of time. Â The bird feeders are busy with visits from the chickadees, cardinals, blue jays, woodpeckers, and whatever else stops by for an easy meal. We got a late start getting the dogs walked this morning. Â At the very back of the pack was Wendy who unexpectedly decided she wanted to come along with us. Â Because of her arthritis, she very rarely goes on walks with us anymore,. Â Instead Wendy tools around the yard and will roll in the grass or just soak up an incredible world of  scents that I will never know. Â Eventually she'll go back to the house to wait for us to return. Carl and the other dogs were a little ahead of us, so I waited for Wendy who will sometimes decide to wander off in another direction. Â At more than 14 years old, and having been with us the longest, she is the matriarch of the pack. Â Because of her position, I really believe that Wendy feels that she is my equal. Â Yes, she's indeed right about that. Â This may explain why she pretty much goes where she wants to, does as she pleases, and returns to us when she's ready. I found that this morning was a rare, special time with just the two of us. Â She and I don't have many walks alone these days. Â Several times, she stopped for a moment to rest. Â I told her to take her time, and as she always does, she looked at me like she totally understands what I've said to her. Â After all of our years together, I think she does. Â Too soon our walk was over and we were back home. Â A brief time to spend with my old friend, but such a special  time, and one that we both needed.Â ~Wendy in November~

title: I Just Want to Sit
text: With my list written out, I got an early start for another marathon day of shopping on Thursday. Â My last stop, was Wegmans for groceries for the weekend and for baking. Â While organizing my final list, I realized that I didn't have my credit card. Â Of course my mind started spinning as I thought of the 'what if's' of someone else having it. Â Since I wasn't far from the last place I'd used it, I went back only to find there were no parking spaces near the store. In my rush, I parked Â 'illegally' to retrace my steps. Â Thankfully the store had my card, but for some reason it took several minutes to locate the manager to open the safe andÂ retrieveÂ it. Â When I came out, a policeman was just walking up to my van with his ticket book in hand. Â I bombarded the officer with my explanation that came complete with a plea for leniency and goodwillÂ since it's the holidays. Â He bought it, and let me go!Re-energized and feeling lucky I was in and out of the grocery store quickly and on my way home; still feeling grateful for finding my credit card unharmed and for the kindness of the police officer. Â I was up late last evening, but I finished my baking, made potato soup and wrote a few Christmas cards. Too tired to do the dishes, I left them overnight secretly hoping my luck would hold and someone like Carl or the dish-fairy would do them while I was sleeping--No such luck, they were still there waiting for me this morning. It was another early start to the day, but I got everything cleaned up,Â put away and a few packages ready to be mailed. Â Â Then I was off again to our little (but new) post office to stand in line.Â Our 7-11 was busy too. Â As this video shows, Todd and I were a lot alike in our 'running' this morning,Â I just wish I had his speed.Â Â But with everything done for now, I've been able to sit,and enjoy a warm bowl of potato soup for my lunch. Â Â There's a part of me that would kind of like to just take a nap,But I really just want to do nothing, look out my window at the birdsand read what you've all been up too.I think that's just what I'm going to do...

title: A Do Over
text: I got off work early because I had to take Sheba back to the vet. Even though she's wearing a 'comfy cone of shame' she had a partner in crime that I think, somehow managed to remove all the staples in her leg. Â Todd wouldn't leave her wound alone, so there really is no other explanation as to how the staples came out. Â Despite this little set back, everything is healing nicely. Â However, from where her skin was shaved, its become reallyÂ irritatedÂ and red from the clippers. Â It's really bothering her and the vet and I think that her skin will either heal, or become hot-spots. Â I've got medication to try and ease the discomfort I know she's having. Today I also picked up the second printing of our Christmas cards. Â Long story, but suffice it to say that my 'obsessive compulsiveness' kicked in, and I had them redone. Â  I am also finished with work for the rest of the week. I'm hoping to get some of my cards written and packages put together and mailed. Â I feel like I'm where I was this past Sunday when I was thinking I'd be able to relax. Â I'm really worn out and tired and am hoping I'll get that 'do over' and the chance to relax that I didn't get last weekend. Â Stay tuned!~Something about this picture of Todd made me laugh...~

title: On the Mend
text: I'd really hoped for the chance to sit and relax and enjoy my Sunday afternoon. Â Unfortunately, that didn't happen. Â I was sitting at my computer when I heard the Todd barking outside. Â It was a high pitched non-stop bark that I don't know that I've heard from him before. Â Figuring it was probably nothing, I sent Carl out to see what the commotion was. Â A couple of Â minutes later, he came inside with Sheba, covered in blood. Â Carrie was behind her with blood on her as well. The two had gotten into a fight. Â Sheba had a large wound on her front leg that was laying open. Â She let me wash the debris off, and I then went to check on the other dogs. Â Todd was continuing to bark, and I was concerned that he'd been part of the fight too. Â Thankfully he was not. Â Carrie's wounds were superficial and didn't require much more than being washed off. Â So I put Sheba into the van and took her to the animal emergency. Â Almost 3 hours later, we left with Sheba having staples on her face, and leg. Â She has other wounds that will only need to be kept clean. This morning they were stillÂ tentativeÂ around one another. Â I left Carrie in her crate all day and this evening they are fine. You may recall that this is not the first time that Sheba has started a fight. Â A friend of mine suggested that I think about re-homing Sheba. Â Needless to say, I don't know what to do. There's a lot about this that continues to tumble around in my head. Â But thankfully I don't have to do anything for now, except let the mending begin for all of us.

title: Focus, Patience and Persistence
text: The last few days have been really busy ones. Â I was out late on Friday night because of our office Christmas party. Â Saturday morning was off to an early start Christmas shopping. Â I wanted to get ahead of the afternoon crowds and I thought I was doing well, but ran into another parade in the town of Leesburg. Trying to remain focused on the tasks at hand, and not really in the mood for a parade, I only took a couple of pictures and was off again. Â I was on a mission after all! It paid off as there were few people in the stores. Â Finally after about 5 hours of shopping, I was home! Â It was then time to try and capture that elusive perfect pictureof the dogs for this years Christmas card. Â Here are a few examples of my trying to get the dogs to cooperate...Â ~Toby~~Sheba~Needless to say, I was worn out at the end of the day and the photo session...But determinationÂ and patience and a little bit of creativity did pay off when an unexpectedÂ almost perfect picture was taken. Â Last night I ordered the cards online and I'll pick them up tomorrow. Â I'm my worst critic when it comes to my photos. Â This is why this morning I can't even look at the picture that we decided to use, so I won't post it today.Today I'm looking forward to relaxing, watching the birds out the windowÂ and catching up on your blogs! Â Enjoy your Sunday!

title: I Love a Parade!
text: There's nothing like a Christmas parade to give you a dose of the holiday spirit!For me, there's just something about the simplicity that's found in small town parades. Â I love their beauty...Â And the poise and grace...Of the people within them.Â The sound of the music always electrifies the air...And seeing the dogs never fails to put a smile on peoples faces...I enjoy the riders on magnificent and beautiful horses...That walk with their dogs...It's always fun seeing the local groups in the parades too...with their dogs...(Great Pyrenees Mountain Dogs)It's so hard to say what my favorite part is about small town parades. Â I guess it's the dogs...

title: At Last a Happy Ending!!
text: Every single soft toy that we had has been ripped to shreds. Â The best and biggest rope toys that have been around for several years, have been unraveled and every tennis balls de-fuzzed and chewed up. Â The culprit of this dog-toyÂ massacre was not the puppy, but Jasmine. From early October when she arrived, despite trying to hide them, no toy was safe as she used her Golden Retriever instinct and found them. Â The rein of Queen Jasmine didn't stop there. Â At any given time, her bark could be heard all over Golden Pines as she would let me know that her meal wasn't being prepared fast enough, treats were not as plentiful as she wanted, and outside is where she wanted to go. Â  Â  The reign of Queen Jasmine ended today. You may recall that she was supposed to have surgery this past Friday. Â However, there was a change in plans when Jasmine was all prepped and ready for a spay surgery and tumor removal, it was discovered that Jasmine had other tumors in her abdomen. Â Closer examination and x-rays showed that there were multiple mammary tumors that should not be disturbed becauseÂ if they are the cancerous-type it may cause them to spread more quickly. So, no spay or tumor removal was done, which meant that Jasmine was ready for adoption! Â I called and discussed everything at length with her new family and took Queen Jasmine to her new kingdom this afternoon. Â Â So tonight, with Jasmine dethroned there's nothing but the mostÂ indestructibleÂ of dog-toys left behind, and a bit of a sting in my heart because she's gone. I am going to miss her. Â But I'm thankful for the time that Jasmine was here with us. Â And I am especially thankful for a happy ending because a good and kind family opened their hearts and home to her. Â  Â Â Even with all the dogs, with Jasmine gone there is a different feeling in the house tonight. Â Carl reminded me that this is the first time in a long time that we've not had a foster dog for the rescue. Â I wonder how long that will last? Â Â ~Bubba~

title: Difference in a Day
text: This was Charlie yesterday...This is Charlie after spending today at the 'spa.'Â What a difference a day makes!!I hope you've enjoyed yours!

title: There's No Place Like Home
text: I came home early from work today. Â I don't know if it is just everything catching up with me, or if it's the post-Thanksgiving blahs that are clogging my brain. But when the schedule fell apart, I asked if I could take the afternoon off work and come home. So far the week is off to a quiet start. Â That is if you don't consider zebras sauntering around Loudoun  County where I live. Â This happened when a couple of them got loose from an animal park. Â A maintenance man left a gate open allowing the zebras to escape. Â Their adventure lasted about three hours before they were recaptured and returned home safely.Todd is being kept home from day-care this week because of his surgery last Wednesday. Â I've no doubt that he misses the fun and games with his friends at 'Belly Rubs.' Â  Â Â But there really is no place like home!

title: Ending on a Good Note
text: Thank-you all for your kind thoughts that you left for the loss of our boy Jake. Â Your e-mails and comments have again reminded me that I'm not alone in my loss. Â I used Saturday as my personal day of mourning Jake. I didn't really do anything other than eat all the wrong things, nap, surf the internet, read blogs and tend to the dogs. Â I have to admit, that I didn't even get dressed. Â Today however I was ready and needed to rejoin the human race. Â The weather could not have been nicer today with temps warm enough to have the windows open to bring in some fresh air. Todd is doing really well since his surgery this past Wednesday. Â We have followed the post-op instructions and not allowed him to over do it. Â He's been resting quite nicely in his crate and not complaining. What a good patient he has been! Â ~Todd taking it easy and not overdoing it~I did hear from the family that Jasmine picked as her 'forever family.' They have decided to wait for her to recover from her surgery which is scheduled for Friday. I also heard from some friends of mine who are also a foster home for the rescue. Â Marilyn, who you will recall was also interested in Jasmine has found her new companion in their 10 year foster girl named Abigail!~Marilyn and Abigail~The weekend is ending quietly and peacefully and on a good note. Â I hope yours is too.

title: Good Bye to a Dog Named Jake
text: There are some who wouldn't love or want an old Golden Retriever named Jake with a large growth over his eye, a thin dry coat, long lanky bowed legs and funny looking feet that thumped each time he took a step. But I did. Â There are some who wouldn't want a dog named Jake that couldn't always make it outside in time and would have accidents in the house. Â But I did. Â There are some who wouldn't want a dog named Jake around that kept to himself and didn't interact much with you or your dogs. Â But I did. Â There are some who wouldn't notice the little endearing things a dog named Jake did like rub his head on your leg for a hug or attention. Â But I did. Â There are some who while holding the paw of a dog named Jake in their hands, and petting him for the last time, not be able to see that Jake was just as handsome, just as dignified and just as perfect as the Golden Retriever in the portrait above him. Â But I did. Â There are some who wouldn't allow an old dog named Jake to break an already broken heart. Â But I did. Â  Â  God speed Jake until we meet you again at the Rainbow Bridge...Thank-you for being part of our lives for 24 days. Â ~~Some of you asked what caused Jake to leave us so quickly. Â There was really no final diagnosis. Â One vet thought Jake may have had a small stroke and a kidney infection. Â Another thought it may have beenÂ Hemorrhagic gastroenteritis (HGE) because he had many of the symptoms that appeared so quickly. Â Whatever it was, because of Jake's age and already compromised and weakened system it was all just too much for him to overcome.

title: Jake in Intensive Care
text: Thank-you to everyone who have stopped by today to leave your good thoughts and support for Jake. Â At the vet this morning, 'Dr. Taylor' made up for what he lacks inÂ sincerity with excellent care and brutal honesty which I respect and very much appreciated. Â It has taken a little bit of doing, but the board of the rescue agreed to give Jake a chance, and he's been taken to a critical care unit and is in intensive care. Â He is on a heavy dose of antibiotics and fluids to try and get him to come around. Â However his condition has been described as 'grave' Â and there is not much hope from the vet's that this will change. Â Despite the cost of his care and the small odds of his recovering, the board of the rescue agreed with me to provide supportive care to see if there is any improvement by this evening. Â I am holding onto a little bit of hope and a spark I saw in Jake's eyes as I held his paw and kissed him good-bye. Â Jake is not doing well. Â He was sick throughout the day on Thursday and I thought that maybe it was the stress of being caged at the vet all day on Wednesday. Â Perhaps it was. Â Whatever caused it, he's unable to stand this morning. Both preferred vets are out of town and we'll have to be seen by the vet I like the least. Â I need to remember that it's about getting Jake back on his feet and not my feelings about the vet who I have seen more than once give my senior dogs a roll of his eyes and shake of his head. The current appearance of Jake, I know will elicit this same response. Â I can only hope for compassion and that I'm wrong.

title: Thanksgiving and a Memory
text: One of the things I'm thankful for today is that Todd, although he's a little worse for wear and as you can see in the picture, he's not very happy, he did just fine with his surgery yesterday. Â He ate part of an evening meal and slept all night. Â A question was asked on a radio station yesterday that if Â you could only have one item for your Thanksgiving dinner, what would it be? Â Of course the answers varied from the obvious of the turkey to someone saying their Grandmother's tripe stew (blech!!). Â Mine would have to be my Mother's cornbread dressing. Â There was no written recipe so it varied from year to year. Â Sometimes there would be to much sage in it, other years it may have been to dry, another it would be perfect. Â Even though its been a long time since I had it, I can still remember its taste and smell. Â I'll be missing it and my family today.... Â What's your single favorite dish for Thanksgiving? Â Whatever it is, and wherever your Thanksgiving takes you, I hope your day is a safe and enjoyable one! Â ~Fallen pine needles on our road yesterday~

title: Crossing My Fingers and T's
text: The day before Thanksgiving started out cloudy, rainy and foggy. Â But as the morning has progressed there has been some clearing and we are getting some welcomed sun and temps well above freezing. Â  Â  Todd is having surgery this morning to be 'altered.' You'll recall it had to be rescheduled when I gave him a teeny-tiny training treat last week. Also spending the day at the vet with Todd is Jake, our newest addition. Â He's having x-rays taken of his heart and lungs and a couple of other tests. Â Results were returned on a thyroid panel that was done, and it came back 'normal.' Â What explanation could there be for his baldness and very thin coat? Â Could the reason be as simple as a poor diet? Â I have no idea, but I do know that I'm going to have to find my dog coats for him, because he's going to be cold this winter. Following Todd and Jake will be Bubba. Â He's going in later today to have follow up blood work to check the level of seizure medication in his system. Â So far, he's not had any seizures, so I'm hopeful that the vet got the dosage right on the first try. ~Jasmine and Toby~Then, last but not least Jasmine's adoption has been put on hold because she's having surgery next week. Â I really wanted to make sure to cross my T's and make sure she was healthy prior to her adoption. Â So I called the vet to  make sureÂ a hard and lumpy quarter-size tumor on her belly wasn't an issue.Â  Apparently,  it is an issue. Â Jasmine's initial test results were coming in at the same timeÂ Bubba  was having his cluster of seizures so somewhere it didn't registerÂ that aspirate confirmed that something should be  done about it.Â  But itÂ may explainÂ why I was a little unsettled about the lump  in the first place if Â (when) the vetÂ mentioned that it should be removed and biopsied. Â At any rate,  I dropped the ball and feel really terrible about it. Â But her having this surgery will ensure that she's healthy at the start of her new life. Â Which is the positive that I need to keep in mind. I'm off work today and am going to spend it catching up on your blogs, which will also help to keep my mind off worrying about our crew. Â I hope you'll keep your fingers crossed and positive thoughts in mind for Todd, Jake, Jasmine and Bubba. Enjoy your Wednesday!~Charlie and Barney the donkey~

title: Jasmine Makes Her Choice
text: I took Jasmine to meet two families this weekend. Â The first, was the lady in her 60's named Marilyn. Â As expected, she was very kind, caring and compassionate. Â She had a lovely home and a perfect setting for any dog. Â Jasmine made herself right at home, and was relaxed and seemed to like Marilyn. Â I left there thinking that Jasmine would be very lucky to have this as her forever home. But later I received another call asking about Jasmine, and was a little bit surprised. Â Typically there are not many calls for the senior dogs. Â But it was a couple with an 8 year old daughter, and a 14 year old Golden named Sugar. Â We decided to meet yesterday afternoon in Gettysburg, (a 3 day battle took place here during the civil warÂ in July, 1863)Â Â The meeting went really well. Â Jasmine responded the family and was so attentive, going to them for attention and ear rubs. Â She really seemed to connect with them. Â We had a very nice visit, and when it was time to go, I told them I would let them know by the end of the week if Jasmine would be going to their home, or Marilyn's--I honestly didn't know. Â As we walked to my van, Jasmine seemed a bit confused about why they were going in one direction and we were going in another. Â I think she had made her choice of who she liked and wants as her Â forever home. I called them this evening and they were so happy! Â Jasmine will probably be leaving us by the end of the week. Â It's bittersweet because I feel kind of sad for Marilyn who has no one, and I hope she will understand that it's what's best for Jasmine. Finally, many thanks to all of you who entered the drawing for the book 'Pure Gold!' Â I wish I could give each of you a book, but unfortunately I can't. Â We held the drawing in our kitchen, letting Todd pick the name after we tipped the hat filled with the names. I learned to not let a puppy grab a piece of paper because you may not get it back. Â But after a brief chase around the kitchen, living room, and dining room, we got it back from Todd and he had picked, Noreen whose blog is titled 'Life Blessings'Â as the winner! Â Congratulations Noreen, and thank-you all for your interest in the book and entering the drawing!

title: An Unsung Hero
text: ~Todd & Josh~Today is my 30th wedding anniversary. Although we felt 'grown up' when we got married, I was 20 years old, Carl was 23, we were just kids. Â We really had no idea what we were getting ourselves into. We just  knew we couldnâ€™t imagine the world without us together in it. Â Like  most young couples we schemed, dreamed and planned our way into a picture  perfect future. But life doesnâ€™t always work out exactly as you plan. Â After graduating from college in Wisconsin, Carl went to Georgia for 'Officer Candidate School' while I stayed behind in Oshkosh. He was then off to Virginia to an advanced course, and the army then sent us to Alaska. Â After a year of Carl being unemployed, he got his dream job and it brought us back to Virginia. Through all the changes and lost dreams new ones took their  place. And a partnership emerged that wasn't based on a pre-scripted end state  but instead a winding journey that twists, turns and entangled us, making us stronger than either of us would be on our own. Â Carl has talked me off of ledges that no one has seen me on. He's stood up for me when I felt I couldn't defend myself. Â He also calls me out when no  one else will, andÂ believesÂ in me when no one else does. Â Too often spouses are unsung heroes, so thank-you for letting me sing the praises of mine today--Happy 30th Anniversary Carl! ~Sam~

title: It All Worked Out!
text: I'm so glad that it's Friday! Â The week started off routinely enough, but some where it seemed to change direction. Some of you saw and commented on the post I had on Wednesday about Todd but later deleted. Â I planned about 3 weeks ago to take Todd in to be 'altered.' I knew that he wasn't supposed to have any food or water, but I gave him a small training treat before I remembered that I shouldn't. Â Not thinking it would create a problem, I didn't worry about it. Â Well, it created a problem and the vet wouldn't do the surgery and I had to reschedule it for next week. Â As upset as I was, of course I would have been more upset if something would have happened to Todd during the procedure because of it. Â ~Yet another picture of a Tennessee barn~The next problem I had was what to do with a hungry puppy for the day. Â Too far from home and patients scheduled, the day-care thankfully had room for Todd that afternoon. Â So I took him to work with me for the morning and the shop where I buy dog-food gave me a small sample bag so I didn't have to purchase any.~And another...~This was just how the week went. Â Whenever things didn't seem to go as I thought they should, something happened and they would work out another way. Â Unfortunately I didn't realize that until I started writing this post...I guess I really need to work on being a bit more flexible... Â  I'm really excited that Jasmine and I are going to meet someone tomorrow morning that is interested in adopting her. Marilyn is a widow in her early sixties and lost her last Golden several months ago. Â She has adopted senior dogs from the rescue 3 times before. Â And in talking with her, she seems to have a tremendous capacity to give, grieve and give again. Â I'm looking forward to meeting her and I so hope that she and Jasmine have a connection. Â Marilyn is meeting other senior dogs next week so we'll see how it goes. ~Jasmine~Finally, don't forget, if you'd like to be entered in the drawing for the book, Pure GOLD, please post a comment on my previous post by Sunday. Â Enjoy your weekend!Â ~Toby~

title: The Return Home
text: ~The back seat drivers~We arrived home from Tennessee on Sunday evening. Â A good trip that was met with happy 'left-behinders' when we walked in the door! Â As we brought everything inside, I'd taken everything out of the cooler and left it sitting on the floor. In the corner of my eye I saw Bubba eating the ice (which he loves). I didn't think anything of it, and just let him help himself. Â After I fed the dogs their dinner,Â Â I noticed Bubba'sÂ teeth were chattering andÂ he was shivering.Â Â He was layingÂ under a window fan, so I turned itÂ off andÂ covered him up. Â Bubba'sÂ gums were pale and his feet were also cold and we had a hard time getting him to stand.Â Â We put an insulated dog coat on him and got him off the floor and onto a dog bed. Â I added more warmed towels and blankets under and on top of him. Â Eventually BubbaÂ stoppedÂ shivering, and heÂ felt much warmer.Â  He seemed so tired and fell asleep, however,Â his gum colorÂ didn't improve.Â  I checked on him through the night, making sure I could wake him, and each time I did that, he seemed a bit more alert and responsive.Â (Probably wondering why I was waking him up!) But I've no idea why this happened. Â I wonder if it could have been the combination of eating the ice, not having eaten, then being given a full meal and all of his medications all at once.Â Â Could it have been a hypoglycemic reaction? Â Have any of you had this happen with one of your dogs before? Â Yesterday and this morning BubbaÂ seems fine...Me, of course I'm still worried because, well, that's just what I do. ~Bubba~Other than that, while just a little bit behind because of being out of town,Â our week is off to a good start!Â  I hope all of you are doing well. I'm sorry I've not been able to visit many of your blogs, but I'm working on it, and looking forward to reading what you're up too! Â Enjoy your Tuesday!~Another Tennessee Barn~

title: Update on Jake and a Road Trip
text: Today we're off to eastern Tennessee near Gatlinburg, to spend a few days at Autumn Dancer Llama Farm with a few of our pups. You'll recall that the trip had to be rescheduled when Todd swallowed a cap from a plastic water jug in September. Â There are no water jugs in the house this time, and I'm hopeful that we'll make it out of town. Â I'm hoping to be able to keep up with your news while we're away, but if not, I'll look forward to catching up when we return on Sunday. I did take Jake to the vet last evening. Â We did all the senior blood-work, including a thyroid test which may help to explain his thin coat and bald patches. Â Preliminary test results will be in on Friday, the thyroid test in a couple of weeks. Â He has severe arthritis in all his limbs, it's worse in his front legs. Â We discussed his feet and he received a really good nail trim. Â The vet feels that the problem with his feet could be congenital Â because allÂ 4 feet and all  his toes are wide andÂ spread apart.Â Â The tendons are really stretched, and all of this together makes it difficult for him to walkÂ because his reflexesÂ areÂ delayed, especially in the  back, but they are better in the front. Â I have decided that watching him walk reminds me of someone with scuba flippers on. Â Jake also has a 'Grade 3' heart murmur and his lungs have a raspy sound. Â As expected, and as you can see, there is a lot going on. Â But my vet and I have made a pact to keep Jake going as long as we can. Â Not just for him, but because we've lost 4 dogs in the past 6 months, and I don't want to make it 5. Â So please, keep those good thoughts coming for Jake!!THANK YOU for stopping by, I hope you enjoy your day!!

title: An Upside Down World for Jake
text: In my experience I have found that people give up their pets for the most trivial of reasons. Â I have also found that they give them up because they feel they have no other choice. Â Financial hardship, working two jobs, Jake alone for about 15 hours a day, and a daughter requiring medical care all contributed to the reasons why Jake's former owner felt like she couldn't keep him. Â She had asked everyone she knew if they could take Jake and as a last resort, contacted our county animal shelter. Â They were honest with her, and told her that because Jake is 13 years old, he probably would not be adopted and would beÂ euthanized. Â They provided her with the rescues number and she contacted them.This brought me into the picture on Wednesday when I was asked by the rescue if we had room for him. Â The owner was getting ready to go out of town, so a quick decision had to be made. Â Where Jake lived was practically around the corner from my office, so using that flimsy reason to justify taking him in, I agreed and picked him up after work. Â I felt very sad for the owner and we both cried as she said good-bye to him. Â I didn't tell her that I was the one who would be caring for Jake, but I did promise to let her know how he was doing. ~Jake's paw~Â As I mentioned on Thursday, Jake is not the most handsome of Goldens and his care has been neglected. Â He is tall, lanky and thin. Â His nails are really long and curled under, looking more like talons than nails. Â Added to that, there is a problem with his feet and he walks on his wrists. He has a very thin coat and his skin is visible in places including on his tail. Â There is also a large cyst over his eye. Â ~The trouble maker~Meeting our crew did not go as smoothly as it has in the past. Â For some reason Todd had an issue with Jake. He meets new dogs practically each time he goes to day care, and I can only guess that the problem started because he was crated when I picked up Jake, and couldn't meet him on equal ground. Â The 'hostility' from Todd continued even after he was let out of the crate, fed his dinner, and played with. Â Of course all of this upset the entire household, making it chaotic and very stressful for everyone. Â I finally made Todd a 'Kong' and put him to bed. Even with Todd out of the picture, Jake continued to be a nervous wreck. Â His entire 13 years of life had been turned upside down. Â He paced, panted and had several accidents. Â Jake had always lived as an only dog, walking on wood floors and not being allowed in the kitchen and never having to do steps. Â Our house is full of area rugs, dogs and he has to walk through the kitchen to get outside and down two steps. Â You can see why he was so upset and confused about what was happening to him.~Jake~Worn out and tired, we all went to bed. Â I'm not sure where Jake slept that first night. Â But the last couple of days have been better ones, and even Todd has gotten over his issue with him. Â We're working on getting Jake to feel more comfortable coming into the kitchen. He's still reluctant to walk on the rugs, and learning the steps is going to take some time. But he comes to us for attention and will sit next to me and and we're seeing tail-wags more and more. Â The last two nights he has slept on a blanket next to the bed--I think we're headed in the right direction.

title: Resilience and Perseverance.
text: With the exception of the clouds that kept us from viewing the Orionid Meteors on Saturday morning, the day was a perfect one at home! Â The clouds finally cleared in late afternoon and we caught up on things around the house. We even had this little visitor stop by several times, reminding me that I need to get the feeders filled.This morning started out well too. Â We had our first frost and took a walk at the start of a gorgeous fall day. Funny how quickly things can change. Â Getting breakfast ready for the dogs, there was a fight between Sheba and Jasmine. Â Thankfully all Jasmine has is a bloody-nose and a sore ear. Â Both dogs quickly forgot about their disagreement and as I write this they are sleeping nearby to one another. Â Riley was also 'complaining' this morning, but we managed to get her to settle down. Â But then CarrieAnne got after Todd for something that I've no idea about. Â Even though he was yelping and whining and there wasn't a mark on him, I still felt bad for him. Â But things are quickly forgotten in 'puppy-dom,' and let's not forget that he's a Scottie after all. I noticed this morning that the butterfly bush that was cut down to the ground in August because the stink-bugs totally consumed it, is blooming again. Â I think the theme for my day is going to have to be 'resilience andÂ perseverance.'

title: The Weekend Ahead
text: We have a weekend guest. Â Riley has come to stay with us until Sunday while her foster home is out of town. Â  You may recall that she had her first surgery a few weeks ago. Â She is doing wonderfully!! Â The foster home that is now caring for her is doing an amazing job! Â Riley is unable to walk without assistance, so she is walked with a sling to help keep her balanced and to not allow any extra weight on her knee that is still healing.Riley will be easy enough to care for this weekend because she has to remain confined. Â Although she lets us know she's unhappy about theÂ accommodations, her complaints areÂ falling on mostly deaf ears--Well, we may be deaf by the end of the weekend because she can really voice her objections! Â It's times like this that you just wish you could explain to them that there's a bigger plan in motion, that this is only temporary and they'll be okay. Â But since we can't do that, we're letting the 'calming medications' do the talking for us.Tonight in Virginia, there will be two events. Â The first, is the prediction of our first frost. title: Feeling Better
text: THANK YOU all for the good thoughts for Bubba!! Â It worked because we were able to get the Potassium Bromide yesterday and started him on it. Â A few of you commented about the use of Phenobarbital instead. For more than a year, Bubba has taken Rimadyl twice daily for arthritis. Â Like phenobarbital it can damage the liver and the vet felt that his taking the two medications may not be the best combination.It has been a quiet weekend for Bubba and thankfully there have been no more seizures. Although he is still pretty unsteady and needs help to get to his feet, today he seems a little more stable and was able to eat his morning meal standing up. Progress!I can tell that Toby is concerned about Bubba, because he has been staying nearby. title: A Bumpy Road for Bubba
text: I mentioned in my last post that it had been a 'good week for the dogs.' Â That was mostly true. Â The one who really wasn't having such a good week was Bubba. Â You Â may recall that he's prone to having seizures. Â I've kept a journal of them, and since he came to us in June of 2010, he's been having them every 4 to 6 weeks. Â He would have 1-3 grand-mal seizures within a 24 hour period. The vet suggested starting him on medication for them. Â Not liking the effects they can have, I felt strongly that we should wait, but I knew that there would be a time when Bubba would have to be on them. Â The time has come. Â On Sunday he had one seizure, another on Monday, another Wednesday. Â On Friday he had 4 that we knew of. I took him to the vet after work on Friday, and I was given the prescription for PotassiumÂ Bromide. Â It's often considered the firstÂ choice drug for any dogs with idiopathic  epilepsy, and because it has noÂ effect on  the liver. Unfortunately the medication has to be 'compounded' and I won't be able to get it until Monday or Tuesday. Bubba is totally exhausted from the seizures and we're having difficulty getting him to stand. But he has a good appetite, and if we can all get our rest I think we'll be okay until then. Â Paws and fingers crossed.

title: A Little Jasmine at Golden Pines
text: You know that an empty dog bed does not last long around our house. Â Today we welcome a sweet little girl Golden named Jasmine, who is 12 years old. Â Her previous owner put her on 'Craigs List' to be given away. Â Many of you may be aware that dogs that are given away in this manner are many times used for training dogs to fight, or sold to research. Thankfully there are people in rescue who watch for these ads and try to prevent this from happening and so someone contacted Jasmine's owner. Â Even though she was a bit wary of giving her to a rescue, she finally agreed. Â  The owner told me to come this morning around 9 o'clock. Â I did just that, and ended up waking them. Its been a long time since I dealt with an owner first hand and I've forgotten just how cut and dry these things can be. Â They came to the door with Jasmine in hand, signed the paperwork, gave me practically nothing for her, and I was gone in less than 5 minutes. Â I always wonder how you can have a dog for so manyÂ yearsÂ and give them up so quickly and easily and without a single item that belongs to them that you'd like them to have in their new home. Â But I suppose that I should have remembered to consider their reasons for giving Jasmine up, which ranged from the owner having a skin problem, to not being to take her with them to their new apartment. Regardless of the reason, Jasmine is a very sweet, small and petite Golden, weighing less than 50 pounds. Â She's had several litters of puppies, and I think has problems seeing outside because she has stumbled on our steps each time she has been out. Â Meeting our gang was uneventful. Â Todd was very attentive to Jasmine, no doubt hoping he had another playmate--I think our cat CC probably hoped for the same thing. Looks like CC will just have to keep hoping..THANK YOU as always for stopping by my blog, I hope you're enjoying your Sunday!

title: Update on a Girl Named Riley
text: Our weather here in northern Virginia could not be better this weekend with warm temps and lots of sun! Â The day started out with a beautiful mist on the field next to us, and my having breakfast with two friends. Â Carl is mowing for what we hope will be the last time this season. Â The dogs have been outside soaking up the sun too. Â The only thing keeping me inside are the mass of stink-bugs covering the side of our house and buzzing all around. Â The good and bad of this time of year. I thought I'd give you an update on Riley. Â You'll recall that she's the golden that came to us and needed extensive knee surgery. Â Riley had her first surgery on Thursday, and below is the update that I received from her foster home. Â It's pretty good news, and I continue to be grateful that she's able to have the surgery and a chance at a healthy, active life. Here is a portion of the e-mail from the foster home: Â  Â "I spoke to Dr Walker earlier today, he said Riley's knee was one of the worst  he's ever seen.Â  Her condition was allowed to go on so long that the "fix"  wasn't able to beÂ 100%.Â  If she had come in earlier, there was a chance that  surgery would have made her "normal" but as it is now, we're settling for a  compromise.Â The malformation of the tibia was so much that he had to do three cuts  instead of one, and the groove in the front of the knee where the tendon is now  laying is very deep, a little more than expected. Â Riley's patella is now back in  place and her foot placement is 80% better but there was no way to make it 100%  better because of what she had to work with. Â The pain Riley will Â feel is not so much what they did  to her bones, it's the stretching of the muscles in ways they haven't stretched  before."I hope you will all send good thoughts and prayers for Riley as she begins this new chapter in her life. Â She has one more surgery just like this one and a long, hard road to travel, and extensive rehabilitation which won't be easy for her, but it'll be worth it! I hope you're having a relaxing and enjoyable weekend!

title: Sheba's Wrinkle
text: As you may know, when you bring a 'rescued dog' into your home, you are accepting some of Â the proverbial wrinkles that they may have in their personality. Â Our girl Sheba is a dog with a wrinkle all her own. Â She came to us at almost a year old in October of 2007 when the family who had young children, couldn't afford her hip surgery. I can only think that the kids were allowed to torment her, because Sheba in no shape or form likes young children. Â Knowing this, I keep her away from them. Â If anyone comes to our home with kids, I put her in her crate. Â When I take Sheba anywhere with me, I am always watching so that we can avoid contact with any children. Â It was no different today when I took her to the vet. When we were waiting for medications and our bill at the end of our appointment. Â I sat in the far corner of the waiting room away from everyone. Â Someone came in with their dog, a stroller and a little boy that looked about 3-4 years old. Â The little boy smiled when he saw Sheba and took a step towards her. Â I stopped him and politely asked the Mother to please keep him away from Sheba, explaining that children made her really nervous. Â She replied telling me that she didn't believe this because all Golden Retrievers loved children. Â I told her that 'this one didn't, and it was best if she just kept an eye on her son and made sure he kept his distance.' The whole time I am talking, I'm holding Sheba very close and I have her leash cinched up very short, and my other hand on her collar. Â I could feel her growling. Â When the little boy started jumping up and down and hopping in our direction, I tried to be polite and tell him that he needed to go play somewhere else. Â The mother looked but did nothing. Â Sheba continued to growl. Â The girl at the front desk said something to me and as I stood up the little boy threw a magazine in our direction. Â At that, Sheba started barking and lunging at the little boy. Â Thankfully I still held onto her leash and collar and so I was able to keep her under control. Â The Mother unleashed aÂ barrage ofÂ accusations and threats, telling me that I had no business having such a vicious dog in public that was out of control! Â I really tried to not show how upset I had become but told her that the only thing that was out of control was her son! Â The rest of the incident is a bit of a blur that ended with the office manager (who had seen the whole thing)Â escortingÂ the Mother and herÂ entourage into a treatment room, and apologizing to me for their client.Sheba, I think, is really a lovely dog. Â There is so much about her that is everything that a Golden Retriever is supposed to be. So even knowing this, why am I still upset about the reminder of 'Sheba's wrinkle' and why am I taking this all so personally?

title: Back to Work!
text: The end of our stay-cation and back to work on Monday for Carl and I. Â This weekend has been cold, rainy and dreary! Â I even turned the heat on to get take the cold edge off the air inside the house. Â Any thoughts we had about doing anything outdoors didn't happen. Â But in the end, it was okay I got a few things done inside, and just relaxed.
