title: Stay-Cation and Puppy-Doody
text: When I finally got over the disappointment of not being able to go out of town, our stay-cation become an enjoyable one. Yesterday a friend told me about an estate sale not far from me, so I went to that. Â It began at 10 in the morning, and I arrived around noon. I'm guessing that I was a little too late because there really weren't a lot of things left that I could spend my money on. Â Â I did however end up with this. I'm not sure exactly what 'this' is, but it was only $4, so I knew I had to have it. Â As you can see, it's a pretty good size, and weighs about 20 pounds. Â It does have a hanger on the back, but I've no idea what to do with it--Any suggestions will be appreciated!Â  Â Last evening we met some good friends for dinner at a place I'd been hearing about not far from us. Â It's calledÂ Patowmack Farm. Â It has a stunning view of the Potomac river and bridge at 'Point of Rock' between Virginia & Maryland. Â We felt like VIPs with customized menus, and other special unique touches. Â The food is amazing and is 'farm to table.' Â I had the 'Autumn Blend' as an appetizer, and 'Farm Beef Duo' as my entree. I cannot remember when I've had a more enjoyable evening out with friends!Â Back on the home front, we are STILL on 'puppy-doody' as we look for the reappearance of the cap that went to the water jug. Â I'm starting to doubt that Todd actually ate it. Â But if it's going to show up, my vet feels like today will be the day. Â I wonder if Todd knows that...It's a new month and a new feel to the weather. Â Our day is starting out with cold winds and clouds and some showers. Â After a couple of errands, it'll (hopefully) be another quiet day at home, following Todd around. Â I hope you have an enjoyable day too!~Sheba and Todd~

title: A Stay-Cation?
text: Our little getaway is being postponed. Â This morning Todd decided that what looked like a fun play toy was a water jug. Â He dragged it down the hallway and water got all over the house, which was not a problem. Â What was a problem is that we were unable to find the cap that went onto it. Â After turning our house upside down in its search, we could only conclude that Todd had swallowed it. Â I took him to the emergency vet hospital where an x-ray was done. Â Because it's plastic it didn't show up. Â So we decided to give him Bariam to see if there was any kind of a blockage. Â The first vet we saw told me to bring him back this evening to do the x-rays. Â I left their office about an hour later and called my vets office. Â I decided to take him there and have x-rays done at hourly intervals to see if the bariam was moving through his system. Â By 12:30 it looked like everything had moved through normally. Â I've brought him home and given him a little bit of food and water. Â Thankfully he's keeping everything down and is acting just fine. Â We're to keep an eye on him for the next couple of days and watch for him to have any signs of discomfort or vomiting. Words can't begin to explain how terrible and how sick I feel about all of this. This water jug of distilled water had been sitting in our laundry room since June. Â I never thought of it as a possible problem...That aside, I'm trying so hard to remain optimistic and praying so very fervently that 'it'll all come out in the end.'

title: Riley and a Road Trip
text: The week is off to a running start. Â Carl and I are leaving on Wednesday to go to Tennessee for a couple of days. Â We visited there in March and we decided that we wanted to come back when it was better weather and maybe enjoy a few fall colors. Â I'm not sure about the colors, but I think that the weather will definitely be better. Â You may recall that our friends have a Llama farm, and they've had a couple of new additions born since our last trip. I'm looking forward to getting out of town for a few days and recharging my inner batteries. We've also had another 'subtraction' in our household as Riley has been placed in a new foster home. Â The rescue has decided to go forward with the surgeries, and her first one will be next Wednesday! Â I was a little sad to see Riley leave us, but I am so excited for her and that she's going to get the chance at an active and pain-free life! Â The foster home that has taken her, is the board member that also attended the evaluation with the orthopedic surgeon. Â I have known her for more than 10 years and she has cared for several dogs with complicated recoveries, and there is no doubt that she will be able to handle Riley with no problem--She also lives close to the vet hospital where Riley will be having her surgeries and doing her rehab; it could not work out any more perfectly! I hope you're having a perfect week too!!

title: It's All About Todd
text: A few of you have asked how it's going for Todd at his new daycare. To answer that, I'll let a couple of the pictures that the daycare posts daily on Facebook answer that question. Â Todd is having a great time playingÂ with his new friends! Â I like that the staff interacts with the dogs, and knows each of them. Â I have total peace of mind knowing that he's allowed to be himself!~What do you think the dogs are saying in this huddle?~Speaking of Todd being himself, he got his first 'big-boy haircut' on Saturday when he went to the groomer. Â He certainly looks like a Scottie now, doesn't he?I think he also looks grown up...Enjoy your Monday!

title: I Feel Like...
text: What a week! Â There has been a lot going on, and losing Reggie on Thursday, just added to an already emotional week. Â Being who and how I am, I have run the gambit of emotions from feeling like I was hanging by a thread...To feeling a bit beat up like this butterfly...And just plain ole grouchy and mean like this snapping turtleÂ that I tried to help get out of the road yesterday.There was even a moment on Friday that I felt like I wanted to pick a fight with some unsuspecting person...But (thankfully) that feeling passed. Â Then I felt like this praying mantis that was climbing up our down-spout to the roof, who didn't seem to know where she was going...Or did she?I have to admit that more than once I felt like hiding from the world...Okay, I did do that...But then this morning I reread all your comments from my last post on the loss of our girl Reggie. Â I'm humbled and grateful that people I've never met have again shown me such kindness and compassion at a sad time--You and your friendship have once again made a difference! Â I am now feeling like that proverbial cloud that has been over my head and outside is lifting--And I have you to thank for that!HoweverÂ YOUÂ are feeling, I hope it doesn't keep you from having an enjoyable weekend!! Â ~Toby, one of the Chub Brothers~

title: Another Good-bye and a Celebration of 92 Days
text: For the fourth time in six months, I sent a Golden Retriever to the Rainbow Bridge; that Golden was Reggie. Â While my heart is broken, I decided that instead of mourning her loss, I want to try and remember the good things of the 92 days that she spent with us...I want to remember how happy Reggie lookedÂ the first day she arrived wearing 'Ugg boots.'Â I want to remember how easily Reggie settled into our home andÂ the look on her face when she would roll in the grass. Â And how peaceful she looked when she slept. Â I want to especially remember how she was a Mother to Todd.Â Â She was so attentive to Todd and seemed to worry about him.I want to remember Reggie's beautiful 'golden smile' and that we shared a great summer together.Â I will remember how thankful I am that she was part of our lives for 92 days. Â I will remember how thankful I am that her life didn't end on the porch of someone who didn't care for her. Â I will remember Reggie.... Â God-speed my 'pretty 'Regimina' Â ...Until we meet again at the Rainbow Bridge.

title: Update on Our New Girl Riley
text: Riley was taken to see the orthopedic surgeon, who by the way is the same one who did surgeries on Hamlet, our boy Josh and Sheba too. There was a lot to digest and I'm thankful that a board member from the rescue attended with me to try and remember everything. Â  Riley has, 'Grade 4 Medial Patellar Luxation.' Â She wasÂ likely born with compromised knee joints so this wasn't from an  accident.Â  What we're seeing today is a result of tendons being too tight, that has caused her knee caps to move to the inside of her legs, causing her legs to draw up.Â   Over time, the quadrecep (muscle of the thigh most responsible for walking) has  tightened up and the tibia bone in the lower leg has become warped. The good news is, is that she's not in any pain, and surgery can be done to try and fix it.The bad news is, is that it'll be 4 procedures done in two surgeries, and 6 to 8 months recovery at the very least. The key to success with these surgeries will be the months of physical therapy afterwards. Â This includes an underwater treadmill, cold laser therapy, passive  stretching, etc.Â  Dr Walker (surgeon) said that if the commitment can't be done to do the therapy, there's no use in doing the surgery.Â  It's critical because the muscles  need to be stretched and re-trained. Â As I said, it was a lot to digest. Â ~Riley during the 'dirt debacle' on Saturday~I spoke to the board member afterwards about everything. Â I had to be honest with her and tell her that I feel stretched pretty thin these days. Â I don't know that I have the time to be able to give Riley all that she will need. Â I feel like it's her one chance to have a good healthy and active life, and I don't want to short-change her. Â Of course I feel guilty, but this isn't about me, it's about giving Riley all the time and the dedication she deserves. Â I'm hopeful that the board member understood. Â Finally, some of you asked about where the money will come from to pay for Riley's surgeries. Â When we bring dogs into our home, we pay for all their food, etc. Â But anything beyond that, like these surgeries, the rescue will pay for. The rescue that I work with is a large 5 state rescue that has generous donors and vets who give the rescue a discount for treatment. Â Riley will be no exception. Â The surgeon has offered to discount his service, and all of her physical therapy will be discounted as well. Â (The rescues total cost for Riley will be around $10,000)Riley has settled in nicely here. Â But I do think that she will and should be moved to another foster home. Â But until the Board of Directors of the rescue decides what to do, and who should take her, she'll be just fine here, living in the 'group home!' Â  ~In Our Yard on Sunday~

title: Lesson Learned?
text: When it's early in the morning, and all is quiet and peaceful and you have a puppy, there's just something that you should always do...That's check on that puppy and find out just why it's so quiet and peaceful...This morning Todd knocked over the flowerpot on the back porch and as he dug into the pot, all the dirt was thrown into the house..And tracked through the house...Lesson learned??I don't think so...At least not for Todd!I hope you're having a good weekend!

title: The Arrival of a Girl Named Riley
text: ~Toby celebrating the return of the internet! ~As you can see, our internet (and our land-line) have been repaired and I can once again step away from my world and take a peak into yours. Â I've really missed reading about what you're up to and I look forward to catching up! Â  It has been a busy few days and there has been a lot going on. Â I was asked by the rescue on Friday if I would consider taking a new foster dog. Â I have to be honest and say that I've really been trying to cut down on our expenses and decided to not take in another dog. Â I'd received a mass e-mail from the rescue earlier in the week asking all the foster homes to consider taking an eight year old girl named Riley. Â What first caught my attention was her having what could be considered a 'boy name' like our beloved Rudi, and Reggie. Â But Riley had some 'special needs.' And as I read the e-mail about her, knowing foster homes are at a premium, I remember hoping that the rescue would be able to find a place for her. Â I then forgot about Riley until I was asked specifically if I would consider taking her. Â Not being able to say no of course I agreed. Riley's story is of course a bit of a sad one. Â Her family lost their home. Â Unable to care for her, and unable to take her to the apartment that they were moving to, they contacted the rescue. Times were really difficult for this family, and another dog that they had, aÂ Papillon died from heart-worm. Â Riley had not been to the vet since 2007. ~This is how Riley stands~Among some other issues, Riley is handicapped. Â She is lame in her hind-limbs. Â As you can see in the picture, she has a slumped posture and is unable to fully extend her back legs, walk or stand normally, and can't even be taken for a walk. Â Stairs are very difficult. Â Riley needed a home that was easy to navigate inside and out and on one level, a house like ours. I picked her up last night, and she's a nervous wreck. Â She is pacing and panting and is so confused by what is happening to her that she won't settle down or eat, and has barely paid attention to the other dogs. Â It's times like this that I wish I could just tell her that she's going to be okay. Â But all I can do is give her lots of reassurance that hopefully she'll soon understand. At the moment, Riley does not have a lot of 'outer beauty' Â like Sheba or Reggie. Â She has a severe overbite and because of the poor condition of her coat, she was shaved down completely. Â Her eyes and face are full of worry. Â However despite what's on the outside, I'm finding is that she has a kind heart and gentle personality. Â For some reason, I'm finding myself humbled by her this morning. Â I am hoping that the rescue will allow her to be seen by an orthopedic surgeon to see if anything can be done to help her. Â I am hoping that I can make a difference for a girl named Riley. ~Riley~

title: No Internet and No Land Line
text: ~Reggie~Living in the country, at least for me, has had very few drawbacks.Â One drawback however, has been struggling to keep a good internet connection.Â  While we are on 'high-speed' it's pretty slowÂ andÂ only a little faster than dial-up.Â  There are many times where staying connectedÂ seems nearly impossible.Â  I've learned to live with it.Â Â For some whoÂ live on our road, dial-up isÂ their only choice.Â  On Friday, we lost use of our land-line and use of the internet.Â Â Our phone connection was partially restored on Saturday morning, and so was the internet.Â  But it quickly went out again.Â  Carl called Verizon and theyÂ have promised to come by Thursday....Carl, knowing my sanity was at risk, called again and they said they would try to fix it sooner.Feeling a little isolated from the world, (and needing an internet fix) Â I've come to my office this morning to catch up on e-mails.Â  ButÂ until Verizon makes good on that promise to fix everything,Â I won't be able to visit your blogs.Â  I'll miss reading what you are up too--But IÂ hope you've had a good weekend!Â  Despite the dark cloud hanging over me because ofÂ no internet connection, ourÂ weather in Virginia has been gorgeous!Â Â I've gottenÂ things done outside, and taken the dogs for several longÂ walks.Â  Â Â Â  Finally, as we all know, today isÂ a day of remembranceÂ as weÂ rememberÂ the events and those that lost their lives on September 11th.Â  I knowÂ we are alsoÂ keeping inÂ our heartsÂ the loved ones they left behind as well.Â  There are many, many stories from that day.Â  One thatÂ touches my heart is written by a friend of mine who was living in New York City with her husband andÂ two Goldens, Hope and Darwin.Â Â I posted this last year, but I find Nan's storyÂ very compelling, because it is one of survival and determination.Â Â I hope you'll takeÂ a minute toÂ read about 'Two Who Survived.'Â  http://landofpuregold.com/2whosurvived.htm

title: The Interview
text: Today was a big day. Â Todd was going for his 'interview' to attend the new daycare. I could tell by the 8 page application and being told to expect to stay there for at least 2 hours, that this wasn't going to be an ordinary place for him to spend a couple of days a week. We've had nothing but rain the entire week so needless say, Todd was smelling a bit 'doggy.' Â So I remedied that this morning with a bath. Â How could he be denied entry into a daycare being clean and fluffy and smelling likeÂ lavenderÂ and mint? Â Todd was not particularly happy about the bath, especially before breakfast--Being a terrier, he had his own opinion and I think the picture below pretty much summed up his thoughts on the whole thing...The evaluation went really well. Â He did just fine with meeting everyone two and four legged. Â The person doing the interview said several times how nicely he got along with the other dogs. Â Thankfully there were no cats there! After an hour-and-a-half, I was told that 'they thought Todd would be a good fit there.' I knew he would be, how could you say no to that face anyway? Â I know I can't! Â Finally, I'll just let you all know that Reggie has eaten all of her meals today, and is up and around just a bit more than yesterday--A little golden ray of sunshine at the end of a rainy day!

title: Paws and Fingers Crossed
text: I've so appreciated the good thoughts for Reggie! Â My concern for her grew when she hardly moved off the dog-bed on Monday and wouldn't eat. Â I reluctantly left her on Tuesday when I returned to work. Â However I felt that she would be 'okay' Â because our dog walker was coming midday and she would let me know ifÂ ReggieÂ wasn't doing well. Â When I got home from work, Reggie was still in the same place as she was when I'd left her in the morning. Â My dog walker had been unable to get her to go outside. Â Thinking and hoping that the medications that she has been taking might be the cause for the sudden change, I decided that I would take Reggie off of them.The vet that I have come to respect and trust for the past 6 years is currently on maternity leave. Until she returns we are seeing a recently graduated vet named 'Chrissy Johnson.' Â I think her name fits her because she looks like she's about 12 years old, and is no bigger than a pencil. Â We discussed everything and I was glad that she supported my taking Reggie off the medications for now. Â This morning Reggie ate a little and met me at the door when I got home this evening. Â While Reggie is still not herself, and her appetite hasn't fully returned, I'm really hoping that maybe we're heading in a positive direction--Paws and fingers crossed!! .~Sam & CC~

title: Our Girl Reggie
text: Its been a busy few days. Â Despite not feeling well, we've had company come for dinner one evening and things to get caught up on. Â One thing that I had to do was take Reggie to the vet. Â She's also not been feeling well the last few days. Â Her activity has decreased as has her appetite; which I've learned is unusual for her. Â She has been limping and I'm hoping that it's just because her shoulder is bothering her. Â At one time in her life it was broken and repaired with about a 7 inch plate, screws and a wire pin. Â I've found that we have to not allow Reggie to pull on the lead or her shoulder starts to bother her and she can't put any weight on her leg. Â We've put her on pain medications and stopped taking her for walks. Â Today is the first day she's not limping. I'm really hoping that's what it is and she'll perk up. Â It goes without saying that since we first met in June, I've gotten pretty attached this sweet girl named Reggie.

title: Loss of Appetite
text: A doctor appointment took me to Reston Virginia, the place where our life inÂ VirginiaÂ began in 1995. Â We lived in what was then a 'small town,' for about a year before we moved to our last house the following year. Â That small town has really grown into a large location for businesses and residences. The heart of the town is the Reston Town Center which has many upscale shops, restaurants and condominiums. Â Large brand name companies such as Rolls-Royce North America and Google have offices in the town center. Â I always look forward to going there and enjoying the shops that we don't have in the county where I live. Unfortunately my doctor appointment didn't go all that well because the subject of my needing to lose a 'few pounds' was brought up. Â I think that's just what doctors do. Â I know in our office we stress brushing and flossing more to patients who are really doing pretty well. Â But the subject of weight loss always bothers me. Â So needless to say I was feeling a bit discouraged afterwards and I did the only thing I could do that just seemed to make sense...I stopped at 'Einstein Brothers Bagels.' Â I hadn't been there since last year andÂ IÂ love their 'everything bagel' with cream cheese. Â Â  Â Then I went to 'Trader Joes.'They have great produce and flowers!The next stop was 'Whole Foods.'They have a really nice bakery--Their cheese danish is a favorite!Finally, I went to 'Wegmans' for the rest of the needed groceries. Â It's all good there!When Carl got home from work he asked me what was for dinner. Â For some reason, I wasn't hungry and didn't feel like cooking. Â Doctor appointments do have a way of making you lose your appetite, don't they?? Â  Â  Â  Â ~Reggie~

title: Daycare Woes
text: Those of you who have seen my posting on my Facebook page know that I had a bit of an issue with the daycare where I've been taking Todd. Â When I arrived there on Tuesday to pick him up, he had on a 'no bark collar.' Â When I asked why he was wearing one, theÂ girl told me that it was because he'd  been barking constantly.Â  I have to admit I was taken back by their putting one  on him, but tried to not make too much of an issue about it. Â The staff member told me that they'd  tried squirting water at Todd to get him to stop barking, but he just playedÂ with  the water--Which he does.Â  Then it was mentioned that theyÂ MIGHT use a  small shock collar on himÂ if he continues to bark all the time. Â When I was told that, I remained polite, but made it pretty clear that I really felt that this type of correction was inappropriate to use on such a young dog. I was then told that Â Scotties can become  incessantÂ barkersÂ and that it was the only way to teach them not to  bark. Â Needless to say, I was upset by this whole thing. Not having a place to leave Todd, I took him back to the daycare on Wednesday. Â The whole day all I could think about was the bark-collar, and how I am Todd's owner and his best advocate, so of course I felt guilty all day and worried about him. Â Last evening when I picked him up I asked if the bark collar had been used. Â They told me that it hadn't but that Todd had spent part of the day alone in another room, and part of it with another terrier mix. Â More guilt thinking that he was by himself.For several other reasons, I had already been considering taking Todd to another daycare, and this past Monday I set up a consultation with a new one for next week. Â All of this just confirms what I've been thinking and feeling. Â But it's also a reminder to follow and act on my instincts when it comes to the care of our dogs and to remember that I'm their voice when someone is trying to quiet theirs.

title: Leader of the Pack
text: As with all dogs, there is a social system. Â This goes for our dogs too. Â In watching them I can see that it's actually pretty well developed. Â I feel like there is an orderly relationship and  'communication' among them as they relate and interact with one another. Â With Rudi gone, we knew there would be  changesÂ within the pack.Â  We don't force these changes, but let the dogs decide  for themselves when and how these changes will occur.Â Â It has been interesting  to watch.Â  Rudi really kept everyone 'in line' and they followed her lead. Â When one of the dogs didn't come when called, she'd chide them when they returned. Â Even  when she wasn't feeling well, they seemed to know what was expected of them.Â   After she passed, we had several days where there was definite discord and  direction.Â  I really had to get after a couple of the dogs because they would  wander off, or not listen when asked to do something. Â There were a few brief squabbles and you could see that there was not a sense of unity among them. Â I knew things would settle down and eventuallyÂ there would be a new  pack leader.Â Â Who would it be? Â Well, we knew who it wouldn't be. Â Within the group there are 'the followers' who are not really involved in the politics of the pack. Â That is saved for a few of the others.Â The new comer to our pack, Reggie, is one of those followers. Â Â Wendy, (who came to us in 1999) at almost 15 years old is considered the matriarch of the pack.Â Even Todd has learned to give her that respect. Â Â  Â But at the top of the pack, is the fair andÂ mischievousÂ Carrie-Anne...Â Followed by Sheba who is very energetic, social, but can be bossy and dominant. Â She hasÂ often needed to be reminded of her place.Then there's Josh. Â Regal, proud, quiet and self assured. Â His confidence in himself often shows. Â While they could all fill that role,if you think that our new pack leader is one of them, you're wrong. The new pack leader at Golden Pines is...Todd--Young and energetic and full of confidence,he has us hopping and jumping to meet his every need!! Â But don't tell Charlie, he thinks it's him!~Okay, I was kidding about Todd,but as we expected, Charlie has become the new pack-leader~Â But the cat, CC thinks it's her (actually it's her, but don't tell Charlie...) Â Whoever is 'in charge' of your household, whatever you're doing,Â I hope you're having a enjoyable day!Rain here in northern Virginia todayand just as with the earthquake this week,we may feel the effects ofÂ HurricaneÂ Irene this weekend.

title: The Tooth Fairy
text: I thought that when we got a puppy our life would be totally turned upside down. Â I'm actually finding that (at least right now) it really isn't. Â I can only conclude that our life must be upside down to start with. Â Todd does what all puppies do, he gets into everything. Â And just when we think that he couldn't get into anything else, he finds something to literally getÂ tangled in. But you may be able to imagine my concern this afternoon when Todd started whining and opening and closing his mouth. Â I thought maybe the cookie I'd just given him had gotten caught in his throat. Â But my finger in his mouth felt nothing but had blood on it. Â He managed to get away from me and ran out the open back door. Â I finally was able to catch him and I had Carl hold him as I looked down his throat...Nothing...FINALLY my eye caught sight of what it was...He was losing one of his molars--It was really loose and just barely hanging on, and so I pulled it out. Â Â Mystery solved and Todd did the only thing he could do after that kind of event--Take a nap!! Â I wonder if Â he'll be hoping for the tooth fairy to leave something under that stuffed animal?

title: Good Feelings!
text: One of the first of many tenth-anniversary commemorations of the 9/11 terror  attacks began today when almost 2,000 motorcyclists launched the America's 9/11 Ride. When I got home, those 'good feelings' continued when I watched wild turkey's in our yard. Â  Â Then I let the dogs out and CarrieAnne found something green and smelly to roll in and needed a bath...Good feeling gone... Â  I hope you have a 'good-feeling' weekend!!

title: Back to Life--Did You Miss Us?
text: I can't begin to tell you how touched I was to  receiveÂ the many kind and thoughtful commentsÂ on the loss of our girl Rudi.Â Loss  can be a lonely time, but your friendshipÂ changed that. Â Saying thank-you for  the cards, candles and e-mails doesn't seem like enough or express how you've  made a difference at a sad time.Â Â Moving on from a loss isn't something we can always just  decide to do and I found that IÂ needed a little time to myself.Â Â So that was  what I did, I took a break from just about everything.Â Â I didn't read blogs, I  didn't cook,Â I didn't do a lot of things...But yesterday I started to feel a bit better.Â  It's time to  get back to my everyday life.Â  At just the right time,Â I was given the  'Versatile Blogger Award byÂ jodi stone--Life with Sampson and Delilahâ€¦.The 411Â  Jodi is someone I have just met andÂ is an every day blogger who writes about her life with her two retrievers, Sampson and Delilah, and a supporting cast member, a cat named Bob. I hope you'll take a moment and pay her a visit! Â Â WhileÂ I know they are not true awards I am  happy to accept this one because it's given me the nudge to get me started blogging  again. Â This award comes with three rules which are:Â 1.Â Â Thank the person passing on the  award.Â Thank-you Jodi for giving me something to write a post about!! Â Also thank-you so much for your kind, Â friendly e-mail!Â  I look  forward to getting to know you and your crew a bit better!! Â 2. Â The second thing when you get this award is to: Write 7 things about yourself.Â I don't really  like talking about myself, so I've decided to change it up a bit, and list 7  things about where I live that you may not know. Â 1. Â Our property is situated on 3.5 acres at the foot of theÂ Short Hill  Mountains inÂ Loudoun County Virginia.Â  2. We have no nearby neighbors and are surrounded by 30 acres of open  farmland.Â  3. I didn't like our house when I first saw it. Â It had been empty for almost 2 years and seemed so void of life. Â But what I loved was the big  front porch andÂ the outside space which is still my favorite!Â Â The house and I  have learned to get along.4. Where our house is now, was once a cornfield.5. One of our oldestÂ trees on our property is a huge, beautiful mapleÂ tree. Â It's one of my favorites. Â I love its big, long branches. Â 6. I never grow tired of seeing the wildlife we have around. Â The picture below is one of two deer that wandered through our yard this afternoon. Â 7. A favorite, a Barred Owl has just returned. Â Actually, there are two. The last thing I'm to do with this award is to pass it onto 15 people whose blogs I have just discovered. I am really really bad about things like this. I have found several new blogs lately that I really enjoy but I have a hard time singling them out because I don't want to forget anyone...For me it kind of feels like having a birthday party and being forced to invite  only a fewÂ friends instead of the whole class! Â Find one that you're not familiar with and pay them a visit, and make a new friend, just like I did in meeting Jodi! I look forward to catching up on everyone's blogs! Â I hope you're enjoying your Thursday!

title: A Tribute to Our Girl Rudi
text: Today was the day I'd been dreading for the last 56 days. Â Today I held Rudi one last time, and sent her to the Rainbow Bridge. It was a hard decision, but was one made out of my love for her and compassion...Rudi came to us from the rescue in September of 2003.Â  A homeless woman who lived in her car, had seen her in a shelter in North Carolina.Â Â  Rules were different at the time, andÂ the shelter released the oneÂ year old Golden named Sandy to her.Â She hadÂ been returned to the shelter 3 timesÂ for her wild and uncontrollable behavior and was considered 'un-adoptable.'Â Â She wasÂ renamed Rudi and in a car full of other dogs, she came to Virginia.Â  Not knowing her history, I agreed to foster Rudi because I thought that she'd be an easy placement.Â Â She turned out to be anything but that.~Rudi enjoying the cat-food~There is so much I could say about the first months we spent together.Â Â Rudi was an insecure dog with very high energy and never seemed to be able to focus on anything.Â Â It didn't take long to figure outÂ that others had not been as patient, and had mistreated her.Â  There were timesÂ that I doubted thatÂ I would be able to help her find her way or teach her anything.Â Â There were days that I felt pushed to the edge by the seemingly uncontrollableÂ dog that barked all the time who would jump up andÂ nip me in the face.Â  She was always into everything.Â Â Nothing left on a counter was out of her reach, the cat food was her favorite.Â Â Medications seemed to have the opposite effect on her.Â  She couldn't be crated alone because she'd break out of them. Â When many were telling me to 'give up' I just couldn't.Â Â It was only because in my mind I had a vision of what she could become if given the chance.Â I have no idea when things started to change andÂ come together.Â Â I guess it wasÂ me that changed. Â I stopped trying to fit her into a mold and just let her be herself.Â Â RudiÂ had such a bigÂ personality, wasÂ very bright andÂ was so eager to please. Â She was very sensitive and was 'in tune' with my moods. Â Rudi was a dog with great character.Â If dogs have a sense of humor, she had one and sheÂ loved to 'show off.' Â She could always make me laugh. Â When you askedÂ her to do things,Â she would start barking at you or ramble on inÂ high-pitched short barks like she was questioning you.Â  She always seemed to haveÂ an opinion of anything you did.Â  Her tail was always wagging and her eyes always sparkled with mischief andÂ she would look at youÂ like she had a secret that she wanted you to guess.~Rudi (left) and Kasey--October 2009~RudiÂ foundÂ mentors in Kasey and Wendy. When Kasey passed a few years ago,Â Rudi becameÂ the top dog in the pack. SheÂ took Kasey's place on the bed that first night and neverÂ slept anywhere else.Â Â Her passion was the frisbee.Â  She was wildly crazy about it!! Â From the start it was theÂ perfect outlet that allowed her to get rid ofÂ all her energyÂ andÂ just be herself.Rudi was more to me than 'just a dog.'Â  If I had to tell you all the things that she taught me, it would be hard to give you a completeÂ answer.Â  She made me become a better person and a more understanding and patient dog owner.Â  To me, she was the essence of friendship, trust and pure unbridled joy and enthusiasm.Â Â Life with Rudi wasn't ordinary, but then Rudi wasn't ordinary.Â Â She was an affectionate dog that was my constant companion forÂ 8 years.Â Â I am going to miss her more than I've ever missed any dog.Â  WalksÂ won't be the same. Â Games of frisbeeÂ won't be as much fun. Â Mealtimes will be quieter.Â  Life will be quieter.God speedÂ 'my little fruitcake.'Â Â You will have quite a welcome when you reach the Rainbow Bridge...Waiting for you there are a threeÂ Goldens, Tod,Â Ben and Cougar that left us before you came.Â Â But Kasey will be there andÂ I know she'llÂ be happy to see you. Â Also there are Scout, Tosh,Â Tucker, Logan, Cubby, Cowboy, Maguire, Tanner, and Hamlet.Â  Give them our message and know that we look forward to the day when we'll see you all again.Â  I just hope there will beÂ a frisbee there too.

title: What Did I Miss Most?
text: All is quiet here at home. Â Carl is finally back from his 10 day trip to Wisconsin to see family. Â It's kind of hard to say which I missed more, him or my good camera that he took with him, having his help with the dogs, or the good camera (did I mention that already?) Â All of them I guess! The weather today could not have been more gorgeous! Â There was low humidity and lots of sunshine! Â I sat on the porch for awhile with the dogs and we enjoyed one another's company as the sound of cicadas filled the air, and the elusive hummingbirds which I've been trying to get a picture of buzzed around. Â  Todd who hasn't spent much time on the front porch enjoyed it too. Being overprotective, I've been afraid that he would try to leap off, but so far, he hasn't...At least not yet. Rudi has almost totally lost her appetite. Â She wants nothing except dog-treats, which I give her by the hand-full. Tomorrow I'm going to try to remember to bring home a fast-food-hamburger. Â Dogs always love them, right? Â I left work early yesterday when our dog-walker called and said that she was laying in the crate and wouldn't come out. Â When I got home, Rudi was up on her feet but was very quiet and seemedÂ uncomfortable. Â I've started her on pain medication which seems to have helped because this afternoon she found the enthusiasm to play frisbee. Each day that we have together is a good day! Â I hope yours has been a good one as well! Â (Did I mention that it's so niceÂ to have my good camera back, and oh, Carl too?!)

title: Just What I Needed
text: The day has been just what I needed, quiet and uneventful. Â It gave me the chance to get caught up on everything from the dusting to the laundry. Â Todd'sÂ curiosityÂ about everything continued as he explored the inside of the dryer this afternoon.Last night he became acquainted with a big toad on our porch.I silently gave a cheer and a prayer of thanks as Rudi reached day 50 of grace today. Each day that passes becomes more of a valued treasure, time more precious. Â We quietly celebrated with a very, very brief game of frisbee. Â Anytime she has one, she seems happy. Â It goes without saying that I'm happy too. Â Â Â I hope you've had a good weekend!

title: Dog Tired!
text: I can't begin to say what a good feeling it is that it's not even noon, and I'm home and done with all my errands. Â The dogs have all been walked, fed, loved and played with. Â They are all napping nearby. Â Sitting here at my computer I'm watching the hummingbirds out my window at the feeder. Â There is a welcomed feeling of peace and calm as we wait for the forecasted rain later today. Â  It was a week that started out so well, but took a bit of a detour. Â With Carl gone it became very busy and hectic. Â It didn't help that I got a ticket on Wednesday for making a turn in an 'authorized vehicle only' place on the highway. Â Of course I have my reason for why I was turning around that comes complete with the excuses that I didn't see the sign at first and with another car behind me doing the same thing, I had no choice but to make the turn. Â The police officer, who I thought was arrogant and indifferent, didn't care about any of it. The maximum fine for this horrible crime that I have committed is $250. Â I can only hope forÂ leniency. Â Â  Â  Rudi continues to do 'just okay.' Â I took her with me to the farm stand this morning. Â She tries to accompany us on our daily walks, but because she wears out easily, she'll stop along the way and lay down. Â I usually go back and sit with her until she has the energy to walk back to the house. Â On some days she'll have no appetite whatsoever, other days she'll eat most of her meal. Â For the next mealtime I try to make the exact same thing for her hoping she'll eat again, but she'll refuse it. I can only keep trying.Todd started day care this week. Â He really loved it!! Â One of my biggest reasons for wanting him to have this experience is because I'm concerned about Todd being so shy and reserved around people that he doesn't know. So I think that his having positive interactions with people when I'm not around will be good for him. Of course playing with 'kids his own age' is just as invaluable. Â When we've gotten home in the evenings, Todd has been so worn out, he has just eaten his dinner and fallen asleep for the rest of the night. Â I have had to wake him up to take him outside and he's even been too tired to chase the cat--Now that's dog tired!

title: The End of the Weekend!
text: ~Bubba~I"m so glad this weekend is over!! Â Carl left on Saturday to take my brother back home to Kentucky and is leaving from there to go to Wisconsin on Monday. Â But it does mean that I'm a 'single parent' for a week. Â We got off to a rocky start when I had another, yes another flat tire on my van. Â I've no idea how it keeps happening, but I'm glad that we bought the warranty that went with the tires! This morning at about 3:30, Todd woke me up whining. Â He'd been playing in the water, so it was only right that he would need an extra trip outside during the night. Â Just as things were settling down Bubba started having a seizure. I sat with him and waited for it to end, knowing he would be disoriented afterwards and need some reassurance. Â I'm not sure what time we finally got back to bed.This direction continued when Rudi's day didn't start out well. Â As the day has continued, she has rallied to be with us another day. Â She ate part of her meal this evening. Â I can feel her spark dimming, but I marvel at her strength and determination to take in as many moments as she can.I don't know what the week ahead will bring for Rudi. Â But for Todd it will be a busy one because he starts 'day care' on Monday. title: What I Did on My Summer Vacation
text: I've always been intrigued with old empty buildings and abandoned homes.Â   SoÂ the chance toÂ visitÂ Waverly Hills, which is a closed sanatorium in Louisville  was something I just couldn't pass up.Â  In the early 1900's, Jefferson County  where it's located, was full of swampland making the area a perfect environment  for an outbreak of tuberculosis.Â  TheÂ sanatoriumÂ was built to accommodate 400Â tuberculosis  patients and opened in 1910.Â Â  During the thirty five years of its existence it  was reported thatÂ 63,000 people died at Waverly Hills.Â Â However,Â the county puts  that number at around 10,000.Â  Either way itÂ is an eerieÂ place that sits on a hillÂ over looking the city of  LouisvilleÂ Kentucky.Â  To me it looks a little like aÂ reigning fortress of gloom. Â But it has been given theÂ reputation of beingÂ 'one of the most haunted places in  the United States' by those in the paranormal field who have visited there extensively.Over the years, Waverly Hills has been totally vandalized. Â But the structure remains sound and work is currently being done to restore it and make it into a hotel for ghost-seekers. Â As a way to make money for this undertaking, all kinds of tours are given from 2 hour tours to overnight stays. Â The two-hour tour that my brothers and IÂ went on Saturday night is touted as being a 'paranormal ghost tour.' Â While most were there hoping for a ghostly encounter, I was there out ofÂ curiosityÂ and to see the inside of this historical building.~Down one of the hallways--If the walls could talk.~One of the most talked about and famous aspects of the Waverly Hills Sanatorium  is the Body Chute or Death Tunnel. Â At the  peak of the TB epidemic, many patients died everyday.Â In order to keep morale up  and not upset patients, the hospital administration decided to use the  Body Chute to discretely send bodies away from the hospital by the use of a rail-car wench-type system in the tunnel that transported the bodies of deceased TB patients to waiting hearses or trains. Â Due to the lack of electricity, there is total darkness inside of the tunnel  after about thirty feet down. The acoustics  are interesting and there is a strong echo when you talk.Waverly Hills was a state-of-the-art facility. The rooms were very nice, and  many lead out to porches so the patients could get plenty of fresh air; many spent as much as 15 hours each day on these porches. Â Electric blankets were used in the winter. Â Patients even had radios with headphones on the porches and in the rooms so they could listen to music. The sanatorium had a chapel, a school for the children,  and special housing for the hospital staff also.Here's a picture of what the porches used to look like:Â The tour takes you to all the floors and you're told many stories including being able to hear voices of children chanting "Ring Around The  Rosy" on the roof top terrace. Â There is even said to have been encounters with an apparition of one of the two nurses who died  in room 502, and of visitors who have crossed paths with the shadow people of the fourth floor. One story is told of the spirit of a child that haunts the third floor who has been known to play with toys and roll balls. Â With this in mind there are balls placed around each floor because they've been known to start rolling with no explanation. Â In complete darkness we waited for a ball to roll...It didn't move until.... I walked past and nudged it with my foot! Â I don't know what made me do it--But those behind me on the tour thought they were having that awaited encounter with the paranormal because when I glanced over my shoulder and watched them with their flashlights, and heard their exclamations, I realized they hadn't seen me bump the ball as I walked past. Â I didn't have the heart to tell them anything differently and it gave my brothers and I a really good chuckle afterwards! Next year, my brothers want to do the 'overnight stay.' Â We'll see...Would you visit Waverly Hills?

title: Tuesday at Golden Pines
text: I'm back from Kentucky with my youngest brother who will be here until the end of the week. Rudi and Charlie went with me, and are great traveling companions! Â Both don't seem to mind the almost 11 hour trip as long as they get their turn at sitting in the front seat. The mishaps from the trip were a flat-tire on Saturday morning and on Sunday a fall at a gas station. I was so thankful that the flat didn't occur during the drive home, and that I'm only bruised and skinned up from landing practically face down on the pavement--Both could have been so much worse! Carl did a great job taking care of the dogs including Todd, who I think grew while I was gone.Â On Wednesday I'm taking Reggie back to the vet for the x-rays of her chest. Â She's doing well too, and I really think she's feeling better. Â Her skin has really improved and is healing. Â Her ears have cleared up nicely as well, all good signs! Â There is a content feeling about Reggie and she seems happy. Today is 'day 38 of grace' for Rudi. Â She has good days and like today, some not so good ones. She's very quiet and subdued, but still seems to be 'okay.' Â Whatever kind of day it is, I continue to cheer her on and hope for more, and I thank-you all for doing the same!

title: Road Trip!!!
text: I wish I could say that I am going some place to cool off, but unfortunately I'm not. Â Today I'm driving to Kentucky and right through the heat wave. Accompanying me on this trip will be Charlie, of course. Â I am on the fence about taking Rudi. Â She didn't eat yesterday and I worry that something may happen on the way. Â But she seems to feel 'okay' and there's a part of me that thinks this trip would be a good one for both of us to share because it'll be our last one. Â Time together, even just in the car is always good.I was going to take Todd with me too. Â But I've decided to leave him at home. Â I'm really going to miss him. Â I'll be back at the start of the week, and will look forward to catching up on your news when I return.

title: Trying to Escape!
text: A National Weather forecaster called the heat wave gripping the country 'unrelenting.' Â It's supposed to get worse by the end of the week. Â I try to not complain about it because after spending 10 years in Alaska, I remember the days when I thought my summers were way too short and way too cool.Â Â But there's just no way to escape the searing temperatures. Â  Â However Todd is trying to escape and doing a pretty good job! Â I hope you're finding ways to escape the heat!~Toby~

title: Justice for Reggie
text: Off to the vet this morning with Reggie. Â Her last blood work results showed some abnormalities and it needs to be rechecked now that she's finished a long course of antibiotics. Â Also on the list are x-rays to see if there are any changes in her heart and lungs since June. As you know, she's doing well. Â I find her to be endearing and it's not just because of her attentiveness to Todd. Â I think it's just in how she looks at you; her big, brown soulful eyes draw me in, she is gentle with great character and heart. Â A reminder of why I love senior Goldens.Among the paperwork I received with Reggie are all papers related to the neglect charges that were filed against the owner and their name. Â Thanks to all court cases in Virginia being online I was able to find the case and its result. Â It appears that the previous owner spent 15 days in jail, paid all fees relating to the case, (which hopefully included Reggie's surgery), a fine, and they are not allowed to own a pet for two years--I personally don't think they should ever be allowed to own one, but that's just my opinion. But I do feel like an amount of justice was served in Reggie's case, and I hope 'they' are feeling regret over how she was neglected, and maybe, just maybe, they realize the treasure they've lost. Â  Â  Today our beautiful and cooler weather continues ahead of what will be another heatwave predicted for next week. Â On the list today is the hopes and goal of catching up on your blogs--I so appreciate your stopping by and keeping up with us, I really enjoy reading your comments and hope you enjoy your weekend!!~I just cannot stop taking pictures of butterflies~

title: Late to Bed Early to Rise
text: This week I'mÂ really tired.Â Â I'mÂ blaming it on advancing age, poor blood,  lack of vitamins, air pollution, the heat andÂ the hole in the ozone.Â Â I'm quite sure it has nothing to do  with getting up at 4 AM and staying up too late. But whatever the reason, I am  glad the week is coming to an end!Rudi is doing just okay. Â She has been quieter the last couple of days and continues to not have much of an appetite. We are able to get her to eat a little, but I'm wondering if she eats because she knows we want her too. Â However she still has that spark and will follow me around. Â She seems comfortable enough and content and that's all that matters. Â Â  Â The only one whose not worn out this week is Todd. Â He's been so good at work! Â I think that Reggie misses him because she seems happy to see him and plays with him when we get home. But Todd being crated all day shows when we get home. He's energetic and into everything! Â We're finding that socks are making their way outside.....But it's all okay...They're Carl's socks!Â I hope your week is going well!Â Â I'm really trying to get caught up on my blog visits and look forward to reading about what's going on in your world. Â ~Sammy~

title: Dog Days of Summer
text: A quiet weekend. Â Well, as quiet as it can be when you have a puppy around! Â Todd is finding his place and forging relationships with all the dogs. Â He and Charlie had a real bonding moment when the two of them worked on digging a hole next to the barn. Â I think Charlie was probably digging it so Todd could escape never to be seen again, and Todd was just digging for the fun of it. Â Whatever their reasons, it seems to have helped them toÂ almost work out the differences Charlie felt they had.Today we are atÂ day 23 of grace with Rudi. Â I have remained a bit humbled and grateful for each day, because I don't know if it'll be our last. Â There has been a different look in Rudi's eyes the last week or so and I've noticed herÂ watching me. Â I even wake up at night and she's there on the bed looking at me.Â Â I can't help but wonder what she's thinking or if she's trying to tell me something; I've always felt that if Rudi were a person she'd never be able to keep a secret.Â Â Her appetite has decreased over the last few days, and we try to tempt her to eat with baby food--Sometimes she'll eat, other times she won't. Â She sleeps more and wears out pretty easily. Â Yesterday evening she hadn't eaten all day and didn't want to go outside with us for a walk, but I insisted. Â She was laying in the driveway and on a whim I threw her, her most favorite toy of all, a frisbee--Suddenly she came to life and wanted to play. Â A couple of very small tosses for her was all it took to lift both our spirits. Â When we came back in, she ate her whole meal. Mother Reggie is also doing well, and continues to watch over Todd.Â Â I see aÂ spark as she now anxiously goes for walks with us, never looking back towards the house. Â She doesn't even mind being outside alone and is much more relaxed.Â Â I take all this as an indication that she's feeling secure and has found her place here with us--Wait, wasn't she only supposed to be here temporarily?I hope your week is off to a good start and you're getting some relief from the heat. Our news is reporting that the Washington D.C. area has been named the 6th hottest city in the nation--What an honor as we are currently in the dog-days of summer!

title: A Promise Kept??
text: For 2 days, I had Todd at the office with me. Â I kept my part of the bargain that I made with the doctor. Â I didn't take Todd into the waiting room...Or let him near the front desk....Todd stayed out of the sterilization area...And didn't go any where near the operatories....He was so good and stayed in his crate in the break-room the whole time ...At least while the doctor was there and working...

title: Off to the Dentist!
text: Socialization as you know is really important for any puppy. Â And since we are gone from home 2-3 days a week, I've been trying to find a day care for Todd during those times. Â However I'm running into an unexpected problem in that while he has 'age appropriate vaccines' he is still missing a couple like rabies, which he is not yet old enough for, and bordetella. Â The daycare that I really wanted to take him to Â allowed puppies to come without their rabies and 4th distemper vaccine. Â But 2 weeks ago they changed theirÂ requirements and now all dogs regardless of age must have ALL vaccines and mustÂ be immunized for canine influenza, which I won't give him--I learned from an 'insider' that they'd had a couple of dogs there that had it, so this was why it was added to their list. Â (My vet doesn't give the CIV vaccine, and since I'm trying to limit the vaccines the puppy gets, he wouldn't have gotten it anyway. Â Do you have any thoughts you'd like to share about this or any other vaccine, I'd be interested to hear). Â Â Finding another day care has been trickier than I thought it would be because of his age. Â However I knew before we got Todd that this might become an issue. Â So with a little bit of convincing, the doctor I work for agreed to my bringing Todd to the office. Â However there are a few rules, one being that he must be kept in his crate in the break-room, and cannot be taken out (except by me and only to be taken outside) and is not allowed in other parts of the office--Of course I agreed, and I will be the model employee during those times--Wish us luck at the dentist!

title: Tod and Todd - What's In a Name?
text: A few of you have asked where we got the name 'Todd' for our newest, and youngest addition. Â Today I thought I'd share with you where the name came from.Carl and I got our first Golden Retriever in June of 1996. Â Of course we wanted to pick out the perfect name for him. Â I wanted to name him 'Fox' but Carl and the person we got him from, balked at that. Then I remembered a favorite Disney movie called 'The Fox and the Hound' which you may recall tells the story of two unlikely friends, a red fox named Tod and a hound dog named Copper--The name Tod means fox, so Tod it was! Tod was as all Goldens are supposed to be, handsome, friendly, playful and easy going...Sadly though, he was diagnosed with lymphoma and died just before his 6th birthday. Â  ~Tod and our cat Drifter~Being the sentimental person that I am, I thought of naming our first Scottish Terrier, Tod, after our first Golden Retriever, adding the second letter 'd' to the end, but I just wasn't sure. Â Then when I was researching Scottish names, I came across a website that explained that Tod is a Scots word for fox. (In Scotland and the north of England a todhunter is a fox hunter.) While the doubling of the final letter is a 'corruption,' it's the more common spelling, and most of the 'Todd's' are Scots. Â With that, I decided that Todd was to be the name of our new puppy! Â It has been a long time since I've called a dog named Tod. Â And I Â have to admit that at first its use brought back a lot of sadness because of its connection to a life that ended much too soon. Â But now I'm finding that a name that was connected to heartbreak is changing with the antics of a little Scottish Terrier who shares the same name.

title: Life Goes On
text: A very quiet holiday weekend for us. Â All we've done is spend time at Â home with the dogs. Â Rudi had been doing really well--Her appetite was good, and she felt well enough to go on walks with us. Â But yesterday her abdomen again started to feel bloated, and the paleness of her gums returned. Â With that brought a loss of most of her appetite and energy. Â We'll take each day as it comes, enjoy them and let her decide the pace she wants to take. On the flip-side we are of course enjoying the energy that only a puppy has!Â Â Todd had hisÂ first vet appointmentÂ Friday, and our little growing boy weighed over 10 pounds!Â  ThereÂ are also very brief moments when Charlie doesn't seem to mind Todd--Progress!!Around us the fruit and vegetable stands are opening up for the season. Â  Â And just as I decided that I liked the overgrown field next to us, it was cut for hay. Â Life, like Todd keeps moving on in our little corner of northern Virginia. Â I hope you're having a good weekend!

title: The DMV and a Lesson Learned??
text: I knew in May that I needed to renew my drivers license.Â  ButÂ I did what I  always do, and I putÂ off renewing it because I had plenty ofÂ time.Â  In Virginia  you can do it online, so there just didn't seem to be any hurry.Â  ButÂ on the  evening of the 29thÂ I decidedÂ the time had come to renew it.Â  It didn't take  long to realize I was unable toÂ renew itÂ because my license expired on my  birthday and not at the end of the month like I thought it did.Â  That meant that  forÂ 19 days I wasÂ unknowinglyÂ driving around on an expired license.Â  The punishment by the  DMVÂ (Department of Motor Vehicles) for not renewing on time is that you have to  go into one of their main offices to renew it and bring with youÂ proof ofÂ 'legal presence' which as  you may know means that I need to show that I'm aÂ U.S. citizen andÂ legally  authorized to be in the United States....Thankfully Carl is organized andÂ gave  me my birth certificate and on an impulse gave me our marriage license too.Â    Â Many of you may knowÂ that any trip to the DMV typically means long lines  and endless waiting.Â  I came prepared with magazines, my camera and cell phone and I wondered why the Virginia flag was at half mast...Was that a sign? Â I was about to find out as myÂ odyssey began with standing in line waiting for a number.Â  It was mid-morning and with the long line and people waiting I happened to  notice there was practically no one at any of the counters.Â  Why was that?Â My turn in line to get a number to wait and I told the person at the  counter that I was there to renew my expired drivers license.Â  She looked at my  license and told me it was expired...Of course she mentioned that I had to be  able to show that I was a US citizen.Â Â I gave her my birth certificate which was  met with some skepticism because it's not notarized.Â  I told her that it was the  one given to my Mother; howeverÂ it still needed a supervisors approval andÂ I was  asked to give proof of my married name. Â Thank-you Carl for thinking that I might  need that marriage license.Â  Both were approved and I had my number and was now  going to get to wait...again. Â Â ~Rudi~FinallyÂ my number was called, and I repeated to the DMV employee my  reason for being there.Â  She looked at my license and told me it was expired and  I needed to show that I was a US citizen.Â  I gave it to her and mentioned  thatÂ my birth certificate was an original butÂ wasn't notarized but had been  okayed by the other clerk and a supervisor and IÂ gave her my marriage license.Â  She told me that she  would have to get an approval from a supervisor because my birth certificate  wasn't notarized...There was something that I really wanted to say to her, but I  thought it best to just let it go.Â  FinallyÂ after several more minutes everything was approved--I am now able toÂ drive legally again!!Â Â The punishment and fine, or rather the fee for coming into the DMV and not doing it online  wasÂ increased byÂ 5 dollars and my license will arrive in about 10 days.Â It'll  be good for 8 years.Â  I wonder if I'll remember next time to renew early or wait until the  last minute?

title: The Weekend is in Sight!
text: Summer is really in full swing, and the July 4th holiday weekend is in  sight!Â  Today is my last day of work until next Tuesday.Â  Carl however goes back  to work for two more days.Â Â We have no plans for the long weekend, but the town  we live in is having a street fair and since we've never gone, we may have to go  this year.Â Â We'll see. Â Â The dogs are still getting used to having a puppy around the house.Â  Being  Goldens they are pretty adaptable and don't seem to really mind the change in the routine and  energy.Â  However Charlie remains in a real snit!!Â Â I guess Todd knows that they  are both terriers because despite what Charlie may be telling him, he remains undaunted and wants to make friends with his cousin,Â but  Charlie will have nothing of it!Â  I am pretty sure he'll get over it, but he has  to make a show of it first.Â  The cat and Todd have had a couple of  encounters--ToddÂ who is a little smaller than the cat is giving her the respect  she commands, so she has given her tentative approval and warning that he needs  to stay away from her--I think they'll be just fine!Â Â I hope your Wednesday is  'just fine' too!! Â  I'll look forward to catching up on your blogs later today!Â ~Todd & Sam~

title: The Little Things
text: I'd like to thank-you all for your ideas to tempt Rudi to eat something. Â Since Saturday evening she's been eating what are calledÂ 'Satin Balls,'Â which are consideredÂ a total canine diet. Â They can be fed by themselves or as a supplement. Rudi seems to like them, and that's what's most important. Â But I know that may change at any time, so the next trick I have up my sleeve to get her to eat is all ready, which will be baby food. Â This is the tenth day of grace with Rudi. Â She seems to be feeling pretty well, because last evening she got the cat food bowl off the kitchen counter. Â I know it may sound silly, but it's the little things like that, that I've missed her doing the most. Â Yesterday for the first time she grabbed a frisbee off the work bench in the garage and wanted to play a round. Â But knowing she would overdo it, as she always does, and with the heat, I reluctantly told her no. Â I've decided that at times like this,Â it all comes down to the small and sometimes trivial things, that you didn't think meant much at the time, you suddenlyÂ realize you miss them the most. I really do love the little things...And this 'little thing' too! Â Enjoy your Tuesday!

title: Reggie the Mother Hen
text: Its been exactly a week now since Reggie came to Golden Pines. Â Her transition into our household has been seamless. Â There has not been a moment of trouble from her and she has shown time and time again, what a nice dog she is. Â Reggie seems to know things like sit, down, stay which makes me think that at one time she must have been a treasured companion--Why that would have changed is anyone's guess. Reggie has adjusted the routine and has made herself right at home. Â She continues to always wag her tail and does seems to be happy and content. There seems to be a connection between Reggie and Todd. Â Any noise that he makes, Reggie is right there checking on him. Â When we're outside, she is never that far away keeping a watchful eye on him. Todd is always close to her too and when he sees her he'll run over to her. Â  Â  We decided that we're going to keep Reggie here for now. Â And when her medial issues are all resolved, which won't be for a Â few more months, we'll try to find her another home through the rescue, (does anyone really believe I'll do that??) Besides, I think she and Todd might miss one another.

title: Todd and Everything is Just Fine!!
text: It was a whirlwind trip to Southwest Virginia but it could not have been a better one! Â I really enjoyed meeting Lynn from Rocky Creek Scottie AdventuresÂ Â  who was just as I knew she would be, welcoming, kind, thoughtful and so easy to talk too--She has such a beautiful setting for her home and IÂ thoroughlyÂ enjoyed getting to know her, meeting her husband and her pups too! Â Today Todd is trying to get to know his new pack just a little bit better and is either following them around or.... Â ~Reggie & Todd~laying around with them...~Sam & Todd~And really trying to make a friend out of Charlie who is, as expected, non too happy right now and is just trying to stay a few steps ahead.Â We are keeping him away from Rudi, who is mostly ignoring him, which is just fine--In fact as our first day together is coming to an end, I think everything is just fine!

title: The Adventure Begins!
text: The day that I've been anticipating since April has finally arrived!!Â Â I'm leaving shortlyÂ on a road trip to get our new addition and meet LynnÂ from the blog Rocky Creek Scottie Adventures.Â  I've never met a fellow blogger before, so it's going to be a first.Â  Another first will be having a Scottish Terrier--We are nervous but excited!! Â We have moments where she seems like herself, other times when she isn't. Â Right now I am struggling with getting her to eat something--anything.Â  I thought I had fooled her when I got her to eatÂ a meal out of the cat food bowl.Â  But she only fell for that twice.Â  Rudi has always been a real chow-hound--She's always beenÂ fed last, and finished first.Â  SoÂ this is really hard to see.Â Â If any of you have any suggestions on how to get her to eat, that would really be appreciated.I'm really sorry that I've not been able to visit your blogs very often this week.Â  It has really been a busy week with Reggie arriving and a few other things behind the scenes.
