title: The Arrival of a Girl Named Reggie
text: We have a new addition at least for now, that arrived on Monday. Â At the beginning of June I was asked by the rescue if I would consider taking a 13 year old senior girl named Reggie. At the time, Hamlet was doing okay, and after really thinking about it I agreed. Because of some 'issues' and because she was 6+ hours away, it took some doing to bringÂ her in this direction.Â  I was contacted on SundayÂ and told that everything had been arranged and she wasÂ on her way to me.Â  With everything that has been going on, I didn't think it was such a good idea for her to come here.Â  But with no place for her to go I agreed to take ReggieÂ and see how it went.Â  I know thatÂ with Rudi not feeling well and the puppy arriving in a few days, the timing for this gal to become part of our household is not the best.Â Â I think that she needs to perhaps go to another foster home. Reggie was confiscated from her owner by Animal Control in the county where she lived because she was found lying on her ownerâ€™s porch with a ruptured dinner plate sized mass on her back that was infected with 'fly larva.' Â Other sores on her body were infected as well, andÂ understandablyÂ she was not feeling well and was having problems walking. Â The owner was charged with animal cruelty and neglect andhad toÂ surrenderÂ Reggie. Â While the case is pending, the judge is NOT tolerant of animal abuse and neglect and they most definitely will be held accountable for theirÂ actions--Thank-goodness!!Â Â  Reggie has had the surgery to remove the mass.Â Â  Because of the condition of her coat and the other sores, she had to be shavedÂ downÂ to the skin. Â She has a large mammory tumorÂ but the vet felt it was too close to her heart to risk removing it. She is also thought to be in the early stages of heart failure.Â  Reggie gets along nicely with our crew who don't mind her at all because they are seasoned veterans withÂ dogs coming and going from our household.Â Â Rudi is also un-phased by her andÂ ignores her.Â Â Reggie does seem a bit bewildered by what's happened to her. Â I don't think she understood my taking her on a walk with us yesterdayÂ morning. Â She was tenative and nervous the whole time and kept looking back towards the house.Â  WhenÂ we let her into the backyard she hurries back onto the porch and stands with her head pushed into the door to be let back inside.Â Â She is following us everywhereÂ and I don't think her tail has stopped wagging. Â I think she's grateful and happy...Yes, there is no question about it, she's a sweet old girl!Â  But as I mentioned, the timing of her arrival is not the best and she may have to use her charmÂ to win a place in someone else's heart besides mine, which she has already done.

title: Days of Grace
text: We took Rudi to see our vet on Monday who looked at the x-rays, examined her and agreed with the diagnosis of Â hemangiosarcoma. Â We talked about the very few options that we have, and have decided to let nature take its course. Â More than likely Rudi only has a matter of days left with us, weeks maybe, but nothing more. Â Yesterday was a good day. Â Her gum color is good, but we struggle with trying to get her to eat. Â I'm hoping that putting her on an antacid will help because we think she may be feelingÂ nauseous. Â She remains really quiet and subdued, so we're letting her set her own pace and decide what she wants to do (she pretty much did that anyway). Â But Rudi's days of wildly chasing the frisbee, running laps around the house and getting the cat food off the counter are behind us.When some of you have been given a grim diagnosis for your own dogs, and they exceed the time a vet has predicted, those days have been called 'days of grace.' Â I've never really known personally just how precious those days can be until I was told on Saturday that Rudi probably wouldn't live through the night. Â It's Tuesday morning and she's still with us. Â Knowing that this can change at anytime makes me realize just what a treasure each day (with Rudi) really is. Â  ~Rudi in May, playing frisbee~

title: Riding a Wave
text: We are riding a wave. Â Rudi had a relatively quiet night, although mine was a sleepless one. Â This morning she's up and around a little bit and even wanted to go outside. Â She's nowhere close to being 'just fine,' but that's okay, she's here with us, and seems to be comfortable and not in pain. I'm sure that her system is absorbing some of the blood that's in her abdomen which is why there seems to be an 'upswing' in her mood and attitude. Â I'm just hoping that we can make it through another night and to my vet first thing on Monday. Â Many many thanks for your continued good thoughts and prayers that are at the moment putting us on top of the wave, and helping me come to grips with what I know is coming.

title: Another Loss At Golden Pines???
text: To start, I cannot begin to express how much your kind words on the loss of Hamlet have meant to me. Â Your remembering Hamlet on your blogs, sending an e-card, and lighting candles for him have left me feeling humbled and grateful to all of you, my friends--You've made a difference and made his loss easier to bear, because you have shared it with me.Yesterday on the way to the vet with Hamlet I didn't want to listen to the rambling on the radio, so I plugged in my iPod and the song by Israel "IZ" KamakawiwoÊ»ole, Somewhere Over the Rainbow - Wonderful World started to play. Â I thought it was an appropriate song to listen to. Â I replayed it a couple of times and I held Hamlet's paw as I drove and sang along. Â Last evening we were standing on the porch after a storm and over my house was a rainbow. I stood and marveled at the rainbow because I knew that it was a reminder that everything was 'okay' and everything was how it should be. Â I said a prayer of thanks for knowing that and felt that inner peace. ~Charlie & Rudi (right)~The past week as you know has been an emotional one. Â One of our dogs, Rudi, who is about 9 years old has always been really sensitive to my moods, when I'm upset she'll be upset as well. Â Her refusing to eat during those times is not uncommon. Â I'd noticed during the week that she was not quite herself and I attributed it to everything that was happening with Hamlet. Â I thought that a fun outing would be good for her (and me) so today I decided to take Rudi with me as I visited a friend over in West Virginia. Â Rudi hardly wanted to do anything but lay around. Â When she had problems walking up a hill I checked her gums and noticed they were pale and her stomach seemed bloated...I took her to the animal emergency and x-rays were taken and the vet gave his diagnosis of HemangiosarcomaÂ Â  and thought that I should let her go because he thought she only had hours to live. Â To say that I felt like I'd been hit in the stomach was and is an understatement. Â I explained to the vet that I'd just let a dog go the day before and I wasn't ready to do it again. Â However he felt that I should because he doesn't think she'll live through tonight. Â I took Rudi outside and talked to Carl who had met me there. Â Whether it's right or wrong, or selfish of me, I felt I just couldn't go through with it and so I've brought Rudi home. Â Her gums remain pale and she's very quiet and I don't think she's in pain. Â I'm just praying that she lives through the night and that somewhere and somehow I find the strength and the courage to let her go when it's time.Just as a caveat I'll add that I know that you don't know Rudi that well. Â She came to us in 2003 from a shelter in North Carolina. Â We were her 4th home, and she was just over a year old. Â Rudi is our undeniable pack leader. Â She is very bright, active, sensitive,Â mischievous, into everything and always acts like she has a secret she wants you to guess. Â She is truly a once in a lifetime dog that is one of the cornerstones of our pack Rudi has a way of always making me laugh and her loss will leave a huge hole in our pack and in my heart.

title: Good-Bye & God Speed Hamlet
text: Dear Hamlet, As I write this you are quietly resting nearby.Â  In just a couple of hours I'll hold you for one last time and say good-bye.Â Â You're having problems standing,Â you've hadÂ no appetite the last few days and are drinking very little water...You and I both know it's time for you toÂ leave us.Â  Â  ~Hamlet, the first day I met him~How well I remember the day you came intoÂ our lives 19 short months ago.Â Â It seems like only yesterday, in some ways, I guess it was.Â Â I remember being so firm inÂ my decision to no longer foster for the rescue.Â  But thenÂ I got a call from a new volunteer asking me if I couldÂ pick up a dog named Hamlet whoÂ had been left in the garage of a house that had been foreclosed on.Â Â I agreed because I was going to be in that direction that day,Â and where youÂ needed to go was on my way home; I would hardly be going out of my way.Â  Needless to say, when I saw you, so ill and unable to stand, I knew IÂ couldn't turn my back on you.Â  I called the foster home coordinator and asked if I could foster you.Â  The rest shall we say is history.Â Â You'veÂ enjoyedÂ your health for the most part.Â Â But in the shadowsÂ and always on our minds was the tumor on your shoulder.Â Â You've hadÂ two major surgeries to remove it, and both times you'veÂ fully recovered.Â  I have marveled and given thanks so many times for that as well as your spark and zest for life.Â Â  Hamlet, I know that you've been happy here.Â  Its shown as your personalityÂ has blossomed.Â Â My heart would literally leap each time you wouldÂ run past me on our walks to get back to the house first, or prance aroundÂ when I came home each day.Â  I loved how youÂ wouldÂ come to me quietly wagging your tail and bury your head in my lap for me to scratch your head.Â  We taughtÂ some 'important things' like how to begÂ and I never minded sharing a bite of whatever it was I was eating.Â Â My attempts to try and get you to bark never worked--A small 'woof' was all I could ever get, but that spoke volumes. Â Hamlet you willÂ beÂ greatly missed!Â  You've shown over and over again what a quiet, kind, gentle soul you are.Â  IÂ will never be the same, both for bearing yourÂ loss, and for theÂ joy you've given us and others that I've told about you.Â Â It has been a privilegeÂ to have such a noble dog likeÂ you as part of our lives.Â  God speed my precious, precious Hamlet.Â Â We've lit our candle to help you find your way to the bridge where you'llÂ meet and join our other Goldens,Â Tod, Ben, Cougar, Tucker, Scout, Tosh, Logan, Kasey, Cubby--Cowboy, Maguire and TannerÂ are there too.Â  Please give them our message and know that we'll see you all again one day.

title: We Wait
text: I stayed home from work today and spent it with Hamlet who is not doing so well. Â I sat on the front porch with him and the other dogs enjoying a beautiful sunny morning where there were birds singing and a breeze. Â Hamlet who was sleeping on the porch lifted his head and closing his eyes, sniffed the air that was blowing on his face. Â As I watched him, the wind seemed to whisper in my ear that his time to leave us is drawing near. Â Of course I don't know when that will be. So I wait for this most un-welcomed guest and pray for more time and peace. Â Â With my 'milestone birthday' behind me, we had another 'celebration' here at Golden Pines. Â Some of you may recall that back last fall I was upset when the property behind us was put up for sale. Â A couple of attempts by us to purchase part of it from the owner were turned down. Â While the property was priced well with the current market, over the last 6 months we've noticed very few people looking at it. Â I was contacted by ourÂ RealtorÂ on Monday and told that the property had been 'withdrawn' from the market and yesterday the sign was taken down. I have to admit that I'm relieved that it didn't sell. Â But the owner is a Realtor, and so I know at some point the property will once again be put back on the market to be sold. CarrieAnne decided that she wanted to celebrate on her own and so she went for a private swim. Â The water level must be up after the rain from this past weekend. Â She returned very happy! The celebration was short lived however because as we were getting the dogs in the house, Carrie was nowhere to be found. Â  Â We looked for her for almost 2 hours. Â I called and called, and blew the whistle for her to return, but she didn't come. Â I asked Carl several times if he checked the house for her and he assured me he had. This was so unlike her because CarrieAnne always, always comes when she's called...It was starting to get dark and so we came back into the house and when I came in I called her and there she was--She'd been in the house the entire time. Â Once again, relief and celebration and the reminder to never ask Carl to find something for me!

title: A Milestone Birthday
text: Along with the record makingÂ heat we had this week,Â another one which some  of you know about (thank-you Facebook) is that I had a milestone birthday,Â I  turned 50 on Friday.Â  I've thought a lot about that this week.Â  I know  thatÂ Â Iâ€™ve made plenty of mistakes and I know that I can be demanding and short  when I am passionate about something. I really do try to have patience for life's little  nonsense's and I have to admit that I have problems tolerating people who are unkind and pretentious. Â I hope that I am a good person with a good heart and I'm fair minded. I hopeÂ I have somewhere, somehow made some small difference to  others through my work with the rescue and other things I've been involved  in.Â Â I haveÂ good people in my life that I cherish dearly.Â  But what I truly hope  that I have accomplished in my 50 years on the planet, more than anything else,  is to be a good partner, a good friend, a good sister,Â and at my core, 'I hope I am the kind of person the dogs think I am.' Â  Enjoy your Sunday!!~The Chub Brothers, Toby (left) and Bubba~

title: The Signs of Summer
text: We are again chasing record heat here in northern Virginia. The temperature on our thermometer mid-afternoon said it was at almost 100Â°. Â The National Weather Service reported that Washington DC hit 102Â° which tied the all-time June record set in 1874. Â All I know is it was hot and the dogs and I spent little time outdoors. Â I did get them all walked before 6 AM when it was already about 80Â°. Â It's hot, humid, sticky and really 'buggy!' Â When I took a good look, the signs of summer are all around! Â Rudi and Sheba showed me this morning on our walk that the blackberries are starting to ripen. Â Its been a race each year to see who will get more of them, the dogs, the birds or me--I'm hoping this year it'll be me, but they are pretty good at getting to the ripe ones before I do! Â It makes me wonder if they would have made good 'truffle hunting dogs?' Â  ~Rudi enjoying Â a blackberry snack!~Today I saw another sign of summer, my first day lily! (By the way, I read on another blog today that you should deadhead them toÂ keep them blooming.Â  Am I the only one who didn't know that?) Â  Â The thistle is starting to bloom too. Â And the dogs are starting to shed...And so are the snakes...Okay, there are some signs of summer that I really don't need to see, especially so close to the house!I think I'm just going to stay inside where it's cool! Â Â What are you doing to stay cool?

title: First Milestone of the Week
text: This week there are a couple of milestones--One comes later in the week, and I'll tell you about it then. Â But the first was on Monday morning on my drive to work. Â The 5 year old van that I drive, has gone 100,000 miles... Â Wow... This is the second 'Dodge Caravan' I've owned, and I know it's not the sportiest or the coolest thing to drive. Â But the biggest reason IÂ have it is because afterÂ HurricaneÂ Katrina people said they had to leave their pets behind because they didn't have a way to take them with them. Â It started me thinking and I realizedÂ that if something were to happen and we needed to leave our home,Â I want to be able toÂ take all of the dogs with us.Â  I know this may sound silly....At any rate, it has been pretty dependable. Â In the nearly 5 years I've had my vanÂ I wonder how many days and how many times I've sat in traffic in it?Watching some drivers do some pretty dumb things. Â Like this man yesterday morning. Â I saw him a few times and each time his head was back and his eyes looked like they were closed--Sleeping while driving??!! I notice a lot of people on their cell phones too. Â In Virginia you don't have to use a 'hands free device.' Â But I'm seeing more and more drivers texting while driving which makes me nervous!Â  Â Then there are the vanity plates that I often see while driving. Â Some, are simple in what they say.Â Some I have to think about for a minute or two...Do you know what this says? Â It's probably easy for you to figure out...Carl has mentioned getting me another van and we chuckle at this persons approach to try and sell his car. But I think that for now, I'll keep my van. Â Besides, I've gotten used to finding it in a parking lot.AreÂ there anyÂ milestones for you this week?Â  If so, I hope they are good ones, and your week is off to a good start!Â ~The field next to our house~

title: Winner of This Round - Hamlet!
text: ~Josh, left & Rudi~The weather the last couple of days could not be more beautiful! Â The warmth of the sun and cooler temperatures has given everyone more energy! Â We started our afternoon with a round of frisbee.~Hamlet~Once the dogs were worn out, we came back in just in time to get a call from the vet about the results of Hamlet's culture. Â I was so sure it would be bad news for him, just goes to show you what I don't know. Â Last time there were six different kinds of bacteria found in this same wound. Â This time there are only two. Â One is a strain of e-coli, but it's not the 'really bad' one that was there last time. Â The other is a staff infection. The bottom line is that it's treatable with the antibioticÂ Augmentin that we'll put him on for 6 weeks. Â I don't know if it's because I'm still worn out, but I found myself feeling humbled and thankful for this news. Â I know it doesn't mean that this will be the end of the problems with this tumor--I know it is going to continue to grow and be an ongoing problem. Â But I feel like right here and right now now, we've won this round against it.

title: A New Dog at Golden Pines!
text: Okay, not really a 'new' dog....But it sure seems that way becauseÂ Charlie went from looking like this...To this!!!Â The groomer, Irina who is from Romania in her very thick accent saidÂ to me when I dropped CharlieÂ off that 've vouldn't do a zoom-zoom for Chaaalee,' meaning she wasn't going to clip it really short.Â  When I picked him up, Irina explainedÂ that she had to because he was pretty mattedÂ in a few places.Â  She apologizedÂ for having to do that, and also for what happened with the other customer, (see yesterday's post) andÂ she tookÂ off $25 from the bill.Â  It may not work for Charlie, but did for me.

title: Worn Out!
text: I remember a day about six years ago when Carl came home and told me that the entire agency that he worksÂ for wouldÂ be moving to a new building located more than 2 hours from us.Â  Knowing how the government does things, and how slow they can be, I thought it would never happen.Â  Well, it did...His office being relocated isÂ part of what's known in this area as 'BRAC' which stands for Base Realignment and Closure. They are defining it as "a congressionally authorized process of theÂ Department of DefenseÂ toÂ reorganizeÂ its base structure to more efficiently and effectively support our forces, increase operational readiness and facilitate new ways of doing business."Â Â  Whatever that means...All I know is that this week Carl startedÂ  a very long commute to his new office, where the building is said to be the length of an aircraft carrier. Â Fortunately he has been able to get into a 'van pool' so he only has to drive about 30 minutes to the meeting place. Â But another downside to all of this is that toÂ get there he'sÂ leaving home by 4:30 in the morning.Â Â I'm getting up early too because it leaves me to get everything done before I go to work. I have never been very good at change.Â  AndÂ this change, at least this week has left us both worn out, and exhausted. Â When I get this way, things that wouldn't ordinarily bother me, do.Things like what happened yesterday when we noticed that the Phoebes thatÂ built their nest just more than a week ago are no longer around.Â  We really tried to stay away from the area of theÂ nest as much as we could.Â  But it really bothered me that they were gone.Â Â I checked and was glad to see that there were no eggs. I was also upset when Hamlet chose a couple of times this week to not go for a walk with us and hasn't wanted to come outside. Â I know he's been really sensitive to the heat and just have to hope that it was because of thatÂ and nothing more.Â  I've not yet heard back from the vet about the results of the culture, hopefully I will in the next couple of days.Â  The ulcerations on the tumor, while still draining a little bit, I think, aren't nearly as 'angry' as they have been.Â  As I write this, Hamlet isÂ laying on his left side, which is the side of the tumor--I've no idea if that means anything, but I am a tiny bit encouraged by that.Another moment came at the groomers when I dropped off Charlie this morning. I met someone who was bringing in two Scottish Terriers to be groomed. Â Of course I mentioned that we were getting one at the end of the month. Â I was totally unprepared for her telling me that she didn't think that anyone should get puppies when there were so many in shelters that needed homes. Â I tried to tell her that I've devoted the last 12 years of my life to rescue, in particular the senior dogs, but it fell on deaf ears and ended in my feeling on the verge of tears. Â I left the shop and was called a few minutes later by the owner who apologized for what happened. Â She gave me some very kind words of encouragement which I appreciated. As I said, typically these kinds of things don't bother me, at least not to much. Â Which is why on my day off it has been so nice to just be home, eating all the wrong food, watching reruns Project Runway, relaxing and catching up on your blogs. Â I hope you're having a nice day too!

title: We're Having a Heat Wave
text: Searing heat here in northern Virginia the last several days. Â I was reminded yesterday by a co-worker that we didn't have air-conditioning when we were growing up. Â We wondered how we managed and decided it was because we were younger then. The dogs of course are feeling the effects of the heat too. Â The seniors, Wendy, Hamlet and even Toby go out, and quickly come back inside. Â The younger crowd (the 9 year olds) still want to play a round of frisbee, but it's short lived because we put the brakes on. ï»¿ ~Josh~ï»¿ Sam loves to just lay in the sun and bake...Charlie is having the hardest time in the heat because of his very thick and heavy coat. Â He goes to the groomers on Thursday which will be just in time for the weather to cool off. Â Â The one dog really finding relief in it all is CarrieAnne. Â Last evening she once again did her thing, and slipped away to her private little swimming hole. Â The water level must be a little low because after several minutes she returned all wet and muddy and quite happy with herself...And this time, not even the bath afterwards caused her to have any remorse. Â Do you mind the extreme heat? Â How do you stay cool in it?

title: Memories for What's Ahead
text: Some call them fireflies, I call them lightning bugs. I think they're summer's mascot and they're back. The memories I have of them is like 'magic.' Even now seeing them is kind of like a mini-fireworks show . As I stood on my porch watching them last night, I remembered something I readÂ about how each minute of our lives is unique unto itself and how connected we can be to what came before and what will come next. I wish I knew what will come next for Hamlet. He was taken back to the vet on Friday. His appetite isÂ reallyÂ good, but there isÂ a lingering cough andÂ the tumor is still draining.Â Â (We're doing our best to keep it very clean). I don't thinkÂ that he's feeling all that well, but despite thatÂ his tail still wags and the spark is still there.Â Â We have had a culture doneÂ to see what bacteria is present and will hopefully be able to find an antibiotic to treat the infection. Prior to Hamlet having his 2nd surgery, one of the bacteria that was identified from a culture was e-coli. The medication to treat that particular strain of it was very expensive (about $1500 per bottle) required his being hospitalized for several days, and had an arms length of side effects which included kidney failure. It was then we opted to do the surgery and hope all the bacteria and infection were removed. I knew going into it that there was a chance it may not be. As far as doing surgery again, right now I don't feel like that's an option. His recovery from the 2nd surgery was a little more difficult than the first one, and a 3rd would no doubt be harder for him. Hamlet is an old dog (we guess about 13-14) and I think it would be too much for a dog his age. We've had a wonderful and memorable year and-a-half together; the past six months, the best. He had times where he would make little running dashes on our walks, manage a single bark and we'd get a 'snorty whine' from him when we come home. I know those days are now gone.Â Â ButÂ like the lightning bugs, I have the memories of them.Â Â I think they've givenÂ Hamlet and I a connection andÂ the courage for whatever will come next.

title: Help Needed
text: You all know how I love the senior animals, and how IÂ stop and help turtles across the road.Â  Well, this Granddaddy of all snapping turtles certainly didn't want any help!Â  I just read that snapping turtles can live to be 80 years old.Â Â I wonder how old this one is and how many times he got help crossing the road to the nearby pond? Â Â  Here at Golden Pines,Â we neededÂ some help...We lost ourÂ internet connectionÂ on Thursday evening, and Carl spent hours (and I do mean hours) on the phone trying to get it repaired.Â  He and someone from 'Verizon' were finally able to get it working this morning.Â Â I will admit that I'm a bit of an 'internet junkie' and thankfully there was enough to keep me busyÂ and my mind offÂ not being able to get my 'internet fix.'Â Â  I look forward toÂ catching up on your news and will post an update on Hamlet later today.Â  I hopeÂ your weekend is off to a good start!

title: Coming Soon--A Rocky Creek Scottie!!!
text: We have been keeping a secret here at Golden Pines for several weeks now.Â Â The secret? We are getting a puppy! No, it's not a Golden Retriever (a shock I know) but a Scottish Terrier!Just over a year ago, I became acquainted with 'Lynn' from the blog Rocky Creek Scottie Adventures. Our cyber friendship began when Angus, at Wilf the PON Discovers France posted about our both losing 4-legged-family members, Java and Cowboy, on the same day. Lynn sent me an e-mail and a friendship began. We marveled that a blog in France would introduce the two of usÂ who both live in Virginia.Â Â (Thank-you for that Angus!!!)I've known for a long time that I wanted to get a puppy. And IÂ knew that if and when we added one, the timing of it wasÂ really going to be important.Â  I also knew that for several reasons, I didn't want the puppy to be aÂ Golden Retriever. Because of Lynn and her blog, I became smitten with Scottish TerriersÂ and started to do more reading about them. It didn't take long to realize that I wanted to add a Scottie to our household. When Lynn told me that herÂ girl, Carrleigh was expecting a litter in April, the timing seemed to be right. This week, I picked the puppy, a little boy, whose name was Jock, and we have re-named Todd. Being a 'sentimental old lady' I will tell you in another post how and where this name came from. But 'Todd' will be coming to Golden Pines in about a month. Carl and I are of course really excited! I know some of you may be wondering why in the world we would want to add a puppy when we already have so many dogs. The answer is a very personal one that has to do with knowing that the loss of some of our dogs will be coming way to soon. Last year, we said good-bye to three of our pups, not including Doris's boy Sam. With our dogs getting older, I feel this need to 'bridge that gap' and begin a new generation. I feel strongly that there's nothing like a puppy to liven up a laid-back quiet crowd, especially a spirited Scottish Terrier!! (The picture below are the little boys, 'Todd' is the one on the far left)I hope you'll take a moment to stop by and meet Lynn and her crew at Rocky Creek Scottie Adventures, andÂ Angus at Wilf the PON discovers France.

title: Lost and Found
text: On Monday on my way to work, I saw something in the road that at first I thought was something that had been hit by a car--As I passed it, I glanced down and saw what I thought looked like a wallet. I turned the van around, and went back for a better look. It was indeed a wallet. I picked it up and even though it was soaking wet, there was a little more than $80 in cash, a credit card, drivers license, all the usual things. The wallet belonged to a young man who was 19 years old, and had just celebrated his birthday on Sunday. Off the drivers license I was able to get the address which led me to a phone number and I called and left a message. At the end of the day was a call from the grateful father of 'Andrew' who had lost the wallet. He said before they got my message they had been out looking all down the road trying to find it. Andrew was a little frantic at losing it. They didn't live far from me, so I offered to drop it off on my way home from work. Â I met a relieved and very grateful Andrew along with his dad, who thanked me several times and even offered me a reward. Of course there was no way I was taking a reward and I told them I was just glad I was able to return the wallet and its contents to the owner. Tuesday morning when we had the dogs out, we lost track of our boy Josh. Josh at 9 years old is just now being trusted to be off lead. However, we always keep a really close eye on him because he will wander off and that's what he did. It was a moment of panic when Josh didn't come when we called him and he seemed to have disappeared. We decided to get all the dogs inside and go out and look for him. We had just gone back outside when a truck pulled into our driveway. The driver got out and so did Josh! He'd seen him on the neighboring field, called to him and he came. He looked at his tags and realized where he belonged and brought him back. I was so very grateful that he'd found Josh that I offered him a 'reward' for his trouble, but he told us no, that he was glad to be able to bring Josh back to where he belonged. I thought later Josh's being returned was kind of like the wallet, both owners relieved and very thankful for the kindness of strangers. Finally, again I am grateful and so appreciate for all your good thoughts and prayers for Hamlet. Â He's doing well, and there are no changes--The below picture was taken on Saturday where he's doing what he always does, taking everything in stride.

title: A Phoebe for Good Luck
text: I love birds.Â  I love to watch them, hear them, take pictures of them, and feed them.Â  The first summer we wereÂ livingÂ where we are now, one bird in particular drove me a little crazy.Â  I'd never heard it before and was able to identify it as the 'Eastern Phoebe.'Â  The birdÂ gets its name from its distinctive but rough two note call, 'whee-bee,'Â reminds me of a dogsÂ squeaky toy.Â Above all the other birds that summer, the Phoebe is all I heard, over, over and over again....When the end of summer came and it left,Â outside seemed a bit lonelyÂ without it.Â Â However, it returned the next year and I'dÂ listen for it each time we were outside.Â  Last year, I hardly heard it at all and foundÂ myself missing the constant 'whee-bee, whee-bee, whee-bee.'Â Â This year, it's back and has built a nest above our garage door.Â  I hear it first thing in the morning and during the day.Â Below is a video I took of the PhoebeÂ and you can decide for yourself if hearing all the time would drive youÂ to the edge...ï»¿Finally, many thanks again for the good thoughts for Hamlet.Â  For now, he seems to be feeling pretty well.Â  Unfortunately, last evening the tumor on his shoulderÂ 'broke' open.Â The tumor feelsÂ warm to the touch and the tissue is veryÂ 'angry.'Â  I am heartsick that despite all theÂ efforts and with so much optimism,Â and feeling like we'd done everything right, we couldn't prevent this from happening again.Â  We've cleaned it the best we can, and he'sÂ once again sporting a tee-shirt to helpÂ keepÂ the debris out of it, and theÂ other dogs away from it.Â Â I've taken this pathÂ before and so I know where this is leading.Â However because it's considered good luck to have a bird nesting around your house,Â I continue to have hope and wish for good-luck to be on Hamlet's side.

title: Riding the Wave
text: Off to the vet this morning with Hamlet. Â He's developed a cough this week, and his paw is swollen. Â The vet felt thought that his lungs didn't sound as clear as they did last week. He has a little bit of a temperature, so we've put him on antibiotics. We both don't think that the cancer is encased in the tumor alone and think that it probably has spread elsewhere, but we've no way of knowing. Â But what I do know is that given everything, Hamlet really does to seem feel pretty good. Â He has a great appetite, he still wants to go on walks with us, so we're just going to ride the wave and be thankful for each day! On the way home, I saw this littleÂ pedestrian crossing the road alone, where there was no crosswalk. Â I knew he would never make it across 4 lanes of traffic, a median and survive in a construction zone, so I stopped and picked him up and brought him home. This makes 4 terrapins I've moved off the road this year. Â This little guy was in a hurry to be on his way, so we let him go at the edge of our woods and of course wished him 'good luck!'

title: The Sound of Silence
text: We woke this morningÂ to the sound of silence.Â  Quite a change fromÂ Wednesday morning when I thought I was hearingÂ a fan running that I'd left on overnight, only to find out it was the pouring rain.Â The grass is now so tall that I think we'll need a hay bailer if it doesn't dry up soon.Â  But the creeks are full and flowing.Â  MyÂ Iris are wilting... Yesterday Carl took his car into aÂ body shop in Maryland (where he'd taken it previously) to have it repaired. Â You'll recall that it was hit by a stray bullet a couple of weeks ago. Â We've no idea where the bullet originated from, only that his car was struck by it when he was leaving his 'old' office to come home. Â I drove in a torrential downpour to pick him up. (I know I shouldn't have been taking pictures as I drove)In an effort to save money when possible, I planned a stop at a grocery store in Maryland that was having a pretty good sale.Â  But when I went into the store, nothing in the flier that I had brought with me was on sale.Â  When I went toÂ customer service and asked about it, the manager looked at the ad and pointed out that the flier was datedÂ exactly a month ago.Â  We both had a nice little chuckle and I've decided that I've got to clean my car out more....It was good to get home where the dogs never point out my dumb mistakes!Â ~Hamlet~Â  ~Josh~I don't think Charlie would notice anyway...~Charlie~ï»¿

title: A Good Start
text: As rain ran down our driveway the news is filled with reports of the flooding farther south. Â I worry about my 87 year old Aunt in Mississippi and hope she continues to be safe. She has so many people that look out for her, so I'm sure she'll be just fine. Our weekend was relatively quiet because of the weather. Â Carl did try to catch up on the mowing. Â  I'm thinking we may need to get the cows across the road to help if he's not able to get ahead of it. Â Problems with mice in our barn have been resolved by the arrival of a black snake that's about 4 feet long. Â I know it's supposed to be a 'good snake,' which to me, is a contradiction in terms, but I asked Carl to evict it, which he did. Â I also asked him to take a couple of pictures for me, because there was no way I was going any where near it. Â I'd much rather be sitting on my porch taking pictures of the deer.... The butterflies....The flowers...And of course the dogs. Â Thank-you all for the good wishes for Hamlet. Â The pain medication seems to be helping. Â He is up and around a bit more, which is a good sign. Â  He's even smiling...Which is also a good way to start our week! Â I hope yours is off to a good start too!

title: Good News and Not So Good News
text: ~Sammy~Feeling pretty confident in my dog-handling abilities, I took 4 of the dogs to the vet today. Â They were all relatively simple appointments, so how hard could it be? Â Thinking about it now, maybe I'd not used my best judgment when I made the appointments. Â But I did get help when I arrived at the office which was really nice. The errands that I ran afterwards were made easier when I threw a handful of crackers behind me and the dogs forgot about wanting to jump out the door when I opened it. Â It was good news for Sam. Some of you have seen on Facebook where Sam has lost 14 pounds since his last visit. Â He contributes his weight loss to healthy eating, lots of exercise and not snacking too much in between meals! Â He makes it sound so easy! The other two pups, Sheba was there to have her eye rechecked and Bubba for blood-work so he can continue taking the Rimadyl for his arthritis.~Hamlet~The other pup I had with me was Hamlet. Â I've not reallyÂ mentioned anything about him lately and thought I'd give you an update since I know that there are some of you who are pretty fond of him. I don't quite know where to start. Â As you know, he had his last surgery in late November. Â Since that 2nd surgery he's been taking Chinese herbs to slow the return of the tumor. Â In comparing the time that has passed when he was taking the herbs verses when he wasn't taking them, I really feel that they have worked pretty well and have given him some good time. Â But the tumor has returned, just as we knew it would. Â What was once the size of the palm of one hand, is now the size of both hands, and is growing relatively quickly. Â There has been a change in Hamlet in the past week. Â While he still has a great appetite, is very much a part of the group and my shadow on our walks and around the house, his energy level has dropped. Â When he's resting, I notice him breathing heavily, and sleeping more soundly. Â  The vet recommended we put Hamlet back on pain medication, in case he may be having come discomfort. Â I don't know what any of this means, and don't feel that another surgery is an option...I just hope that when the time comes to make any decision on the path to take, we'll both know. Â Send some hope and prayers for Hamlet if you think about it, okay? ~Hamlet~Â ï»¿ï»¿ ~Hamlet~ï»¿ï»¿Carl returned to his old but new job this week.Â Â On Thursday he called my office and I was unable to come to the phone.Â  ButÂ he left a message asking me to call him back, andÂ saidÂ that there had been an incident at work, but he was okay.Â  Of course since 'worry' is my middle name, I was worried.Â  The problem with calling him back was that he hadn't given me his new work number.Â  Carl and I don't work to far from one another andÂ just as a coincidenceÂ I noticed a helicopterÂ overhead in his direction--which didn't help.Â Â I did knowÂ thatÂ he wouldn't answerÂ his cell phone because he's not allowed to bring it into the office--that didn't help either.Â  CarlÂ finally called me about an hour later and told me what happened;Â two suspicious packages found in an unmarked, unattended van on the outside gate ofÂ the building where he works--Police and trucks everywhere....He asked why I didn't call him back.Â  I told him it was because I didn't have his office phone number.Â Â Carl said it was the same number he'd always hadÂ (before he left on his 'year long assignment.')Â  Now I ask, how was I supposed to know that he would return to the same desk and have the same phone number?Â  I guess there are some things I'm just supposed to know...ï»¿ ~Toby~ï»¿

title: Back to Boring!
text: To some, the past weekend I hadÂ would no doubtÂ be boring.Â Â The weather was bright and sunny; a little too bright for Hamlet (below) and we had warm temps. When I was tired of catching up on things inside, the dogs and I enjoyed several walks. Â How is it that they always seem to find some great smell to enjoy....and roll on?Â  We played a few rounds of frisbee, which the dogs love!When the gang wasÂ worn out from that, they relaxed in the grass. ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿ ~Rudi, (left) and Sheba~Â ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿ ~Josh~ï»¿Carl ended his job assignment yesterday and today he goes back to his old/new job with a commute a little closer to home. After a year, he's finally backÂ on a daytimeÂ schedule.Â Â  This means I will have to start cooking dinner each night, andÂ the dogs are back to seeing the dog walk on a regular basis.Â  What was I saying about boring?Â Â  Actually after last week, I'm really okayÂ with that!Â Â I hope your week is off to a good start!Â ï»¿ï»¿ ~Wendy~ï»¿ï»¿

title: Finally It's Friday!
text: The end of a rotten week has finally arrived! Â It started out so well with the beautiful portrait of Tanner arriving on Monday.Â  But then a down-hill spiral started which includedÂ Carl's car gettingÂ hit by a stray bullet, (Carl is fine, his car will be too!) I had a flat-tire in the pouring rain, and thenÂ I didn't get a day off, added to that was theÂ sad event of putting a sweet pup like Sandy down.Â  Needless to say, its all left me worn out!Â Â On top of all this, which given everything else seems kind of trivial, is that I was itching away from poison ivy. Â Yes, spring has just barely arrived, and despite my best efforts to avoid it last weekend, and use the 'special soap' after I weeded my flower beds, I got it on my face and arms. (I'm really thinking I should run a contest to see who can guess how many times I'll have gotten it by Labor Day in September!) Â Thank-fully it's starting to clear up. Â But it didn't stop an 11 year old patient from joking about it--He asked me, 'what do you get if you cross a four leaf clover with poison ivy? A rash of good luck' Â Â ... Â I wasn't feeling all that lucky. However, that may be changing. Â When I came home today I found a package in our mailbox, from The Rocky Creek Scotties!Â  I'd guessed several weeks ago when a litter of Scottish Terriers would be arriving--There were 2 winners in the puppy-pool, and I was one of them! Â If you want a real moment of cuteness, hop over to Rocky Creek ScottiesÂ (click on the name)Â and pay them a visit--The puppies are now almost a month old and are growing and changing so fast! Â I've really become smitten with them, and while I think the girls are adorable, for some reason, I'm drawn to the little boys.......But the package is full of lots of tasty treats for our pups, a couple of new toys and a few fun things for me too!! Â Thank-you Rocky Creek Scotties for letting us be part of your puppy pool and for the fun package!! Finally I'm looking forward to a quiet weekend of catching up on things around the house, your blogs and just relaxing. Â After a year, this is Carl's last weekend at his current job assignment, and he returns to a regular job with the Department of Defense on Monday. Â We're really excited that he'll no longer be working a rotating shift that included nights and weekends. Â I hope whatever you are doing this weekend, that it's an enjoyable one!!~Hamlet~

title: I Had Really Hoped
text: Its been a long and emotional day that started with rain and a flat tire. Â Thank-youÂ again for your kind thoughts and prayers for Sandy. IÂ had so hopedÂ that the news would have been better for her.Â Â Blood work that was done last week, showedÂ significant changes in all the wrong places this week; her blood pressure was so low that the techs had problems drawing blood.Â Â An x-ray taken showed a mass in her abdomen the size of a small cantaloupe and she was bleeding internally.Â Â The kind thing to do, was to let her go.Â  Carl brought her home and spent the day with her.Â  I was at work hoping for a miracle. Â I'd hoped Sandy would be able to enjoy the warmth of the sun on our front porch.Â  I'd hoped she'd be able to enjoy the walks around our property and the chance to lay in the green grass.Â Â I'd hopedÂ to be able to take more pictures of her.Â  I'd hoped we'd have more time to get to know one another...But it was what I wanted, and not what wasÂ meant to be. Â We sat with Sandy as her sweet, quiet soul left this world for the next.Â  This evening after we leftÂ the vets office,Â we saw thisÂ rainbow. Â God speed Sandy. Â  Â Even though we hardly knew you, we won't forget you.Â I'm at work, and just thought I'd post an update on Sandy.Â  Blood work, x-rays all point to a diagnosis ofÂ hemangiosarcomaÂ  Those of you who have had dogs with this, know how suddenly it can and does occur, and that there is sadly nothing that can be done.Â  After I speak to the rescue and get the needed 'approval' we'll say our good-byes and send herÂ to the Rainbow Bridge.Thank-you all for your positive thoughts and prayers for Sandy.Â Â I know she has just come to us,Â and we hardly know her, but I'd hoped for more time...

title: Hoping for the Best
text: I wish that the news about Sandy was better....But she has no energy, no interest in food (very unusual for a Golden!) and is drinking very little water. Â I thought a morning walk with the gang might perk her up, but all it did was wear her out and caused a bout of bloody 'gastroÂ upset,' which she has had for several days. Â Sandy hardly leaves our spare bedroom, except to be taken outside, which we insist she do. Â The vet that sees our dogs doesn't work everyday and will be in the office on Wednesday. Â Sandy is being seen first thing. Â When I sit with her and talk to her, it's so easy to see that there's a spark there, which is why I'm hoping for the best.

title: Blogging Friends - Among the Best!
text: A busy and tiring Monday wasÂ forgotten about when I came home this evening and found a package waiting for me.Â Â Inside the box, a very special gift fromÂ Tina from the blogÂ One Wild SwanÂ Â ï»¿whoÂ so thoughtfully and without my knowing, painted a portrait of our beloved Tanner who left us in March.Â  I've been following Tina's blog for some time and each time she posts one of her portraits,Â IÂ am in awe ofÂ her talent and how each piece she creates is brought to life.Â  I think this is what she did in her painting of Tanner; she captured hisÂ sweet spirit and kind soul.Â  I have found myself drawn toÂ Tanner's eyes in the portraitÂ and remembering how gentle they were...I am so touched by Tina'sÂ thoughtfulness forÂ aÂ gift that has become a treasure.Â Â Thank-you again Tina forÂ your beautiful gift that has truly touched my heart andÂ soul.Â Â Â Â Tina's gift reminds meÂ of how blessedÂ I am to have her friendship and yours.Â  Even though I've never met any of you, I feel like I have because of your blogs.Â Â You have given me a glimpse into your lives,Â told me aboutÂ places I'll never get to visit,Â and shownÂ kindness that I'll always be grateful for--Thank-you for that!Â  If you'd like to visit Tina's blog, here's the link:http://onewildswan.blogspot.com/When I agreed to let Sandy come here, I was told that getting her to us wouldn't occur until at least the middle of the week. Â But the sun and the moon lined up perfectly and I think before I could change my mind, a ride for Sandy to my neck of the woods was arranged.I met the transport in Frederick Maryland at a local McDonalds. Â I was told that Sandy hadn't eaten the night before and very little that morning. Â She's on medication for anÂ intestinalÂ problems, so it was thought that this might be the reason for the lack of appetite. Â However I had an appetite and decided I would grab something to eat on the way home. Sandy had been laying in the back of the van, and went I pulled up to place my order, suddenly Sandy was standing there wagging her tail, ready to give her order. Â Obviously she's been to a drive-thru before!Â  I shared a little of what I had with her and she and I are now good friends! Introductions were met with a few growls from Sandy, but otherwise its been a quiet evening. Â Sandy is used to being an only dog and living in the group home will no doubt be a little of an adjustment for her. Â But she's a sweet little lady with spark and a continually wagging tail!Medically, I don't know what will happen. Â Sandy has cancerous tumors called 'epulis,'Â in her mouth. Â That's why her upper lip and teeth look a little uneven. She also has some other ongoing health issues and last year the vet and the previous owners were going toÂ euthanizeÂ her, why they didn't, I don't know.Â  But what I do knowÂ is that Sandy doesn't feel well.Â  She's very slow moving because sheÂ does seem to have a bit of arthritis in her hips--SoÂ when she did something she never had done before such as snappingÂ at a child that fell right on top of her, was that a reason to send her away?

title: My Heart Can't Say No
text: Saturday could not have been a more perfect day! Â Bright sunshine and warmth, my favorite! Â I finally was able to get my rain barrel set up for the year. Â I figure with the strange weather we've been having, our summer is probably going to be one with lots of rain or none at all. The birds were feeling industrious too. Â Each year as the dogs start to shed, I collect some of their hair and put it out for the birds to use in their nests. Yesterday the 'Titmouse' was collecting some. Â I like the thought that the hair from my dogs will be keeping baby birds warm. While a couple of the dogs watched from the porch, I also got some weeding done. Readers of this blog may recall that poison ivy and I donâ€™t mix well. Â I know that it's growing in my flower beds and I 'think' I know what it looks like. Â While I avoided what I 'think' it is, I know that there was no way to not come in contact with it. I used a special soap to wash off the oils afterwards, and this morning despite a few blotches, I think I've avoided getting it....This time...Afterwards we took a walk up into the field in back of us.~Hamlet~Today is supposed to be a quiet one. We 'might' be getting a new addition to our crew in the next couple of days. Â A senior Golden, who is about 13 years old, named Sandy needs a hospice-home without stairs for the time she has left. The rescue was unable to find a place for her to go and asked us. For once, I really, really resisted because our lives will be undergoing some changes over the next few months (I'll write about them very soon). Â I asked them to work and find another place for Sandy. Â The family from the rescue that has her, decided that they did not want her to stay with them, and the rescue was unable to find another foster home.Â The rescue communicatesÂ almost totally via e-mail.Â  SoÂ an unusual step was taken and an actual phone call was made to meÂ to askÂ again.Â Â I'd had a feeling this might happen and I'd already given itÂ a lot of thought and discussed itÂ at length with Carl.Â  SoÂ after talking to this volunteer about it and discussing how to get her here from the state of Delaware,Â I agreed. Â Sandy is not in the best of condition right now. Â But in my heart I knew that I couldn't say 'no' to a Golden Retriever that needs a place to go, especially one that's not feelingÂ well.Â Â Below is a picture ofÂ Hamlet this morningÂ on the back porch.Â  As he stood there lookingÂ so relaxed andÂ was sniffing the air, the feeling came over meÂ that bringing Sandy hereÂ is the right thing to do.

title: Creatures Golden and Small
text: I really enjoy sleeping with the windows open, but it can come with a price. Â This morning at 4:30, the price was a crack of lightening, and the sound of rumbling thunder that woke everyone. Â When a couple of the dogs started to pace and pant, I knew I had no choice but to get up. Â CarrieAnne, the most nervous hid under my feet while I sat at the computer. Â Outside, the storm battered us with high winds and a torrential downpour. Â Tornado warnings were issued and there was a reported siting of one in an area minutes from us. Â What a way to start the day! I delayed the morning walk with the dogs until Carl got home from work and the storm passed. Â In our yard we found this cow-bird. Â My guess is that it was a casualty from the storm. Â When we tried to catch it, it did fly some, but not much.Carl finally caught it and we put it into the field next to us to keep it safe from the dogs until it can regain its strength. Â I have to admit to not liking cow-birds. Â They are actually the very reason why I've cut back on feeding the birds. Â They come in flocks, gobble down everything and chase the little birds away. Â But as it sometimes is with Â people, you put all those feelings aside and do what you can to help. Running errands this morning, I saw that the creeks are full and some of the fields are flooded. Â Water was across the road in some places as well. On my way home, I found this little terrapin trying to cross the road. I don't know if this little guy wanted my help or not, but it got it, because I always stop and and pick them up. I think it knew it was safer in its shell because it never came out, but looked at us from the inside. Â  Maybe a couple of the dogs thinking I had a snack for them was the reason....When I was a kid and we would see a terrapin on the road, my Mom would stop the car and either me or one of my siblings would pick it up and either set it well across the road, or we'd take it to a place where it would be safe. Â My Mom always told us when we let it go to wish it good luck...Afterwards she'd always ask us if we did that. So, of course when I let this one go in our woods, I wished it 'good luck' Funny what you can remember from so long ago...I hope if any of you have been caught in these storms, that you've had 'good luck' and are safe too!~Sheba~

title: The Theme For the Day
text: CarrieAnne disappeared to her private swimming holeÂ this evening.Â  AsÂ you can see she wasÂ quite happy with herself when she returned.Â  However she wasÂ covered in mud andÂ needed a bath.Â  So I told her:Â  Don't do the crime...If you can't do the time....Hope your week is off to a better start than CarrieAnne's evening!

title: What'll They Think of Next?
text: If you're from the south like I am, then you know that all good things come fried. So you can imagine how my interest was peaked when I read in the paper a couple of weeks ago about a 'new' Easter tradition, deep fried Cadbury Creme Eggs--I could tell in reading about them that they are an important part of a balanced diet and are a terrific source of sugar, calories, and saturated fat.Â  I could also tell that theyÂ greatly reduce the chances of avoidingÂ a heart attack. I knew I had to try them.Â  So, with Carl working,Â I decided today was the day to give thisÂ nutritionalÂ goodness a try.Â  They weren't too bad--I think the secret is to eat them while they're still warm.Â  They tasted a little soggy when cold.Â Â But I have to wonder just what'll they think of next? ï»¿ ~Bubba (left) Toby (right)~ï»¿ I'd like to thank everyone for the good thoughts for Bubba. He didn't have any seizures last night. But he did have one mid morning today. If I saw the clock correctly, it lasted 6 minutes. His seizures seem to come in 3's, so I'm hoping that'll be the last of them for now. Amazing how afterwards he continues on like nothing has happened. If only I could do the same! Sheba's eye is much better too.Â  The swelling on her eye as you can see is almost totally gone.Â  So I think our day is ending on a good note, with the help of deep-fried Cadbury Creme eggs!HAPPY EASTER!!

title: Good and Bad Friday
text: Every time the dogs have had the chance, they have checked under Carl's car. Â We've no idea what it was and continues to be soÂ intriguingÂ to them. We have another ground-hog that lives on the other side of our driveway and last year it managed to wedge itself into the engine of the car. Â I'm wondering if it didn't find another place to hide when surprised by the dogs.The work week ended uneventfully and I got out of the office on time. Â With cold rainy weather, I just wanted to get home. A good thing since Bubba has had 2 seizures this evening. Â I looked at the clock when they started and noted that they lasted 3 and 5 minutes. Â When BubbaÂ has a seizure to keep him  fromÂ injuring himself, especially if he is on the wood floor, I  place a folded towel under his head to cushion his thrashing and catch the drool. Â He also loses control of his bladder and so I put a towel on top of him because I don't want the floor to be slippery when he tries to stand. Â If there's a lot of noise or light I'll turn downÂ the lights and turn off  any music or the television. Â While he is still lying there I pet and  talk to him and reassure him (and me!) that everything is 'okay.' Â I think it might help to give  him something to focus on. Â Of course I hope he doesn't have any more, he's exhausted. Â Thankfully Bubba always sleeps on the floor on my side of the bed and I'll hopefully know if he does. Â It may be a long night...

title: A Dog With a Bone
text: I got home early from work on Wednesday, and as our routine dictates, we go for a walk. Â But the dogs had another thing in mind.... Â ~Rudi and Josh~I doubt it was Carl's full tank of gas that the dogs found so interesting, but rather something with four legs. Â Whatever it was, Rudi was determined.We're getting ready to go for our morning walk, and I'm sure this scene will be repeated and repeated and repeated...The words 'a dog with a bone' keeps coming to mind! Enjoy your Thursday!~Bubba~

title: Never a Dull Moment!
text: There's never a dull moment around here!Â  Last evening when I got home I noticed a little bit of swelling around Sheba's eye.Â  This morning she looked like she'd gone a few rounds with a prize fighter!Â  Carl took her to the vet whoÂ thinksÂ Sheba lost a battle with a spider.Â  SheÂ was due for a yearly exam anyway, so since she was there, they popped up the hood and checked everything else.Â  Dogs testing positive for lyme disease isn't uncommon in this area, and for the first time Sheba tested positive for it.Â  She's not showing any symptoms of the illness so we'll do a round of 30 days of antibiotics andÂ hopeÂ that'll take care of it. I hope the medications that she has for her eye will take care of that too.I don't know that I've mentioned thatÂ Sheba is our youngest Golden at six years old.Â Â Given up by her owners because sheÂ needed hip surgery, (that they couldn't afford) sheÂ came to us via the rescue in the fall of 2006 at almost a year old as a foster dog. Â Sheba alwaysÂ has something in her mouth and with people she is affectionate andÂ leans and melts into you when you pet her.Â  But around dogs that sheÂ doesn't know she can be bossy and wants to be top dog.Â Â There was a time after we adopted her that I thought I was going to have to return her to the rescue because she was picking fights with the other dogs, which resulted in trips to vet for the other dogs. Â HoweverÂ with some good outside help andÂ theÂ dogs figuring it all out,Â (and Sheba getting LOTS of exercise) sheÂ foundÂ her place within the peking order, but not at the top--Rudi is ourÂ top dog, and Sheba, I can tell has a lot of respect for her.Â  Sheba's favorite playmates are CarrieAnne and Charlie who thinks we got her just for him--He loved her from the minute she first came to us, and that has never changed--For eitherÂ one of us--Even with a swollen eye!

title: Last Time--I Promise!?
text: ~Sheba~I know, I know, I'm sounding like a broken record with my constant andÂ never-endingÂ posts about my nemesis, the dreaded brown marmarated stink bug. Â Tonight however, I went to a whole new level when I attended a 'stink bug lecture' given by our congressman, Frank Wolf. Two experts spoke about the ongoing research and damage (30+ million dollars to apple growers alone)Â they've caused toÂ agriculturalÂ crops in the mid-Atlantic region.Â Â Â Interesting at least to me, is that the Virginia grape growers face the prospect of harvesting the bugs along with the cabernet and chardonnay and putting them through the crusher â€“ and then the risk of stink bug aroma is in what had been a fine wine -- It takes as little as 5 stink bugs in one ton of grapes to have this occur. ~Left to right, Hamlet, Josh, Sheba & Sam~They have no 'natural'Â predator in the States so there is no 'silver bullet' that will kill them. Â If you think you've sprayed something on one and killed it, you may not have, it can fully recover in as much as 7 days. Â Remind me to check the ones I thought were dead.By mid September, we will have 2 more generations of them. Â By mid September, I may be posting from a padded room, that hopefully is stink-bug free...Okay, I'm done now, I won't bring them up again. Â At least I'll try not too. Â I hope your week is off to a good start. Â Sorry I wasn't able to stop by your blogs today, but I'll make time to see what you're up to on Tuesday!~Left to right: Toby, Sheba & Rudi~

title: Picking Up The Torch
text: While I worked on Thursday afternoon my co-worker attended her daughters play (pictured below). Â Any thoughts about what the play was about? Â I think that may be Mother Nature front and center, but I've no idea who the boys in the upper left may be. Â  Â Â  With a slow schedule, I took Friday off and caught up on yard work.Â  The  dogs helped. Â Â ~Sheba left & Hamlet on the right~Today we'veÂ had tornado warnings, thunderstorm warnings, and severe storm  warnings.Â  Heavy rain fell off and on all day.Â  We have standing water in our  backyard and the dogs have literally had to wade out to the grass.Â  There have  also been periods ofÂ thunder and lightening.Â Â Off and on throughout the years  we've had dogs that have been afraidÂ of the storms.Â Â The last few years the one  to have the most fear was Tanner.Â  Now that he's gone, I have to admit to  looking forward to not having a dog with storm-phobias.Â  However that changed  today when CarrieAnne (below) picked up that torch and came and sat next to me after  every rumble of thunder. Â  Â Â Â Despite all the noise outside, itsÂ been another quietÂ day at home.Â A TV  show that has been on all day and I've been watching off and onÂ isÂ one I've  never seen before called 'Parking Wars.' The show focusesÂ on the employees of  the Philadelphia and Detroit Parking AuthorityÂ and their daily work: ticketing,  booting (via wheel clamp)Â and towing cars all the whileÂ dealing with the tempers and rants that arise with the car ownersÂ who are all innocent victims.Â  Remind  me to check to see if we have any unpaid tickets and to not to park in Philadelphia. Â Actually, I don't recall  everÂ gettingÂ a parking ticket (speeding, yes, more than once!)Â  Have you ever  gotten a parking ticket?Â  Where were you and did you remember to pay  it? Â Another question, have you ever left your dog out in the rain...I accidentally forgot Charlie outside today, but remembered him...eventually...

title: Work Not Play
text: Another quiet and mostly uneventful week. Â If you're enjoying a sunny day, you can thank me for it! Â I have to work this afternoon because a co-worker of mine is attending a play at her daughter's school. Â It seemed like a good idea when I agreed to work for her a couple of weeks ago. ~Hamlet~But with the sun out, I've decided that rather than go to work, I'd much rather be hanging around the house...Maybe playing a round of frisbee with the dogs...~Sheba~Or just enjoying the sun!~CC~I hope whatever you're doing, you're enjoying your day--Our resident groundhog seems to be!

title: Cautious Optimism and Secrets
text: I'm wondering why it is that Monday is a nicer day than the weekends? Â We had really warm temperatures today with lots of sun, quite a change from the weekend. Â The great weather was one reason why I hurried home this evening. Â Another was to see how many stink-bugs were inside the house. Â From last Monday, on a scale from 1 to 10, with 10 being the worse, I would have given it 13. Â Tonight however, I give it about a 6. Â There were not nearly as many, and I only spent about 45 minutes vacuuming them this evening--Much better!! Â There were also not nearly as many on the outside of the house or on the screens. Â A good sign! Â We'll see how long it lasts. Â I'm afraid I'll jinx it but I am cautiously optimistic and hopeful. Long time readers of this blog may remember that our girl CarrieAnne on warm evenings will often disappear to take a little swim in a place that only she knows about. Â She did this tonight. Â After 3 years, I still have no idea where she goes to cool off.... Â  Â And Carrie is not telling her secret!

title: The Price of My Sanity
text: ~Josh left--Sam, on the right~On the warmest day last week when I returned home from work, I spent (no kidding) 2 hours vacuuming up stink-bugsÂ inside the house.Â  I'd left many of the windows open and theyÂ were everywhere--on the ceiling, on the floor,Â on the furniture, everywhere--And some were flying around! Â The next morning when I cameÂ into the kitchen there were 3 together 'nose-to-nose' on the kitchen counter, like they were having a meeting--I really think there's a plot to overtake our house!Â Â Needless to say, I admitted defeatÂ inÂ the battle the night before.Â Â On the way to work that morning (I have to add that there was a stink-bug on the back window of my van) I formulated a new plan of attack.Â  This would require bringing in the bug-guns, I mean, the big guns...I avoid the use ofÂ pesticides and chemicals, but I felt the time had come to call a pest control company.Â Â Two different people came yesterday, one for the bugs, the other came laterÂ to check for termites.Â I took part of the dogs for a car-rideÂ while they were here.Â Â ChemicalsÂ were not used inside the house, butÂ hopefully the 'repellant' will work to keep themÂ away.Â  They'll return again in a month to spray again.Â Â Its been cold the last few days but warmer weather is predicted for the coming week, so we'll see.Â Â Right now the total for this round of the battle is:Â Gas to drive the dogs around for 2 hours - $10.00Cost of two drive-thru tripsÂ toÂ McDonalds -Â $7.00Bill from the pest control company - $165.00My Sanity if this works - $-Priceless!ï»¿

title: Poor Charlie...
text: In our house when it comes to scrappy, scruffy charm and sheer entertainment, Charlie takes the cake!Â  There is no question that he is the 'star' of our household.Â  TheÂ Goldens areÂ laid back easy going, they like routine andÂ go with the flow.Â Usually if there's a little injury, or they don't feel well, they are stoic and uncomplaining--Not Charlie,Â he's the total opposite.Â Â Right now he has a smallÂ place on his leg that he's been licking (and licking) that is nowÂ sore.Â Â I shaved theÂ hair around it, cleanedÂ it really well,Â put on an antibiotic and wrapped it up and put a 'sock and shoe' on him to keep him from being able to get to it.Â Â While I've no doubtÂ it's a little tender, Charlie cried and whined and tried to get away from me the whole time.Â  Today whenÂ I've come near him his eyes are full of suspicion and doubt.Â Â I can only hope that my treating thisÂ at home willÂ do the trick and he won't have to go to the vet.Â  If he does, IÂ may have to find a therapist for him...AndÂ for me!All in all, a quiet day at home--The weather is finally feeling like spring, and I'm seeing more of my Â perennialsÂ every day. Â I've been reading about keeping guineas.Â Â Someone told meÂ that they will eat stink-bugs.Â  Does anyone know if this is true?Â  The news is reporting that the number of stink-bugs is expected toÂ be 'biblicalÂ proportions' this year.Â  IfÂ what we're seeing already is any indication,Â we'll need all the help we can get!~We saw this guinea hen while in Tennessee in March~

title: The Things That Bump in the Night!
text: ~Josh~ï»¿ï»¿I don't make a secret out of not liking to be at home alone by myselfÂ at night.Â  While IÂ actually do feel pretty safe with all the dogs here,Â the problem is that when IÂ go to bed and everyone isÂ finally settled down,Â my mind sometimes starts to wander and I hear noises and every creek and rattle.Â  So, you may be able toÂ imagine the thoughts that were going through my mindÂ the other night when there wereÂ high winds, thunder and lightening and I kept hearing this tapping noise that sounded like it was right outside my window.Â  Each time it happened, the dogs would either growl or start barking.Â  Add to that a couple ofÂ Â phone calls from an 'unknown caller' that left no message and hung up--Needless to say, my wild imagination and my OCD trying to figure out what it wasÂ took off!Â  I really did try to think rationally thatÂ 'maybe'Â a piece of sidingÂ hadÂ come loose from the house.Â  So,Â I gathered some courage, turned on all the outsideÂ lights, grabbed a flashlight and the dogs and I went out onto the front porch to take a look--In the darkness I saw nothing--But more noises fromÂ the woods made us quickly goÂ back inside.Â  Eventually I fell asleep, waking up a few times to that same tapping noise that would cause aÂ growl from one or more of the dogs.Â Â  It's true what the say. Â Things always look better in the morning. Â When it got light, I went outside to take a look and this was what I found... Â A stone wind chime that I had takenÂ down a few days ago and put over the porch railing.Â Â The wind must'veÂ caused it to occasionally hit the side of the house.Â  I'd overlooked it in the darkness.Â  Needless to say, I had to laugh at myself for once again letting my totallyÂ irrational fear and thoughts get the best of me! Â We're so brave here at Golden Pines, aren't we?Â ~Hamlet~

title: A Forever Home for the Chub Brothers
text: ï»¿ ~Bubba~ï»¿ The call came earlier today from the rescue.Â  The Chub Brothers, BubbaÂ and Toby (pictured below)Â will be staying at Golden Pines!!Â  Carl and IÂ will 'officially' adopt Toby and the rescue will continue to 'officially' own Bubba, paying (only) for his vet care.Â  There are a few caveats with this arrangement;Â howeverÂ I'mÂ optimistic that it's one that has only Bubba's best interest in mind and no ones personal agenda.Â Â I'm relieved and very thankful.Â  I'm also thankful for all of you who sent positive thoughtsÂ while I waited and worried.Â ~Toby~

title: Waiting and a Lost Piece of History
text: I was told yesterday that the board of directors for the rescue would be meeting this morningÂ and on the agenda will beÂ 'The Chub Brothers.'Â  While I really think (and hope) that good sense and logic about their situation will ultimately win outÂ and the boys will stay here, I still am nervous about it.Â  This in part is why IÂ wasn't sure if it was that or theÂ cookies I had for breakfast this morning that made me really antsy and IÂ just couldn't sit still.Â  To rid myself of that extra energy,Â I packed up Rudi and Charlie and ran a couple of errands.Â  One of my stops wasÂ Southern States for bird food whereÂ I wasÂ taken in by another kind of bird--Lots of baby chicks!!Â Â They are really cute, and I thoughtÂ were inexpensive at about $5 each; I had $25 in cash but resisted!Â Â Â Â On my way homeÂ I drove pastÂ this barn.Â It was built in the 19th century and isÂ the last intact barn that the townÂ had.Â  It is alsoÂ the spot for a new shopping center andÂ the barn and silo as per the agreement with the town wereÂ supposed to be dismantled andÂ incorporatedÂ within theÂ center.Â  However, the construction company's version of 'dismanteling' the barn with the use ofÂ two backhoes looked more like a demolition!Â Â Of course the town is reallyÂ upsetÂ andÂ issued a 'stop work order' and is fining the constructionÂ company $1000 per day until it's resolved.Â Â The construction companyÂ in turn fired those responsible for the 'mistake' and vowed toÂ 'make it right'Â  in aÂ written apologyÂ to the town and its residents that appeared in the local papers.Â Â But I think it's really sad that such a beautiful piece of the towns history andÂ theÂ gateway into it have apparently been destroyed.Â  I'll be sure to post when I hear somethingÂ from the rescue about 'The Chub Brothers.' I hope you're enjoying your weekend!

title: Groundhog Day on April Fools?
text: To begin, I really enjoyed reading yourÂ comments from my last post about inconsiderate cell phone usersÂ andÂ which is your favorite day of the week!Â  Thursday didn't turn out to be to bad for me.Â Â Late yesterday afternoon I got a call from the office manager where I work asking if I'd like to take Friday off because of a 'wide open schedule.'Â  Not wanting to be at the office looking for something to do, I said I would.Â  WednesdayÂ had also been a bit slow and with no patient after lunchÂ another co-worker and IÂ decidedÂ to make 'banana boat s'mores' in our little toaster oven for everyone--NowÂ you know what goes on in a dentalÂ office when there areÂ no patients--They had been featured in a magazine we received and we thought 'why not?'Â Â I've never had them before and have to admit, they weren't too bad--But then isn'tÂ anything that hasÂ melted chocolate on it?Â Â Â Â The dayÂ at home has been a pretty quiet one.Â Â As I write this, 'stray cat' is eating the food we put out this morning.Â  Of course itÂ runs when it sees us, or crouches down in the grass and watches as we put the food down; butÂ itÂ is coming every day to eat.Â  I did notice the crows got there before the cat did, so I hope there was something left.Â I also have caught my very first glimpse of our one of our resident ground-hogs!Â  A sure sign that despite the cold that spring is here--At least I 'think' it was the ground-hog.Â  It is April Fools day after all!Â  I'll end this post with aÂ picture of Hamlet.Â  You can see on his left shoulder a tumorÂ that is a little smaller than aÂ tennis ball.Â Â It's not the same one that he had removed, but it has been there sinceÂ he came to us.Â  It has gottenÂ a littleÂ bigger, butÂ it doesn't seem to bother him, so with that, it doesn't bother me...At least not too much...

title: The Best Day of the Week!
text: ~Wendy~For the most part, I really enjoy the patients that come into the office  where I work.Â Â But every once in awhile one comes in that has a way of getting on my very last nerve. Â TheÂ patient I'm referring to isÂ habituallyÂ late for his  appointments and is always talking on his cell phone.Â Â Today it was the same  thing,Â he came in late and was talking on his cell phone.Â  When seated, just as  the appointment was about to begin, the phone rang and heÂ got up fromÂ the chair  to take the call without so much as a word to me. Â Have you seen the Verizon commercialÂ where the two guys are  on a ski-lift and the otherÂ takesÂ the cell phone from his friend and throws it?Â   That's what I felt like doing when it rang yet a second time--Fortunately for  him, he let it go to voice-mail.Â But each week I realize just how much IÂ just love Wednesday.Â Â I  think because it always reminds me that I'm half way through the week and I only  have one day left to work and two days until the weekend.Â  But in thinking about  it, maybe it'sÂ Friday that I love the most...Yeah,Â I just love Friday, that's my  favorite day of the week! title: All is Calm on the Home-Front
text: An uneventfulÂ weekÂ led to a quiet weekend. Â If there is something exciting happening, it's not happening here. Â It was sunny and cool on Saturday and this morning the day started with clouds and a little bit of snow. Â Â The most excitement we had were the dogs playing frisbee.Hamlet could hardly contain himself...Â It got to be so much for CarrieAnne that shetook a break in the  neighboring field...Last night after dinner, Carl was cleaning up the kitchen (how nice was  that??) And I asked him if he would bring me a glass of water and of course he  said that he would.Â  After a few minutes into the office he came with a  FLY-SWATTER...He really thought that was what I said I wanted.Â  Clearly we have  a communication problem or someone has a hearing problem, I'm not sure of  which. Â (Below Rudi)I know I should relish these quiet times. Â As the weather warms up, peace and quiet will give way to work outside. Â One of our projects will be to plant the 10 bare-rooted Scottish-Pine trees that we got from Virginia Department of Forestry a few weeks ago.
