Â But I'm optimistic and hopeful I'll be here to see them grow into beautiful trees, providing a natural screen for the far side of our yard where the new driveway has been put in. Â I hope you've had a good weekend!!

title: Will They Stay and the Stray
text: ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿Another non-eventful but busy work week coming to an end. I thought Spring was going to remain, but Old Man Winter remains tough and determined and is threatening us with snow flurries for the weekend. ï»¿ ~Toby~ï»¿ I've been waiting to hear back from the rescue about our foster boys, The Chub Brothers, Bubba and Toby. No, we've not officially adopted them and so they are still 'owned' by the rescue. I've known since they got here last June that they probably weren't going anywhere, but I just never did anything to make sure they would be staying.Â  Then whenÂ I wasn't asked for several months about them, alongÂ with all that was going on with Hamlet and Tanner, it just was easier to put it all on the back-burner.Â  But I came back onto the rescues radar aÂ couple of weeks ago when I was asked about them, and if or when they would be put up for adoption, since that's the goal.Â Â However we're facing a dilemma with Bubba. For one day aboutÂ every 2 months or so, he'll have 2-3 grand-mal seizures. I've spoken to my vet about them, and I don't feel like it's time yet to put him on medication for them; but I know there may well be a time when the seizures will become more frequent and he will need to be. Along with Toby he is also unable to do flights of stairs. ï»¿ï»¿~Bubba~ï»¿ï»¿The 'adoptability' of both dogs in my mind is in question. The Chub brothersÂ are a bonded pair and so one cannot be adopted without the other.Â Â Can anyone be foundÂ (beside me) willing to take on a pair of 11 year olds that can't do stairs and one that has medical issues?Â  AddÂ to thatÂ the expense of nearly $100 monthly for Bubba'sÂ medication for arthritis.Â  Having placed dogs for about 10 years now, I have my doubts about someone being found that will fill the needs for bothÂ these boys.Â  Thinking ahead, I know thatÂ we can't incur the expense of both dogs.Â  But IÂ have offered to adopt Toby and take on his expenses if the rescue will allow Bubba to remain in our home as a 'long term foster dog.'Â  Meaning thatÂ he would remain in our homeÂ for the rest of his life and all his medical expenses would be paid for by the rescue.Â  I felt it was a fair offer.Â  However IÂ know how the rescue sometimes operates andÂ I know that 'politics' always goes along with this type of thing (which is why I prefer to stay on the sidelines)Â so I guess I shouldn't be surprised that I've heard from no one.Â  In other news, the 'stray cat' that I last saw in January sometimeÂ has returned.Â  I was so happy to see it!!Â  It came closeÂ to the house so this is the first timeÂ I've gotten a really good look at it.Â  IÂ think that it's a pretty cat and a relatively young cat too.Â  And while this picture doesn't really show it, it's a little on the thin side as well.Â Â The poor thingÂ was eating the bird seed and stalking birds--So guess what I did?Â  Yes,Â even though I knew it would run off, I sent Carl out right away with a plateÂ of food for it.Â Â Â Â Paws crossed for 'it' to find the food and that the Chub Brothers can stayÂ with us...

title: Tennessee, Llamas and Donkeys--Oh My!!!
text: We've had such a nice day!!Â  Blue skies and sunshine, but a littleÂ cooler than it was yesterday.Â But that didn't keep us from getting outside into the fresh air and taking the dogs for a walk. (below is Hamlet)It was quite a change from the weather we had last week while in Tennessee.Â  We had everything there from snow to rain to warm sun--TheÂ view were just stunning;Â eastern Tennessee is reallyÂ beautiful! But theÂ trip there was really nice!!Â  The cabin at 'Autumn Dancer Llama Farm' is just perfect!!Â  It has every comfort of home that you could possibly need or want!Â  It is the perfect 'dog friendly' getaway--Carl and I and the dogs felt right at home!Â  The miniature donkeys were really friendly but the dogs had a hard time being convinced of that!Â  I really loved theÂ llamas!Â  Unlike Carl (below) IÂ kept my distance from them and admired them from afar.Â Â I took a lotÂ pictures of them--It was hard to pick out my favorites because the llamasÂ seem to beÂ photogenic--WhoÂ would have guessed that?Â Â Â Â BelowÂ is a French-Canadian Appaloosa Llama...Even though we lost Tanner just after we returned, we really feel like our batteries have been recharged.Â  I think it gave us the extra energy to get through the week.Â  We can't wait to go back again, and may return in the fall.Â  If you're looking for a really niceÂ 'dog friendly' place to stay near Gatlinburg Tennessee,Â here's the link to where we stayed: http://www.vrbo.com/233853

title: From Darkness to Gray to Light
text: I know that it's natural that itÂ has been a sad week for me as I've come to accept the loss of Tanner--Times filled with the realization that I'll never see him sleeping in the hallway, hear his 'woof's' as I get dinner ready, keepingÂ track of him when we're allÂ out for a walk, picking up his medications from the pharmacy...In the quiet timesÂ filled with grief, I've beenÂ comfortedÂ by the very kind thoughtful, encouraging e-mails andÂ comments left by you on my blog, yours andÂ others on Facebook.Â  Thank-you doesn't seem like enough as I've read and re-read them several times, feeling your friendship and support.Â  Through it all, I've looked for that sign that everything was okay.Â  That Tanner was okay.Â Â I've waited and watched and hoped that I would know it when and if it came...On Monday eveningÂ I wasÂ fixing dinner for the dogs,Â and as I was lost in a moment of silence and sadness,Â outside I heard a single goose honking as it flew over the house...The next morning I saw aÂ foxÂ pouncing and playing in the field.Â  When I stopped and watched it, it also stopped and looked at me...Then there wasÂ the cardinal singing so loud and beautifullyÂ at the end of the day,Â was that the sign?Â  I thought maybe it wasÂ a single daffodil that is blooming...Then again, maybeÂ the signÂ cameÂ from Wendy, who always came in right before Tanner after our walks.Â  On TuesdayÂ as I was getting everyone inside, IÂ was thinking ofÂ him and Wendy hesitated andÂ stared at me for a moment,Â cocked her head, barked twice,Â thenÂ went up the steps.Â Then on my commute this weekÂ the words of a song from 1984Â thatÂ I've heard 3 times on the radioÂ says,Â Â "After my picture fades and darkness has turned to grayWatching through windows you're wondering if I'm okay. Secrets stolen from deep inside, the drum beats out of timeIf you're lost you can look and you will find me, time after time..." ï»¿Could that have been it?Â  Is all of this 'theÂ sign' telling me that Tanner isÂ okay?Â  Finally, today when Carl and I had all the dogs outside this afternoon, we took a walk upÂ to theÂ fieldÂ in back of our house.Â  I marveled at what a warm, beautiful springÂ day it was.Â  In the distance across the field at the edge of the pond was a blonde Golden Retriever.Â  It was unusual to see a dog because we typically don't seeÂ other dogs--However the people on the other side of the field have them too.Â  But I becameÂ caught up in the beauty of the moment and how stunning the golden looked as it stood there peacefully sniffing the air.Â Â The thought again crossed my mind about Tanner and the hope that he was okay...I continued to watch the golden as it explored...Then I realized the dog that I was watching was actually our girl Rudi...She'd taken a moment and wandered off...That little sneak...Back to reality, home andÂ our life that goes on without Tanner, but with good memories of him that cannot be taken away.

title: Tanner at the Rainbow Bridge
text: It's with a broken heart that I post this evening and tell you that I sent our precious boy Tanner to the Rainbow Bridge. As you know, we had been giving him medication to try and control his laryngeal paralysis. Last evening when we returned from Tennessee, in the excitement he had problems breathing, but I was able to get him to relax by taking him for a ride in the van. This evening, he again had problems catching his breath andÂ something told me that this time it was different. I put him in the van and I drove the entire distance to the animal emergency clinic; his breathing had not improved. After what seemed like an eternity a vet called me back and rambled on with a grim diagnosis, treatment options and possibilities. I'm not sure of all that he said, but I totally understood that when Tanner was taken off the oxygen for even a few minutes it againÂ made it worse for him. In my heart I knew that the kind thing to do was to let him go...There was little time for a good-bye as I held Tanner thanking him for being a part of our life...He quietlyÂ left this life for the next taking a part of my heart with him and leaving part of his with me.Â Â Tanner was with us for almost 3 years and was about 14 years old. Our time with him wasn't nearly long enough--But I know that when we see him again, we will have all the time together that we didn't get in this life. I hope he will be met at the bridge by our pups Tod, Ben, Cougar, Kasey, Tosh, Tucker, Scout, Cubby, Logan, my beloved Cowboy and Maguire...When I returned home a candle was already burning...Did Carl know before he went to work?Â Â  God speed Tanner...

title: The Tales of Tennessee
text: We're having a really nice time here in Tennessee!! Â There has been snow, cold and rain, but it doesn't matter, it's such a beautiful place!! Â The cabin is just perfect and is well equipped with all the comforts of home; which means we have everything you could possibly need!!Just outside our window are the Llamas. Â The farm, called 'Autumn Dancer Llama Farm' is home to 17 of these beauties. Â My friend Ginny says there's a certain protocol that has to be followed when you meet them for the first time. Â So I've been admiring them from a distance because we've not been formally introduced--Who would have thought that formalities were so important to a llama? There's so much to do, and we've enjoyed seeing a few of the sites. Â The dogs have loved the walks with all the new smells. Â The only 'downside' to being here is that with the rotten weather we've not been able to freely access the internet. Â But that's okay, we've reallyÂ enjoyed our evenings relaxing and visiting with our friends!Â Â They've told us all about theÂ local legendsÂ and their storyÂ of finding a body in the road (still alive),Â a parcel of property that has had a home built on it twice and twice it has 'mysteriously' burned down, and then of course there are the tales of those who make moonshine...What a place!! Unfortunately tomorrow we leave it all behind and return to Virginia. Â I've missed Â reading your news and I look forward to reading what you've been up to when we get home! Â THANKS for stopping by my blog, and I hope you've had a good week!

title: Ready or Not!!
text: My van is washed, blinker fixed, and all the needed food for us and the dogs hasÂ been bought.Â  The list of instructions is all written out for the dog-walker, laundry done and my house is all cleaned up.Â  We're 'almost' ready for ourÂ much anticipated trip to Tennessee.Â Heavy rain is expected for the drive tomorrow.Â Â But the forescast improves on Thursday and Friday. Rain or shine, I am like a kid before Christmas and am really excited about the trip!Â Â  However, with the rising price of gasoline that seems to be going up every day, I just hope we'll be able to afford the gas to get there and back without having to take a second mortgage on our house!I'm really going to miss the pups that we're not taking with us.We've never both left the dogs before, but I know they'll be just fine!Â  (Carl & Toby)One thing I can't leave behind is my computer.Â  As you may know, I'mÂ an 'internet junkie' so we are taking one with us.Â Â HopefullyÂ I'll be able to post pictures of our trip while we're gone.Â  If not, look for an update by the end of the weekend whenÂ we return!Â  I hope you have an enjoyable week!!Â  (Tanner below)

title: Hamlet and Hope
text: Its been just over 3 months since Hamlet had his last surgery.Â  I marvel at how well everything has healedÂ because I think I would still be recovering from it all.Â Â But being a worrier, I'm still concerned about him.Â Â With each meal Hamlet isÂ given threeÂ Chinese herbs which total 14 pills a day--In the evening Maitake mushroomÂ is added.Â  All of this in hopes that it willÂ prevent the regrowth of the tumor that I was told would come back.Â Â My only worry is where the tumor was.Â Â I do feel a hard lump that I don't think was there before.Â  To see if it's growing, I've measured it, andÂ four of my fingers fits snuggly around it.Â  I've no ideaÂ if it's scar tissue, since there is a similar oneÂ in the same spot on the other side that isÂ softer and almost moveable.Â Â I suppose that I shouldn't focus on what could happen,Â but remember to enjoy our daily walks...Â Â Our time together...Â (left to right, Rudi, Josh, Charlie, CarrieAnne, Sheba, Hamlet)Just hanging out...Â And try not to worry...At least not too much...And remember to have hope...Sometimes that's all you can do...

title: In Search of Spring
text: Its been a relatively quiet week for us.Â  So, I'm sorryÂ if you're looking for an exciting post becauseÂ you won't get it here today!Â  That'll be next week when we take our trip to Tennessee.Â Â I'm getting really excited about getting out of town!Â Â To get my mind off of everything, IÂ went in search of signs of spring this morning.Â  MyÂ daffodils are starting to come up!Â  Rudi (standing) and Sheba weren't interested anything that was growing.Â  They went in search of their own signs of spring.Â  I can always count on them--It's nice that they areÂ willing to wait for their turn to roll on something...Â  WeÂ did have a tree fallÂ in the last windstorm.Â Â Today we'll try to get it cut up, save someÂ of it for firewoodÂ and drag the restÂ back into the woods to eventually create a 'rabbitat.'Â  At leastÂ that's the plan anyway.Â Â We'll first haveÂ to charge the chainsaw that we've not used since last year.Â  The only problem is, is that we don't seem to be able to find the charger.Â  I know I've seen it, and CarlÂ knows he did as well.Â  Why is it that you canÂ never find something that we've been literally tripping over for the last six months?Â  Too bad the dogs can't talk and tell us if they've seen it.Â  I have a feeling Rudi may know.ButÂ even if she could, I think she's much too occupied lookingÂ for those signs of springÂ to roll on.I hope you have an enjoyableÂ weekend!

title: The Circle of Life
text: I posted this picture on my Facebook page, but thought I would share it here too.Â  TheÂ puppy, named Pork-chop (for now) is one of 11 puppies that were born in the early morning hours of Sunday.Â  Their Mom, Roxie, came into the rescue about two weeks ago.Â  All are doing well.Â  YesterdayÂ aÂ couple of my friendsÂ sent theirÂ precious Goldens to the Rainbow Bridge.Â  AndÂ to me there's something comforting about seeing the face of a life that is so brand new--ItÂ reminds me of the beauty and circle of life.God speedÂ Lady and Cleo...

title: A Good Day to Play!
text: ï»¿ ~Rudi/left - Josh on the right~It was such a beautiful day in Virginia on Sunday!Â  The warmth of the sun and spring that was in the air truly energized all of us!Â  The dogs wanted to play a round of frisbee.Â  How did IÂ know that?Â  Rudi magically found a frisbee that had been lost months ago.Â How do they find these things?Â Â The first games of spring are always a lot of fun and IÂ realized how much I''ve missed warm weather andÂ just being outside~Sheba~ï»¿ï»¿I did stop at the grocery store on the way home from church.Â  I never shopÂ on Sunday, but I'd notÂ gone on Saturday.Â Â But as I was standing in the shorter express line ofÂ  '15 items or less,'Â I counted, and the person in front of me had 19.Â  Why do people do this?Â Â I always thinkÂ they need to have their rights read to them and they should be arrested and hauled off when this happens--But thenÂ as I wasÂ taking my things out of the basket, and counting, I realized I had 18.Â  IÂ tried to hide the 3 little cans of cat food in case the person in back of me noticed...Maybe we shouldn't be so harshÂ withÂ those that break that rule--At least not on such a beautiful spring day!Â Â (Below: left Sheba - Rudi right)I hope your week isÂ off to a good start!Â  (Below: Rudi)

title: Almost on Time!
text: With Carl working nights for now, that leaves yours truly to get the dogs walked and fed in the morning.Â  Being a bit obsessive compulsive, I try toÂ stay on schedule in the morning byÂ doing each taskÂ at the same time.Â  But for some reason, if I end up getting behind, I canÂ never make up that lost time and I end up being late for work.Â Â That's what happened on Friday morning.Â  While I did oversleep just a little, I was doing okay with my time.Â Â I was all ready for work--With efficiency and focus the dogs had all beenÂ walked, fed, talked to andÂ hugged--I let them outside one last time, andÂ to get them to comeÂ back inside, I gave them a treat.Â Â All the dogs were happyÂ and accounted for...Except for one little sheep...A look out in the yard revealed this.A call to the culprit, who was not happy about leaving his job undone...And I was late for work.Â Â You just can't make up the time it takes to give a dog a 'quick' bath!

title: Behind and Burned Out
text: To start, my apologies for not visiting your blogs this week!Â  I so enjoy starting and ending my day by reading your posts and catching up on news in your corner of the world.Â  But this weekÂ something happened...I didn't even enjoy my husbands birthday dinner at our favorite restaurant or aÂ snowfall this week...Picking up Carl'sÂ car from the repair shop today did little to lift my spirits...I thinkÂ my family drama, work, and the end of the winter, have left meÂ tired and burned out.Â  The lack of sun shining days hasn't helped either!Â  I decided that nothing recharges your inner batteries better than getting away.Â  So,Â I tried to wrangle an invitation from my very good friend in Pennsylvania.Â  Despite dropping a number of hints, no offer to come and visit her was mentioned...So, it was time to go to another plan.Â  I'd been thinking of a friend, GinnyÂ that moved to Tennessee about 6 years ago.Â Â She and her husband have a dog-friendly cabin that they rent out on their Llama farm.Â  Ginny has been asking me for several years to come down for a visit.Â  The cabin was available in a couple of weeks, Carl and IÂ both got a few days offÂ work, and so I made the reservation.Â Â It's all set.Â  We'll take the dogs with us that can't be trusted at home with the remote and the internet, and leave the others to be cared for by our dog-walker.Â  I can't wait!Â Â KnowingÂ we're going to be getting away in a couple of weeks really lifts my spirits--That and lunch I had this afternoon with my two good friends.Again, I'm sorry I've not visited your blogs this week.Â  IÂ look forward to getting all caught up on your news!!~Am I the only one with problems seeing all the updates on my dashboard?~Â Â (Below: Tanner)

title: The Smells of Saturday
text: The weather remains a mix of all seasons. On Friday, we had a warm day that hardly required a sweater. Today, it feels like February again and there may be a rainyÂ snow mix at the start of the work week. The high winds that have been wreaking havoc around us the last couple of days toppled our nation's live Christmas Tree. It had stood on the Ellipse since 1978, and had beenÂ through five different presidencies in its time. Thankfully here, we've not lost our power and had no damage to any of our trees, other than a fewÂ small branches.Â Â  This morning, it was our cat, CC's turn to go to the vet. She was one year past her yearly exam and needed a rabies vaccine. My thought to get her to the vet was put on the front burner when a couple of nights ago, she was outside growling at something. This afternoon, I did spotÂ this visitor. Although it's February and it's a skunks-monthÂ for finding romance, I'm hopeful that it will want to be alone and not stay around--As you know, nothing says I want to be alone quite like an atomized sulfur cloud does!Â  The dogs however don't know that.Â  TheyÂ are still rolling on the exact spot where the dead mole was picked up 3 days ago. Given the choice of their rolling onÂ theÂ spot where thereÂ was aÂ mole or meeting the skunk, it's an easy choiceÂ to make--At least for me!

title: It's All About Charlie!
text: Two scoldings at the groomersÂ  yesterday.Â  One from Irina (groomer) who remindedÂ me when I came to pickÂ Charlie up, about his weight and to not wait 4 months to bring him back.Â Â The other from Charlie telling me that he'd had a really difficult day at the spa and could we please go through the drive-thru at McDonalds for a cheeseburger--Okay, IÂ was hungry and figured that's what he would have said...ButÂ since he is the star of our householdÂ and much of the time the world revolves around him,Â one thing is for sure, he really did wantÂ to hearÂ that he smelled wonderful and looked great!Â Â Personally, I can never decide which look of Charlie'sÂ I like the best.Â  I really love shaggy-dogs (who doesn't?) but then there's his appearance when he'sÂ fresh from the groomers thatÂ does seem a bit more polished.Â  What do you think?

title: All Eyes on Tanner
text: No one lovesÂ a good snow fall more than I do!Â  But the warmer temps this week have me hoping that theÂ winter isÂ finally behind us.Â  The signs of spring are starting to appear everywhere.Â  Birds can now be heard singing in the morning.Â Â And yesterday on the way to work, I saw my first groundhog.Â  Today, Charlie is at the groomers for his 'spring do.'Â  The groomer, Irina,Â who is originally from Romania, with herÂ heavy accentÂ scolded me for waitingÂ so long to bring him in and for theÂ extra weight he's put on over the winter.Â  Her 'lecture' ended withÂ giving me free samples of a lower calorie kibble to try.Once back home, Carl and I did a little bit of yard clean up.Â Â Yesterday Rudi and Sheba found a dead mole in the yard that they both of course rolled on.Â  Carl was unable to findÂ it againÂ and I told him to take Rudi with him, and she'd show him where it was.Â  NotÂ really believing me, he took her with him--As you can see in the picture, thrilled with the chance to roll on the moleÂ again, she took him right to it.Â  Â Â Â  Tanner started his new medication on Monday.Â  The medication called 'Doxepin' hasÂ antihistamine effects in dogsÂ butÂ isÂ labeled as an antidepressant.Â  As you know, his getting overly excited is when he has problems breathing.Â  So our hope isÂ this medication will alleviate that.Â  So far, I've no idea if it's working or not.Â HisÂ breathing still sounds the same toÂ me.Â Â The precautions and side effects in taking the medication warn against his drinking and driving while taking it.Â  It also saysÂ thatÂ when taking DoxepinÂ suicidalÂ thoughts could develop.Â Â I'm wondering howÂ I will know ifÂ TannerÂ develops that urgeÂ to 'end it all?'Â  Will he start jumpingÂ off the three steps into the garage?Â Start tightening his collar?Â  Develop this urgeÂ to run out in front of cars?Â  How will I know?Â  I guess we'll all just have to keep an eye on him...(Hamlet, front--Tanner foreground)

title: Best In Show!
text: ï»¿ ~Wendy~ï»¿Today is the first day of the Westminster Kennel Club dog show. Winning 'Best In Show at Westminster' has become the most-coveted award in the dog show world. I've always enjoyed watching the show, and seeing and hearing about all the different breeds of dogs. It always reminds me of another dog show that I attended a few years ago in GettysburgÂ  Pennsylvania. The Golden Retriever Club of America was having their national event. Golden Retrievers from all over the United States came toÂ compete in everything from conformation to obedience. One of the events held duringÂ the week was called 'The Rescue Parade.' Since our Golden Retriever Club was hosting 'the National'Â as president of the rescue, I was asked to take charge of 'The Rescue Parade.' For those of you who have never attended one, I find it to be a very touching event. It is one where rescued dogs have their moment to beÂ the star and in the spotlight.Â Â As they walk around the center show ring, their story of rescue is told. We start with the oldest Golden andÂ end with the youngest.Â  When I did the parade, each dog was given a rosette (ribbon) with their name and a toy as they left the ring. Ed Rendell, the Governor of Pennsylvania even participated by bringing his 2 rescued Golden Retrievers.~Sheba~ï»¿At the start of the parade, the gentleman, named Bob, who was announcing the event said something, that to me, was so poignant and I've never forgotten it. He said that 'the dogs that were about to enter the show-ring will never win best in show. But what they had won, was a place in our hearts and home.' Bob was so right. No, the dogs that most of us have never will compete for the coveted title of Best in ShowÂ at Westminster or win any other dog show.Â Â But to me, my dogs and I will always have something better than that, each other. Happy Valentines Day everyone!

title: It Was Bound to Happen
text: With the miles that we drive weekly, it was bound to happen...I was worried when Carl wasn't home by midnight.Â  AndÂ when the phone rang, I knew right away what it was about, even before IÂ saw on the caller ID that it was him.Â  InÂ a split-second a deer jumped in front of his car, there was no time toÂ swerve or stop.Â  Carl of course stoppedÂ and checkedÂ and thankfully the deer didn't suffer; only Carl and his much loved car have.Â  They both arrived home viaÂ a tow-service about 2 o'clock this morning, spirits broken.Â Â Rudi, trying to make the damage look a bit better...

title: The Calm After the Storm
text: Tanner continues to have problems breathing.Â  On Thursday there was yet another episode where he was clearly in distress and unable to breathe.Â  Though not as severe as the first time, (still a littleÂ pink in his tongue)Â I waited a few minutes to see if it would pass.Â  When it didn't, I put TannerÂ into my van and we were off to the emergency vet.Â Â His breathing did seem to be improving along the way. This wasÂ whyÂ in my mind IÂ marked a placeÂ in the trip that if he wasn'tÂ better by the time we reached it, I would let them know that we wereÂ coming.Â  When we got to the landmark, Tanner was comfortable,Â his head was up and he was okay.Â Â I stopped and made sure and could easily see that theÂ color to his tongue and gums had returned.Â  I turned around and went home.Â  The vet that Tanner sees wasn't workingÂ Thursday and so I spoke with her on Friday.Â Â There is a human medication that has been used to ease the symptoms ofÂ laryngeal paralysis in dogs.Â  It's a bit experimental in its use for thisÂ condition--My vet has not given this medication to treat laryngeal paralysis, but has given it for use with animals that have skin conditions.Â Since it has very few, if any, side effectsÂ we've decided to try it and see if it helps.Â Â OF COURSE the pharmacy didn't have the medication, so I'll have to get it on Monday.Â  (I know there areÂ some readers of this blog who like to know the names of medications, so I'll post its name when I pick it up--All IÂ  know is that it's an antihistamine that he'll take twice a day.)Â Â Â ï»¿ ~Tanner~ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿My day today has been a welcome calm after the storm of the week.Â Â The 'issue' with my sister and her family only escalatedÂ after I'd decided to wash my hands of them.Â  There will still be a few storms that come from all of this, but I remain hopeful that they will pass.Â  Thank-you all for your kind and thoughtfulÂ comments of support on my last post.Â  Your kindness and friendshipÂ continue to humble and strengthen me.Â  This evening IÂ am looking forward to sitting at my computer,Â with a blanket on my lap, the dogs around me and catching up on your blogs.Â  I hope you're having an enjoyable weekend!Â ï»¿ï»¿ ~Winter Wren~ï»¿ï»¿

title: A Sleepless Night
text: ~Rudi & Charlie~ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿ ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿I was awakened in the early morning hours by Rudi, whining and pacing around the bed. Then even though she hadn't 'asked,' I got up to let her outside. I knew that would be her next request. IÂ wasn't sleeping all that well anyway and so I was unable to get back to sleep. His mother really appreciated it, and byÂ what he wrote in his card, I think he did too...The card was totally unnecessary, but very thoughtful and his 'way with words' gave me a bit of a chuckle.

title: That Hindsight Thing!
text: I have to admit that while I enjoy spending time with Carl, there are times that when he's working on the weekends, andÂ I don't mind his being gone all day.Â  This wasn't the case on Saturday.Â Â I was looking forward to the day.Â  But when I went toÂ run errands in the early afternoon, I let the dogs out one last time and noticed that our heat-pump had frost all over its outside.Â Â A closer look and I could see that there was a significant amount of ice built up on the inside.Â I had noticedÂ earlier in the week that ice had formed along the bottom, but never thought much about it.Â  I 'googled' the problem on the internet and readÂ that it could just be lack of air circulation and the ice shouldÂ be removed.Â IÂ don't know how many buckets of hot water IÂ pouredÂ on the iceÂ to thaw everything.Â  I even laidÂ on the groundÂ in an effortÂ to break all theÂ ice up underneath--After 2 hours of back-breaking work that I know Carl could have done in half the time,Â I had cleared most of the iceÂ and was feeling pretty good about what I'd been able to do.Â Â IÂ turned the systemÂ back on and waited.Â Â A little while later I went out and looked at it, and could see frost wasÂ forming again...I called my brother who told me to turn the thermostat to 'emergency heat' and call someone.Â  I didn'tÂ know whether to be upset about the 2 hours I spent laying on the cold-wet-ground or because we're going to be chargedÂ $100 JUST to get someone to come to the house to look at it.Â  Feeling defeated,Â worn out and cold I did the only thing I could do--I made a chocolate cake (from scratch) and took a nap.Carl was thankfully off of work on Monday and someone came to look at it.Â  A circuit board or something is out and needs to be ordered and will be put in later in the week.Â  I'll let him handle it.Â  All I know is it's aÂ fix that will cost about $500.Â  It would have cost us only aÂ deductible if we'd renewed our home warranty at the end of lastÂ year.Â  What's that saying about hindsight?Â  In hindsight I should have also not waited to make a grooming appointment for Charlie.Â His coat is long and thick, and starting to mat a bit.Â Â But I kind of like the shaggy-dog look--He's well suited for the cold weather, don't you think?

title: The Reappearance of My Arch-Enemy
text: ~Hamlet,Â Sleeping with the Enemy~Â ï»¿ï»¿In July of 1863 Robert E. Lee retreated south and General Mead, who commandedÂ the Union Army of the Potomac, crossed the river into Loudoun County fromÂ Brunswick Maryland.Â Â He headquarteredÂ briefly in the town where I live,Â before movingÂ intoÂ the surrounding area.Â Â If only my arch-enemyÂ the brown marmorated stink bugÂ would follow suit and leave town too.Â  Warmer temps have brought this foe,Â one that I truly despise, out of its winter hiding place inside our house.Â Â While there as not as many as there are in late summer, they areÂ moving pretty slow, and are unable to fly.Â  But to me, none of that matters,Â they are still practically everywhere and on everything--sometimes evenÂ us.Â The stink-bugÂ has one enemy that easily kills it,Â the cold.Â  ButÂ like trueÂ soldiers, theyÂ are afraid of nothing.Â Â However,Â I have to be honest because I know there areÂ not many things that are afraid of me or the Goldens...sigh...Â  WendyÂ in the only place that is free of stink-bugs.

title: Thursday Predictions
text: ~CarrieAnne~ï»¿Yesterday the country's most famous groundhog, Punxsutawney PhilÂ predicted an early spring.Â  HeÂ even wentÂ out on a limb to forecast thatÂ his state's Pittsburgh Steelers will win the Super Bowl;Â we'll see.Â  I'm going to predictÂ that even ifÂ the dogs and I do another snow-dance, we won't get any more 'significant snow' because we've finally found someoneÂ toÂ plow out our drive way when needed.The massiveÂ storm that clobbered much of the country totally missed us here in Northern Virginia.Â Â We were even supposed to get an ice storm and it missed us too.Â  What we have gottenÂ are cold highÂ winds.Â Â Last evening just after the dogs were all fed and happy,Â I settled intoÂ the evening of watching American Idol and enjoyingÂ a 'white-pizza' that I'dÂ picked up,Â andÂ the lights went out.Â  Thrown into pitch blackness, I did the only thing I could do, finished dinner and went to bed early.Â  The power came back on around the time Carl arrived home from work.Â Â This morning theÂ wind is still blowing, the temps are below freezing, butÂ it'sÂ beautiful andÂ clear.Â  After several days of clouds, it's so good to have the sun backAfter errands this morning, I'm looking forward toÂ catching up...But I'mÂ predicting there may be a nap too.Â Â ï»¿ï»¿ ~Tanner~ï»¿ï»¿

title: Too Much Excitement For Tanner
text: ï»¿ ~Tanner~ï»¿TannerÂ has laryngeal paralysis.Â  This means that he has thisÂ hard edged panting along with throat clearing that soundsÂ a lot likeÂ a goose honking or a loud "HRRRAAACH."Â Â When he inhales there is a harsh edge soundÂ similar to the wheeze of an asthmatic. These sounds areÂ more pronounced and prolonged when he'sÂ excited or stressed.Â On WednesdayÂ as the storm was starting to roll inÂ I got the dogs outside,Â and something caused Tanner to not be able to catch his breath.Â  After several minutes of nothing more than a squeak from him as he tried to inhale, he started foaming from the mouth,Â his tongueÂ and gums turned gray, and heÂ collapsed.Â You know as well as I do thatÂ time is critical andÂ I knew I had to get him to the animal emergency.Â  He was totally limp andÂ IÂ somehow managed to get him in theÂ van.Â  Typically the drive would take about 20 minutes but with the storm, the road conditions were quicklyÂ deteriorating.Â Â IÂ tried to not panic but I have to admit thatÂ I reallyÂ thought he was going to die before I got there--Along the way the sounds stoppedÂ all together.Â  I pulled over on the side of the roadÂ opened Tanner'sÂ mouth and pulled on his tongue andÂ IÂ heardÂ and saw him take in a breath.Â Â Â In just a minute or two heÂ had his head up and by the time I got to the animal emergencyÂ Tanner was fine...The vet, no bigger than a pencilÂ and looked to be about 12 years old, did an exam and x-rays.Â  SheÂ gave him an injection of a steroid in case he aspirated fluid or irritated his vocal cords.Â  Within the hour we were onÂ our way home with the instructions to keep him quiet.Â  Other than his bark sounding a bit hoarse, he's been just fine.Â Â  Yesterday afternoonÂ Carl and I finishedÂ clearning out the last of the snow from our driveway.Â  We had the dogs outside with us andÂ someone stopped by.Â TannerÂ became excited andÂ just as a precaution IÂ got him inside and away from the commotion--I figure thatÂ it's better to be safe than...well, you know...Â Â Â All in all aÂ quiet weekend for us.Â  Another storm is predicted for Tuesday, but there won't be a snow-dance for this one.Â Â I think we have enough snow, at least for right now.Â  I thought I'd end this post with aÂ picture of Hamlet.Â  I thought he lookedÂ a bit regal standingÂ in the snow.

text: ~Rudi~You may thinkÂ nature makesÂ snow happen. SoÂ with another snow fall predicted we decided to take matters into our own hands (and paws) and get that snow to come.Â  Since we all know that there is oftenÂ some amountÂ of truth found in legends,Â we have decided to putÂ the student rituals to the test. One of the most popular waysÂ that is said toÂ get the snow to comeÂ is that you shouldÂ wearÂ your pajamas inside out.Â  Since Hamlet is the only dog that wears clothing, we putÂ his shirt on inside out...Yet another way isÂ to throw ice-cubes down the toilet...Well, I improvised on that one, andÂ I just put them on the ground...Â The dogs promptly ate them...I hope it will still count...Â It is also traditionalÂ to put a spoonÂ under your pillow...I put oneÂ under a dog bed butÂ Tanner found it...And finally Charlie dug a hole...Okay that wasn't one, but he had a good time and we all figured that it couldn't hurt...We'll see if it works!But if you know of something else we should try, let us know, okay--We're game!Stay tuned!!!

title: Just Another Week
text: Monday thru Wednesday are busy days for me. These are the days I work and am gone from home all day.Â Â Carl is working days as well right now and he getsÂ home around midnight.Â  ItÂ leaves me to get everything done in the evenings.Â  But I start my days around 4:30.Â  First thing is toÂ of course let the dogs out.Â  I always allow them to stay out as long as they want to--They enjoy barking at the darkness, their shadows, the moon, each other, and anything else that needs to be barked at!Â Â Â Â  One day this week we had snow and ice.Â  Even with 'just' and inchï»¿ of snow, we had a delayed start at work, which was a huge help.Â  It allowed me time to feedÂ Â the stray cat IÂ told you about.Â Â I really appreciated every one's thoughts on what to do--I decided I wouldÂ justÂ 'let it be,' with the thought that maybe it did belong to the farm that is across the roadÂ from us and was okay.Â Â I thought that if it needed anything, I just hoped I'dÂ be able to tell.Â  WhenÂ I arrived homeÂ on Monday night, I caught sight of the catÂ coming out of the brush and goingÂ up the driveway. Carl said he had seen it also. I decided with the cold, rain and snow, I would feed it the next morning.Â Â When I put out theÂ food and got back to the house, I looked back and saw that the foodÂ had beenÂ promptly found and was being gobbled up byÂ a hawk and a couple of crows.Â Â OnÂ Wednesday IÂ put food out again.Â  When I came home last eveningÂ I stopped at the bottom of our driveway to getÂ the plate I'd put the food on.Â Â When I reached to pick it up,Â in the dark something I couldn't see that seemedÂ about as big as a cat, brushedÂ past me--I can only imagine what it was...I put more food outÂ again today.Â  And as I write this I am watching the cat eat the food that has been left for it.Â  I don't know if it's the right or the wrong thing to do, but I feel like it'sÂ something I shouldÂ do.Â Â ï»¿ï»¿~Stray Cat before it foundÂ the food I put out for it~ï»¿ï»¿Now that I've told you a little about my week,Â perhaps you can understand why when I get home in the evenings, I feel like this...ï»¿~Sam~ï»¿And after everything has settled down, I just want to do this...ï»¿ ~Hamlet~ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿and more of this...~Rudi~ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿I hope you've had a good week!Â Â I am looking forward to the weekendÂ and catching up on your blogs!

title: A Day of Work or Play?
text: Today the United States honors the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., the slain civil rights leader. However, some states also honor other men in history as well. The Commonwealth Of Virginia (where I live) on the Friday before, celebrates Lee-Jackson Day, a state-holiday to mark Robert E. Leeâ€™s birthday and Thomas J. â€œStonewallâ€ Jackson. Both of these men were natives of Virginia and served as Generals for the Confederacy during the Civil War. Lee-Jackson Day became more of a controversy when, for a time, it coincided with the celebration of Martin Luther King, Jr.â€™s birth, during that time (only in Virginia) it was called Lee-Jackson-King Day. When I first moved to Virginia the idea of Lee-Jackson-King Day seemed, to me anyway, to be a bit of a contradiction. While Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson may well have been honorable men, they fought on the side of a nation founded principally on the idea that one race of man was inferior to another and that human beings could be owned as property. I thought 'combining' it with the legacy of Martin Luther King, Jr., for some reason, just didnâ€™t seem right--At least not to me.Â  ï»¿ ~Toby~ï»¿ ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿So if you are observing 'Martin Luther King Day,' and got the day off, or if you are like Carl and I and it's 'just another Monday,' and have to work, I hope your week is off to a good start!Â  I think mine may very well be--Snow is in the forecast! ï»¿ ~Toby and Bubba~ ï»¿

title: Just a Stray?
text: I don't remember a time in my life when I didn't feel sorry for a cat or a dogÂ that didn't have a home.Â Â If you've felt that same way then you know how I'm feeling aboutÂ a stray cat that we've had around our propertyÂ the last several weeks.Â Â I am quite sure it'sÂ feralÂ because it runs away anytime it sees or hears me.Â  I feel lucky that I have been able to take a few pictures of it becauseÂ it doesn't come too close to the house, butÂ stays on the edge of the woods down by the road.Â  I read on someones blog that you shouldn't feed a feral cat.Â  But I have to admit that I couldn't not do that andÂ I've put a bowl out for it a few times, but the meal mostly goes untouched.Â I am sureÂ it's surviving on whatever it can hunt.Â Of course with the cold I worry about it and am wondering if I should try to trap it, (I have a small trap) or just let it be.Â  From what I can see, it looksÂ healthy and who knows, maybe it does have a home or is quite content with the life it has.Â  What do you think?

text: Our dayÂ is off to a good start!Â  The sun is out and I've had a nice chat on the phone with a co-worker (we don't get the chance to talk much at work) and Carl, who is also off work today,Â and I enjoyedÂ my homemade biscuits for breakfast.Â I thoughtÂ today I would shareÂ a 10 secondÂ video that I tookÂ of Hamlet this morning.Â  I've tried several times toÂ capture on video HamletÂ 'running' and today I did; even though it was a little trickyÂ to balance the camera and hold 2 leashes at the same time.Â Â It has been six weeks since his two surgeriesÂ andÂ each day I marvel and am soÂ gratefulÂ that he is doing well--AÂ tribute to his spirit andÂ resilience!Â Â HamletÂ is still taking the Chinese herbs, and today I pick up yet another refill of the antibiotic that he's been taking for the pastÂ 9 weeks.Â Only time will tell if everything is working to prevent the recurrence of the infection and the tumor.Â Â Â Â I hope you have a wonderful weekend!ï»¿ ~Hamlet hoping for a bite of a biscuit~ï»¿

title: Lost and Found
text: Another busy and hectic week is coming to an end. I've been off work today and have Friday off as well. I'd really hoped that the snow-storm on Tuesday night would bring something 'substantial' as the weathermen had predicted because I was ready for it--IÂ bought new snow boots.Â  But Mother Nature onlyÂ brought us about an inch--Maybe next time!Â  Even though we didn't get the snow, we did getÂ cold biting winds and frigid temperatures that are below freezing.Â Â I've noticed several times Hamlet standing with the wind blowing right in his face.Â  I wonder what he isÂ thinking.Â  (You'll notice that he's once againÂ wearing a shirt--This is because he started licking an area just above his elbow after he would come back inside. I don't know if the cold is affecting his mostly bare skin, but I don't want the area where he had surgery to become irritated and sore.)Â Â Â Â Â ï»¿ ~Hamlet~The week has also had meÂ thinkingÂ just how useful our dogs are. While much of what they do is obvious to those of us who share our lives with them,Â a few things they do are sometimes overlooked and taken for granted.Â  Aside from serving asÂ guardians of our home, ourÂ dogs haveÂ  expanded their duties to include barking atÂ trees or anything else nearby that may be a threat.Â Â They are also the greeting committee.Â  This afternoon when a UPS truck pulled into our driveway, 3 of the dogs jumped right into the truck to greet the driver, who thankfully wasn't afraid of them.Â  Our crew are alsoÂ my companionsÂ when we go hunting--Even though I don't know what we're hunting for when we go onÂ ourÂ walks, they usually let me know when they've found it by rolling in it, or eating it. ï»¿ ~Carl and Tanner returning home~ï»¿ ï»¿But the most valuable role they have played, at least today, was helping me to find a couple of things that were lost.Â Â This morning when we had the dogs out for their morning walk, Carl thought I was keeping track of Tanner. Â Since I had my camera to take pictures, I thought he was. Needless to say when the walk was over, we realized neither of us was. Typically Tanner will follow the route that we always take on our walks and is easy enough to find. But this morning he must've gotten distracted by something because we couldn't find him. A bit of a frantic search was helped byÂ Rudi who has demonstrated more than once that she seems to understand what 'find Tanner' means because I followed her and she found him for us. ~Tanner~ï»¿As if that wasn't enough,Â a little later this morningÂ as I was putting on some earrings, I dropped one--it was not just any earring I dropped, but one of my diamond earrings that belonged to my Mother. A careful search on hands and knees for several minutes turned up nothing. Just as I was about to give up, Charlie started sniffing at something buried within the down-filledÂ dog bed, and I realized it was my earring.Â  I felt another huge sense of relief!Now that things have settled down this afternoon, and evening is approaching, I'm wondering ifÂ with all of the dogs we have, if there is one or two among them who can help me find more time?

title: The Good, The Bad and the Cold
text: ~The cold~Howling winds and temperatures below freezing have returned to Northern Virginia. I've been trying to think of a few good things about the cold weather. title: Black-Eyed Peas at the New Year!
text: I have never been one to make New Years resolutions. But I am a person who is bound by tradition. According to southern folklore, the first food to be eaten on New Year's Day for luck and prosperity for the year ahead are black-eyed peas. From grand gourmet dinners to small casual gatherings with friends and family, these legumes are traditionally offered. The practice of eating black-eyed peas for luck is believed to date back to the Civil War. They were first planted as food for livestock, and later as a food staple for slaves in the South. The fields of black-eyed peas were ignored as Sherman's troops destroyed or stole other crops, giving the humble, black-eyed pea an important role as a major food source for surviving Confederates. However it got started, traditions change and morph over the years. But there is no doubt that eating black-eyed peas is a truth held sacred by many southerners who may never touch a black-eyed pea at any other time of the year. But a little luck never hurt anyone, right? So hereâ€™s to 2011!! (And itâ€™s still not too late to go get your black-eyed peas!)

title: The Reality of a Christmas Myth
text: Christmas was a quiet day for us. Carl worked and I worked in the kitchen. I started the day by making cinnamon rolls in a cast-iron frying pan. The pan belonged to my Grandfather, and my Mom gave it to me more than 20 years ago. I'm starting to see more recipes using cast-iron, (the one for the rolls called for one) and I've even seen pans for sale at Macys. I'm wondering if like everything else, they are bringing back the old ideas and calling them new ones--They do that with everything else, so why not with cookware?Â Â Â  I'm sure most of you have heard of the Christmas myth known as "The Night the Animals Talk". Supposedly, on Christmas Eve, for a time, the animals can speak. My Mom told me about this many years ago and about how her numerous attempts to sneak down to the barn to find out if this was true was foiled by her parents. This time of the year always brings this back to mind.Â Â I have thought that it would be interesting to hearÂ what our dogs and the cat would say if they could speak to us.Â  YesterdayÂ I think I was given this chance.Â  The mornings for Hamlet seem to be the time that he is the most playful.Â Â Christmas morning was no exception.Â He seemed to have a bit more of a spark as heÂ pranced around me forÂ attention.Â As I was talking to him and giving himÂ pats and scratches, HamletÂ quickly turned around and with a wagging tail, heÂ lookedÂ at me and barked.Â  It was just a single barkÂ andÂ because I've never heard him do this before, of course I was a little surprised.Â Â ButÂ just as the myth had said, I understood what he saidÂ perfectly.

title: Christmas Means a Little Bit More
text: I can't believe that its been nearly a week since I posted.Â  Time as we all know passes much too quickily.Â  ButÂ this past week, I have been 'plagued' with a few things...The first plague I've had is oneÂ with 'Blogger.'Â  For some reason, I'm having problems posting comments on yourÂ blogs.Â  I can create and read postsÂ just fine, but leaving comments is frustrating to say the least.Â Â As I typeÂ my thoughtsÂ into the comment box, the words are not visible andÂ take several seconds to appear.Â  Going back to change or correct a spelling errorÂ really consumes a lot of time.Â Â To remedy that, at least for now,Â I'm writing my comments in document form and then cut and pasting them into the comment box...I'm hoping the issue willÂ resolve itself... But if anyone knowsÂ the solution to thisÂ problem, or what has caused it, I'd so appreciate your letting me know.Â  ***After I posted this, my blog crashed and IÂ lost 10 posts and ALL of the comments.Â  I've been able to getÂ the posts back up, but the comments are yet to be retrieved...What was that I said about frustration?!***Â The second plague is the weather.Â  We've been hampered by wind, cold and snow this week.Â  Not much snow is needed to make 'real' Virginians miserable.Â  Even though we lived in Alaska for 10 years and Wisconsin before that, I am now like the rest of the people here in the 'Old Dominion' that has difficulty dealing withÂ the smallest amounts of snow.Â Â  The third plague that I've dealt with is just lack of time.Â  Carl is working nights this week, leaving me as a 'single parent' in the evenings.Â Â The crew loves that someone is home allÂ of the time and they can spend more time outdoors.Hamlet (pictured with Toby) continues toÂ doÂ really well!Â Â I can tell he feels good too.Â Â TheÂ staples have been removed and he has healed up just fine!Â Â  Finally, despite all of the rush and frustration something has happened.Â  I'llÂ start by saying how very grateful I am to those of you who understood what I tried so hard to articulate inÂ my last post.Â  IÂ have readÂ yourÂ comments several times from that post.Â Â You all were right in what you said.Â Â I just needed to hear it. One of my favorite Christmas stories is Dr. Seuss's 'How the Grinch Stole Christmas.'Â  You'll recall in the story after the GrinchÂ has stolen every last thing, the Whos wake up on Christmas morning to sing in the town square despite having nothing.Â Â This causesÂ the Grinch to question the basis of his nefarious plan.Â HeÂ then realizes that Christmas is not about theÂ gifts or the decorations.Â Â It is not about the amount of food on the dining room table. It is aboutÂ friendship and love for all. This is what has happened to me.Â  I realize that this Christmas season I have been given the extraordinary gift of friendship from people all over the world that I've never personally met, but feel like I know.Â Â Your giftsÂ have come via e-mail and the postal service and I find myselfÂ humbled andÂ gratefulÂ for the Christmas spirit that youÂ have brought into my 'Grinchy heart' and our home.

title: Where Are You Christmas?
text: This morning I have something to say that has nothing to do with the dogs...It's all about me...I'll start with telling a secret that I don't tell very many people. It's that I love Christmas. It's my favorite time of the year. I love sending and receiving Christmas cards and little packages in the mail. I love the magic, and the glow that everything has, and that for one small part of the year, people are willing to give and to create joy for others. But here it is, less than two weeks before Christmas, and I'm not feeling it. I have looked within myself to find that inner child who lovesÂ the lights and the songs and the giving and you know what? She seems to be sleeping. Or maybe she wandered off.I don't know quite why it is, but I am just not excited about Christmas this year. I've not put up a single decoration, we don't have a tree, and I haven't done any of my shopping yet. I've not even baked anything. And while I've enjoyed reading about the traditions, plans and memories so many of you have, deep down, I'm just not enjoying the season this year.Maybe it's because I'm tired. I feel as thoughÂ I've spent the last few months running, filling every spare moment of my time. I have been better about saying no however--I actually turned down taking in a 13 year old Golden last week. But my free time seems to be packed full. I keep telling myself it's only forÂ a few more weeks, and then things will calm down. But I'm starting to realize that there is no calm. Finding some 'extra' time right now will get to beÂ a little more difficult because for the rest of the year to I'll be working every day because another co-worker will be off.Â Â Carl is also working nights, which includesÂ Christmas Eve and day. I know I'll continue to be in a mad rush.Â Â  So I don't know if any one of these things, or a combination of all of them is keeping me from getting in to Christmas this year. But really, if we were to skip it all together, I kind of think I'd be okay with it. But I'm really hoping that I'll get into the mood this coming week. I pick up my cards todayÂ and I have some plans to do a few things. Maybe that'll help. We'll see.I really hope that you're getting ready and waiting for Christmas morning, with better spirits than I am at the moment.Â Â However, being the eternal optimist I have to believe that for me this will all change.Â  Stay tuned...

title: Mismatched Week and Mismatched Socks
text: Itâ€™s officially winter here in Virginia! Last week we were enjoying seasonably warm weather butÂ fast forward to this week and the cold winds have beenÂ howling and we even had a little bit of snow today.Â I've been enjoying the last couple of planned days off work.Â  I've not been feeling well, so it's nice to have a break.Â  Yesterday I was all set to take Tanner to see the opthamologist for a 4 month check up.Â Â For once I was running on time, even taking him beforehand to the groomer for a nail-trim.Â  I called the office toÂ confirm theÂ time and was told that Tanner'sÂ appointment was today...So much for the good planning...We arrived today a little late.Â Â Tanner'sÂ eye pressure is unchanged and the exam showed everything was fine, good news!Â Â TodayÂ TannerÂ was seen by 2Â Opthamologist, one was a man I'd never metÂ before--He was a very tall, husky man that I figure was in his mid 50's.Â  He didn't introduce himself, so I'm guessing he was an opthamologist.Â  ButÂ when he sat down I noticed that he wore mismatched socks, one wasÂ light green, the other wasÂ dark brown.Â  He also wore aÂ wrinkled white oxford shirt that had streaks of gray running through it. I really tried not to stare, but I know that I was.Â  He was such aÂ contrast to the crisp white coat and neat appearance of theÂ 'lady opthamologist' and the assistant that IÂ couldn't help myself.Â Â I had to wonder if he needed HIS eyes checked...Â  On a final note,Â Hamlet isÂ feeling really well andÂ I feel like the last couple of days we have the 'old' Hamlet back!Â  The drains have been removed, and he's finally leaving the surgery site alone so for now he's not wearing theÂ e-collar.Â  I do think he'll continue to wear a shirt and shoe for now.Â  But he is up and around much more and has returnedÂ to ourÂ room at night to sleep.Â Notice in theÂ last picture of Hamlet thatÂ he is laying on his 'surgery side.'Â  It was theÂ first time I'd seen him do that, and I think it has to be a goodÂ sign.Â I've started him back on the Chinese herbs in hopes that perhaps they will do some good this time. I know it's doing us 'some good' to see him feeling like the HamletÂ weÂ so very much adore!

title: A Final Decision for Hamlet
text: Cold and wind has arrived in Virginia bringing with it temps just above freezing.Â  Areas to the south of us are having a bit of snow.Â  We have blue skies and sunshine, at least today.Â  I took Hamlet (pictured with Wendy on the right) to the vet this cold morning to have the drains removed.Â  We have decided to wait to do that onÂ Monday because there's still draining.Â Â The final culture results were returned on Wednesday and my vet called me and discussed the options.Â  Today we discussedÂ everything again.Â Â Â While the surgeon removed the area of infection,Â because he couldn't remove everything (without removing Hamlet's leg) there is concernÂ that the bacteria mightÂ still be present in Hamlet'sÂ system after thisÂ surgery.Â Â We wonder if this is why there was a recurrence of infection after the first surgery, because we didn't use the right antibiotics to get rid of the bacteria--But this is just a guess...The culture that was done before the surgery identified 3 bacteria which are immune to most antibiotics.Â  One medication that Hamlet is currently taking (zenquin) will get rid of 2 of the bacteria.Â  The 3rd one howeverÂ is a strain of e-coli and the only medication that will work to get rid of it isÂ an antibioticÂ called Amikacin.Â It is a very strong medication thatÂ has a lot of side effects that could occur such asÂ kidney damage, hearing loss, vestibularÂ (balance) disorders. There may also beÂ facial swelling, pain at the injection site, allergic reactions, vomiting, diarrhea, blood disorders, or liverÂ disorders...It goes without saying that Hamlet wouldÂ have to be monitored very closely by the vet during treatment because old dogs are particularly susceptible to the side effects.Â Â I've thought a lot about all of this the last fewÂ days.Â  I've thought of what my goalsÂ are for Hamlet and what my hopes are for him.Â  At the top of the list is for HamletÂ to be able to enjoy the days he has left andÂ be comfortable and free from pain.Â  I feel strongly that he's been through enough.Â  I think Hamlet needs to rest and enjoyÂ theÂ time he has left with us in peace, not be poked and prodded and ill from the side-effects of medications.Â Â So I've decided to continue with the one antibiotic that will get rid of two of the bacteria, and not risk putting himÂ on the Amikacin.Â  I don't know what's ahead for Hamlet.Â  ButÂ tonight for the first time this week while I was eating my dinner in front of the tv,Â Hamlet came to me looking for a small bite of what I was having.Â Â I thinkÂ and I so hope I've made the right choice.

title: Snippets from Thursday
text: Its been an exhausting week, and I'm glad it's winding down!Â Â Hamlet is doing pretty well.Â  Although very slow, he's up and around a bit more and is getting a lot of rest.Â  There is quite a bit of bruising and draining.Â Â I'm hopingÂ the draining will lessen in the next few days.Â  With Carl home today, I ran some errands.Â  One was aÂ trip to Wegmans.Â  IÂ was there last evening, but somehow managed to forget a bag of groceries--Have you ever done that?Â IÂ  decidedÂ that since I was there anyway, I'd go ahead and have a quick lunch.Â  As I sat in the mezzanine watching the peopleÂ below, I noticed an 'older' lady who was working in aÂ kiosk handing out samples and making small boxed lunches for customers. Nothing unusual about that, but in the moments whenÂ no one was around, she pick up a sample or two,Â quickly turn around and eat them.Â Â It gave me a grin and IÂ quickly snapped her picture with my cell phone when I walked past.Â The next stop was to a jewelers toÂ have my watch repaired.Â  As I stood there waiting, a young gentleman who looked to be about 25 named Jared was picking out a diamondÂ engagement ring for his 'significant other' named Lindsay.Â Â I overheard his conversation with the sales person and couldn't help but glance in his direction.Â  As the sales-girl ooooo'd over the ring, and assured him that 'she would justÂ love it!' I looked at him again and couldn't help butÂ smile--At that he said to meÂ that his mother couldn't come with him and asked me to give him my opinion of the ring he'd chosen.Â (I wondered if I reminded him of his mother).Â Â I assured him that it wasÂ absolutely stunning!Â  The ringÂ wasÂ a 2.5Â carat center stone pave set with round diamonds on the band...At least that's what the jeweler said...I just know it was gorgeous!Â  He really felt that this was the ring he wanted, but also wanted to think about it.Â  It cost over $5000, so I told him I wasÂ glad he was going to--I think that's what hisÂ Mother would have wanted me to say.Â Â I can't get over that it cost more than our firstÂ and second car combined!Â Â Â After a couple of other stops I came home andÂ got the dogs walked.Â Â  (Sheba) My day has come to a close with theÂ mailman bringing me aÂ new purse that I ordered from Macys...I was feeling some stress a few days ago and ordered it.Â  Carl can't understand why I need a new one when I just got a new one (on the left) a few months ago...Men...Â Its been a pretty good day!Â  I hope yours has beenÂ too--I look forward to catching up on your blogs this evening!

title: Update on Hamlet
text: I'm here at workÂ and just wanted to postÂ an update to let you all know that I heard from Dr. Taylor a little while ago that Hamlet did very well during his procedure today!Â  He didn'tÂ have to be putÂ under anesthesia, but insteadÂ a local-anesthetic was used to put inÂ two drains.Â  HamletÂ is resting comfortably and I can pick him up on my way home this evening.Â Â The drains will remain in place for about 5 days and were 'tacked in' to help them stay in place.Â Â I'm hopeful we are going to be taking 'this exit' and remainÂ on the road to recovery with no more detours!Many thanks for your continued good thoughts,Â  prayers and for cheering HamletÂ on!Â  I remainÂ humbled and grateful to all of you for your friendship and concern.Â  I hope you're having an enjoyable day!Â  It's rainy and a little chilly in Virginia today, but somehow it feels like the sun is shining.

title: Not Yet Over the Hurdles
text: I wasn't going to post anything today because I'm starting to feel like a broken record, and I know that some of you are no doubt tired of hearing about Hamlet.Â  I really do apologize for that.Â  But he's consuming my life right now, and I so hope you understand.Â Â I amÂ really encouraged by how Hamlet is doing overall.Â Â He hasÂ a great appetite, he's up and around some, and I think that he's generally feeling pretty good.Â  There are even a few tail-wags.Â  The area where the surgeryÂ is of course very tender and bruised.Â Â The only thing is, is that the drain that wasÂ put in came out this morning.Â  I took him to the vet to have them take a look.Â  MyÂ vets feels thatÂ it needs to be put back in becauseÂ he has some fluidÂ around his elbow.Â Â This means another surgery to which I reluctantly agreed.Â Â My vet doesn't work on Tuesday so another vet that I don't particularly like will be doing the procedure--How I feel about 'Dr. Taylor' hasÂ nothing to do with hisÂ capability, we just don't click.Â  That aside,Â my biggest hope is that the swelling will have gone down by morning andÂ he won't need to have the drain put back in.Â Â And if he has to have surgery again,Â it'll be quick and easy and HamletÂ won't have any more hurdles to get over.Â Â I hope you'll keepÂ those prayers, positive thoughts, good karma, and anything else that you can think of coming for Hamlet.

title: Hamlet Clears One Hurdle
text: Once againÂ I'd like to thank-you for your remembering Hamlet today and keeping him in yourÂ thoughts and prayers. I heard from the surgeon a little while ago that Hamlet hasÂ come through the surgery and was resting. He said it went as well as could be expected, and he had removed as much of the infected tissue and tumor as he could. Hamlet still hasÂ a few hurdles to get over, but I'm hopeful that we have cleared the biggest oneÂ with the surgery.Â I'm to call in the morning because he may be able to come home.Â  As I mentioned earlierÂ today, I met a friend for lunch whose dog was also having surgery. (Bella did just fine too!)Â Â We met at a place in Purcellville called "Magnolias at the Mill."Â  TheÂ millÂ was built in 1905. ItÂ served in the production of pasture seed for the Contee Adam Seed Company, and was operated by the same family for three generations. In the middle of the last century, Loudoun County Dairy Business was booming and theÂ millÂ filled the need for grass seed. During the second World War, much of the Virginia Orchard Grass seed produced here was shipped to Europe as packing for artillery shells and armaments. 'Magnolias'Â was alsoÂ a flour mill in the 1940s.Â  It's a lovely place that still retains the original woodwork andÂ equipmentÂ for the decor.Â Â Lunch was delicious (a roasted pumpkin bisque to warm me up and flank-steak caesar salad) and the company of a good friend was enjoyable too.Â Â Â Â Â Â Afterwards I stopped by "Southern States" and once again admired the chicken houses...I still think I need chickens.Â Â But I think (or rather I know) I need to get Hamlet home and back on his feet first.Â THANK YOU all again for your kindness, support and your friendship;Â it has provided so much comfort!Â Â Â I hope you're having an enjoyable weekend!! Â Â Â Â  IÂ dropped Hamlet off this morning for his surgery.Â  I'm feeling a sense ofÂ calmÂ this morning, but am (of course)Â nervous and worried.Â Â I know that there are many of you who are keeping him in your prayers today, and I so appreciate it!Â Â  I'd planned on just staying homeÂ with my cell phone attached to me today.Â  But I received a call just as I was getting home from a friend whose dog isÂ having knee surgery today at the same place, by the same surgeon.Â  WeÂ have decided that we both could use some company and are meeting for lunch.Â Â She was on the board of directors of the rescue when I first became involved and was the one who talked me into taking our boy Josh to foster.Â  It'll be good to see her.Â I'll post an update whenÂ I hear from the surgeon.Â  Many many thanks for your thoughtsÂ and prayers for Hamlet!

title: The Road to a Friends House
text: Yesterday I packed up an entire Thanksgiving dinner and took it to our good friend Sidney in Lancaster Pennsylvania.Â  Other than work later this evening, she had no plans for the holiday.Â Â I just think that ThanksgivingÂ is meant to be shared with someone.Â Â I wasn't going to tell SidÂ I was coming, but decided that I would tell her as I was getting ready to leave.Â It was good to see her, and we enjoyed our meal together.Â  I gave SidÂ the leftovers and I droveÂ the 2+ hours back home.Â  The road to aÂ friends home is never long...It was a nice day.Â  This evening we're having dinner with some friends we've known for about 10 years.Â  They are always so kind and include us in one of their holiday celebrations.Â The picture below is of Rudi doing what she has done nearly every day for the 7 years we've had her; enjoying the cats food.Â  Whatever you are doing, if you celebrate Thanksgiving or not, IÂ hope you're enjoying your day too!!

title: Winding Down on Wednesday!
text: The last several days have been a bit hectic.Â  But all the rush is behind me, and I can focus on what's in front, which is Thanksgiving and about aÂ week of vacation! IÂ took Hamlet to see the surgeon lastÂ evening.Â  Before I tell you what was decided, I want to say howÂ very much I appreciateÂ all of you who have taken a moment to send your best wishes for Hamlet and share your thoughts and experiences.Â  It really does help to have them.Â  This has been a very difficult time trying to decide the direction to take.Â  Hamlet has been through so much.Â  Right now he enjoys a pretty good quality of life.Â  He's got a good appetite, his energy level and attitude are good too.Â The only difference is that he's uncomfortable.Â  The tumor is huge--Bigger than both my hands put together...Dr. Walker (surgeon) agrees that it looks worse than it did originally.Â  The open area of the tumor is about the width of my index finger and getting bigger;Â it's red and angry with infection...I would post a picture, butÂ you understand...But if you're curious and would like to see it,Â let me know...Having said that, we have the option of course of doing nothing.Â Â The tumorÂ will continue to grow, and eventually Hamlet willÂ probably lose use of his leg.Â  There's not enough skin to heal over the open area,Â it'll remain open andÂ get worse.Â  Antibiotics aren't effectiveÂ because the blood supply is very limited to the tumor (that's why it's not getting better).Â Â The riskÂ of doing surgery is that it may not work--We have known that all along.Â  WeÂ take the chance that de-bulking the tumor (not removing the whole thing, only part of it)Â may leave us with all the same problems and more as doing nothing.Â Â But then again, if it works, it buys Hamlet some more time.Â Â I think that 'luck'Â has been on Hamlet's side.Â  It was a rough recovery last time, but I feel like I owe it to him to at least try.Â  He'll have surgery on Saturday.Â Â Â Â Â The rest of the dogs are doing well.Â  I find great comfort in their company.Â  This morning the house is filled with the smell of bread baking and a turkey breast that I cooked overnight in the crockpot.Â  It's part of a Thanksgiving meal that I'm taking to aÂ good friend today.Â Â There is a peaceful feeling as a few of the dogs, including HamletÂ are snoozing nearby.Â  A couple of the other dogs are in the kitchen hoping that the Food-Fairy will come and magically give them a bite of something.Â  The silence of the morning is broken by the sound ofÂ CarrieAnne and Sam barking at something in the darkness.Â  I alwaysÂ wonder what they see?

title: What to do about Hamlet
text: I'm home from the vet with Hamlet.Â  Parked on ourÂ roadÂ when I drove past were a couple of carsÂ with several people looking at the adjoiningÂ property--At least I guess that's what they were doing.Â  For some strange reason, known only to our dogs, we discovered purely by chance that the words "chop-chop" always send themÂ running to the far side of the yard barking--So, when I let the dogs into the backyard, I said those words and off they went running to bark at the people--It just made sense to do it.Â  One couple had a dog with them, so 'maybe' they wouldn't be so bad to have as neighbors.The news for Hamlet continues to not be good.Â  The vet feels that the infection isÂ worse and the antibiotics aren't working.Â  As I've mentioned,Â I can't tell becauseÂ I look at it everyday.Â  I had thought that it was improving butÂ inÂ my heart I knewÂ that it wasn't.Â Â The option of surgery came up again.Â Â Dr. DeSantis (my vet)Â thinks thatÂ surgery to 'debulk' the tumor, removing the area of infection may beÂ an option to consider.Â  Then we wouldÂ useÂ IV and oral antibiotics to get rid of any lingering infection.Â Â The only thing I've discussed with the surgeon was removing the entire tumor.Â  There are some risks.Â Â One beingÂ the loss of the use of his leg.Â  AnotherÂ is that there may not beÂ enough tissue toÂ close up the wound.Â  Dr. DeSantisÂ said thatÂ even though surgery wasÂ 'not really' anÂ option we may not have a choice but make it one.Â Â There are so many things to considerÂ in doing this.Â Â The last surgery took so much out of HamletÂ because of his age (about 13-14).Â  Another is that the infection could be so deep within the tissue that surgeryÂ and antibiotics may not even make a difference and could make everything worse for him.Â ThisÂ is whyÂ I'll have to talk to theÂ surgeon again and see what he thinks about a less invasive surgery.Â Â It'll also take about 5 days to get the results back from the latest culture that we took of the wound which may give us a whole other picture.Â  For some reason the quote from Shakespeare's Hamlet came to mind today, "that it should come to this!".Â ButÂ I don't see that "this" may haveÂ other choices--Unless someone else has a suggestion?Â  Today isÂ our 29th wedding anniversary.Â  We were planningÂ to go out to lunch and enjoy the day.Â Carl and I both don't feel much like celebrating, but think that getting out for a drive may do wonders to clear our heads and get a good perspective on everything.Â Â Â  I do hope you're having an enjoyable day!Â  It's really a lovely day here in Virginia with warm temps and sunshine.Â  This kind of weather always has a way of lifting the soul!

title: A Week of Highs and Lows
text: IÂ really look forward to Thursday's when the week finally slows down.Â  I can catch up on my blog-reading and things around the house.Â  Hamlet has had his highs and lows this week.Â  The high came when I thought that the tumor had started to heal.Â  But a low came when we were gone, he lost the shoe he now wears to keep him from being able to scratch himself, which he did.Â  I think the more he scratched, the more it bothered himÂ and the more he couldn't leave it alone. He's really gouged the tumor and it bled for a long time. I almost thought I was going to have to take him in. But it did stop and today it does look a little better.Â Â I'm hopeful that it'll be okay, but I just don't know.There has been no contact from Fred's realtor about our buying additional property.Â  I do think they're going to see if they can sell the entire 10 acres and not break up the parcel; I guess I don't blame them.Â Â The easement was finished on Monday evening.Â  Let the selling traffic begin...I can'tÂ wait...Another issue with my sister threw me into a tail-spin last evening.Â  I'll spare you the family drama and just say thatÂ IÂ picked myself up, andÂ was reminded of theÂ kindness of friends both that I've met, and those who come to me from cyber-space.The dogs always have a way of providing a much needed lift.Â Â We enjoyed a walk, and Sheba and Rudi shared a stick.Â  It wasÂ good to be outside enjoying the fresh fall air and I felt better about everything.Â  Â  The day stayed on courseÂ when the mailman drove into our driveway while we were outside.Â  I wished I'd been able to take aÂ picture as the dogs mobbed his truck!Â  He stopped mid way up the drive, leaned out of the truck andÂ handed me a package.Â  I was excited to see that it was from our friend Sugar the Golden Retriever and herÂ MomÂ Â  I have been admiring the tasty and healthyÂ treats that they bake up and was so excited by a gift of them for our crew.Â  We did a couple of rounds of treats because they're healthy after all--Carl said they smelled so good that he wanted to try one--The dogs LOVED them, and I did too because theyÂ were baked with love and given in kindness!Thank-you Sugar and Sugar's Mom!Â  We so appreciate your thinking of us, and sharing these wonderful treats!!Â  You can find out more about themÂ by going to their blog.Â  Sugar and her Chef-Mom areÂ on a littleÂ Thanksgiving break for now, but you can still stop by their blog and take a look around.Â Â  Finally, I will end this post with this picture that I took ofÂ  'my boys' Tanner (left) and Hamlet while they were waiting on their treats.Â  I so love the look on their sweet whiteÂ faces.

title: Quiet on the Home-Front
text: I really want to thank everyone for your kind thoughts and support as we navigate the maze of trying to purchase additional property and in doing what we can for Hamlet.Despite the appearance of the "for sale" sign today announcing the availabilityÂ of the property around us, I'm going to try and be optimistic rather than pessimistic. I think Charlie tried to beÂ optimisticÂ when I accidentally locked him out on the front porch this morning.Hamlet did seemÂ a little better today, although he's sleeping quite a bit. He did want to go out with us this afternoon, but opted to sit in the garage while the other dogs played frisbee.Â  ï»¿Overall, it was a nice quietÂ day.Â  Â  I hope your day was an enjoyable one too!

title: Hope for Hamlet and a Better Tomorrow
text: If you're looking for a 'feel good moment' from me, I'm sorry you but you won't get it from this post--AlthoughÂ maybe you will from this picture of CarrieAnneÂ taken today.Â Â But I'm sitting here discouraged and a bit depressed about the day.Â Â As you know from my previous post I took Hamlet to the vet.Â  The news was not good.Â Â The tumor is feeling warm to the touch.Â  Because of the infectionÂ the vet said we can't use steroids becauseÂ they can suppressÂ the immune systemÂ that he needs to fight the infection.Â  We discussed doing surgery again...She wanted to talk to the surgeon who did the surgery.Â  She called him and heÂ happened to be working today and he asked usÂ to come over and he would see us.Â Â He and I discussed everything.Â  The tumor is totally wrapped around the tendons in Hamlet's shoulder.Â  Dr. WalkerÂ told me that the only thing that he felt could be done would beÂ to remove Hamlet's leg, which he did not recommend because he thought it would be very difficultÂ for a dog Hamlet's age.Â  So, in a nutshell, nothing can be done.Â  I was in tears and I left forgetting to pay the bill.Â Â (I called them back and was told it was 'no charge').Â  I called my vet and returned to the office to pick up 2 antibiotics.Â  I feel like Hamlet has beenÂ given a band-aid fix for a gaping wound.Â  But I know I need to beÂ hopeful and optimistic--I know those feelingsÂ will come, butÂ right now it's difficult.When I arrived home there was a large truck full of gravelÂ and a Bob-Cat sitting in our driveway.Â Â Â My heartÂ sank just a little lower as I realized that they were probably there to put gravel on the grassy access to the 10 acres in back of us.Â I got out of my van and asked the man what they were doing--He confirmed what I already knew, but told me that they were making an accessÂ on the OTHER side of theÂ property and not at the top of our driveway--He asked if it was okay to use our driveway this one time.Â  He told me that Fred had asked them to not use our driveway any more than needed.Â  Of course I agreed.Â  It was the only good news of the day.Â  I hope tomorrow will be a better day.Just as I finished my post, I looked upÂ as the moonÂ appeared--It didn't stay around long, but I was so taken by how beautiful it was, an omen perhaps?Â  I'm so glad that the weekend has finally arrived!
